('13', 0, 4, 5, 124) The above 1 is soul stirring.
('13', 0, 4, 6, 154) I was teaching one of the boys this morning and came upon it.

('13', 0, 5, 11, 494) As you will soon be on the tramp I am not sending the agricultural books.
('13', 0, 5, 12, 568) It is right?

('13', 2, 4, 8, 4272) 3. LETTER TO JAMNADAS GANDHI
('13', 2, 5, 9, 4301) Phagan Sud 6 [March 14, 1913] 1
('13', 2, 6, 10, 4333) JAMNADAS,
('13', 2, 7, 11, 4343) The letters you wrote from India have arrived now.
('13', 2, 7, 12, 4394) They were read with great interest.
('13', 2, 7, 13, 4430) I know the restrictions you have placed.
('13', 2, 7, 14, 4471) But in these letters you have given me permission to show them to Chhaganlal and Maganlal.
('13', 2, 7, 15, 4562) They were also shown to Manilal.
('13', 2, 7, 16, 4595) I thought it was in his interest that he should read them, so admirable they appeared to be.
('13', 2, 7, 17, 4688) I shall not show them to anyone else.
('13', 2, 7, 18, 4726) If any letter of yours contains only personal reflections of an intimate nature, I alone will read it and then destroy it.
('13', 2, 7, 19, 4849) Your boils must have disappeared by now.
('13', 2, 7, 20, 4890) You will continue to have one ailment or another till your blood is completely purified and you have suitable diet as dictated by experience.
('13', 2, 7, 21, 5032) With effort, this [trouble] can be overcome.
('13', 2, 7, 22, 5077) This desire [that you should recover] was one of my reasons for wanting you to be with me.
('13', 2, 7, 23, 5168) Ginger, according to our rule, need not be avoided, but it is not beneficial either.
('13', 2, 7, 24, 5253) Its undesirable effects will be immediately observed in those who live on a fruit diet.
('13', 2, 7, 25, 5341) “If we must know English we should know it well”—from this we cannot conclude that if we must travel by railway, we should travel first or second.
('13', 2, 7, 26, 5488) Studying English is not bad in itself, travelling by railway is wholly so; if we must travel, therefore, we should just huddle
('13', 2, 8, 27, 5615) 1 Jamnadas Gandhi left South Africa on December 14, 1912 and any letter from him could not have reached Gandhiji before January 15 of the following year at the earliest.
('13', 2, 8, 28, 5785) In 1913, Phagan Sud 6 corresponds to March 14.

('13', 3, 1, 2, 5872) ourselves in and mind no discomforts.
('13', 3, 1, 3, 5910) Moreover, where countless people are forced to put up with hardships, we should submit to them voluntarily—that is, on occasions when it is not immoral to suffer.
('13', 3, 1, 4, 6073) All the items of the diet on the Farm may not be suitable in Phoenix.
('13', 3, 1, 5, 6143) You fell ill because you did not wait long enough for necessary adjustments to be made.
('13', 3, 1, 6, 6231) A ship is bound to look after the needs of deck passengers.
('13', 3, 1, 7, 6291) I agree that you should not give up milk or curds, but do not give them the chief place.
('13', 3, 1, 8, 6380) They make us more indolent.
('13', 3, 1, 9, 6408) Our friend Kotwal is now in India.
('13', 3, 1, 10, 6443) Cultivate contact with him.
('13', 3, 1, 11, 6471) He still lives on fruit diet.
('13', 3, 1, 12, 6501) You may profit by his experience.
('13', 3, 1, 13, 6535) He is likely to go deep into the matter and discover things which you will not.
('13', 3, 1, 14, 6615) While doing honour to Brahmins, one must maintain a reverential attitude and not treat them with contempt, in the same way that we would respect a person born in a noble family even while we pity him.
('13', 3, 1, 15, 6816) We would, naturally, feel no respect for a prostitute’s son.
('13', 3, 1, 16, 6877) I do not mean, however, that we should support any Brahmins in their wicked ways.
('13', 3, 1, 17, 6959) If you interrupted your studies to offer some little flour to Brahmin beggars who had no business to go begging, you would only be sacrificing your studies.
('13', 3, 1, 18, 7116) I would not think that in doing so you had done honour to the Brahmins; I would rather count it as your timidity or want of judgement.
('13', 3, 1, 19, 7251) Question me again if you have not followed this.
('13', 3, 1, 20, 7300) Give up the afternoon nap, forcing yourself if need be.
('13', 3, 1, 21, 7356) When you feel the urge coming over you, take a bath.
('13', 3, 1, 22, 7409) I am not against schools or against education, but against the stamp.
('13', 3, 1, 23, 7479) This is one ground of objection against government schools.
('13', 3, 1, 24, 7539) A second objection is the lack of character in teachers and the fact that pupils have no intimate contact with them.
('13', 3, 1, 25, 7656) The wasting of time over certain subjects is the third objection, and the fourth that quite often these schools become symbols of our slavery.
('13', 3, 1, 26, 7799) The Parsi cap is not the Parsis’ but ours, though an adopted one.
('13', 3, 1, 27, 7865) Our forefathers may have erred in adopting it.
('13', 3, 1, 28, 7912) The error, however, is not one that need be corrected now.
('13', 3, 1, 29, 7971) But why should we take the trouble of adopting a fresh one?
('13', 3, 1, 30, 8031) Putting on a Hungarian or Moghul cap is suggestive, in a way, of pride and conceit—that we are different from others.

('13', 5, 1, 2, 9630) 4. A PUBLIC EXAMPLE
('13', 5, 2, 3, 9650) A question was raised that the election of Mr. Gokhale to represent the non official members of the Bombay Legislative Council in the Viceregal Council was invalid, as he was an “official” drawing remuneration from the public treasury as a member of the Public Services Commission.
('13', 5, 2, 4, 9932) Mr. Gokhale has, we understand, set the matter at rest, in characteristic fashion, by declining to accept the remuneration to which he would have been entitled.
('13', 5, 2, 5, 10093) Such things are expected from such a man whose whole life has been one of self abnegation in the service of the public.
('13', 5, 2, 6, 10213) We do not congratulate him upon what he would himself regard as a perfectly natural act, but we sincerely congratulate the Motherland upon the possession of so rare minded a son.
('13', 5, 2, 7, 10392) Whilst it is true that an incident of this particular character could not occur in South Africa, where members of commissions are statutorily exempted from the disabilities otherwise attaching to the receipt of remuneration for their services in that capacity, Mr. Gokhale’s example is one that might well be followed even in this self governing Dominion, where, on the contrary, such instances of public morality have been, at least of late years, practically non existent.
('13', 5, 3, 8, 10867) Indian Opinion, 15 3 1913
('13', 6, 0, 1, 10893) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 7
('13', 6, 1, 2, 10938) 5. BRITISH NAVY
('13', 6, 2, 3, 10954) Millions of Englishmen think that British rule is maintained by the strength of the British Navy.
('13', 6, 2, 4, 11052) Many people is Europe believe this and the idea is impressed upon the minds of all citizens of the British Empire.
('13', 6, 2, 5, 11167) Associations have been established for this purpose.
('13', 6, 2, 6, 11220) Newspapers are full of it.
('13', 6, 2, 7, 11247) A huge association named the Navy League has been formed.
('13', 6, 2, 8, 11305) Expenditure on the Navy is rising every day.
('13', 6, 2, 9, 11350) British children are taught from the earliest age that there is nothing at all wrong in this.
('13', 6, 2, 10, 11444) The British sailor is glorified.
('13', 6, 2, 11, 11477) The colonies are even asked to pay a share of the expenditure.
('13', 6, 2, 12, 11540) There was a debate in the Union Parliament last week on this question of contribution, when Mr. Merriman made a very biting and thought provoking speech.
('13', 6, 2, 13, 11694) He said in so many words that Europe had gone crazy.
('13', 6, 2, 14, 11747) It had simply become possessed by the idea of armies.
('13', 6, 2, 15, 11801) The desire for bigger and bigger armies, it would seem, was a kind of disease.
('13', 6, 2, 16, 11880) The poor get crushed in consequence, Mr. Merriman believes.
('13', 6, 2, 17, 11940) He argues, therefore, that South Africa should not join in this craze.
('13', 6, 2, 18, 12011) Though himself an Englishman, he has not much use for British greatness based on the Navy.
('13', 6, 2, 19, 12102) His own view is that it is not from their armed strength that the British derive their greatness.
('13', 6, 2, 20, 12200) He told General Botha and the rest that South Africa should not in any way participate in the British scheme for the [Imperial] Navy.
('13', 6, 2, 21, 12334) Mr. Merriman holds also that the British Army stationed in South Africa should be withdrawn.
('13', 6, 3, 22, 12427) [From Gujarati]
('13', 6, 4, 23, 12443) Indian Opinions, 15 3 1913
('13', 7, 0, 1, 12470) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 7, 1, 2, 12510) 6. GENERAL BOTHA’S SUGGESTION
('13', 7, 2, 3, 12540) There is no doubt that General Botha is a real farmer.
('13', 7, 2, 4, 12595) Everyone knows that he holds land running into thousands of acres.
('13', 7, 2, 5, 12662) But that would not by itself make him a farmer.
('13', 7, 2, 6, 12710) There is a big company in Natal which owns hundreds of thousands of acres of land; none of the members, however, is a farmer.
('13', 7, 2, 7, 12836) They only want to make profits through farmers.
('13', 7, 2, 8, 12884) But General Botha, it seems, lives like a farmer.
('13', 7, 2, 9, 12934) He himself works on the land, is well informed about matters connected with the land and knows all about the various crops.
('13', 7, 2, 10, 13058) On horses and sheep he is an expert.
('13', 7, 2, 11, 13095) Besides, even his speeches touch upon the great importance of agriculture.
('13', 7, 2, 12, 13170) In his heart of hearts, he seems to be convinced that South Africa’s future does not lie in its gold mines.
('13', 7, 2, 13, 13278) There are some who even believe that the gold mines will be exhausted in a few years, and that Johannesburg and other cities will be reduced to the same condition as some American cities.
('13', 7, 2, 14, 13466) Be that as it may, General Botha has recently made a speech which is worth noting.
('13', 7, 2, 15, 13549) He has expressed himself in favour of expropriating the land of the white landlords who do not themselves work on it and transferring it to worthier hands.
('13', 7, 2, 16, 13705) Of course, other whites will not allow him to take such a step and the idea will not be implemented.
('13', 7, 2, 17, 13806) Nevertheless, it is valuable in itself.
('13', 7, 2, 18, 13846) Botha, with his enthusiasm for agriculture, can give it a strong impetus through his influence and authority.
('13', 7, 2, 19, 13956) We would like to see something of the same spirit among us.
('13', 7, 2, 20, 14016) We, too, would do well to turn our minds to agriculture.
('13', 7, 3, 21, 14073) [From Gujarati]
('13', 7, 4, 22, 14089) Indian Opinion, 15 3 1913
('13', 8, 0, 1, 14115) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 9
('13', 8, 1, 2, 14160) 7. WHO IS ENTITLED TO ENTER TRANSVAAL?
('13', 8, 2, 3, 14199) During our representative’s tour a number of leading people wished to know who can enter the Transvaal.
('13', 8, 2, 4, 14303) Hence, though this has been stated earlier, we repeat it below.
('13', 8, 2, 5, 14367) Only those Indians who hold certificates under the Registration Act of 1908 or 1907 can now enter the Transvaal without an application or other formalities.
('13', 8, 2, 6, 14524) Apart from showing their certificates on the border and producing evidence that they are their own, there is nothing they have to do.
('13', 8, 2, 7, 14658) If, however, anyone is accompanied by a wife, or minor under 16 years, he is required to produce evidence in respect of them.
('13', 8, 2, 8, 14784) Very often, the officer is high handed and does not allow one to proceed further.
('13', 8, 2, 9, 14866) This means one’s being kept waiting on the border.
('13', 8, 2, 10, 14917) It is sometimes even necessary to approach the magistrate.
('13', 8, 2, 11, 14976) One has to pay lawyers.
('13', 8, 2, 12, 15000) To save oneself from this harassment one method that is adopted is to flatter the Registrar and take out a permit in advance.
('13', 8, 2, 13, 15126) But method has had an undesirable consequence: the pressure in that direction has increased.
('13', 8, 2, 14, 15219) Even a person with excellent evidence is put to difficulties.
('13', 8, 2, 15, 15281) An alternative way is to put up with the difficulties for the time being and obtain redress through the regular procedure.
('13', 8, 2, 16, 15404) This may mean inconvenience in the immediate present but things will be smoother afterwards.
('13', 8, 2, 17, 15497) If all Indians adopt this course, the matter will be put right quite soon.
('13', 8, 2, 18, 15572) If only some do so, it might take longer.
('13', 8, 2, 19, 15614) In this connection, a question has also been raised as to what minors and women coming in should do.
('13', 8, 2, 20, 15715) The Transvaal officers require evidence on the following lines in respect of minors: (i) A certificate from a first class magistrate to the effect that the minor holding it is in fact the child of the person represented to be the father.
('13', 8, 2, 21, 15953) (ii) The thumb impression of the minor and the father on the certificate for purposes of identification.
('13', 8, 2, 22, 16058) (iii) Evidence as to the child’s age.
('13', 8, 2, 23, 16096) This need not be very precise in every case.
('13', 8, 2, 24, 16141) When it can be seen from the child’s physique that the age is without doubt below 16, no evidence as to age is necessary.
('13', 8, 2, 25, 16263) (iv) It should be clearly stated in the magistrate’s certificate that he has fully satisfied himself that the child is in fact the son of the
('13', 9, 0, 1, 16405) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 9, 1, 2, 16446) person concerned.
('13', 9, 1, 3, 16464) In a genuine case, evidence on these points can be easily secured and a father who wants to take his son with him to the Transvaal would do well to carry such evidence.
('13', 9, 1, 4, 16633) It should, however, be remembered that those who have not brought any such evidence do not on that account lose their rights.
('13', 9, 1, 5, 16759) Poor people cannot sometimes get in India evidence that they can in South Africa.
('13', 9, 1, 6, 16841) We hear that such certificates are also required from women.
('13', 9, 1, 7, 16902) It is our emphatic advice, however, that women must not give their thumb impressions.
('13', 9, 1, 8, 16988) The Government has no authority to be so rigorous in regard to the identification of women for the simple reason that there is no need for that.
('13', 9, 1, 9, 17133) There have not been many instances of Indians trying to bring in women who have no genuine rights.
('13', 9, 1, 10, 17232) About women therefore, we must put up a fight.
('13', 9, 1, 11, 17279) We believe that in the case of women the marriage certificate would suffice and we know that the right of a woman holding such a certificate can be legally established.
('13', 9, 1, 12, 17448) The explanation we have given above relates to the Transvaal.
('13', 9, 1, 13, 17510) The question, too, was about the Transvaal.
('13', 9, 1, 14, 17554) But, by and large, it holds for Natal also.
('13', 9, 1, 15, 17598) We know that there is greater strictness in Natal.
('13', 9, 1, 16, 17649) The Natal officer has more power.
('13', 9, 1, 17, 17683) But it should be enough for anyone to have evidence as indicated above.
('13', 9, 1, 18, 17755) It should also be remembered that we are carrying on a fight against the strictness in Natal.
('13', 9, 1, 19, 17849) If any Indian, in his selfishness, submits to the high handedness of an officer there, he will to that extent strengthen the officer’s position and weaken the struggle.
('13', 9, 1, 20, 18018) This is a simple rule: where there are no slaves, there are no slave drivers.
('13', 9, 1, 21, 18096) It is only where people seem prepared to submit to slavery that others set themselves up as masters.
('13', 9, 1, 22, 18197) Our condition in South Africa is such that vigorous action will bring about an immediate improvement in it.
('13', 9, 1, 23, 18305) But weakness will reduce it to the lowest level.
('13', 9, 1, 24, 18354) This is not so in other colonies because conditions there are neither too good nor too bad so that people do not even realize that they are held in fetters.
('13', 9, 1, 25, 18511) Here, on the contrary, every Indian feels he is a captive in chains.
('13', 9, 2, 26, 18580) [From Gujarati]
('13', 9, 3, 27, 18596) Indian Opinion, 15 3 1913
('13', 10, 0, 1, 18622) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 11
('13', 10, 1, 2, 18668) 8. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XI]
('13', 10, 2, 3, 18708) We have seen that certain things should be avoided altogether.
('13', 10, 2, 4, 18771) It remains to be shown that there are others which, for quite different reasons, should either be given up or consumed only in limited quantities.
('13', 10, 2, 5, 18918) Postponing this discussion for the moment, we shall consider what our diet ought to be.
('13', 10, 2, 6, 19006) We can divide mankind into there very large categories on the basis of diet.
('13', 10, 2, 7, 19083) To one class belong the people who, by choice or necessity, eat vegetable products only.
('13', 10, 2, 8, 19172) This is the largest class.
('13', 10, 2, 9, 19199) It consists of most persons in India and Europe and considerable numbers in Japan and China.
('13', 10, 2, 10, 19292) Of these people, a few are vegetarians as a matter of religious principle, but the majority do without meat because they are unable to obtain it, though, if they get it, they eat it with relish.
('13', 10, 2, 11, 19487) Among these latter are included Italians, Irish and Scottish people and the poor of Russia as well as of China and Japan.
('13', 10, 2, 12, 19609) Thus, the chief food of Italy is macaroni, of Ireland potato, of Scotland oatmeal and of China and Japan, rice.
('13', 10, 2, 13, 19721) People of the second category eat a little meat or fish in addition to vegetable products, once or more than once a day.
('13', 10, 2, 14, 19842) The majority in England comes under this category, as do rich Muslims in India and Hindus who are unorthodox, besides the well to do Chinese and Japanese.
('13', 10, 2, 15, 19997) This division, though quite large, is very much smaller that the first one.
('13', 10, 2, 16, 20073) The third division consists of primitive tribes inhabiting the Arctic regions, as well as some Negroes who live on flesh alone.
('13', 10, 2, 17, 20201) Their number is very small and even these, as they come into contact with European travellers, are learning to add vegetables to their diet.
('13', 10, 2, 18, 20342) The conclusion to be drawn from all this simply is that man can live in all the three ways; what we have to consider, however, is the question as to which diet is the most health giving.
('13', 10, 2, 19, 20529) The structure of the body would seem to indicate that Nature intended man to be a vegetarian.
('13', 10, 2, 20, 20623) A comparison which other animals reveals that our body structure most closely resembles that of fruit eating animals, that is, the apes.
('13', 10, 2, 21, 20760) The diet of the apes is fresh and dry fruit.
('13', 10, 2, 22, 20805) Their teeth and stomach are similar to ours.
('13', 10, 2, 23, 20850) The teeth and the stomach of predacious beasts, such as the lion and the tiger, differ in structure from ours.
('13', 10, 2, 24, 20961) We do not have claws as they have.
('13', 10, 2, 25, 20996) We have, moreover, something in common with non carnivorous beasts—the
('13', 11, 0, 1, 21067) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 11, 1, 2, 21108) ox, for instance.
('13', 11, 1, 3, 21126) We do not, however, possess intestines like theirs and in the same number, for digesting large quantities of grass.
('13', 11, 1, 4, 21242) From this, many scientists conclude that man is not by nature carnivorous nor is he formed so as to be able to eat every kind of vegetable food.
('13', 11, 1, 5, 21387) Even from among vegetable products, fruit alone should be his staple diet.
('13', 11, 1, 6, 21462) Chemists have shown by experiment that fruits contain all the elements necessary for the maintenance of human life.
('13', 11, 1, 7, 21578) Fruits such as bananas, oranges, dates, figs, apples, pineapples, almonds, walnuts, peanuts and coconuts contain all the elements necessary for health and energy.
('13', 11, 1, 8, 21741) These scientists say that this food need not be cooked, and as animals maintain health by eating sun ripened fruit, so should we.
('13', 11, 1, 9, 21871) They go so far as to assert that cooking removes certain essential properties of vegetable foods and reduces their nutritional value.
('13', 11, 1, 10, 22005) The stimulating quality peculiar to vegetable products is partly lost in the process.
('13', 11, 1, 11, 22091) They even advance the argument that vegetable products which cannot be eaten raw are no diet for us.
('13', 11, 2, 12, 22192) If this argument is correct, surely much of the time spent in preparing and eating food be saved and we could finish our meals in a shorter time.
('13', 11, 2, 13, 22338) Much of the time of our womenfolk and the space take up by kitchens, etc., in our homes would then be saved and we would be free to attend to many other matters by putting to good use the time and money thus saved.
('13', 11, 2, 14, 22553) The idea that all cooking will stop, that women will be set free from the prison house of the kitchen, that women will themselves desire such freedom—all this will, I am afraid, seem a mere dream and some may ask why at all we should discuss things which are impossible.
('13', 11, 2, 15, 22824) We are, however, not concerned at the moment with whether everyone can put this into practice.
('13', 11, 2, 16, 22919) We are only thinking of what is best to do.
('13', 11, 2, 17, 22963) If we know what is perfect health, we shall achieve a more or less satisfactory level of health.
('13', 11, 2, 18, 23060) If we know what the ideal diet is, we shall know what we should generally eat.
('13', 11, 2, 19, 23139) Many books have been written on this subject in Europe.
('13', 11, 2, 20, 23195) One even comes across Europeans who experiment with fruit diet.
('13', 11, 2, 21, 23259) Some of them have recorded their experiences.
('13', 11, 2, 22, 23305) These men take to a fruit diet not from any religious consideration but purely for the sake of health.
('13', 11, 2, 23, 23408) There is a German named Just who has written an excellent book 1 in which he has proved, with numerous examples,
('13', 11, 3, 24, 23521) 1 Return to Nature
('13', 12, 0, 1, 23540) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 13
('13', 12, 1, 2, 23586) that fruit diet is the best.
('13', 12, 1, 3, 23615) He has cured many patients merely with the help of fruit diet and fresh air.
('13', 12, 1, 4, 23692) He even claims that men can get all the nourishment they need from the fruit growing in their own regions.
('13', 12, 1, 5, 23799) It will not be out of place if I here describe my own experiment.
('13', 12, 1, 6, 23865) For the past six months, I have eaten nothing but fruits.
('13', 12, 1, 7, 23923) I have not taken even milk or curds.
('13', 12, 1, 8, 23960) My diet has consisted of bananas, peanuts, olive oil, lemon or similar citrus fruit, and dates.
('13', 12, 1, 9, 24056) I do not claim that the experiment has proved completely successful.
('13', 12, 1, 10, 24125) Six months is not enough to gauge the results of such a big change, but I can say this at any rate, that when others fell ill I remained well.
('13', 12, 1, 11, 24268) I have greater physical and mental energy, than before.
('13', 12, 1, 12, 24324) As regards physical strength, I may not be able, I admit, to lift as heavy weights as I could formerly, but I can work for longer periods at a stretch without fatigue.
('13', 12, 1, 13, 24492) Of mental work I do much more at present and cope with it all.
('13', 12, 1, 14, 24555) I have recommended this diet to some patients and the results have been little short of miraculous.
('13', 12, 1, 15, 24655) I intend to describe these in the chapter on diseases.
('13', 12, 1, 16, 24710) In fine, then, the experience of others and of myself and what reading and thinking I have done seem to suggest that a fruit diet is superior to all other kinds of diet.
('13', 12, 1, 17, 24880) I do not for a moment expect that anyone reading this will straightaway take to experimenting with fruit diet.
('13', 12, 1, 18, 24991) What I have will scarcely have any effect on the reader.
('13', 12, 1, 19, 25048) But, if I am to tell the truth, as I wish to, I think it is my duty to present only my own conclusions, such as they are.
('13', 12, 1, 20, 25170) If, however, any reader does plan to experiment with fruit diet.
('13', 12, 1, 21, 25235) I would advise him not to rush into it but to go slow.
('13', 12, 1, 22, 25290) After first reading all the chapters, he should draw his own conclusions and then do whatever he wants to with full deliberation.
('13', 12, 1, 23, 25420) In the following section we shall consider the diet of the second category.
('13', 12, 1, 24, 25496) I think the conclusions of that section will be more acceptable and also that, after he has perused it, he will find it easier to understand the present section.
('13', 12, 1, 25, 25658) To those who have been following these chapters seriously, my request is that they form their own opinions and that, too, after reading the entire series.

('13', 14, 1, 2, 28616) 10 HINDUS AND MAHOMEDANS BEWARE
('13', 14, 2, 3, 28648) The whole question was whether a wife, married by Mahomedan custom, was wife within the meaning of the Immigration Act.
('13', 14, 2, 4, 28768) His Lordship held that the application must be refused as the marriage did not satisfy the requirements of the Immigration Law.
('13', 14, 2, 5, 28896) Thus the Cape Argus report.
('13', 14, 2, 6, 28924) Indians of South Africa will never get a clearer or more important judgment to deal with.
('13', 14, 2, 7, 29014) Hitherto the judgments that have been given affecting the question of marriage have been more or less enigmatic.
('13', 14, 2, 8, 29127) On the occasion in question, a clear cut issue was presented.
('13', 14, 2, 9, 29189) The case was admitted to be a test case and judgment has been given against us Indians.
('13', 14, 2, 10, 29277) 1 This is not a judgment given against an individual.
('13', 14, 2, 11, 29331) The Judge was, no doubt, helpless.
('13', 14, 2, 12, 29366) The Immigration Officer could not be held to blame.
('13', 14, 2, 13, 29418) He had to administer an Act and he has done so.
('13', 14, 2, 14, 29466) The meaning of the judgment is that every Hindu and Mahomedan wife is in South Africa illegally, and, therefore, at the mercy of the Government, whose grace alone can enable her to remain in this country.
('13', 14, 2, 15, 29671) And no one will be blamed but ourselves if the future Indian wives—Hindu, Mahomedan or Parsee—are turned out.
('13', 14, 2, 16, 29781) This is a state of things which our self respect forbids us from tolerating.
('13', 14, 2, 17, 29858) We hope that every Anjuman, every Association, and every Dharma Sabha will send respectful representations to the Government urging that the new Immigration Bill should be altered so as to admit the legality of marriages celebrated according to the recognized Indian religions.
('13', 14, 2, 18, 30136) This request should be promptly granted, not merely because we are part of the British Empire, but even because of the law of comity of nations.
('13', 14, 2, 19, 30281) It is, indeed, a serious question for passive resisters to consider whether they ought not to include in their requirements a redress of this unthought of but intolerable grievance.
('13', 14, 2, 20, 30463) Anyway, it is a question which demands, on the part of the Indians, sacrifice of their all—their businesses, their money, their ease—which will have been dearly bought at the price of the nullity of their or their brethren’s marriages.
('13', 14, 2, 21, 30699) No consideration should be allowed to come in the way of their taking prompt and energetic action.

('13', 15, 1, 2, 30891) 11. ATTACK ON INDIAN RELIGIONS
('13', 15, 2, 3, 30922) We have never read or heard of a judgment as important as the one concerning women recently published in the Cape Times.
('13', 15, 2, 4, 31043) A woman named Bai Mariam had been married according to Muslim rites and her husband brought her from India.
('13', 15, 2, 5, 31151) The Immigration Officer stopped her.

('13', 15, 2, 7, 31268) This was admitted to be a test case.
('13', 15, 2, 8, 31305) There was only one point at issue, whether or not a marriage solemnized according to the Muslim rites or under any religion other than Christianity was legal.
('13', 15, 2, 9, 31464) The Judge decided that such a marriage was not legal and that therefore the woman had no right to enter the Cape.
('13', 15, 2, 10, 31578) She has been ordered to return.

('13', 15, 2, 12, 31730) In other words, a Hindu, Muslim or Parsi wife can live in this country only by the grace of the Government.
('13', 15, 2, 13, 31838) It is quite on the cards that the Government will not permit any more wives to come in or that, if it does, it will be entirely as a matter of favour.

('13', 15, 2, 19, 32565) And so it would not be too much if we, for the same purpose, embrace poverty.

('13', 20, 1, 2, 39448) 16. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XII]
('13', 20, 2, 3, 39490) On the next level and below fruits, comes vegetable diet.
('13', 20, 2, 4, 39548) This consists of all kinds of vegetables, cereals, pulses, beans, milk, etc.
('13', 20, 2, 5, 39625) Just as fruit diet contains all the elements that man needs, so too does vegetarian diet, though the two do not have the same effect.
('13', 20, 2, 6, 39759) Some of the elements we obtain from food are also to be found in the air; yet we cannot obtain them from air and do without food.
('13', 20, 2, 7, 39889) Moreover, all vegetable products lose something of their original nature when cooked and are to that extent robbed of value, one would have cooked food and cannot go without vegetables, it has to be considered what it would be best to take.
('13', 20, 3, 8, 40130) Among grains, wheat is the best.
('13', 20, 3, 9, 40163) Man can live on wheat alone.
('13', 20, 3, 10, 40192) It contains all the nutritive elements in good proportion.
('13', 20, 3, 11, 40251) Many preparations can be made of it, and it is also easy to digest.
('13', 20, 3, 12, 40319) Children’s foods available in the market also contain a proportion of wheat.
('13', 20, 3, 13, 40396) In the same category with wheat are millets and maize, from all of the which rotli 1 or roti 2 can be prepared, though these cereals cannot compare with wheat.
('13', 20, 3, 14, 40556) It is important to understand what the best way of taking wheat is.
('13', 20, 3, 15, 40624) Wheat flour, which we know as mill flour, is absolutely worthless, devoid of all nutritional value.
('13', 20, 3, 16, 40724) Dr. Alinson says that a dog he kept exclusively on such a diet succumbed as a result, but another flourished on bread from a different variety of flour.
('13', 20, 3, 17, 40877) White flour is entirely devoid of bran, which is the source of the taste and energy giving property of wheat.
('13', 20, 3, 18, 40987) White bread is in such demand because, eaten with it, other tasty things are most enjoyed.
('13', 20, 3, 19, 41078) For instance, those who eat cheese derive energy from it but they eat it, and can eat it, only as an adjunct to bread.
('13', 20, 3, 20, 41197) Rotli, too made of such flour is bad; it is tough and offers neither taste not nutrition.
('13', 20, 3, 21, 41287) The best flour is that which is obtained by grinding clean wheat at home and if in addition, it is ground by hand in a quern, it is considered to be the very best.
('13', 20, 3, 22, 41451) If, however, one cannot secure a quern, one can purchase at a low cost a handmill to be kept in the home and grind wheat for
('13', 20, 4, 23, 41576) 1 Unleavened bread 2 ibid
('13', 21, 0, 1, 41602) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 21, 1, 2, 41643) personal use.
('13', 21, 1, 3, 41657) Or one can buy unsifted Boer meal and use it.
('13', 21, 1, 4, 41703) The flour should be used as it is, unsifted, The roti made of this flour is tasty and nourishing and the flour is more economical to use than maida, since, being nutritious, it cannot be consumed in the same quantity as maida.

('13', 21, 2, 8, 42100) This is a great drawback.
('13', 21, 2, 9, 42126) It is the opinion of many experienced people that bread made of such flour is harmful.
('13', 21, 2, 10, 42213) Then again, during preparation.
('13', 21, 2, 11, 42245) the loaf is covered with tandul or fat; hence it should be unacceptable both to Hindus and Muslims.
('13', 21, 2, 12, 42345) To eat shop bread in place of roti prepared at home is nothing but a mark of laziness.

('13', 21, 3, 14, 42527) Porridge, if well cooked in water and taken with milk or sugar, tastes delicious and is much superior to other kinds of food.

('13', 21, 4, 16, 42789) Wheat, on the other hand, cooked in water alone is enough to maintain one in good health.
('13', 21, 5, 17, 42879) Vegetables are eaten mainly for their taste.
('13', 21, 5, 18, 42924) They have a laxative effect and thus help purify the blood.
('13', 21, 5, 19, 42984) However, they are of the nature of grass, they are difficult to digest and give excessive work to the stomach.

('13', 21, 5, 21, 43347) That some varieties of vegetables are a form of grass is plain enough to us.
('13', 21, 5, 22, 43424) Vegetables, therefore, should certainly be eaten but, be it remembered, only in small quantities.
('13', 21, 6, 23, 43522) Pulses—beans, val, 2 tuwar, 3 vetches, tare, lentil—are regarded as good tonic foods.
('13', 21, 6, 24, 43608) They are difficult to digest as they require much

('13', 22, 1, 2, 43784) heat in the stomach.
('13', 22, 1, 3, 43805) The fact that a person who has eaten a quantity of pulses frequently passes wind only means that he has not been able to carry it.
('13', 22, 1, 4, 43936) It is for this reason that pulses are regarded as causing vayu [excess of wind].
('13', 22, 1, 5, 44017) One characteristic of pulses is that they keep one going for a fairly long time.
('13', 22, 1, 6, 44098) A person who has to undertake much physical labour can tolerate pulses more easily and even derive some benefit from them.

('13', 23, 3, 4, 45145) DEAR SIR, There are two matters of urgency in which I feel that I should now write asking for information.
('13', 23, 3, 5, 45252) Being aware of the illness of the Hon’ble the Minister of the Interior from which I hope Mr. Fischer is recovering, I have been reluctant to trouble the Minister acting for Mr. fischer.

('13', 23, 3, 10, 46311) And may I know whether the proposed Immigration Bill embodying the terms of the provisional settlement will be brought forward during the present session of the parliament?

('13', 24, 1, 2, 46850) 18. THE MARRIAGE QUESTION 1
('13', 24, 2, 3, 46878) We dwelt at some length last week upon the momentous decision given by the Cape Provincial Division of the Supreme Court on the question of the validity of non Christian marriage among Indians.
('13', 24, 2, 4, 47072) This week we publish valuable information regarding the action of the Master of the Natal Provincial Division.
('13', 24, 2, 5, 47183) This officer has questioned the validity of Mahomedan marriage for the purpose of assessing succession duty.
('13', 24, 2, 6, 47292) 2 We need not go into the particulars about the difference in the duty chargeable.
('13', 24, 2, 7, 47375) But the great issue raised by the Master, so far as we are concerned, is that of the validity of marriages performed according to the tenets of the great faith of India.
('13', 24, 2, 8, 47545) It might be here remarked that this totally unexpected calamity—it is nothing less—has overtaken us not because of any new law but because of the new interpretation that is being placed upon an old law.
('13', 24, 2, 9, 47748) Ever since the settlement of Indians in South Africa, Indian marriages, celebrated according to Indian religious custom, have been recognized.
('13', 24, 2, 10, 47891) The issues of such marriages have inherited considerable properties as lawful heirs of their deceases parents.
('13', 24, 2, 11, 48002) It is the new spirit of the Union breathed upon the officers administering old laws that has brought about the present intolerable situation.
('13', 24, 2, 12, 48144) Indeed, the logical result of the new interpretation is that even past acts might be impugned and heirs in possession of the inheritances might be dispossessed.
('13', 24, 2, 13, 48305) Indian society has suddenly been plunged into confusion from which it can extricate itself only by a mighty effort.
('13', 24, 2, 14, 48421) For, if the policy of the Government, as foreshadowed in the cases we have published from time to time, is continued, they will be able without resorting to new legislation either to exterminate us or to paralyse us as a progressive community, unless we are prepared to offer stubborn opposition.
('13', 24, 2, 15, 48718) We may now, perhaps, understand the reason for the very cautious reply 3 made by Lord Emmott to Lord Ampthill.
('13', 24, 2, 16, 48829) These cases explain his Lordship’s reticence, but they cannot be allowed to excuse
('13', 24, 3, 17, 48912) 1 Vide also “Hindus and Mahomedans Beware”, 22 3 1913 and “Attack on Indian Religions”, 22 3 1913. 2 In Natal, a Mahomedan had left by his will his entire property to his surviving wife.
('13', 24, 3, 18, 49099) For assessing the succession duty, the Master of the Provincial Division of the Supreme Court had called for proof apart from the husband’s statement and suggested that the parties concerned should get the Supreme Court’s ruling on the point.
('13', 24, 3, 19, 49342) Indian Opinion, 29 1 1913. 3 Vide 1st footnote of “Lord Ampthill’s Advocacy”, 22 3 1913.

('13', 25, 3, 4, 49717) 19. INDIAN MARRIAGES

('13', 25, 4, 11, 50265) The effects will be felt by all Indians.
('13', 25, 4, 12, 50306) Some people argue, we hear, that there can be no satyagraha in a matter concerning women, for they cannot be asked to go to gaol.

('13', 25, 4, 15, 50548) There may be no need whatever for women to go to gaol or to be asked to do so.
('13', 25, 4, 16, 50627) What is needed is that men should be men enough.
('13', 25, 4, 17, 50676) Satyagraha, moreover, is far off yet.
('13', 25, 4, 18, 50714) Where is the question of satyagraha in taking counsel together, parting with a little money, holding meetings and sending petitions?
('13', 25, 4, 19, 50847) If we take cover behind the argument that there can be no satyagraha and sit back with folded hands, we shall only bring ridicule upon ourselves and our womenfolk.

('13', 27, 4, 6, 53218) 22. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XIII]
('13', 27, 5, 7, 53261) We shall now consider what vegetables should be avoided.
('13', 27, 5, 8, 53318) In almost every part of India, it is customary to use chillies together with spices such as coriander seed, black pepper, etc.
('13', 27, 5, 9, 53445) The practice does not obtain in other parts of the world to the same extent.
('13', 27, 5, 10, 53522) If we offer any of our spicy dishes to the Negroes here, they also will hesitate to eat them as they do not care for their taste.
('13', 27, 5, 11, 53652) Many white who are unused to spices are totally unable to eat our pungent food and, if they force themselves to eat it, their digestion suffers and the mouth gets inflamed.
('13', 27, 5, 12, 53825) I have witnessed this myself in the case of some whites.
('13', 27, 5, 13, 53882) We may conclude, therefore, that spices are not themselves appetizing but that, having become accustomed to them by long use, we like their smell and taste.
('13', 27, 5, 14, 54039) We have already recognized, however, that eating anything for the sake of its taste is harmful to health.
('13', 27, 5, 15, 54145) Let us then examine why people eat spices.
('13', 27, 5, 16, 54188) They do so, it will be readily admitted, in order to be able to eat more and digest more.
('13', 27, 5, 17, 54278) Chillies, coriander seed, cummin, etc., produce heat in the stomach and in consequence we seem to feel more hungry.
('13', 27, 5, 18, 54394) If, however, we imagine from this that the food we have thus consumed is all digested and transformed into pure blood, we shall be sadly mistaken.
('13', 27, 5, 19, 54541) Many people indulge in over spicy food.
('13', 27, 5, 20, 54581) Their stomachs become very weak in the long run and some even get attacks of sprue.
('13', 27, 5, 21, 54665) A certain man used to eat large amounts of chillies, a habit which he could not overcome, and he died in his youth after a long illness which kept him on bed for six months.
('13', 27, 5, 22, 54839) It is imperative that we eliminate spices from out diet altogether.
('13', 27, 5, 23, 54907) This stricture applies equally to salt.
('13', 27, 5, 24, 54947) No one will like this idea and some may even be aghast at it, but its truth has, nevertheless, been proved by experience.
('13', 27, 5, 25, 55069) An association has been started in
('13', 28, 0, 1, 55104) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 29
('13', 28, 1, 2, 55150) England whose creed is that salt is even more injurious than most spices.
('13', 28, 1, 3, 55224) Our diet supplies salt to us in organic forms, and that is all that we really need.
('13', 28, 1, 4, 55308) Sea salt and rock salt, on the other hand, are superfluous and when consumed are expelled again through perspiration and otherwise.
('13', 28, 1, 5, 55440) This means that salt has no specific utility for the body.
('13', 28, 1, 6, 55499) One book goes so far as to say that consumption of salt has a toxic effect on the blood and that one who has abstained from salt for many years and has otherwise kept his body clean has his blood stream so pure that even snake bite will do him no harm; for the blood of such a person develops a resistance to the venom.
('13', 28, 1, 7, 55819) We cannot ascertain the truth of this statement but from experience I can at least say that ailments such as cough, piles, asthma, bleeding, etc., respond immediately to a saltless diet.
('13', 28, 1, 8, 56006) A certain Indian had long suffered from asthma and cough.
('13', 28, 1, 9, 56064) These were cured by the adoption of a saltless diet together with the use of the usual remedies.
('13', 28, 1, 10, 56161) I have not come across any undesirable results from giving up salt.
('13', 28, 1, 11, 56229) I myself gave it up over two years ago and have felt no ill effect; on the contrary, I observe some beneficial effects.
('13', 28, 1, 12, 56349) I need less water and feel less lethargic.
('13', 28, 1, 13, 56392) The incident which occasioned my giving up salt was somewhat unusual, too.
('13', 28, 1, 14, 56467) The person 1 whose ailment was responsible for my doing so has had her illness under control ever since.
('13', 28, 1, 15, 56572) I am confident, too, that had the patient been able to give salt completely, her malady would have been entirely eradicated.
('13', 28, 1, 16, 56697) I have observed during numerous experiments that people find it difficult to give up green vegetables and pulses together with the salt but this has to be done.
('13', 28, 1, 17, 56858) I think these articles prove hard to digest without the addition of salt.
('13', 28, 1, 18, 56932) This does not mean that salt stimulates digestion; on the contrary, just as chillies merely give the illusion of aiding the digestive process and are found to be harmful in the long run, so it is with salt.
('13', 28, 1, 19, 57139) It follows, therefore, that those who adopt a saltless diet must give up green vegetables and pulses as well.
('13', 28, 1, 20, 57249) Anyone can make this experiment and watch the effect on himself.
('13', 28, 1, 21, 57314) Just as an opium addict who tries to rid himself of his habit feels out of sorts and weak at first, so is the case with one who refrains from salt.
('13', 28, 1, 22, 57462) One should not, however, lose heart on this account.
('13', 28, 1, 23, 57515) If the person who gives up salt is patient
('13', 28, 2, 24, 57558) 1 Kasturba Gandhi.
('13', 29, 0, 1, 57577) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 29, 1, 2, 57618) enough, he will be rewarded by and by.
('13', 29, 1, 3, 57657) The writer has been bold enough to assert that even milk is among the articles to be avoided.
('13', 29, 1, 4, 57751) One basis for this opinion is his own experience, but that should be kept out of consideration.
('13', 29, 1, 5, 57847) We entertain so strong a superstition as to the value of milk that it would be a vain effort to combat it.
('13', 29, 1, 6, 57954) The writer does not expect that his readers will agree with all the opinions he expresses in these articles, nor does he expect either that all those who approve of them will put them into practice; his object is only to present his ideas, leaving it to others to accept whatever they will.
('13', 29, 1, 7, 58245) There is nothing wrong, therefore, in his writing even about milk.
('13', 29, 1, 8, 58312) Many doctors have stated that milk is the cause of typhoid.
('13', 29, 1, 9, 58372) Pamphlets have been published on this subject.
('13', 29, 1, 10, 58419) Milk gets easily contaminated with airborne germs and those which are inimical to health multiply rapidly in it.
('13', 29, 1, 11, 58532) We have to take a great deal of trouble to keep it in good condition.
('13', 29, 1, 12, 58602) In South Africa there are special laws for [the protection of] consumers of milk.
('13', 29, 1, 13, 58684) Very many recommendation are made for the preservation and storage of milk and cleaning of utensils.
('13', 29, 1, 14, 58785) It seems reasonable to question whether it is worth while using an article which needs so much care to keep and which, if not so guarded, may do harm.
('13', 29, 2, 15, 58936) Moreover, the goodness or otherwise of milk depends on the condition of the cow and what she eats.
('13', 29, 2, 16, 59035) Doctors cite instances of persons drinking the milk of a tuberculous cow and themselves developing tuberculosis.
('13', 29, 2, 17, 59148) It is difficult to find a perfectly healthy cow, and the milk of a diseased cow is unwholesome.
('13', 29, 2, 18, 59244) It is well known that a sick mother’s milk makes the baby also sick.
('13', 29, 2, 19, 59313) When a baby which has not yet been weaned falls ill, vaids treat the mother, so that through her milk the medicine may act on the baby.
('13', 29, 2, 20, 59449) What is true of woman’s milk applies also to cow’s milk.
('13', 29, 2, 21, 59506) In this way, the food and the health of the giver of milk have an intimate bearing on its consumer.
('13', 29, 2, 22, 59606) Would not the right course be to avoid this milk, the consumption of which demands so much trouble and carries so much risk?
('13', 29, 2, 23, 59731) The strength giving property of milk is to be found in other substance as well.
('13', 29, 2, 24, 59811) Olive oil is a good substitute for milk in many ways.
('13', 29, 2, 25, 59865) A preparation of sweet almonds made by soaking them in hot water, peeling and grinding them to a fine paste and mixing this thoroughly with water,
('13', 30, 0, 1, 60012) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 31
('13', 30, 1, 2, 60058) will have all the beneficial properties of milk and none of its risks.
('13', 30, 1, 3, 60129) Finally, let us consider the law of Nature: a calf gives up sucking after a few months and, as soon as its teeth are developed, it turns to food which requires their use; this should be the rule with human beings, too.
('13', 30, 1, 4, 60348) We are meant to take milk only so long as we are infants.
('13', 30, 1, 5, 60406) We, too, should, when our teeth are grown, employ them in chewing fresh fruit such as apples and dry fruit such as almonds, or rotli.
('13', 30, 1, 6, 60540) This is not the place to calculate how much money and time can be saved by anyone who has shaken off his slavery to milk, but each one will be able to find out for himself.
('13', 30, 1, 7, 60713) Milk products, too, are unnecessary.
('13', 30, 1, 8, 60750) The acid content of whey is available from lemon and its other nutrients from almonds, etc.
('13', 30, 1, 9, 60842) As to ghee, thousands of Indians consume oil instead.
('13', 30, 2, 10, 60896) Let us now turn for a while to the third type of diet.
('13', 30, 2, 11, 60951) It is a mixture of vegetarian and non vegetarian elements.
('13', 30, 2, 12, 61010) This diet is adopted by a large number of people, of whom many suffer from various ailments and many others are found to be healthy.
('13', 30, 2, 13, 61143) That we are not meant to be meat eaters, each one of our organs and the constitution of our bodies make evident.
('13', 30, 2, 14, 61256) Dr. Kingsford and Dr. Haig have vividly described the ill effects of non vegetarian diet on the body.
('13', 30, 2, 15, 61358) They have proved that the acid produced by consumption of pulses is also produced by that of meat.
('13', 30, 2, 16, 61457) Meat eating damages the teeth and causes rheumatism.
('13', 30, 2, 17, 61510) It makes a man more prone to anger, and therefore a sick man.
('13', 30, 2, 18, 61572) According to our definition of health, one who is quick to get angry cannot be counted a healthy person.
('13', 30, 2, 19, 61677) Those who eat the fourth and last type of diet, that is, who subsist exclusively on flesh, need not detain us here.
('13', 30, 2, 20, 61793) Their state is so vile that the very thought of them should be enough to put us off meat eating.
('13', 30, 2, 21, 61890) They are not healthy in any sense of the term.
('13', 30, 2, 22, 61937) As soon as they come up a little and get some knowledge, they tend to accept a vegetarian diet.
('13', 30, 2, 23, 62033) What all this adds up to is that very few people will be found ready for an exclusively fruit diet, but that a diet of dry and fresh fruit, wheat and olive oil is worth a trial, it being possible to maintain sound health on it.
('13', 30, 2, 24, 62261) Among fruits, bananas occupy the first place.
('13', 30, 2, 25, 62307) Besides, dates, plums and figs are strength giving fruits.
('13', 30, 2, 26, 62366) Fresh grapes improve the blood.
('13', 30, 2, 27, 62398) Orange, lemons and apples can be mixed with
('13', 31, 0, 1, 62442) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 31, 1, 2, 62483) bananas and eaten with rotlis.
('13', 31, 1, 3, 62514) The addition of olive oil to rotli does not impair its taste.
('13', 31, 1, 4, 62576) Such a diet costs very little trouble or money and does not require salt and chillies, milk or sugar.
('13', 31, 1, 5, 62678) Plain sugar is an absolutely useless article of food.
('13', 31, 1, 6, 62732) People who are very fond of sweets lose their teeth early and the sweet food does them no good in any way.
('13', 31, 1, 7, 62839) Wheat, almonds, peanuts, walnuts, fresh fruits—from every on of these a number of edible preparations can be made.
('13', 31, 1, 8, 62954) What we have now to consider is how much food to eat and when; this we shall do in the next chapter.

('13', 31, 4, 11, 63097) 23. LETTER TO JAMNADAS GANDHI
('13', 31, 5, 12, 63127) Phagan Vad 7 [March 29, 1913] 1
('13', 31, 6, 13, 63159) JAMNADAS,
('13', 31, 7, 14, 63169) I got your three letters together.
('13', 31, 7, 15, 63204) You want to have a letter every week but, since I do not have one from you so frequently, I do not know how I can meet your wishes.
('13', 31, 7, 16, 63336) However, I shall try to write oftener.
('13', 31, 7, 17, 63375) After the stipulated period of six months is over, you need not persist in saltless diet.
('13', 31, 7, 18, 63465) It is not intended that in clinging to it one should sacrifice one’s life.
('13', 31, 7, 19, 63540) We have adopted diet without salt and sugar in the belief that we should be healthier without them.

('13', 36, 1, 2, 72154) 25. LETTER TO MINISTER OF INTERIOR 1
('13', 36, 2, 3, 72191) [PHOENIX,] April 1, 1913
('13', 36, 3, 4, 72216) [TO THE MINISTER OF INTERIOR CAPE TOWN]
('13', 36, 4, 5, 72256) DEAR SIR,
('13', 36, 5, 6, 72266) Mr. Justice Searle’s decision 2 regarding the validity of Indian marriages and the statement said to have been made by the Immigration Officer in Natal, to the effect that no boys or girls claiming to be the children of resident Indians would be admitted unless they or their parents produce certificates of birth, have created great consternation among my countrymen.
('13', 36, 5, 7, 72635) And passive resisters have also felt compelled to examine their own position.
('13', 36, 5, 8, 72713) According to Justice Searle’s decision, no Indian marriage whether celebrated in South Africa or elsewhere can be recognized unless it is in accordance with the marriage laws of the Cape Province, i.e., every Indian marriage is invalid that is not registered before a Marriage Officer or celebrated according to the Christian rites.
('13', 36, 5, 9, 73046) This, in my humble opinion, is an intolerable position and disturbs rights hitherto exercised by Indians.
('13', 36, 5, 10, 73152) I need hardly draw the attention of the Hon’ble the Minister to the fact that marriages celebrated according to the Hindu, Mahomedan or Parsee rites are fully recognized in India by Indian law.
('13', 36, 5, 11, 73346) With reference to children, it is a well known fact that very few births are registered in India.
('13', 36, 5, 12, 73444) Registration of birth is not universally compulsory.
('13', 36, 5, 13, 73497) And it is practically impossible to produce certificates of birth except in rare cases.
('13', 36, 5, 14, 73585) The practical result of both the cases is almost completely to prevent the entry of wives and minor children of domiciled Indians.
('13', 36, 5, 15, 73716) In the circumstances, I venture to submit that, apart from other considerations, it is necessary in order to give full effect to the
('13', 36, 6, 16, 73849) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion, 7 6 1913, under the heading “Correspondence with Mr. Fischer”.
('13', 36, 6, 17, 73952) 2 Vide Appendix “Text of Searle’s Judgement”, 21 6 1913.
('13', 37, 0, 1, 74009) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 37, 1, 2, 74050) provisional settlement 1 to so frame the new Immigration Bill as to restore the position as to wives as it availed before Justice Searle’s decision and to revoke the instructions regarding children.
('13', 37, 1, 3, 74249) May I also suggest that it would be better if the leading members of the community were consulted regarding proof required by the Government as to marriages or the age or sonship of boys.
('13', 37, 1, 4, 74437) I am sure that the Indian community has every desire to co operate with the Government in facilitating the examination of relationships of wives and children so as to avoid fraud or deception.

('13', 37, 5, 10, 75282) A very old established section of the Cape population, and a large one in point of numbers, viz., the Cape Malay community, has always followed the Mahomedan faith and conducted its marriages according to the tenets of that religion; but such unions, unless solemnized by a Marriage Officer, are not recognized under the Marriage Order in Council or officially recorded in any way.
('13', 37, 5, 11, 75664) “You will note that the law does not demand that unions before Marriage Officers should be in accordance with Christian rites in order that they may be duly recognized as marriages.
('13', 37, 5, 12, 75846) The unions effected before such officers are by no means exclusively confined to persons holding the Christian faith.

('13', 40, 3, 10, 80905) 28. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XIV] 1
('13', 40, 4, 11, 80949) 6. HOW MUCH AND HOW OFTEN TO EAT
('13', 40, 5, 12, 80982) We have considered what the ideal diet should be.
('13', 40, 5, 13, 81032) It is necessary to inquire how much and how often to eat, and the topic calls for a separate article.
('13', 40, 5, 14, 81134) To some extent the two questions, “How much should one eat?” and “How often should one eat?” are interrelated.
('13', 40, 5, 15, 81245) I say “to some extent” because one cannot, and one should not, eat at a single meal the total quantity of food to be consumed in one day, so that “how much to eat” and “how often” are not so closely inter related.
('13', 40, 5, 16, 81459) Doctors differ widely on the question: how much one should eat.
('13', 40, 5, 17, 81523) “In plenty”, says one doctor, and he recommends different amounts of various foods according to their properties.
('13', 40, 5, 18, 81637) Another
('13', 40, 6, 19, 81645) 1 Articles in this series were later published as a book which was translated into Hindi and other Indian languages.
('13', 40, 6, 20, 81762) Based on the Hindi version was A Guide to Health, an English adaptation by A. Rama Iyer, published by S. Ganesan, Madras, in July 1921. The book was translated into several European languages.
('13', 40, 6, 21, 81955) In August December 1942, during his incarceration in the Agakhan Palace at Poona, Gandhiji wrote in Gujarati what became, in its English translation by Dr. Sushila Nayyar, Key to Health, published by Navajivan Publishing House, Ahmedabad, in 1948. While this book was not based on the series of articles published in Indian Opinion, according to Gandhiji, it did not fundamentally differ from them.
('13', 41, 0, 1, 82354) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 41, 1, 2, 82395) doctor says that physical and mental workers should eat different kinds and quantities of food.
('13', 41, 1, 3, 82491) A third opines that a labourer and a prince should eat the same quantity of food—that it is simply not true that a prince can make do with less but a labourer must have more.
('13', 41, 1, 4, 82666) Everyone knows that a weak man and a strong man need different quantitiesof food.
('13', 41, 1, 5, 82748) The diet of a man differs from that of a woman.
('13', 41, 1, 6, 82796) There is a difference in the quantities of food for adults and children, for the aged and the young.
('13', 41, 1, 7, 82897) Lastly, there is one writer who even states that, if the food is so thoroughly masticated that it turns into liquid and is swallowed with ease like saliva, we would find two to four ounces of food quite sufficient.
('13', 41, 1, 8, 83112) He has carried out thousands of experiments.
('13', 41, 1, 9, 83157) His book has been sold by the thousand and is widely read.
('13', 41, 1, 10, 83216) Such being the position, it is useless to recommend definite quantities of food; most doctors have said, however, that 99% eat more than they require.
('13', 41, 1, 11, 83367) Even otherwise, the thing is simple enough to be obvious to us all.
('13', 41, 1, 12, 83435) This being so, it is not necessary to prescribe a minimum diet for fear that people might eat loo little.
('13', 41, 1, 13, 83541) To tell the truth, what needs to be emphasized is that, while planning a diet, all of us should cut down on the quantity we consume.
('13', 41, 1, 14, 83674) As mentioned above, food should be thoroughly masticated.
('13', 41, 1, 15, 83732) By this means, we shall be able to extract the utmost nourishment from even a small quantity of food and gain in every way.
('13', 41, 1, 16, 83856) It has been shown that the faces of one who eats only as much as he can comfortably digest are small, well formed, darkish, sticky, dry and free from bad odour.
('13', 41, 1, 17, 84017) One whose faeces are not so formed must have eaten excessive and unsuitable food and failed to masticate it and mix it with the saliva in his mouth.
('13', 41, 1, 18, 84166) Thus, from the appearance of our faeces we can make out if we have eaten too much.
('13', 41, 1, 19, 84249) He whose tongue is coated on rising, who sleeps uneasily and dreams frequently, must have been eating too much.
('13', 41, 1, 20, 84361) One who has to get up often at night to pass urine must have taken too much liquid.
('13', 41, 1, 21, 84445) By such detailed observation, anyone can decide the quantity of food required by him.
('13', 41, 1, 22, 84531) Many people have offensive breath.
('13', 41, 1, 23, 84566) Clearly, they have not digested their food.
('13', 41, 1, 24, 84610) At times, those who over eat get boils and pimples on the face and in the nostrils.
('13', 41, 1, 25, 84694) But we do not take these affections seriously.
('13', 41, 1, 26, 84741) Some get continuous hiccups.
('13', 41, 1, 27, 84770) Others suffer from flatulence.
('13', 41, 1, 28, 84801) The simple meaning of all these ailments is that we have turned our stomach into a commode and that we carry this commode with us wherever we go.
('13', 41, 1, 29, 84947) If we could spare the time to think quietly about this matter, we would thoroughly despise our own habits.
('13', 41, 1, 30, 85054) We would definitely eat less and
('13', 42, 0, 1, 85087) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 43
('13', 42, 1, 2, 85133) put an end to dinners and feasts, would make it a rule never to attend or give community dinners.
('13', 42, 1, 3, 85231) Our hospitality would take an altogether different form, much to our own relief and that of the guest.
('13', 42, 1, 4, 85334) As for dinner parties, one would forget the very mention of them.
('13', 42, 1, 5, 85400) We do not invite people to join us when we clean our teeth or when we drink water.
('13', 42, 1, 6, 85483) Eating a meal is a similar bodily function.
('13', 42, 1, 7, 85527) Why do we go fussing all over in performing it?
('13', 42, 1, 8, 85575) Every time we have a guest, we must not make things unbearable both for him and us.
('13', 42, 1, 9, 85659) The explanation is that our palate has been spoilt through constant indulgence, so that we trump up one excuse after another for eating something.
('13', 42, 1, 10, 85806) We feed our guest sumptuously in the hope of being similarly treated at his house.
('13', 42, 1, 11, 85889) Actually, we seek such occasions so that we can have more opportunities of feasting on rich dishes.
('13', 42, 1, 12, 85989) If we asked someone with a whole some body to smell our mouth about an hour after we have indulged in such eating and heard his comments, we would certainly have cause to be ashamed of ourselves.
('13', 42, 1, 13, 86185) There are even some young gourmets who, in order to be able to enjoy eating, take fruit salt immediately after a meal or vomit out what they have already consumed and then fall to eating the sweets again.
('13', 42, 1, 14, 86390) To a greater or lesser extent, we all behave like this.
('13', 42, 1, 15, 86446) That is why our great men laid down for us certain religious observances like fasts, rozas 1, etc.
('13', 42, 1, 16, 86545) There are numerous fast days among Roman Catholics too.
('13', 42, 1, 17, 86601) There is nothing wrong whatever in anyone fasting completely or partially once in a fortnight purely for the sake of good health.
('13', 42, 1, 18, 86731) It will do him a world of good indeed.
('13', 42, 1, 19, 86770) The practice followed by many Hindus of eating only once a day during the chaturmas 2 is based on considerations of health.
('13', 42, 1, 20, 86894) When the air is humid and the day is overcast most of the time, the digestion becomes slack and one should, there fore, eat less at such times.
('13', 42, 1, 21, 87038) Let us now consider how often one should eat.
('13', 42, 1, 22, 87084) Most people in India eat only twice a day.
('13', 42, 1, 23, 87127) Those who eat thrice will be found to belong to the labouring classes.
('13', 42, 1, 24, 87198) People learnt eating four times only when they began to ape English ways.
('13', 42, 1, 25, 87272) Recently, certain societies have been formed in England and America.
('13', 42, 1, 26, 87341) Their function is to persuade the public to refrain from taking more than two meals a day.
('13', 42, 2, 27, 87432) 1 Fasts observed by Muslims from sunrise to sunset, during the month of Ramzan 2 The four monsoon months, from about mid July to mid November, during which pious Hindus observe partial fasts
('13', 43, 0, 1, 87623) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 43, 1, 2, 87664) advise us to go without breakfast.
('13', 43, 1, 3, 87699) The night’s sleep serves the purpose of food.
('13', 43, 1, 4, 87745) At daybreak, therefore, we are ready not for food but for work.
('13', 43, 1, 5, 87809) They believe that we are ready for food only after two or three hours of work.
('13', 43, 1, 6, 87888) These men, therefore, eat only twice a day and do not even drink tea, etc., between meals.
('13', 43, 1, 7, 87979) A well known doctor called Dewey has written a book on this subject in which he has described in a convincing manner the benefits accruing from fasting, cutting out breakfast, generally eating less, etc.
('13', 43, 1, 8, 88183) My own experience during the past eight years is that, after the period of youth is past, there is absolutely no need for anyone to eat more than twice a day.
('13', 43, 1, 9, 88342) Once a person’s body is fully grown and further development has stopped, he has no need to eat either much or often.

('13', 48, 1, 2, 95645) 34. LETTER TO E. F. C. LANE
('13', 48, 2, 3, 95673) PHOENIX, NATAL, April 9, 1913
('13', 48, 3, 4, 95703) DEAR MR. LANE,
('13', 48, 4, 5, 95718) The papers have given the information that General Smuts 1 will be in charge of the Immigration Bill whose text I have only just seen.
('13', 48, 4, 6, 95853) I enclose herewith copy of the telegram 2 I have addressed to the Government which will show General Smuts how seriously open to objection the Bill is, examined purely from the passive resistance standpoint.
('13', 48, 4, 7, 96061) You will see that my telegram covers practically the whole ground.
('13', 48, 4, 8, 96128) You may remember that some of these objections were discussed thoroughly, and General Smuts, so far as I am aware, promised to meet them all.
('13', 48, 4, 9, 96270) One thing has been omitted from the telegram.
('13', 48, 4, 10, 96316) In the correspondence between us of last year, I questioned whether declaration would be required from educated entrants under the Free State reservation clause.
('13', 48, 4, 11, 96478) If it be eligible, the clause will have to be altered so that, whilst the prohibition against the ownership of fixed property, farming, etc., continues, the declaration is dispensed with as regards those who enter under the proposed measure as immigrants into the Union.
('13', 48, 4, 12, 96749) The question about Indian marriages might conceivably be treated as a new point, but is it in reality?
('13', 48, 4, 13, 96852) I certainly never dreamt that Indian marriages that have been hitherto recognized by the Courts of Law in the Union were unlawfully recognized.
('13', 48, 4, 14, 96996) It cannot for a moment be denied that the Searle judgment shakes the existence of Indian society to its foundation.
('13', 48, 4, 15, 97112) Will you place this letter before General Smuts and, even if he is not to be in charge of this Bill, may I look to him for support?
('13', 48, 4, 16, 97244) I know he will accept my assurance that I am not itching for passive resistance, indeed, I was so sure of the Bill carrying out the provisional settlement both to the letter and in the spirit that I was preparing for a visit to India in June, but I fear that, if the objections are not met, a

('13', 51, 1, 2, 100131) 38. LETTER TO SECRETARY FOR INTERIOR
('13', 51, 2, 3, 100168) PHOENIX, April 11, 1913
('13', 51, 3, 4, 100192) TO THE SECRETARY FOR THE INTERIOR 1
('13', 51, 4, 5, 100228) CAPE TOWN
('13', 51, 6, 6, 100238) I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant.
('13', 51, 6, 7, 100318) I beg to thank the Minister for accepting the two names that were rejected from among the educated entrants for the past year.
('13', 51, 6, 8, 100445) It is not my intention that the names of entrants submitted by me in future should always.
('13', 51, 6, 9, 100536) be accepted.
('13', 51, 6, 10, 100549) But I do respectfully submit that the names of such entrants up to six for the Transvaal should be submitted by me in my representative capacity and that they should be accepted by the Government so long as the settlement remains in a provisional state.
('13', 51, 6, 11, 100803) As soon as it becomes final, as I hope it will be during the current session, no doubt, some arrangement, satisfactory alike to the Government and the Indian community will be made for the selection.
('13', 51, 6, 12, 101003) Personally, I think that the Government of India can have no voice in the selection for the simple reason that they cannot judge the wants of the local community.

('13', 53, 4, 5, 103814) 40. THE NEW BILL
('13', 53, 5, 6, 103831) The long promised Immigration Bill has at last seen the light of day.
('13', 53, 5, 7, 103901) We might say, at once, that it is disappointing, it is worse than its predecessor, and fails in material respects to give effect to the pro visional settlement.
('13', 53, 5, 8, 104062) Elsewhere will be found a detailed list of the points 1 in which it falls short of the settlement.
('13', 53, 5, 9, 104161) It is a pity that this is so.
('13', 53, 5, 10, 104191) The Government have so often declared their intention of carrying out the terms of the settlement that the Bill will come as a rude shock to those who have at all cared to follow that settlement.
('13', 53, 5, 11, 104387) The Bill confirms the suspicion that the Government only want to give us what they must, that they wish ill even to those who have established rights in the Union, and that, by hook or by crook, they desire to compass our ruin.
('13', 53, 5, 12, 104615) In carrying out this ruthless policy, they have gone as far as they dare in their precious Bill.
('13', 53, 5, 13, 104712) If it becomes law in its present form, it will whittle away some of our cherished and existing rights and make our position, insecure as it already is, doubly so.
('13', 53, 5, 14, 104875) The Bill plays with words regarding the Free State difficulty and is quite on a par with the Immigration Act of the Transvaal in unscrupulous subtlety.
('13', 53, 5, 15, 105027) The immigration law of the Transvaal, as we have pointed out so often, has created a legal racial bar without anyone, save those well versed in the Transvaal laws, knowing it.
('13', 53, 5, 16, 105203) So it seems to us, does this Bill create a legal racial bar without a superficial reader being able to detect it.
('13', 53, 5, 17, 105317) Unless the Government yield and amend the Bill materially, passive resistance must revive, and, with it, all the old miseries, sorrows and sufferings.
('13', 53, 5, 18, 105468) Homes, just re established, must be broken up.
('13', 53, 5, 19, 105515) Those passive resisters who have resumed their ordinary vocations, must exchange them for that of becoming once more His Majesty’s guests in his gaols in South Africa.
('13', 53, 5, 20, 105683) We do still hope that the Government will
('13', 53, 6, 21, 105725) 1 Vide “ Its Effect”, 12 4 1913.
('13', 54, 0, 1, 105758) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 55
('13', 54, 1, 2, 105804) see their way to grant relief.
('13', 54, 1, 3, 105835) But, if they do not, we must learn the lesson again of finding pleasure in pain.

('13', 54, 2, 5, 105942) 41. THE MARRIAGE IMBROGLIO
('13', 54, 3, 6, 105969) The letter on the marriage question from the Master of the Supreme Court, Natal Provincial Division, and Counsel’s opinion obt ained thereon, both of which will be found in another column, 1 show clearly what an important issue faces the Indian community.

('13', 54, 3, 8, 106434) This case shows, in a manner in which it could not be shown otherwise equ ally vividly, how absolutely necessary it is for the Indian community to secure an amendment of the law as to non Christian Indian mar riages.
('13', 54, 3, 9, 106651) Mr. Cachalia has received an apparently soothing reply from the Government on the resolutions of the recently held Johannesburg mass meeting.
('13', 54, 3, 10, 106793) The Government assure Mr. Cachalia and, through him, the community, that they do not intend to disturb the practice that has hitherto existed, in spite of the Searle judgment.
('13', 54, 3, 11, 106969) We accept the assurance but it is not worth much.
('13', 54, 3, 12, 107019) In vital matters, assurances which are in conflict with an actual legal position can afford little relief.
('13', 54, 3, 13, 107126) For the question is not, in the present case, that of introducing a few Indian wives into the Union per year, but it is one of determining the theoretical status of Indian women.
('13', 54, 3, 14, 107305) In plain language, the Searle judgment reduces their status from that of being honoured and honourable wives of their husbands to one of concubinage.
('13', 54, 3, 15, 107455) In the eye of the law, now Mrs. Cachalia, Mrs. Naidoo, Mrs. Cama and Mrs. Gandhi are concubines, and their offspring not honoured and beloved sons or daughters of their parents but illegitimate children.
('13', 54, 3, 16, 107659) What comfort can it be to these husbands that, though the law may consider their dear ones as the lepers of society, the Government will condescend not to do so?
('13', 54, 3, 17, 107821) So much for the sentiment of the matter, which, to us, is the reality.
('13', 54, 3, 18, 107892) It often happens that what hurts the sentiment also hurts the matter.
('13', 54, 3, 19, 107962) At any rate, such is the position in this
('13', 54, 4, 20, 108004) 1 These are not given here.

('13', 55, 1, 2, 108073) marriage question.
('13', 55, 1, 3, 108092) The Janubie case 1 illustrates our point.
('13', 55, 1, 4, 108134) The Government’s condescension is of no avail to the poor widow.
('13', 55, 1, 5, 108199) The Master of the Supreme Court has no discretion to do otherwise than carry out a law which he has to administer.
('13', 55, 1, 6, 108314) So long as the Searle judgment stands, he must treat Janubie, not as the widow of her husband but as a kept woman, and as such disentitled to remission of succession duty.
