('13', 55, 3, 12, 108966) 42. ITS EFFECT
('13', 55, 4, 13, 108981) The above Bill 2 fails to carry out the provisional settlement because it takes away, contrary to the settlement, existing rights, i.e.,
('13', 55, 5, 14, 109118) (1) Section 3 takes away the Court’s jurisdiction, hitherto exercised in terms of existing statutes now to be repealed.
('13', 55, 5, 15, 109238) (2) Clause (a) sub section l of Section 4 seems to take away rights acquired by educated Indians who may have entered the Cape or Natal by passing the education test.
('13', 55, 6, 16, 109405) (3) Sub section 3, Section 4 restricts rights possessed by the Natal and the Cape Indians to re enter at any port.
('13', 55, 7, 17, 109520) (4) Sub section (f), Section 5 deprives Natal Indians, not strictly domiciled, but of long residence therein of domiciliary rights hitherto possessed.
('13', 55, 7, 18, 109671) (This may turn thousands of Indians now resident in Natal into prohibited immigrants.)
('13', 55, 8, 19, 109758) (5) Proviso Section 5 very largely nullifies the legal effect of Transvaal registration certificates.
('13', 55, 8, 20, 109860) (These, in spite of treble registration, in most cases, cease, under the Bill, to constitute, in Lord Milner’s words, “an indefeasible title to residence in the Transvaal”; for three years’ absence from the Transvaal would, under the Bill,
('13', 55, 9, 21, 110100) 1 Vide “Janubie Case”, 12 4 1913. 2 The reference is to the Immigration Bill.
('13', 56, 0, 1, 110178) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 57
('13', 56, 1, 2, 110224) destroy the title to residence created by the certificates.
('13', 56, 2, 3, 110284) (6) The same proviso invalidates the Natal domicile certificates, after three years’ absence by the holders.
('13', 56, 3, 4, 110393) (7) The same proviso restricts the right of Cape or Transvaal Indians to enter Natal by passing the present education test of Natal, and of the Natal and the Transvaal Indians to enter the Cape by passing its education test.
('13', 56, 4, 5, 110618) (8) The same proviso takes away the right of South Africa born Indians to enter the Cape under its existing statute.
('13', 56, 5, 6, 110735) Further examined from the passive resistance standpoint only, the Bill is also defective in that:
('13', 56, 6, 7, 110833) (1) Sub clause (a) sub section I of Section 4 seems to contemplate the prohibition of the entry into the Free State of new immigrants who may pass the education test.
('13', 56, 7, 8, 111000) (2) Even if it does not prohibit such entry, the Bill seems to require a declaration from an educated immigrant which would not be required from any other immigrant as an immigrant.
('13', 56, 8, 9, 111182) (3) Sub clause (g) of Section 5 does not recognize the right of the wives and minor children of new immigrants to enter the Union with their husbands.
('13', 56, 9, 10, 111333) (4) And the Bill does not correct the defect, discovered by the Searle judgment, in the existing South African laws as to Indian marriages and minor children born of such marriages.
('13', 56, 10, 11, 111515) Indian Opinion, 12 4 1913
('13', 57, 0, 1, 111541) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 57, 1, 2, 111582) 43. THE NEW BILL AND THE OLD
('13', 57, 2, 3, 111611) There are many points of difference and of similarity between the above Bill and the abortive draft of 1912 1. The structure of the new Bill is very dissimilar to that of the 1912 measure.
('13', 57, 2, 4, 111800) Section 1 corresponds with sub sections 1 and 2 of Section 3 of the 1912 Bill, but sub section 3 of Section 3 is elaborated and extended, both as to scope and methods of administration, in the twelve sub sections of Section 2 of the new Bill, providing the machinery for appeals to Immigration Boards, which are to have, subject to instructions to be given them by the Minister pursuant to the general terms of the Bill, final jurisdiction except on questions of domicile, and Section 3, excluding the jurisdiction of the courts of law, except in matters of domicile, is entirely new.
('13', 57, 2, 5, 112385) Section 4 corresponds generally with Section 4 of the 1912 Bill, but it also includes the Provincial restrictions of Section 7 of the old Bill.
('13', 57, 2, 6, 112529) There are, however, two provisions which radically distinguish it from that measure.
('13', 57, 2, 7, 112614) First, there is the clause providing for exclusion, at the will of the Minister, upon economic grounds, and secondly, the education test is to be that of the existing Provincial statutes.
('13', 57, 2, 8, 112802) Sub sections 2 and 3 are new.
('13', 57, 2, 9, 112832) Sections 5 of the two Bills correspond, except that sub section (f) confines the exemption to persons domiciled in any Province, persons otherwise resident not being protected.
('13', 57, 2, 10, 113009) No provision is made for the recognition of non Christian Indian marriages or for the protection of the children of these marriages.
('13', 57, 2, 11, 113142) South Africa born Indians, who have today the right to proceed to the Cape Province unmolested, are deprived of that right by the first proviso of this section, whilst the second proviso enables the authorities to prevent the return to South Africa of any Indian who has been absent from the country for more than three years.
('13', 57, 2, 12, 113469) This proviso is new.
('13', 57, 2, 13, 113490) Sections 6 of each Bill, though differing considerably in language, have substan tially the same effect in each.
('13', 57, 2, 14, 113603) Section 7 corresponds substantially with sub section 2 of Section 28 of the 1912 Bill.
('13', 57, 2, 15, 113690) Sections 8, 9 and 10 of each substantially correspond.
('13', 57, 2, 16, 113745) Chapter III of the new Bill corresponds
('13', 57, 3, 17, 113785) 1 Vide “Extracts from Immigrants’ Restriction Bill (1912) and Orange Free State Constitution”, 3 2 1912.
('13', 58, 0, 1, 113890) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 59
('13', 58, 1, 2, 113936) in the main with Chapter II of the 1912 measure, and deals with the special powers for preventing the entry of and dealing with prohibited immigrants at the ports of entry.
('13', 58, 1, 3, 114109) Section 19 appears to be intended to cover the provisions of Sections 18 and 19 of the old Bill, but the new Bill provides that any person found within the Union is liable to an inquisition by the Immigration Officer, and may be, unless he satisfies the Immigration Officer that he is not a prohibited immigrant, dealt with as such, subject to his right of appeal to a Board.
('13', 58, 1, 4, 114485) Sub section 2 provides a new procedure not contemplated in the obsolete measure.
('13', 58, 1, 5, 114566) Section 20 of each Bill is the same.
('13', 58, 1, 6, 114603) Sections 21 and 22 of the new Bill, whilst including the same general provisions as those of the corresponding sections of the 1912 Bill, exempt from their operation persons born in South Africa.
('13', 58, 1, 7, 114799) Sub sections 1 and 2 of Section 23 of the new Bill correspond with the similar sub sections of the old measure.
('13', 58, 1, 8, 114911) Sub section 3 is new.
('13', 58, 1, 9, 114933) Section 24 is the same.
('13', 58, 1, 10, 114957) The first part of sub section 1 of Section 25, giving the Minister the power to exe mpt any person from the provisions of Section 4, is new.
('13', 58, 1, 11, 115098) Sub section 2 speaks of a “certificate of identity”, and not of a “permit”, as does the corresponding sub section of the 1912 Bill, and the period of its validity is not limited.
('13', 58, 1, 12, 115277) But this advantage is nullified by the second proviso of Section 5. Section 26 corresponds, generally, with Section 26 of the old Bill, and provides for the issue of regulations by the Governor General.
('13', 58, 1, 13, 115480) Section 27, providing for penalties, is the same.
('13', 58, 1, 14, 115530) Section 28 corresponds generally with sub section 1 of Section 28 of the old measure, save that any Asiatic not exempted from the pro visions of Section 4, all of whose tests he may have passed, is required to register under Act 36 of 1908. Section 29 corresponds with Section l of the 1912 Bill, and sets forth the measures to be repealed.
('13', 58, 1, 15, 115871) Section 30 is generally identical with Section 2 of the old measure.
('13', 58, 1, 16, 115940) Section 31 brings the Bill, if enacted, into force on July 1st next.

('13', 62, 4, 10, 122828) 47. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XV]
('13', 62, 5, 11, 122869) 7. EXERCISE
('13', 62, 6, 12, 122881) Exercise is just as essential to mankind as are air, water and food, though it is true that man cannot get on for a long time without air, water and food as he can without exercise.
('13', 62, 6, 13, 123063) It is a fact of common experience, however, that one cannot enjoy really good health without exercise.
('13', 62, 6, 14, 123166) We have to interpret exercise in the same way that we did “food”.
('13', 62, 6, 15, 123232) Exercise does not necessarily mean moidanda 1, football, cricket or going out for a walk.
('13', 62, 6, 16, 123322) Exercise means physical and mental activity.
('13', 62, 6, 17, 123367) Just as food is necessary for the mind as much as for bones and flesh, so also is exercise necessary both for body and mind.
('13', 62, 6, 18, 123492) If the body has no exercise, it is sickly and, if the mind has none, it is dull.
('13', 62, 6, 19, 123573) Stupidity should also be regarded only as a kind of illness.
('13', 62, 6, 20, 123634) It betrays sheer ignorance to describe as healthy a wrestler who, though adept at wrestling, is mentally a boor.
('13', 62, 6, 21, 123747) There is a saying in English that he alone is healthy who has a sound mind in a sound body.
('13', 62, 6, 22, 123839) What is this exercise?
('13', 62, 6, 23, 123862) Nature has so arranged things for us that we can be continuously taking exercise in one way or another.
('13', 62, 7, 24, 123966) 1 An Indian game

('13', 63, 1, 2, 124024) but think calmly enough, we shall see that a majority of people in the world live on agriculture.
('13', 63, 1, 3, 124122) All members in a farmer’s family have some form of exercise.
('13', 63, 1, 4, 124183) It is only if they work eight, ten or even more hours every day in the fields or elsewhere that they can get their daily bread.
('13', 63, 1, 5, 124311) They need no separate exercise for the mind.
('13', 63, 1, 6, 124356) A farmer cannot work without applying his mind.
('13', 63, 1, 7, 124404) He must be able to test the nature of his soil, must watch changes of weather, must know how to manipulate his plough skilfully and be generally familiar with the movements of the stars, the sun and the moon.
('13', 63, 1, 8, 124613) However clever a city dweller may be, every time he goes to a farmer’s house, he feels altogether out of his element.
('13', 63, 1, 9, 124731) The farmer can say how seed should be sown; he is familiar with all the by ways in the vicinity and knows all the men in the neighbourhood.
('13', 63, 1, 10, 124871) By looking at the stars he can judge the direction even at night.
('13', 63, 1, 11, 124937) He can make certain deductions from the voice and speed of birds ; for instance, when certain birds cluster or sing together, he sees in it a sign of the approach of the monsoon or some other similar phenomenon.
('13', 63, 1, 12, 125149) Thus, the farmer knows enough of astronomy, geography and geology to serve his needs.
('13', 63, 1, 13, 125235) He has to feed his children and has, therefore, some idea of the duties of man, and, residing as he does in the vast open spaces of this earth, he naturally becomes aware of the greatness of God.
('13', 63, 1, 14, 125431) Physically, it goes without saying, he is always sturdy.
('13', 63, 1, 15, 125488) He is his own physician, when ill.
('13', 63, 1, 16, 125523) Thus, we can see, he does have an educated mind.

('13', 63, 1, 22, 126312) Now, merchants and others certainly obtain mental exercise in the course of their work, but this is one sided.

('13', 64, 1, 3, 126709) In this type of work, the body does perform some movements now and then, but they are too slight to be of any account.
('13', 64, 1, 4, 126828) In the West, they have invented games like cricket for such people.

('13', 64, 1, 6, 127041) This is one method which we may consider.

('13', 67, 1, 2, 132689) 48. LETTER TO SECRETARY FOR INTERIOR 1
('13', 67, 2, 3, 132728) April 14, 1913
('13', 67, 3, 4, 132743) I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, in reply to my telegram 2 of the 2nd instant, regarding the recent judgment given by Mr. Justice Searle.
('13', 67, 3, 5, 132928) I am to submit that it had never, before the judgment of Mr. Justice Searle, become clear to the community that non Christian marriages not registered in South Africa would not be recognized by the South African Courts.
('13', 67, 3, 6, 133148) Mr. Justice Wessels’ judgment 3, delivered sometime ago, went perilously near such a pronouncement, but his judgment turned rather upon the legality or otherwise of bigamous marriages than upon the validity of marriages celebrated according to the rites of the various great Indian faiths.
('13', 67, 3, 7, 133438) As the Hon’ble the Minister will have noticed, Mr. Justice Searle’s decision was not based upon any precedent, but was an original pronouncement upon the Marriage Law, the case before him having been considered a test case.
('13', 67, 3, 8, 133662) Moreover, up to now, Hindu, Mahomedan and Parsee marriages have not been questioned, and the Masters of the several Divisions have recognized them.
('13', 67, 3, 9, 133810) But, since the judgment referred to, the Master of the Natal Provincial Division, my Association understands, has questioned the validity of a Mahomedan marriage in connection with the succession of the widow of a deceased Mahomedan to his estate.
('13', 67, 4, 10, 134058) My Association is grateful to the Government for giving the assurance that it is not their intention to apply the law in a harsh or arbitrary manner, but, in view of the judgment in question, I hope that the Government will understand the attitude of the community repres ented by the meeting in considering the assurance as not sufficiently meeting the requirements of the situation.
('13', 67, 4, 11, 134443) In the eye of the law now, Indian wives of non Christian persuasion are not wives but concu bines.
('13', 67, 4, 12, 134542) I feel sure that the Government will appreciate the position of
('13', 67, 5, 13, 134606) 1 This was signed by A. M. Cachalia.

('13', 68, 1, 3, 135167) My Association, therefore, ventures to hope that the Government will be graciously pleased to give due consideration to the feelings of the Indian community in the matter, and take the opportunity that the introduction of the new Immigration Bill offersto remedy the evil created by the unexpected judgment of Justice Searle.

('13', 71, 4, 4, 139839) I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, in reply to mine of the 1st instant, 1 on the question of Indian marriages.
('13', 71, 4, 5, 139996) With due deference to the Hon’ble the Minister of the Interior, it is respectfully submitted that the Searle judgment, if my reading of it is correct, lays down a definitely new principle.
('13', 71, 4, 6, 140185) Hitherto non Christian Indian marriages have been recognized both by the Immigration Department and the Master of the Supreme Court.
('13', 71, 4, 7, 140318) Issue of persons married according to the rites of their respective faiths, but not before Marriage Officers, have been hitherto accepted in intestate estates as lawful heirs.
('13', 71, 4, 8, 140494) But such issue could not, according to the Searle judg ment, be now so recognized.
('13', 71, 4, 9, 140577) The Master of the Supreme Court, Natal Provincial Division, has already, as will appear from the report enclosed herewith, raised the question.
('13', 71, 4, 10, 140721) I am aware that the marriages registered before Marriage Officers have not necessarily to be Christian marriages.
('13', 71, 4, 11, 140835) But the vast majority of non Christian Indian marriages have never taken place before Marriage Officers.
('13', 71, 4, 12, 140940) All these and the marriages celebrated and considered by the Indian law to be legal in India, of Indians lawfully resident in the Union, seem to be adversely affected by the Searle judgment.
('13', 71, 4, 13, 141131) I trust that the Government do not expect that these marriages should be solemnized or registered before Marriage Officers in the Union, in order that they might be accepted as valid in the eye of the law here.
('13', 71, 4, 14, 141342) I gratefully acknowledge the consideration that the Govern ment propose to show by directing Immigration Officers not to dis turb the existing practice.
('13', 71, 4, 15, 141495) But the relief that would be thus afforded would not sufficiently meet the case if only because no administrative

('13', 72, 1, 2, 141706) action can deal with the legal consequences that are sure to arise from the Searle judgment.
('13', 72, 1, 3, 141799) In my letter, I did not raise the question of plurality of wives.
('13', 72, 1, 4, 141865) That question does not affect vast issues as the one raised by the Searle judgment does.
('13', 72, 1, 5, 141954) But as your letter seems to imply that South African law does not recognize plurality of wives, I may be permitted to draw the Minister’s attention to Act 2 of 1907 (Natal) which countenances the practice among indentured Indians.
('13', 72, 1, 6, 142185) I refer to Sections 6 and 7 of the Act which I copy and enclose herewith for the information of the Minister.
('13', 72, 1, 7, 142295) In my humble opinion, the issue raised by the Searle judgment can be effectively dealt with only by amending the marriage laws of the Union so as to legalize marriages celebrated according to the rites 1
('13', 72, 2, 8, 142499) of non Christian religions and performed before non Christian priests.

('13', 74, 1, 2, 144514) 52. CONVERSATION WITH KASTURBA GANDHI 1
('13', 74, 2, 3, 144554) [Before April 19, 1913] 2
('13', 74, 3, 4, 144580) When Mrs. Gandhi understood the marriage difficulty, she was incensed and said to Mr. Gandhi: “Then I am not your wife according to the laws of this country.” Mr. Gandhi replied that that was so and added that their children were not their heirs.
('13', 74, 3, 5, 144827) “Then,” she said, “let us go to India.” Mr. Gandhi replied that that would be cowardly and that it would not solve the difficulty.
('13', 74, 3, 6, 144958) “Could I not, then, join the struggle and be imprisoned myself?” Mr. Gandhi told her she could but that it was not a small matter.
('13', 74, 3, 7, 145089) Her health was not good, she had not known that type of hardship and it would be disgraceful if, after her joining the struggle, she weakened.
('13', 74, 3, 8, 145232) But Mrs. Gandhi was not to be moved.
('13', 74, 3, 9, 145269) The other ladies, so closely related and living on the Settlement, would not be gainsaid.
('13', 74, 3, 10, 145359) They insisted that, apart from their own convictions, just as strong as Mrs. Gandhi’s, they could not possibly remain out and allow Mrs. Gandhi to go to gaol.
('13', 74, 3, 11, 145518) The proposal caused the gravest anxiety.
('13', 74, 3, 12, 145559) The step was momentous.
('13', 74, 4, 13, 145583) Indian Opinion, 1 10 1913

('13', 75, 1, 2, 145917) 53. THE IMMIGRATION BILL
('13', 75, 2, 3, 145942) This Bill will be read a second time on the 24th instant when we shall learn more about it than we do from merely reading it.
('13', 75, 2, 4, 146068) In order, however, to understand and appreciate its deadly effect on the Asiatic communities of South Africa, it is necessary to go back to what is somewhat ancient history.
('13', 75, 2, 5, 146242) Those who have felt interested in the Indian struggle in this land will recall how strenuously the Government tried, by giving a forced interpretation to Act 2 of 1907 and Act 36 of 1908, to prevent from entering or re entering the Transvaal a certain considerable class of minor children of lawfully resident Indians.
('13', 75, 2, 6, 146561) If they had succeeded in their attempt, a large portion of the resident Indian population of the Transvaal would have been obliged to leave the Transvaal and face ruin.
('13', 75, 2, 7, 146730) Happily, this attempt was frustrated by the public spirited action of the late Mr. Chhotabhai who, at great cost, took his son’s case to the Appellate Court and won it.
('13', 75, 2, 8, 146899) 1 Indians have, ever since, watched every new move of the Government with the greatest suspicion.
('13', 75, 2, 9, 146997) The most recent events have but confirmed the suspicion.
('13', 75, 2, 10, 147054) Their circulars about wives and children mark the second big attempt to reduce the number of resident population.
('13', 75, 2, 11, 147168) The Bill now before Parliament seeks legislative sanction for this policy.
('13', 75, 2, 12, 147243) And every one of its restrictive clauses has to be studied in the light of this bitter experience.
('13', 75, 2, 13, 147342) For it should be remembered that the Bill is not wanted for meeting any difficulty of European immigration.
('13', 75, 2, 14, 147450) It has been brought forward principally, if not solely, to satisfy the passive resisters and to carry out the compact entered into between the Imperial Government and the local Government about the Indian settlement.
('13', 75, 2, 15, 147667) And yet, instead of carrying out the spirit and the letter of it, and instead of liberalizing the existing laws where they tell harshly against the resident Asiatic population, the Bill represents a deliberate policy of ridding South Africa of its resident Asiatic population.
('13', 75, 2, 16, 147944) That is how General Botha’s statement that there was every desire, on the
('13', 75, 3, 17, 148018) 1 The court of trial had ruled that entry of his son’s name in his registration certificate did not entitle the former to register.
('13', 75, 3, 18, 148150) Vide “Letter to Members of Asiatic Conference”, before 18 11 1910; “Chhotabhai Case”, 26 11 1910; “Chhotabhai Case”, 28 1 1911 & “Chhotabhai Case”, 4 2 1911.

('13', 76, 3, 4, 148486) 54. LORD AMPTHILL’S COMMITTEE
('13', 76, 4, 5, 148516) The representation, made by Lord Ampthill’s 1 Committee, to the Secretary of State for the Colonies is a weighty and exhaustive document.
('13', 76, 4, 6, 148654) It enables one to study, in a connected and compact form, the march of events in South Africa regarding Indian matters.
('13', 76, 4, 7, 148774) The Committee has shown clearly how the cases cited by it evidence a policy, on the part of the Union Government, of exterminating the resident Indian population.
('13', 76, 4, 8, 148937) The administration of the immigration laws of South Africa makes Indian residence in it more and more difficult.
('13', 76, 4, 9, 149050) And the licensing law of Natal, at any rate, steps in where the immigration laws fail to compass our ruin.
('13', 76, 4, 10, 149157) The Committee’s letter will be a difficult document for the local Government to answer.There is one point made by the Committee which will come as a surprise both to the Imperial and the local Governments.
('13', 76, 4, 11, 149363) The latter have so often stated that South African law does not recognize polygamy.
('13', 76, 4, 12, 149447) But the Committee has been able to show that it has been recognized even as late as 1907 and that, too, by a statute.
('13', 76, 4, 13, 149565) Sections 6 and 7 of Act 2, 1907, of Natal provide: Sec.
('13', 76, 4, 14, 149621) 6. The provisions of Section 68 of the Indian Immigration Law, 1891, shall, as regards Indian immigrants arriving in the Colony after the commencement of this Act, apply to all marriages shown in the certified copies of their marriage register, notwithstanding that any such marriage may be a polygamous marriage.
('13', 76, 4, 15, 149935) 7. The Protector of Indian Immigrants may, on the applica tion of any Indian immigrants, men and women, who shall have

('13', 77, 1, 2, 150539) arrived in the Colony prior to the commencement of this Act, and who shall produce certified copies of their marriage registers, and shall show that they are the persons therein referred to, register such marri age, notwithstanding that any such marriage may have been a poly gamous marriage or that the man may have been married in this Colo ny under the provisions of the said law to any other Indian woman.
('13', 77, 1, 3, 150949) It is true that it was inconvenient for the then Government not to recognize polygamy, because indentured Indians were wanted by an influential class.
('13', 77, 1, 4, 151100) It is now inconvenient to recognize it for free Indian settlers because they are intruders.
('13', 77, 1, 5, 151192) It will be interesting to know how the local Government deal with the dilemma.

('13', 77, 3, 7, 151297) 55. NATAL INDIANS, BEWARE!
('13', 77, 4, 8, 151324) The Government Notice, published elsewhere, regarding the issue of certificates for the protection of those who may wish temporarily to absent themselves from the Province, is a veritable death trap into which we hope not a single Indian will be caught.
('13', 77, 4, 9, 151578) The Notice seeks to do what the Natal Immigration Act provides no warrant for.
('13', 77, 4, 10, 151657) It is a bare faced attempt to bring the Natal Law into harmony with the Cape Law, even in advance of the new Immigration Bill.
('13', 77, 4, 11, 151784) It will be seen from the Notice that an Indian who takes out the certificate provided for therein will have only one year in which to return if he wishes to escape the ordeal of a re examination.
('13', 77, 4, 12, 151980) This certificate carries with it a fee of £1 and, as the document has to be surrendered immediately after use, every absence from Natal means not only a fresh inquiry but a fresh imposition of £1. so that, if a businessman has to leave Natal, say, for the Cape four times a year and wishes to arm himself with these tickets of leave, he must pay £4 for them.
('13', 77, 4, 13, 152339) This is a monstrous impost.
('13', 77, 4, 14, 152367) And the method that has been devised to fine poor people is wicked.
('13', 77, 4, 15, 152435) It is the duty of Indians to send a strong protest against this latest attempt of the Government to harass us into leaving the country.
('13', 77, 5, 16, 152571) Indian Opinion, 19 4 1913
('13', 78, 0, 1, 152597) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 79
('13', 78, 1, 2, 152643) 56. SNARE
('13', 78, 2, 3, 152653) Like a hunter, the Union Government lays a number of snares for us.
('13', 78, 2, 4, 152721) Whichever of them catches us, the Government will have its prey.
('13', 78, 2, 5, 152786) On one side, there are rigorous restrictions on children, on the other, humiliation of women; thirdly, harassment about licences; fourthly, the new Bill; and now, for those in Natal, a net has been cast among the Indian people, with a bait that smells sweet but contains poison inside.
('13', 78, 2, 6, 153072) The number of fish that take in the bait will be so much of a gain to the Government.
('13', 78, 2, 7, 153158) According to a notice in theGazette of April 11, those who wish to leave Natal for temporary periods may, if they so desire, apply for such permits for absence.
('13', 78, 2, 8, 153319) It will be for the officer to decide whether or not to grant a permit.
('13', 78, 2, 9, 153390) Any Indian going out may have one on payment of £1 if he supplies the information required by the officer.
('13', 78, 2, 10, 153497) One of the conditions of the permit will be that the person concerned must return within one year.
('13', 78, 2, 11, 153596) If he does so, he will he allowed to disembark without going through an education test.
('13', 78, 2, 12, 153684) On the expiry of one year, the permit will lapse.
('13', 78, 2, 13, 153734) A permit that has been used once cannot be used again, but must be surrendered to the officer.
('13', 78, 2, 14, 153829) Here, a bait is held out that there will be no education test on return.
('13', 78, 2, 15, 153902) Before issuing a permit, however, they will have done enough to make the applicant gasp; what more can they put him to, within a year’s time?
('13', 78, 2, 16, 154044) Let us consider the consequences of applying for such a permit.
('13', 78, 2, 17, 154108) First, the applicant will have to pay, as it were, a fine of £1. He will have to pay this fine every time he leaves.
('13', 78, 2, 18, 154225) Secondly, the officer will put him to a test on every such occasion.
('13', 78, 2, 19, 154294) Thirdly, if a great many Indians take out these permits, the Government can argue that the provision for three years’ absence in the new Bill is a big concession.
('13', 78, 2, 20, 154457) What objection, besides, can be raised against the limit of one year?
('13', 78, 2, 21, 154527) As against these dangers, the advantages of not taking out such a permit are many.
('13', 78, 2, 22, 154610) Anyone who leaves may remain outside without the least anxiety and, on returning, re enter by furnishing the [required] evidence.
('13', 78, 2, 23, 154740) If he keeps the evidence ready before leaving, there will hardly be any difficulty.
('13', 78, 2, 24, 154824) Another important advantage is that a person not applying for a permit would have done no harm to the community.
('13', 78, 2, 25, 154937) We hope that not a single Indian will look at this permit.
('13', 79, 0, 1, 154996) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 79, 1, 2, 155037) We also hope that those who read this note will explain it carefully to others and advise them not to walk into the snare.
('13', 79, 1, 3, 155160) It is the duty of Durban leaders to protest against this notice without losing any time and to tell the Government in strong, clear terms that the community, instead of regarding this notice as having been issued for its benefit, thinks it injurious and insulting to them.
('13', 79, 2, 4, 155433) [From Gujarati]
('13', 79, 3, 5, 155449) Indian Opinion, 19 4 1913
('13', 79, 4, 6, 155475) 57. NEW BILL
('13', 79, 5, 7, 155488) We entreat every responsible Indian to give the most serious thought to the new Bill.
('13', 79, 5, 8, 155574) With great dexterity and malice, the Govern ment have tightened the screw on every section of Indians.
('13', 79, 5, 9, 155677) If the Bill is passed in its present form, it will be impossible for us to continue our residence in this country.
('13', 79, 5, 10, 155792) Indians long settled here live now with a certain sense of security; this Bill will shake them out of it.
('13', 79, 5, 11, 155898) The rich and the poor, the educated and the uneducated, those born here and those born outside—the Government have laid hands on all.
('13', 79, 5, 12, 156032) We know that the Government will even seek to delude us with sweet assurances that the law will not be enforced.
('13', 79, 5, 13, 156145) Should any Indian get into the Government’s clutches, he will have reason to be sorry afterwards.
('13', 79, 5, 14, 156243) This Bill and the Searle judgment will have the effect of depriving us of heirs though we have heirs living.
('13', 79, 5, 15, 156352) Our wives will come to be looked upon as concubines.
('13', 79, 5, 16, 156405) If we leave South Africa and remain absent for a period of three years or, leaving one province, live in another for the same period, we shall altogether lose the right of returning.
('13', 79, 5, 17, 156588) No matter what documents we may take with us regarding the business we have left behind, none of it will avail.
('13', 79, 5, 18, 156700) How long can we hold our own under such conditions?
('13', 79, 5, 19, 156752) Through this Bill, the ground is being prepared for our total undoing.
('13', 79, 5, 20, 156823) And yet, we are sorry to say, all South Africa, with the exception of Johannesburg, is slumbering.
('13', 79, 5, 21, 156922) We are persuaded that, even if a single Indian who understands things comes forward to work in each area, the whole of South Africa will be roused.
('13', 79, 5, 22, 157070) Our lethargy is bound to be our ruin.
('13', 79, 5, 23, 157108) It is the duty of every Indian who realizes this
('13', 80, 0, 1, 157157) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 81
('13', 80, 1, 2, 157203) to rouse himself and others from such lethargy.
('13', 80, 1, 3, 157251) If any of them, thinking that it is none of his concern, holds back, he too will go down along with the others.

('13', 80, 4, 6, 157405) 58. MRS.
('13', 80, 4, 7, 157414) PANKHURST’S SACRIFICE
('13', 80, 5, 8, 157436) All Indians are familiar with the celebrated Mrs. Pankhurst 1 who has been fighting for franchise for British women.
('13', 80, 5, 9, 157553) This lady has broken all bounds in fighting.
('13', 80, 5, 10, 157598) She advises women to plunder, to destroy.
('13', 80, 5, 11, 157640) We are against all these things, but about her courage, there is no doubt whatsoever.
('13', 80, 5, 12, 157726) She has money, and much ability; she has used these in the service of her chosen cause.
('13', 80, 5, 13, 157814) She is no longer young.
('13', 80, 5, 14, 157838) She had never before known suffering and has not been trained to bear it; still, she is ever in the front volunteering to suffer.
('13', 80, 5, 15, 157968) A short while ago, the house of Mr. Lloyd George, Finance Minister, was burnt down at Mrs. Pankhurst’s instigation.
('13', 80, 5, 16, 158084) She willingly took on herself the entire responsibility for this.
('13', 80, 5, 17, 158150) She was prosecuted and was sentenced to three years’ imprisonment.
('13', 80, 5, 18, 158217) Even in gaol, these ladies are bent on harassing the authorities and so getting themselves released.
('13', 80, 5, 19, 158318) Accordingly, tho ugh Mrs. Pankhurst was offered a variety of delicious dishes in gaol, she refused to touch them and fasted for eight days.
('13', 80, 5, 20, 158458) She was about to collapse, and was, therefore, released.
('13', 80, 5, 21, 158515) And now this brave lady is in hospital in a critical condition.
('13', 80, 5, 22, 158579) This kind of fighting is not satyagraha.
('13', 80, 5, 23, 158620) A satyagrahi’s object is to get into a prison and stay there.
('13', 80, 5, 24, 158682) He will not even dream of harming others.
('13', 80, 5, 25, 158724) If, however, we leave aside her mode of fighting and only think of the suffering she has borne, we shall find much to learn from her.
('13', 80, 5, 26, 158858) Despite numerous difficulties in their way, she and her companions do not yet feel dispirited, nor are they likely to do so.
('13', 80, 5, 27, 158983) They will struggle on till death.
('13', 80, 5, 28, 159017) Though a woman, Mrs. Pankhurst is as manly as any man.
('13', 80, 5, 29, 159072) Indians should emulate all this courage, for the British women being without the franchise is

('13', 81, 4, 5, 159377) 59. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XVI]
('13', 81, 5, 6, 159419) 8. ATTIRE
('13', 81, 6, 7, 159429) If health depends on diet, it is also affected to some extent by dress.
('13', 81, 6, 8, 159501) White women, for the sake of what they fancy to be beauty, dress so that their waist and feet should look narrow and fall victims to various ailments in consequence.
('13', 81, 6, 9, 159667) In China, women’s feet are kept so small that even our children’s feet are larger in comparison.
('13', 81, 6, 10, 159764) The practice does great harm to the health of Chinese women.
('13', 81, 6, 11, 159825) The reader will easily see from these two illustrations that what we wear does, in some measure, affect our health.
('13', 81, 6, 12, 159941) The choice of our costumes is not, however, in our own hands.
('13', 81, 6, 13, 160003) We dress the way our elders did and this seems the right thing to do in our present circumstances.
('13', 81, 6, 14, 160102) The real function of clothes has gone out of people’s minds and these have come to serve as symbols of our religion, country, community, etc.
('13', 81, 6, 15, 160244) Again, the costumes worn by the labourer and the office worker differ greatly from each other.
('13', 81, 6, 16, 160339) It is indeed difficult in these conditions to consider clothes from the point of view of health; it will be useful, though, to give this matter some thought.
('13', 81, 7, 17, 160497) The term attire should here be understood to include also shoes, ornaments, etc.
('13', 81, 8, 18, 160578) Let us first examine the basic purpose of clothes.
('13', 81, 8, 19, 160629) In the natural state man wears no clothes.
('13', 81, 8, 20, 160672) Men and women cover only their private parts, the rest of the body remaining bare.
('13', 81, 8, 21, 160755) This makes their skin tough and strong.
('13', 81, 8, 22, 160795) Such men and women find it easy to withstand the rigours of the open air.
('13', 81, 8, 23, 160869) They do not suddenly catch cold.
('13', 81, 8, 24, 160902) In the chapter on air, we saw that we breathe not only through the nose but also through the countless pores of the skin.
('13', 81, 8, 25, 161024) By covering ourselves with clothes, we obstruct this most important function of the skin.
('13', 81, 8, 26, 161114) In cold countries, man had to cover himself with more and more clothes as he grew

('13', 82, 1, 5, 161345) By and by, people came to look upon clothes as a mode of personal adornment, and, ultimately, costumes came to be a means of identifying one’s community, etc.
('13', 82, 1, 6, 161504) In fact, Nature has provided man with the best dress in his skin.

('13', 84, 6, 7, 166457) DEAR MR. GOKHALE,

('13', 88, 1, 2, 172057) 63. £3 TAX DISAPPOINTMENT
('13', 88, 2, 3, 172083) We learn from an authoritative source that, owing to the exigen cies of the political situation, the Government do not intend to intro duce this session a Bill to repeal the £3 tax required, under Act 17 of 1895, of ex indentured Indians who remain free in Natal at the expiry of their contracts.
('13', 88, 2, 4, 172380) The news will come as a shock and a bitter disap pointment not only to those immediately affected, but to the entire Indian community, who rightly regard the impost as a tax upon its honour and social integrity.
('13', 88, 2, 5, 172592) BecauseGeneral Botha 1 and General Hert zog 2 are engaged in a party quarrel, the business of the whole country must come to a standstill.
('13', 88, 2, 6, 172731) General Botha has adopted the attitude that he is fighting his opponent in the interests of the Empire.
('13', 88, 2, 7, 172835) He does not seem to realize the inconsistency of that attitude with his inability to keep his unwritten pledge to the Hon.
('13', 88, 2, 8, 172958) Mr. Gokhale to repeal this tax at an early date.
('13', 88, 2, 9, 173007) It is an open secret that the only reason why no public announcement of the intentions of the Government was made during Mr. Gokhale’s visit was because Ministers desired, before definitely committing themselves, to ascertain the feeling of the Natal members.
('13', 88, 2, 10, 173267) The views of most of these, as is now well known from General Smuts’ statement in the House on the Financial Relations Bill, are against the retention of the tax as inequitable and there is, therefore, no valid excuse for the dilatory tactics of the Government beyond a cowardly fear to arouse further antagonism from the Free State reactionaries, who are in no way interested in the question beyond their notorious obsession by [sic] anti colour mania.
('13', 88, 2, 11, 173721) We have no doubt that Mr. Gokhale, who is now on his way to England, will have certain home truths to speak to His Majesty’s Ministers at the gross manner of the betrayal of his own and the Indian community’s hopes.
('13', 88, 2, 12, 173937) The least the Government can do, to save their face, is to give instructions that the tax and its arrears are not to be demanded, pen ding the passing of the necessary repealing legislation next session.
('13', 88, 3, 13, 174141) Indian Opinion, 26 4 1913
('13', 88, 4, 14, 174167) 1 Louis Botha (1862 1919); Boer General and statesman; Prime Minister of the Transvaal, 1907, and of South Africa Union, 1910 19 2 James Barry Munnik Hertzog (1866 1942); South African nationalist leader and politician; Prime Minister of South Africa Union, 1924 39
('13', 89, 0, 1, 174433) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 89, 1, 2, 174474) 64. THAT BILL
('13', 89, 2, 3, 174488) The Immigrants’ Restriction Bill is apparently meeting with all round opposition.
('13', 89, 2, 4, 174570) The scathing criticism of the Natal Witness on the withdrawal of the right of access to the Supreme Court, except in certain rare cases, is highly appropriate.
('13', 89, 2, 5, 174730) It is not the autocracy of little “tin tsars” that the officials now demand.
('13', 89, 2, 6, 174807) The people of South Africa are now called upon to hand over their liberties into the keeping of an infallible bureaucracy that is afraid to face the criticism and the scepticism of His Majesty’s judges.
('13', 89, 2, 7, 175010) We do not need to emphasize the glaring audacity of the Government’s attempt to impose upon the public—or, rather, the Indian public—Immigration Boards whose decisions are to be unappealable, when there is almost daily record of the havoc wrought to Indian interests by the existing Licensing Boards of Natal and the Cape.
('13', 89, 2, 8, 175333) We are rapidly reaching, in South Africa, that Government by bureaucracy against which Sir James Rose Innes recently inveighed so strongly, and it is difficult to believe that people with such splendid traditions of liberty and freedom as the South African Colonists can boast will be content to deliver to a close corporation of unchecked permanent officials the control of their movements into and within the Union.
('13', 89, 3, 9, 175751) Indian Opinion, 26 4 1913
('13', 90, 0, 1, 175777) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 91
('13', 90, 1, 2, 175823) 65. NEW BILL
('13', 90, 2, 3, 175836) Perhaps, as we write this note, further news of the Bill is already available.
('13', 90, 2, 4, 175915) At the moment, it seems quite possible that the Bill may fail for reasons not connected with our struggle.
('13', 90, 2, 5, 176022) There is a split in General Botha’s camp.
('13', 90, 2, 6, 176064) The supporters of General Hertzog have shown their teeth.
('13', 90, 2, 7, 176122) They came together at a meeting in Bloemfontein and passed a resolution supporting General Hertzog, so that there is little possibility now of the Orange members supporting General Botha.
('13', 90, 2, 8, 176310) Even in the Cape, General Hertzog has some members to help him.
('13', 90, 2, 9, 176374) Likewise, there may be a few here and there in the Transvaal too.
('13', 90, 2, 10, 176440) It does not, therefore, appear that General Botha will be able to continue in power with the support only of his own party.
('13', 90, 2, 11, 176564) If he seeks the support of the Unionist Party, not only will it be a humiliation to him, but General Hertzog will grow stronger still, and General Botha will be left with very few supporters among the Boers.
('13', 90, 2, 12, 176772) Many believe that, in this difficult situation, he may not be able to retain the reins of power in his hands.
('13', 90, 2, 13, 176882) If this view is correct, there are two possible consequences; one, that General Botha may dissolve the Parliament and order fresh elections, so that a new Parliament will come into being; alternatively, he may accept all the demands of General Hertzog’s supporters.
('13', 90, 2, 14, 177148) In either case, there is little chance of this Parliament being able to do much.
('13', 90, 2, 15, 177229) The papers also report that General Hertzog’s supporters have raised two issues, first, that Mr. Sauer 1, who has always been known as a friend of the Zulus and who champions their cause, has been appointed by General Botha as Minister for Zulu Affairs, and secondly, that he has decided to grant relief to the Indians out of deference to the Imperial Government.
('13', 90, 2, 16, 177593) Thus, we have also become a cause of friction among them.
('13', 90, 2, 17, 177651) This is, however, nothing for us to be happy about, for these two reasons just happen to have come in handy.
('13', 90, 2, 18, 177760) The unthinking Boers are likely to be taken in by them, for there is an element of truth in both of them, which, however, will do good neither to the Zulus nor to us.
('13', 90, 2, 19, 177927) Mr. Sauer, as Minister, is not
('13', 90, 3, 20, 177958) 1 J. W. Sauer, Member of the Union Cabinet, a philanthropist and radical who refused knighthood.
('13', 91, 0, 1, 178055) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 91, 1, 2, 178096) going to present the Zulus with cart loads of wealth nor General Botha to gift away a kingdom to us in order to oblige the Imperial Government.
('13', 91, 1, 3, 178240) We have seen what it is that he is prepared to give.
('13', 91, 1, 4, 178293) But the fine words to which General Botha treated the Imperial Govern ment in our case are being deliberately used against him by General Hertzog’s supporters.
('13', 91, 1, 5, 178453) We can, therefore, hope for no advantage to us from all this.
('13', 91, 1, 6, 178515) Even if General Hertzog comes to power, we shall secure neither more nor less than what we can by our own strength.

('13', 91, 3, 9, 178761) Indian Opinion, 26 4 1913
('13', 91, 4, 10, 178787) 66. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XVII]
('13', 91, 5, 11, 178830) 9. AN INTIMATE CHAPTER
('13', 91, 6, 12, 178853) Those who have carefully followed the chapters on health so far should read this, I submit, with especial care and ponder well over it.
('13', 91, 6, 13, 178989) Other chapters are still to follow and will, I feel, prove useful, but there will be none in the series as important as the present one.
('13', 91, 6, 14, 179126) As I indicated earlier I have in these chapters said nothing on which I have had no personal experience or of which I was not firmly convinced.
('13', 91, 7, 15, 179270) There are many things which promote good health, all of them necessary, but the most important is brahmacharya 1. We can have good health by means of good air, water and food; but, if we spend all that we earn, we shall be left with nothing on hand.
('13', 91, 7, 16, 179520) Similarly, if we fritter away the health which we gain, what remains ofour capital behind?
('13', 91, 7, 17, 179611) For both men and women, therefore, brahmacharya is an absolute necessity if they are to preserve the wealth of physical well being; no one need doubt this.
('13', 91, 7, 18, 179767) He who has conserved his generative fluid is known as viryavan, a man of strength.
('13', 91, 8, 19, 179850) 1 Literally living in the Brahman, the Absolute.
('13', 91, 8, 20, 179899) In ordinary usage the term has come to signify celibacy, which is considered essential for attainment of that state.
('13', 92, 0, 1, 180016) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 93
('13', 92, 1, 2, 180062) What is brahmacharya?—it may be asked.
('13', 92, 1, 3, 180101) It consists in men and women refraining from carnal enjoyment.
('13', 92, 1, 4, 180164) “Refraining from carnal enjoyment” does not mean merely refraining from contact with each other with such enjoyment in view, but also keeping the mind free from the very thought of it—one must not even dream about it.
('13', 92, 1, 5, 180382) Man should not be disturbed by the presence of woman and woman by the presence of man.
('13', 92, 1, 6, 180469) We should hold back and store within our bodies the mysterious power that Nature has bestowed upon us and use it to promote our health, the health not only of the body but also of the mind, the intellect and the memory.
('13', 92, 1, 7, 180689) Let us now take a look at the strange things that go on around us.
('13', 92, 1, 8, 180756) Most men and women, whether young or old, are submerged in this infatuation.
('13', 92, 1, 9, 180833) On such occasions we go utterly mad.
('13', 92, 1, 10, 180870) Our reason ceases to function, a veil seems to come over our eyes and we are blinded with passion.
('13', 92, 1, 11, 180969) I have observed men, women and young people of both sexes looking distraught when possessed by passion.
('13', 92, 1, 12, 181073) My personal experience is no different.
('13', 92, 1, 13, 181113) Whenever I have been overcome by this state, I have lost all sense.
('13', 92, 1, 14, 181181) Such is the nature of passion.
('13', 92, 1, 15, 181212) Thus, for the sake of a grain of pleasure 1, we lose a maund of vitality.
('13', 92, 1, 16, 181286) When our excitement dies down, we find ourselves in a pitiable state.
('13', 92, 1, 17, 181356) The following morning our body is heavy, we are ill at ease, and a lethargy sets in.
('13', 92, 1, 18, 181441) Our mind is out of sorts.
('13', 92, 1, 19, 181467) In order to set these things right again, or keep them right, we must needs drink milk boiled with spi ces, swallow iron, take yakutis 2, approach vaidyas for strength giving drugs and look around for foods that will serve as aphrodisiacs.
('13', 92, 1, 20, 181707) Thus, as the days and years go by, we decline in body and mind and find our intellect gone in old age.
('13', 92, 1, 21, 181810) This, surely, should not be—in old age, the intellect should grow sharper rather than duller.
('13', 92, 1, 22, 181904) We should be in such condition that the experience gained during a life time can be of use to us and to others, a condition possible to those who observe brahmacharya.
('13', 92, 1, 23, 182072) Such a person is unafraid of death and does not forget God evenat the moment of death.
('13', 92, 1, 24, 182159) He does not indulge in vain attempts and does not
('13', 92, 2, 25, 182209) 1 The original has a pun on the Sanskrit word rati which means pleasure and, also, a measure of weight.
('13', 92, 2, 26, 182313) 2 Tonic preparations of the Unani system of medicine
('13', 93, 0, 1, 182366) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 93, 1, 2, 182407) behave like a dandy.
('13', 93, 1, 3, 182428) He who gives up this frame with a smiling face and goes to render his account to the Master is truly a man and she who dies thus is truly a woman.
('13', 93, 1, 4, 182575) Such persons alone may claim to have maintained true health.
('13', 93, 2, 5, 182636) We do not, as a rule, stop to consider that the basic cause of pleasure hunting, envy, ostentation, hypocrisy, anger, impatience, violent hatred and such other evils is our violation of brahmacharya.
('13', 93, 2, 6, 182836) If one’s mind is not under one’s control and one behaves more foolishly even than a child, indulging oneself once every day or oftener, what other crimes would not one commit, knowingly or unknowingly?
('13', 93, 2, 7, 183038) What unforgivable sins would one stop short of?
('13', 93, 3, 8, 183086) But does one ever find anyone observing such brahmacharya?
('13', 93, 3, 9, 183145) If everyone did so, the world would come to an end.
('13', 93, 3, 10, 183197) [So runs the argument.] This is likely to involve a discussion of religious issues.
('13', 93, 3, 11, 183281) I shall, therefore, pass over that aspect of the matter and consider it from a worldly point of view.
('13', 93, 3, 12, 183383) In my opinion, both these questions have their origin in our fear and weakness.
('13', 93, 3, 13, 183463) We do not want to observe brahmacharya and, therefore, seek excuses to escape from it.
('13', 93, 3, 14, 183550) There do exist people, and in large numbers, who observe it; if, however, they were easy to discover, what would be their worth?
('13', 93, 3, 15, 183679) Thousands of labourers are imprisoned in the bowels of the earth in order that diamonds might be obtained and, even then, only a handful of these are found in a mountain of broken earth and rock.
('13', 93, 3, 16, 183875) What efforts, then, would be necessary to discover the jewels among men who observe brahmacharya?
('13', 93, 3, 17, 183973) Let us do a simple sum in the rule of three to calculate.
('13', 93, 3, 18, 184031) If the world comes to an end because we observe brahmacharya, how is that any concern of ours?
('13', 93, 3, 19, 184126) We are not God.
('13', 93, 3, 20, 184142) He who has created the world will look after His affairs.
('13', 93, 3, 21, 184200) Whether others observe it or not is not a question for us to ask.
('13', 93, 3, 22, 184266) When we select business or law or anything else as a career, we do not ask what would happen if everyone became a lawyer or business man.
('13', 93, 3, 23, 184404) Finally, those men and women who observe brahmacharya will, in the course of time, receive answers to both the questions, that is, they will find others like themselves.
('13', 93, 3, 24, 184574) And it will also be as plain as daylight to them what will happen to the world if all did the same.
('13', 93, 4, 25, 184674) How can these ideas be put into practice by men caught up in
('13', 94, 0, 1, 184735) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 95
('13', 94, 1, 2, 184781) worldly responsibilities?
('13', 94, 1, 3, 184807) What should the married ones do?
('13', 94, 1, 4, 184840) And those who have children?
('13', 94, 1, 5, 184869) What should they do who cannot control their desire?
('13', 94, 1, 6, 184922) We have seen what the ideal is.
('13', 94, 1, 7, 184954) If we always hold it before us, we shall either be able to follow it faithfully or approximate to it in some measure.
('13', 94, 1, 8, 185072) If we place before a child the finest models when teaching it to write the letters of the alphabet, it will copy them to the best of its ability.
('13', 94, 1, 9, 185218) Similarly, we can place before us the ideal of un broken brahmacharya, and then make every effort to approximate to it.
('13', 94, 1, 10, 185338) What if we happen to be married?
('13', 94, 1, 11, 185371) The natural law is that men and women should depart from brahmacharya only when they desire progeny.
('13', 94, 1, 12, 185472) If a couple do so after full deliberation, once in a few years, they will not wholly forget themselves and will remain well stored with vitality.
('13', 94, 1, 13, 185618) Rarely do we come across couples who indulge in sexual intercourse only for the purpose of procreation.
('13', 94, 1, 14, 185722) The rest in their thousands seek the pleasures of lust, yearn for them and indulge in them.
('13', 94, 1, 15, 185814) The consequence is that, against their wish, children are born to them.
('13', 94, 1, 16, 185886) In enjoying these pleasures, we become so utterly blind that we have no consideration for our partner.
('13', 94, 1, 17, 185989) In this matter men are more guilty than women.
('13', 94, 1, 18, 186036) In his stupidity man gives no thought to the woman’s weakness; he does not stop to consider whether she is strong enough for the burden of bearing children and bringing them up.
('13', 94, 1, 19, 186214) People of the West have broken all bounds in this matter.
('13', 94, 1, 20, 186272) They adopt various techniques so that they may have their pleasure without being burdened with children.
('13', 94, 1, 21, 186377) Books have been written on these techniques and there are professionals who explain how to indulge in the pleasures of lust and yet have no children!
('13', 94, 1, 22, 186527) So far at least we have been free from this sin; but we do not think for a moment before imposing burdens on our women and we do not care if our children are weak, lacking in vitality, timid and dull of intellect.
('13', 94, 1, 23, 186741) Whenever a child is born, we offer thanks to God.
('13', 94, 1, 24, 186791) This is only a way of covering up our pitiable condition.
('13', 94, 1, 25, 186849) Why should we not regard it a sign of divine anger that we have weak, crippled, lustful and worthless children born to us?
('13', 94, 1, 26, 186972) What reason for satisfaction can there be over a child of twelve having issue?
('13', 94, 1, 27, 187051) Why should this be an occasion for merry making?
('13', 94, 1, 28, 187100) Why should we not regard it as a manifestation of divine wrath that a girl of twelve should become a mother?
('13', 94, 1, 29, 187209) We know that, if a tree bears fruit too soon after it has been planted, the latter is immature and we take good care
('13', 95, 0, 1, 187326) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 95, 1, 2, 187367) to see that fruit does not appear too early on a tree.
('13', 95, 1, 3, 187422) When, on the contrary, we have a celebration on the birth of a child to a child wife by a child hus band, surely we behave with incredible blindness.
('13', 95, 1, 4, 187572) Of what good is it to India or the world to be swarmed over with worthless creatures, as with ants?
('13', 95, 1, 5, 187672) Animals are better off than we are inasmuch as the male and the female are brought together only when we intend them to have progeny.
('13', 95, 1, 6, 187806) Subsequent to the union, the period of pregnancy and the period between the birth and the weaning of the child, when it can fend for itself, should be looked upon as sacred and during this time at least the husband and wife should scrupulously observe brahma charya.
('13', 95, 1, 7, 188073) But we give no thought whatever to the matter and continue to take our pleasures recklessly.
('13', 95, 1, 8, 188166) Such is the sickness of our minds—a good example of incurable sickness.
('13', 95, 1, 9, 188238) It is a disease which brings us to death, and until that time we wander about like insane men.
('13', 95, 1, 10, 188333) It is the especial duty of married couples that they should not mistake the purpose of marriage, but should understand it aright and come together only while they have no child and desire an heir.
('13', 95, 2, 11, 188530) In our present pitiful condition, this is extremely difficult.
('13', 95, 2, 12, 188593) Our diet, our way of life; our talk, the sights which surround us, are all such as to excite our lust.
('13', 95, 2, 13, 188696) Sexual pleasure, moreover, has become a craving with us, much like opium.
('13', 95, 2, 14, 188770) Is it likely that in such a state we would take thought and turn back?
('13', 95, 2, 15, 188841) But to any sceptic who wants to know how the ideal can be practised, there is no answer in this chapter.
('13', 95, 2, 16, 188946) It is intended for those who are ready to think and make an effort to do what ought to be done.
('13', 95, 2, 17, 189042) Those who are satisfied with themselves will find it boring even to read these things; the chapter is intended, rather, to help those who have realized their abject state and are tired of it to some extent.
('13', 95, 3, 18, 189249) We can see from the foregoing that those who have not married should not do so in these difficult times and that, if one cannot do altogether without marriage, one should marry late.
('13', 95, 3, 19, 189432) Young men should take a vow not to marry before they are twenty five or thirty years of age.
('13', 95, 3, 20, 189525) This is not the place to consider the other benefits which, apart from good health, may follow from this course; everyone, however, will know how to gain such benefits for himself.
('13', 96, 0, 1, 189706) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 97
('13', 96, 1, 2, 189752) To parents who may read this chapter, we must say that they are guilty of cruelty in selling away their sons and daughters by marriage or betrothal while they are still children; in doing so, they regard their own interests instead of those of the children.
('13', 96, 1, 3, 190010) They want to feel important and have a name in the community, want to have a big show by celebrating their children’s marriage.
('13', 96, 1, 4, 190138) If they desired the welfare of their children, they would look after their education, care for them and train their bodies.
('13', 96, 1, 5, 190262) What can be more harmful to the interests of boys and girls today than that they should be married off while they are still children?
('13', 96, 1, 6, 190396) Lastly, when a married man or woman is separated from his or her partner by death, it will benefit the survivor’s health to lead the life appropriate to a widower or widow.
('13', 96, 1, 7, 190569) Some doctors have expressed the opinion that young men and women must have opportunities for sexual relief.
('13', 96, 1, 8, 190677) There are also some others who argue that this is not necessary in any circumstances.
('13', 96, 1, 9, 190763) When doctors thus quarrel among themselves, we should take care not to be misled by any of them and sink in self indulgence in the belief that we have their support.
('13', 96, 1, 10, 190929) From my own experience and that of others which I have come to know of, I can affirm without the least hesitation that it is unnecessary to indulge in sexual relations for the sake of health; on the contrary; such indulgence and the resultant loss do much physical harm.
('13', 96, 1, 11, 191200) The vitality of both mind and body developed through many years is so much impaired even by one such occasion that it takes a long time to regain it and, even so, the original state is never restored wholly.
('13', 96, 1, 12, 191408) One may make use of a broken glass by re joining the fragments, but it will always remain a broken thing.
('13', 96, 1, 13, 191514) In order to conserve virility, fresh air and water, wholesome food as described earlier, and pure thought are indispensable.
('13', 96, 1, 14, 191639) In this way morals are closely linked with health.
('13', 96, 1, 15, 191690) A perfectly moral person alone can achieve perfect health.
('13', 96, 1, 16, 191749) Anyone who, prepared to make a fresh start from the moment that he sees the light, meditates carefully over what has been said so far and puts these suggestions into practice will have direct proof in experience.
('13', 96, 1, 17, 191962) Even one who has observed brahmacharya for some period will notice the increase of mental and physical powers and, having once secured this philosopher’s stone, will guard it with care like very life.

('13', 97, 1, 3, 192271) I have committed mistakes even after I had thought over—experienced—the countless benefits of brahmacharya and I have known the bitter consequences.
('13', 97, 1, 4, 192420) I have vivid memories of the exalted state of the mind before a lapse and the pitiable condition after it.

('13', 97, 1, 10, 192951) If anyone learns from my mistakes and my experience and saves himself, I shall be happy to have written this chapter.
('13', 97, 1, 11, 193069) The following calculation is also worth making.
('13', 97, 1, 12, 193117) Many people have said, and I believe it, that I have plenty of energy.
('13', 97, 1, 13, 193188) My mind is not considered weak—as a matter of fact—some think me obstinate.

('13', 97, 1, 16, 193596) I am sure, myself, that there would have been no limit to my energy and I would have had so much of it to spend on service to the public or myself that others would have found it an ordeal to equal it.
('13', 97, 1, 17, 193798) This is the conclusion to be drawn from my all too imperfect example.
('13', 97, 1, 18, 193868) The physical, mental and moral strength of one who has been able to observe unbroken brahmacharya must be seen to be believed; it cannot be described.
('13', 97, 1, 19, 194019) Anyone reading this chapter will see that, when married persons have been advised to observe brahmacharya and widowers to continue in that state, there can be no question of any men or women, married or unmarried, being permitted to gratify their desire anywhere.

('13', 98, 1, 3, 194899) Where there is no adultery, fifty per cent.

('13', 99, 1, 2, 196606) 67. NOTE TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('13', 99, 2, 3, 196637) [P.O. BOX 2493] JOHANNESBURG, April 26, 1913
('13', 99, 3, 4, 196682) 1. The architect business should be wound up with the least possible delay at the most in 3 months; the decision should be announced at once.
('13', 99, 3, 5, 196824) 2. The Mountain View property should be sold without reserve within 3 months.
('13', 99, 3, 6, 196902) 3. Tolstoy Farm should be kept practically at any cost.
('13', 99, 3, 7, 196958) 4. The African Building should be the primary occupation.
('13', 99, 4, 8, 197016) ON PROP.
('13', 99, 5, 9, 197025) You are not a competent architect.
('13', 99, 5, 10, 197060) Study seems to be almost impossible but even if it were practicable, it is not desirable or profitable.
('13', 99, 5, 11, 197164) The beer hall business is the best warning that you must subordinate your conscientious scruples to your business.
('13', 99, 5, 12, 197279) Its continuation means a loss of moral fibre and a reluctant fawning upon people whom you would rather keep at a distance.
('13', 99, 5, 13, 197402) And after all the fawning and all the abandoning of principles, it is a question whether the business has any money in it.
('13', 99, 5, 14, 197525) And the business ties you down as nothing else can if you are really to nurse it and give satisfaction to your clients.
('13', 99, 6, 15, 197645) ON PROP.
('13', 99, 7, 16, 197654) Mountain View is a veritable Devil’s temptation.
('13', 99, 7, 17, 197703) It simply absorbs money and energy without any certain prospect of preventing a loss.
('13', 99, 7, 18, 197789) It is better to lose even £1000 or more than to sink more money and risk losing even that.
('13', 99, 7, 19, 197880) A wise and cautious man will never fear to abandon a proposition which was wrong in the beginning.
('13', 99, 7, 20, 197979) Your action just now is like that of a man [who] fearing to let his rotten shares go, buys in attractive looking ones to recoup himself for the loss on the rotten ones forgetting all the while that the others may prove just as bad.
('13', 99, 7, 21, 198211) The Mountain View proposition is decidedly a
('13', 100, 0, 1, 198256) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 101
('13', 100, 1, 2, 198303) speculation and an honourable man should never speculate, much less to avoid a loss.
('13', 100, 1, 3, 198388) The dividing line (if any) between speculation and gambling is very thin indeed.
('13', 100, 1, 4, 198469) It is a niggardly spirit that fears to lose.
('13', 100, 2, 5, 198514) ON PROP.
('13', 100, 3, 6, 198523) Tolstoy Farm cannot be given up because of the memories connected with it and because in the event of your leaving South Africa for any new enterprise, spiritual or other, you are in a position to look back with satisfaction upon something accomplished in a concrete manner.
('13', 100, 4, 7, 198798) ON PROP.
('13', 100, 5, 8, 198807) The African Building is the cleanest and most reliable asset you possess.
('13', 100, 5, 9, 198881) It is also the most heavily burdened asset.
('13', 100, 5, 10, 198925) And if you want to avoid insolvency in case of unforeseen misfortunes, you will be wise to increase the monthly income from it so that you can pay out the bond debt as quickly as possible.
('13', 100, 5, 11, 199114) It provides steady and healthy occupation according to the ordinary European standard.
('13', 100, 5, 12, 199201) It will not unduly fetter your movements.
('13', 100, 5, 13, 199243) There is nothing of a speculative nature about it.
('13', 100, 5, 14, 199294) The social atmosphere of Pretoria is much purer and calmer than that of Johannesburg.
('13', 100, 5, 15, 199380) Being on the spot, you have a far greater opportunity of getting a buyer for your lease so as to relieve you from the bond debt and leave you £2000 clear after paying all your other debts.
('13', 100, 5, 16, 199569) The monthly withdrawal of £25 enables you to live comfortably and meet your ordinary wants.
('13', 100, 6, 17, 199661) GENERAL REMARKS
('13', 100, 7, 18, 199677) It is necessary to map out the future course in detail and take a solemn vow never to depart from it.
('13', 100, 7, 19, 199779) Your position does not warrant any help to anybody, whether friends or relatives.
('13', 100, 7, 20, 199861) It is quite wrong, I feel sure, to send £30 to Mrs. Daniel and equally so to send £12 to Mrs. Mayo annually.
('13', 100, 7, 21, 199970) Just consider your position by taking a few figures.
('13', 100, 7, 22, 200023) Add up your monthly expenses thus:
('13', 100, 8, 23, 200058) Salaries
('13', 100, 10, 24, 200067) Sundries Household
('13', 101, 0, 1, 200086) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 101, 1, 2, 200128) Rates on Mountain View Premiums on policies Rates and premiums and rent on African Building Personal expenses average Contributions such as Mrs. Daniel, etc.
('13', 101, 1, 3, 200286) Interest on loans
('13', 101, 2, 4, 200304) Against that put down your monthly income and you will find that you are running your various businesses at a loss, thus showing that you are an insolvent.
('13', 101, 2, 5, 200460) You ought to make out this statement not roughly but accurately.
('13', 101, 2, 6, 200525) Again, make out another list putting down all your assets and all your liabilities and then find out what the assets will fetch today under a forced sale.
('13', 101, 2, 7, 200680) And if you come to the conclusion that they will not pay your creditors, you are an insolvent.
('13', 101, 2, 8, 200775) Remember that the forced sale at a current bank rate, a fixed bank deposit, etc., fetches the same amount as an ordinary sale.
('13', 101, 2, 9, 200902) You have practically not a single asset worth mentioning of this character.
('13', 101, 2, 10, 200978) The reason is obvious.
('13', 101, 2, 11, 201001) You have never laid by any money as a prudent worldly man would.
('13', 101, 2, 12, 201066) Your transactions therefore were of a speculative character.
('13', 101, 2, 13, 201127) From that original taint not even the African Building or Tolstoy Farm is free.
('13', 101, 2, 14, 201207) But you cannot abandon these unless you are ready to embrace poverty as you would a brother or sister.
('13', 101, 2, 15, 201310) My recommen dations are therefore intended for you as you are at your ordinary best, not your very best.

('13', 103, 2, 13, 204113) THE RESOLUTION 1

('13', 106, 1, 2, 207689) 72. INTERVIEW TO “THE STAR” 1
('13', 106, 2, 3, 207719) JOHANNESBURG.
('13', 106, 2, 4, 207733) On or before April 28, 1913]
('13', 106, 3, 5, 207762) Interviewed by a representative of The Star, he said the Bill would be totally unacceptable to the Indian community unless it carried out the fundamental principle of the compromise in respect of existing rights and the removal of the racial bar.
('13', 106, 4, 6, 208009) It is perfectly true that there are no local wants of the Indian community in the Free State, and it is also true that no Indian is likely to enter the Free State, but we want the theoretical right of entry preserved in a general way.
('13', 106, 4, 7, 208244) The reason why the first Bill did not pass was because the Government wanted to introduce legislation to meet those points; last year’s Bill provided for it, and we quite recognized that Indians who entered the Free State would be subject to local disabilities, such as the prohibition to hold landed property, to farm and to trade.
('13', 106, 4, 8, 208577) If we accepted the present Bill, the position of Indians would be infinitely worse than it was even before passive resistance began.
('13', 106, 5, 9, 208710) The Government appears to be desirous of consolidating the worst features of the Provincial legislation; for instance, in the Cape the term “domicile” has a stricter meaning, and that is the meaning they want to apply to Natal, a contingency which would not have been possible five or six years ago.
('13', 106, 5, 10, 209010) They want to level down the conditions in Natal to those of the Cape instead of levelling up the Cape practice to that of Natal.
('13', 106, 6, 11, 209139) Mr. Gandhi evidently considers it is almost hopeless to expect a general Immigration Bill that would meet the views of Indian communities in the different Provinces, and in reply to a question as to the most ready way to settle the problem, he expressed himself in favour of amending Provincial legislation, and suggested, as far as the Transvaal was concerned, that the Immigration Law should have the racial bar removed, which would not arouse any hostility, and that the offending Asiatic Act of 1907 should be repealed.
('13', 106, 7, 12, 209663) 1 Gandhiji was on a visit to Johannesburg to consult the European Committee and the executive committee of the British Indian Association.
('13', 106, 7, 13, 209802) The report was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 3 5 1913.
('13', 107, 0, 1, 209857) 108 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 107, 1, 2, 209899) It is clear that the Indians are resolved to resist the provisions of Mr. Fischer’s Bill in the event of it becoming law, and already they have communicated with Mr. Gokhale, who happens to be in London, with the object of placing before the Imperial Government.
('13', 107, 2, 3, 210162) The strained relations between the Indians and the Government began soon after the grant of Responsible Government, and the passive resistance movement continued from 1906 to 1910, when the compromise with General Smuts was reached.

('13', 109, 3, 4, 212195) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('13', 109, 4, 5, 212216) Incidents have taken place in the Farm which have agitated me much.
('13', 109, 4, 6, 212284) Devdas made me weep today as I have not wept for years.1 I shall tell you all about these things when we meet.
('13', 109, 4, 7, 212395) They drive me more and more into the jungles of India.
('13', 109, 4, 8, 212450) This may be counted as a weakness of mine and that it may be proof of coming imbecility.
('13', 109, 4, 9, 212539) Only something within me tells me that I am more and more being driven to Truth.
('13', 109, 4, 10, 212620) You know that in my search for it nothing will daunt me.
('13', 109, 4, 11, 212677) Your simile is right.
('13', 109, 4, 12, 212699) But if in the attempt to straighten out the back it breaks, you have to suffer the breaking.
('13', 109, 4, 13, 212792) Do you nurse a tree whose trunk is rotten though stiff?
('13', 109, 4, 14, 212848) Or do you cut it off and sometimes even see to it that your trim digs deep enough to tear away the roots.
('13', 109, 4, 15, 212954) So it is with us.
('13', 109, 4, 16, 212972) You and I can but break in the pursuit.
('13', 109, 4, 17, 213012) Better to do that than to sit still, remain drones and parasites.
('13', 109, 4, 18, 213078) I know that parasites as well as drones have their place in nature but we are parasites and drones out of place.
('13', 109, 4, 19, 213191) Just examine the last working of your mind.
('13', 109, 4, 20, 213235) You suggest flying to Norwich, as if a loan would settle everything!
('13', 109, 4, 21, 213304) The true position is that the loan would follow if you only woke up to a sense of your own duty and began to work at it.
('13', 109, 4, 22, 213425) No loan is required to wind up your business or to stop the fever at Mountain View.
('13', 109, 4, 23, 213509) With love,
