('13', 110, 1, 2, 213669) 76. THE BILL
('13', 110, 2, 3, 213682) The Johannesburg mass meeting 3 was held none too soon.
('13', 110, 2, 4, 213738) Its resolution is most timely.
('13', 110, 2, 5, 213769) The composition of the meeting, the number of delegates who attended from most parts of the Transvaal, and the messages sent to Mr. Fischer must have shown the Minister that he could not hope to satisfy British Indians unless he was prepared to accede to their request for amendment of the Bill in the direction pointed out in Mr. Cachalia’s telegram.
('13', 110, 2, 6, 214121) It is difficult, therefore, to understand Mr. Fischer when he says, at the second reading of his precious measure, that the Bill would pacify the Indian community.
('13', 110, 2, 7, 214285) Mr. Chaplin, who contributed to the debate in an excellent speech, uttered seasonable warning when he said that the Bill was useless and unacceptable to the Unionist Party unless Mr. Fischer could give a definite assurance that the Indians were satisfied.
('13', 110, 2, 8, 214541) In spite of the Bill being pushed forward a stage further, we imagine that it will never reach the third reading stage.
('13', 110, 2, 9, 214661) But it is well for passive resisters to keep themselves in readiness.
('13', 110, 2, 10, 214731) It is to be hoped that, if the struggle is revived, the impending third campaign will be the purest, the last and the most brilliant of all.
('13', 110, 2, 11, 214872) We share the belief, with Thoreau, that “one true passive resister is enough to win a victory for right”.
('13', 110, 2, 12, 214978) Right is on our side.
('13', 110, 2, 13, 215000) It could not be on the side of a Government that has no regard for its sacred pledges.
('13', 110, 2, 14, 215087) And we have many true passive resisters.
('13', 110, 2, 15, 215128) We would all fail to satisfy the definition of an ideal passive resister, but we feel sure that the community contains many who would approach the ideal as nearly as is possible for mortals to do.
('13', 110, 2, 16, 215325) On such rests a great duty.
('13', 110, 3, 17, 215353) Indian Opinion, 3 5 1913
('13', 111, 0, 1, 215378) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 111, 1, 2, 215420) 77. THE CAMPAIGN
('13', 111, 2, 3, 215437) RESOLUTION ON SATYAGRAHA
('13', 111, 3, 4, 215462) The mass meeting held at Johannesburg has passed a resolution that satyagraha be started against the new Bill.
('13', 111, 3, 5, 215573) If the Government does not accept our demands, there is not the slightest doubt that satyagraha will be revived.
('13', 111, 3, 6, 215686) This was a meeting of no ordinary importance.
('13', 111, 3, 7, 215732) Many Indians were present.
('13', 111, 3, 8, 215759) Leaders of every town were there.
('13', 111, 3, 9, 215793) One can see that, if satyagraha is resumed, the campaign will follow a different pattern.
('13', 111, 3, 10, 215883) In the past, we could not be sure who would go to gaol or be in a position to do so.
('13', 111, 3, 11, 215968) 1 We had no means of judging how strong or weak the community was.
('13', 111, 3, 12, 216035) By now, however, we have had some training.
('13', 111, 3, 13, 216079) We can now make a fair guess how many and who will be able to court imprisonment.
('13', 111, 3, 14, 216161) The Government also knows our strength.
('13', 111, 3, 15, 216201) On the previous occasion, we expected everyone to go to gaol.
('13', 111, 3, 16, 216263) We besieged persons in order to drag them out.
('13', 111, 3, 17, 216310) It was the time for such training.
('13', 111, 3, 18, 216345) Those who besieged people and those who were besieged were alike new to the situation.
('13', 111, 3, 19, 216432) We know better now from experience.
('13', 111, 4, 20, 216468) PLAN OF CAMPAIGN
('13', 111, 5, 21, 216485) Mr. Cachalia has, therefore, made it clear that we will have neither ourselves nor the Government labour under a false impression.
('13', 111, 5, 22, 216616) The very resolution passed at the meeting implies that those who support it are not bound to go to gaol unless they themselves declare that they will do so.
('13', 111, 5, 23, 216773) Everyone who approves of satyagraha can make himself a party to this resolution and declare himself in agreement with it.
('13', 111, 5, 24, 216895) The person accepting this resolution tells the community and the Government that he believes in the justice and the necessity of this satyagraha campaign, that he will oppose the Government, that, even if he does not go to gaol, he will give monetary or other help to those who do, will look after their dependents, will make himself useful in the campaign in other ways, offer body labour if he has no money,
('13', 111, 6, 25, 217305) 1 The reference is to the passive resistance movement of 1909, which was followed by mass arrests of Indians, including Gandhiji.
('13', 112, 0, 1, 217435) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 113
('13', 112, 1, 2, 217482) will regularly spend some of his time working for it, will not avail himself of any of the provisions of the law and will not support the Government in its oppressive measures.
('13', 112, 2, 3, 217659) CAPE AND NATAL
('13', 112, 3, 4, 217674) This struggle is not for the Transvaal [alone], but for all South Africa.
('13', 112, 3, 5, 217748) Therefore, it befits the Cape and Natal also to wake up.
('13', 112, 3, 6, 217805) It is only natural that Johannesburg should lead the way.
('13', 112, 3, 7, 217863) It would be shameful, however, if the Cape and Natal sit back.
('13', 112, 3, 8, 217926) From there, too, people should come forward to go to gaol, and meetings should be held in both these provinces similar to the one in Johannesburg.
('13', 112, 3, 9, 218073) The Government may treat us as if we are separate, but we can demonstrate our “union” by our actions.
('13', 112, 4, 10, 218175) COMPARISON WITH PREVIOUS CAMPAIGN
('13', 112, 5, 11, 218209) It was our experience during the previous campaign that those who did not go to gaol sought to thwart the community’s effort and join hands with the authorities.
('13', 112, 5, 12, 218371) Some others, who did not turn against the community, hid themselves in shame and helped in no other way at all, as they should have done.
('13', 112, 5, 13, 218509) Difficulties of both these kinds should disappear, thanks to the resolution adopted this time.
('13', 112, 5, 14, 218604) If anyone, for whatever reason, schemes against the community, he will only be acting as its enemy and, to that extent, as his own.
('13', 112, 5, 15, 218736) As for those who hid themselves, their absence meant so much loss to the movement.
('13', 112, 5, 16, 218819) Our cause thus received a set back.
('13', 112, 5, 17, 218855) It was, however, not possible for us at that time to fight in any other way.
('13', 112, 5, 18, 218932) We were all being tried in the furnace.
('13', 112, 5, 19, 218972) We could not distinguish one from another.
('13', 112, 5, 20, 219015) It was insulting a man to say that he would not be able to go to gaol and the statement was taken as bringing discredit on him.
('13', 112, 5, 21, 219143) That was but right.
('13', 112, 5, 22, 219163) All the stronger for the testing, we have now emerged from the furnace.
('13', 112, 5, 23, 219235) A man will not be in disgrace for not going to gaol and need not feel ashamed.
('13', 112, 5, 24, 219314) He has realized, and so has the community, that he lacks the necessary strength.
('13', 112, 5, 25, 219395) Those who come forward to court imprisonment must not feel proud.
('13', 112, 5, 26, 219461) They should not think that they are doing something great.
('13', 112, 5, 27, 219520) We are all limbs of one body.
('13', 112, 5, 28, 219550) Just because the eye performs the function of seeing, it is not justified in looking down on the leg.
('13', 112, 5, 29, 219652) The leg should not feel humbled for not being able
('13', 113, 0, 1, 219703) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 113, 1, 2, 219745) to see as the eye does.
('13', 113, 1, 3, 219769) The leg and the eye, each works according to its nature.
('13', 113, 1, 4, 219826) The body needs them both.
('13', 113, 1, 5, 219852) But either of them will call down disgrace on itself if it fails in its natural function.
('13', 113, 1, 6, 219942) Then the body and the organ will both suffer.
('13', 113, 1, 7, 219988) This is equally true of those who volunteer to go to gaol and those who do not.
('13', 113, 2, 8, 220068) TO THOSE GOING TO GAOL
('13', 113, 3, 9, 220091) Now, a few words to those who come forward to court imprison ment.
('13', 113, 3, 10, 220158) This time, the campaign, if it starts, is likely to be a big one.
('13', 113, 3, 11, 220224) If the community stands united behind those who go to gaol, the cam paign will in all probability be over quite soon.
('13', 113, 3, 12, 220342) But whether the com munity is or is not unanimous, whether it helps or does not help, it is not permissible for the satyagrahis to give up their pledge.
('13', 113, 3, 13, 220495) Hence, they must be prepared to submit to heavy suffering in this campaign.
('13', 113, 3, 14, 220571) Moreover, a satyagrahi may not take cover behind what others do.
('13', 113, 3, 15, 220636) He is not concerned with whether others do or do not go to gaol.
('13', 113, 3, 16, 220701) Some people, it is observed, say that they will go to gaol if the leading businessmen do.
('13', 113, 3, 17, 220791) If not, [they say,] they are not prepared to sacrifice themselves, poor people that they are.
('13', 113, 3, 18, 220885) Again, the Tamils say that they will come forward only if the Gujaratis do, and the Hindus only if the Muslims do.
('13', 113, 3, 19, 221000) The businessman says that he can look after himself quite well, but that, for the sake of the community, he will be prepared to come out if the hawkers do.
('13', 113, 3, 20, 221156) None of those who argue thus is a satyagrahi.
('13', 113, 3, 21, 221202) One interested in business will mind his business.
('13', 113, 3, 22, 221253) He will not look to what others do.
('13', 113, 3, 23, 221289) He alone can be a satyagrahi whose soul is possessed by satyagraha.
('13', 113, 3, 24, 221357) He must understand that he has not come forward in order to confer a favour on anyone, but because he has understood and come to like satyagraha and has the requisite strength.
('13', 113, 3, 25, 221534) The first to benefit from it will be himself.
('13', 113, 3, 26, 221580) The community’s benefit follows from his.
('13', 113, 3, 27, 221622) In patriotic work, there is no clash between one’s own interests and those of thecountry.
('13', 113, 3, 28, 221712) If anyone thinks that there is, he is not patriotic enough.
('13', 113, 3, 29, 221772) A mother does not seek domination over her child because she has drudged for it.
('13', 113, 3, 30, 221853) A child is not proud because it has served its mother.
('13', 113, 3, 31, 221908) He who has dedicated his all to his country or religion feels that he is serving his own interests in doing what he thinks to be his duty.
('13', 113, 3, 32, 222047) What, then, is so wonderful about doing one’s duty?
('13', 113, 3, 33, 222099) Why look to what others do?
('13', 113, 3, 34, 222127) Why think ill of others?
('13', 113, 3, 35, 222152) A satya 
('13', 114, 0, 1, 222161) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 115
('13', 114, 1, 2, 222208) grahi can make no conditions.
('13', 114, 1, 3, 222238) He stands ready to sacrifice himself, body, mind and possessions and, hence, is not afraid of losing wealth or life.
('13', 114, 1, 4, 222355) He has entered into a pact with death itself.
('13', 114, 1, 5, 222401) There is no middle of the road line for him.
('13', 114, 1, 6, 222446) One who feels thus will help to keep up the fight.
('13', 114, 1, 7, 222497) He will live on even after death.

('13', 114, 2, 10, 222729) TO THOSE WHO MAY NOT GO TO GAOL

('13', 114, 3, 12, 222842) There will be no one now to shame any person [into doing anything].

('13', 114, 3, 17, 223283) The shame in one’s heart is more painful than what others cause.
('13', 114, 3, 18, 223348) If a man has the requisite strength, he should prefer gaol; and if he cannot go, he should feel sorry.
('13', 114, 3, 19, 223451) It is not proper that one who does not go should seek to brazen it out.
('13', 114, 3, 20, 223523) That’s not the meaning of the resolution.
('13', 114, 3, 21, 223565) What it means is that, if a person wants to go but cannot do so out of sheer weakness, he may be allowed to excuse himself.

('13', 114, 3, 27, 224192) This is the right time for doing so.
('13', 114, 3, 28, 224229) Mr. Gokhale will not be in England for ever.

('13', 114, 3, 30, 224365) This is, therefore, the immediate duty of those who will not be going to gaol and we hope that help will be forthcoming from all the three places, Natal, the Cape and the Transvaal.
('13', 114, 3, 31, 224547) Making up their minds, if satyagraha starts, to

('13', 115, 1, 3, 224767) With that end in view, we must find out who are likely to go to gaol and fix up simultaneously the arrangements for helping them.
('13', 115, 1, 4, 224897) If this is done, we shall have an exciting fight this time, one which will surpass the previous one and which will be recognized as on a higher plane.

('13', 115, 3, 6, 225064) Indian Opinion, 3 5 1913
('13', 115, 4, 7, 225089) 78. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XVIII]
('13', 115, 5, 8, 225133) SOME REMEDIES: 1. AIR
('13', 115, 6, 9, 225155) We have considered how to keep good health, on what it depends and how to conserve it.
('13', 115, 6, 10, 225242) If all men always followed the rules of health and observed unbroken celibacy, the chapters that follow would not be necessary because such men cannot possibly suffer any physical or mental illness.
('13', 115, 6, 11, 225441) But such persons are rare indeed.
('13', 115, 6, 12, 225475) There is hardly one so fortunate as never to have fallen ill.
('13', 115, 6, 13, 225537) The average person is perpetually ill with some sickness or other.
('13', 115, 6, 14, 225604) Such a person will enjoy good health in the measure in which he follows the rules set out in the first part.
('13', 115, 6, 15, 225713) If, moreover, he knows some simple remedies, he will not get into a panic and rush to a doctor or hakim 1 when he does fall ill.
('13', 115, 6, 16, 225842) It is with this in mind that the chapters which follow are written.
('13', 115, 6, 17, 225910) We have seen that fresh air is the first essential for good health: it is also an invaluable cure for certain ailments.
('13', 115, 6, 18, 226030) For instance, if a man whose joints have become stiff is treated with steam, there will be immediate perspiration and the joints will be relieved.
('13', 115, 6, 19, 226177) This method of applying steam is known as Turkish bath.
('13', 115, 6, 20, 226233) If a person whose body is burning with high temperature is made to sleep naked in the open air, the temperature will immediately come down.
('13', 115, 6, 21, 226373) He will feel easy and, if he is covered with a blanket when his body has become cool, he will begin to sweat and the fever will disappear.
('13', 115, 6, 22, 226512) There is a notion among us that, when anyone has high
('13', 115, 7, 23, 226566) 1 Physician practising the Unani system of medicine
('13', 116, 0, 1, 226618) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 117
('13', 116, 1, 2, 226665) fever, all the windows and doors should be closed, even if that should make the place unbearably hot for the patient, that the latter’s head and ears should be wrapped up, and that he should be covered with heavy blankets.
('13', 116, 1, 3, 226888) This is an entirely wrong notion.
('13', 116, 1, 4, 226922) The practice causes the patient acute discomfort and makes him weak.
('13', 116, 1, 5, 226991) It often happens that the patient, having been wrapped up in this way, perspires profusely and the thermometer shows a lower temperature, but the patient is greatly weakened.
('13', 116, 1, 6, 227166) In fever brought on by heat, no one should be afraid to take the air treatment described above.
('13', 116, 1, 7, 227262) The patient will immediately feel the benefit and no harm whatever will come of it.
('13', 116, 1, 8, 227346) One should only make sure that the patient does not shiver when lying exposed.
('13', 116, 1, 9, 227425) If he feels cold, it means that his discomfort [from heat] had not been too severe to bear after all.
('13', 116, 1, 10, 227527) In case the patient is not in a condition to lie naked out of doors, there can be no harm whatever if he is made to sleep covered up in the open air.
('13', 116, 1, 11, 227677) A change of air is a highly effective remedy for prolonged fever or any other sickness.
('13', 116, 1, 12, 227765) The practice of going for a change of climate is, as a matter of fact, part of the “air treatment”.
('13', 116, 1, 13, 227865) There is also a custom, among some, of changing houses.
('13', 116, 1, 14, 227921) Many believe that a house which is never free from illness must be a haunted one.
('13', 116, 1, 15, 228003) This seems to be mere superstition.
('13', 116, 1, 16, 228039) The so called haunting is in fact just polluted air.
('13', 116, 1, 17, 228092) Consequently, the change of house means change of air, and that is in itself a great advantage.
('13', 116, 1, 18, 228188) The air we breathe has so close a bearing on the condition of our bodies that the slightest change in it is bound to affect us for better or worse.
('13', 116, 1, 19, 228336) The rich can go abroad in search of good climate.
('13', 116, 1, 20, 228386) A poor man can also benefit by going to a neighbou ring town or even by a change of residence.
('13', 116, 1, 21, 228481) Sometimes a patient improves merely by being moved from one room to another.
('13', 116, 1, 22, 228558) It is superfluous to caution here that on all such occasions the air in the room, house or town to which one goes should be better than that left behind.
('13', 116, 1, 23, 228712) Sickness caused by a humid atmosphere will not disappear by a change to a more humid place.
('13', 116, 1, 24, 228804) Sometimes no benefit is derived from a change of air, the reason being that the change is made without a knowledge of the principle involved.
('13', 116, 1, 25, 228946) Sometimes health does not improve because, though the change has been to a better climate, other necessary precautions have not been taken, with the result that the benefit derived from a good climate is lost.

('13', 117, 7, 11, 229685) My analysis of your position reacted upon me and made me feel that if my remarks were sincere (and they were that absolutely) I could not possibly let you spend on my behalf without being guilty of having participated in a fraud upon yourself, your creditors and in a fraud upon yourself, your creditors and myself.
('13', 117, 7, 12, 230001) My resolve was a most natural consequence of my discovery long ago made but realized only during our last communion.
('13', 117, 7, 13, 230118) No matter what others may say, I should defend the position before all that you are today in an insolvent position.
('13', 117, 7, 14, 230234) To fully grasp the truth is to avert the crisis and make yourself solvent.
('13', 117, 7, 15, 230309) Your condition is not hopeless or helpless.
('13', 117, 7, 16, 230353) But every insolvent is not necessarily helpless.
('13', 117, 7, 17, 230402) If he can enter into a composition with his creditors he can pay 20/ in the pound.
('13', 117, 7, 18, 230485) But at the moment he has not the money to pay his creditors and is therefore insolvent.
('13', 117, 7, 19, 230573) Such is undoubtedly your position.
('13', 117, 8, 20, 230608) All the same, you are bound to send the £200 to your brother in law.
('13', 117, 8, 21, 230677) Only I wish it would be the final lesson of your life.

('13', 120, 4, 7, 234722) 82. INDIAN WOMEN AS PASSIVE RESISTERS
('13', 120, 5, 8, 234760) The following telegram has been addressed by the Transvaal Indian Women’s Association to the Hon’ble, the Minister of the Interior:
('13', 120, 6, 9, 234892) Committee Transvaal Indian Women’s Association has carefully considered position, in the light of the Searle judg ment, of Indian women resident in South Africa or entitled to enter therein with their husbands possessing rights of resi dence in the Union, and has come to the conclusion that the honour of Indian womanhood is affected by that judgment.
('13', 120, 6, 10, 235245) Committee therefore respectfully trusts that the Government will be pleased to amend the law so as to recognize the validity of Indian marriages which have been duly consecrated accor ding to the religious customs of the parties and are recognized as legal in India.
('13', 120, 6, 11, 235512) I am also to inform the Government that the earnestness of the members of the Association is such that, if the Government cannot see its way to comply with the request, they would offer passive resistance and in common with the male members of the community suffer imprisonment rather than suffer the indignity to which in their opinion the Searle Judgment subjects them.
('13', 120, 7, 12, 235884) SONJA SCHLESIN
('13', 120, 8, 13, 235899) HONORARY SECRETARY

('13', 122, 1, 2, 237725) 83. THE WOMEN’S RESOLUTION
('13', 122, 2, 3, 237752) The remarkable resolution of the Indian women of Johannes burg on the marriage question, that has been agitating our country men for the past few weeks, marks an interesting development of the passive resistance campaign.
('13', 122, 2, 4, 237974) The resolution has been duly wired 1 to Mr. Fischer, and, if the Minister still persists in ignoring the grievance created by the Searle judgment, he will do so with his eyes open.
('13', 122, 2, 5, 238155) He may rest assured that Indian women are not dying to go to gaol, nor do the male members of the community contemplate with equanimity the prospect of their women folk being imprisoned.
('13', 122, 2, 6, 238342) If, therefore, Indian women become passive resisters, they must have what is, to them at any rate, a very serious grievance.
('13', 122, 2, 7, 238467) We congratulate our plucky sisters who have dared to fight the Government rather than submit to the insult offered by the Searle judgment.
('13', 122, 2, 8, 238606) They will cover themselves and the land of their birth, as, indeed, of their adoption, with glory, if they remain true to their resolve to the end.
('13', 122, 2, 9, 238754) 2 We know that they fully recognize what their wire means.
('13', 122, 2, 10, 238813) We hope, too, that the male members of the population will realize their own duty in the matter.
('13', 122, 2, 11, 238910) It is largely in their hands to end the struggle at an earlier stage.
('13', 122, 2, 12, 238980) “The larger the number of passive resisters, the quicker the termination of the struggle” is a mathe matical formula.

('13', 123, 1, 2, 239323) 84. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XIX]
('13', 123, 2, 3, 239365) 2. WATER TREATMENTS
('13', 123, 3, 4, 239385) Air does its work invisibly, so that we cannot fully realize the efficacy of air treatments.
('13', 123, 3, 5, 239478) But the properties of water and the effects it produces are immediately apparent and we can, therefore, readily see how admirably it works.
('13', 123, 4, 6, 239618) Water treatments by steam are more or less familiar to all.
('13', 123, 4, 7, 239678) We give a steam bath to a patient suffering from fever.
('13', 123, 4, 8, 239734) A bad headache can often be relieved by the use of steam.
('13', 123, 4, 9, 239792) If joints are affected by rheumatism and it is desired to give the patient quick relief, treatment with steam, followed immediately by a cold bath, proves highly beneficial.
('13', 123, 4, 10, 239966) When there are boils on the skin, too many of them, we cannot apply ointment or poultice to all of them, but they soften in no time if treated with steam.
('13', 123, 5, 11, 240121) When exhausted, if one takes a hot bath followed by a cold shower, one feels light in body and the fatigue disappears.
('13', 123, 5, 12, 240240) If anyone suffering from insomnia takes a steam bath, followed by a cold shower, he will, more often than not, soon fall asleep.
('13', 123, 6, 13, 240369) In most of these cases hot water can be substituted for steam.
('13', 123, 6, 14, 240432) It is not necessary, therefore, to make any distinction between the two.
('13', 123, 6, 15, 240505) If one suffers from stomach ache, it can be quickly relieved by hot water fomentation.
('13', 123, 6, 16, 240592) This can be done by placing a bottle or other vessel, filled with boiling water, on a cloth over the abdomen.
('13', 123, 6, 17, 240702) Sometimes it becomes necessary to cause vomiting.
('13', 123, 6, 18, 240752) This can be done by drinking plenty of hot water.
('13', 123, 6, 19, 240802) One suffering from constipation can get relief by drinking hot water when retiring or in the morning immediately after brushing the teeth.
('13', 123, 6, 20, 240941) Sir Gordon Spring, a former Prime Minister of the Cape, enjoyed excellent health.
('13', 123, 6, 21, 241023) When asked what it was chiefly due to, he replied that he drank a glass of hot water the last thing at night and the first thing in the morning.
('13', 123, 6, 22, 241168) That was, he said, the secret of his good health.
('13', 123, 6, 23, 241218) Some people pass a motion only after drinking tea and in their ignorance give the credit to tea.
('13', 123, 6, 24, 241315) Actually the tea is harmful: it is the hot water in it that produces the effect.
('13', 124, 0, 1, 241396) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 125
('13', 124, 1, 2, 241443) There is a special kind of tub for a steam bath, but this is not really necessary.
('13', 124, 1, 3, 241526) A spirit or kerosene stove or small wood or coal fire should be placed under a cane chair or wooden stool.
('13', 124, 1, 4, 241633) A pot of water should be covered and placed on the fire.
('13', 124, 1, 5, 241690) A counterpane or blanket should then be spread over the chair and so arranged over the front that the patient seated on it should not feel too severely the heat from the fire or steam.
('13', 124, 1, 6, 241875) The patient should be wrapped in a cotton rug or blanket and seated in the chair.
('13', 124, 1, 7, 241957) The lid should then be slipped off the water pot so that the steam reaches the patient.
('13', 124, 1, 8, 242045) It is our custom also to cover the latter’s head but this is not necessary.
('13', 124, 1, 9, 242121) Heat generated in the body rises to the head and drops of perspiration form on the face.
('13', 124, 1, 10, 242210) If the patient is not in a condition to get out of the sick bed; he may be laid on a cane couch or iron bedstead and given steam treatment.
('13', 124, 1, 11, 242350) In that case, also, the blankets should be so arranged that heat and steam do not escape.
('13', 124, 1, 12, 242440) Care must be taken to see that the patient does not sustain burns and the blankets or other things do not catch fire.
('13', 124, 1, 13, 242558) Should the patient happen to be extremely weak, one should hesitate to give him steam treatment, for if steam has its benefits, it can have harmful effects too.
('13', 124, 1, 14, 242719) After taking a steam bath, the patient always feels weak.
('13', 124, 1, 15, 242777) The weakness does not last long but the treatment, if taken habitually, is bound to have an exhausting effect on the patient.
('13', 124, 1, 16, 242903) Steam should, therefore, be used with great caution.
('13', 124, 1, 17, 242956) It may also be applied locally.
('13', 124, 1, 18, 242988) For instance, in a case of headache it is not necessary to steam the whole body.
('13', 124, 1, 19, 243069) Water should be boiled in a narrow necked vessel or kettle and the forehead held over the opening.
('13', 124, 1, 20, 243168) The head should be partially covered with a cloth so that the steam may reach the head through the nostrils.
('13', 124, 1, 21, 243277) If the nose is blocked, such inhalation will give immediate relief.
('13', 124, 1, 22, 243345) If an inflammation is confined to a particular spot, it may be treated by applying steam to the affected part only.
('13', 124, 2, 23, 243461) The good effects of hot water and steam are fairly widely known, but few seem to know the value of cold water.
('13', 124, 2, 24, 243572) To tell the truth, the beneficial properties of cold water even surpass those of hot water.
('13', 124, 2, 25, 243664) It may be said that on most people cold water has a stimulating effect.
('13', 124, 2, 26, 243736) Even the weakest patient can be given cold water treatment.
('13', 124, 2, 27, 243796) For fever, smallpox, rash and other skin affections, wrapping up with cotton sheets soaked in cold water is highly efficacious.
('13', 124, 2, 28, 243924) The effect seems almost miraculous and anyone can test it without the slightest risk.
('13', 125, 0, 1, 244010) 126 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 125, 1, 2, 244052) cases of giddiness or delirium, a piece of cloth soaked in ice water and placed over the head gives great relief.
('13', 125, 1, 3, 244166) If one has had no motion, it may be possible to get relief by applying cloth soaked in ice cold water to the abdomen.
('13', 125, 1, 4, 244284) Those who have wet dreams often get relief if they sleep every day with a cold wet bandage tied over the lower abdomen.
('13', 125, 1, 5, 244404) The application of an ice pack stops bleeding in any part of the body.
('13', 125, 1, 6, 244475) When the nose is bleeding, immediate stoppage is brought about by dashing a lot of very cold water on the head.
('13', 125, 1, 7, 244587) One suffering from any disease of the nose, or from cold or headache derives great benefit from drawing up water through the nostrils twice a day.
('13', 125, 1, 8, 244734) One nostril should be closed, water drawn in through the other and then ejected through the first.
('13', 125, 1, 9, 244833) Water may also be drawn in through both the nostrils and ejected through the mouth.
('13', 125, 1, 10, 244917) If the nose is otherwise clean and some of the water passes from the nostrils into the stomach, it does no harm.
('13', 125, 1, 11, 245030) It is an excellent habit to clean the nose by drawing in water through the nostrils.
('13', 125, 1, 12, 245115) Those who cannot manage this may do so by using a douche, but anyone can master the technique of drawing water up through the nostrils after a few attempts.
('13', 125, 1, 13, 245272) Everyone should try to learn it since a headache can often be cured instantly by this easy method.
('13', 125, 1, 14, 245371) If the nose gives out an offensive smell, for that, too, this is an effective remedy.
('13', 125, 1, 15, 245457) Some persons suffer from a running nose; they will find the method of drawing water in through the nostrils an unfailing remedy for their condition.
('13', 125, 1, 16, 245606) Many people are reluctant to take an enema, and some even argue that it causes weakness.
('13', 125, 1, 17, 245695) This is a wrong notion.
('13', 125, 1, 18, 245719) There is no better method of immediate relief from constipation.
('13', 125, 1, 19, 245784) In various conditions, where other remedies are ineffective, an enema provides relief.
('13', 125, 1, 20, 245871) It empties the bowels completely and prevents accumulation of new poisons in the body.
('13', 125, 1, 21, 245958) Anyone who suffers from gas, flatulence or any complaint brought about by poor digestion may take two pounds of water by enema, and so have an immediate rest.
('13', 125, 1, 22, 246117) There is a book on this subject.
('13', 125, 1, 23, 246150) Its author had tried many remedies, but failed to cure his dyspepsia.
('13', 125, 1, 24, 246220) He had grown extremely weak and anaemic.
('13', 125, 1, 25, 246261) With the use of the enema, his appetite improved and, in a short time he was in excellent health.
('13', 125, 1, 26, 246359) Complaints like jaundice can be immediately cured by means of enemas.
('13', 125, 1, 27, 246429) If this treatment has to be prolonged, it is advisable to use cold water, as hot water may cause weakness; this,
('13', 126, 0, 1, 246542) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 127
('13', 126, 1, 2, 246589) however, is not to be blamed on the enema as such.

('13', 127, 4, 5, 247834) DEAR MR. CHAPLIN,
('13', 127, 5, 6, 247852) Mr. Fischer’s statement is certainly extraordinary.
('13', 127, 5, 7, 247904) 1 The Imperial Government could never have seen the full text of the Bill.
('13', 127, 5, 8, 247979) As before, in my opinion, the Union Government have merely cabled home a summary giving their interpretation of the debatable clauses.
('13', 127, 5, 9, 248114) If so, they have obtained the Imperial Government’s consent under false pretences.
('13', 127, 5, 10, 248197) Be that as it may, I venture to state that if any of the existing rights as set forth in my letter 2 are disturbed and if the legal status as to marriage is not restored as it existed before the Searle judgment, passive resistance will undoubtedly revive and this time it is bound to be of a general character, i.e., it cannot be confined to the Transvaal.
('13', 127, 5, 11, 248554) You may also have noticed that Indian women will actively participate in the struggle if the marriage question is not settled.
('13', 127, 5, 12, 248681) I trust you do not mind my writing frankly in this matter.
('13', 127, 5, 13, 248740) May I thank you and the Unionist leaders for their sympathetic speeches at the second reading and may I hope that the same vigilance will be exercised by you and them during the
('13', 127, 6, 14, 248918) 1 Moving the Immigrants’ Restriction Bill for the second reading on April 30, Fischer had strongly defended the proposed legislation and the various other measures adopted by the South African Government to control Asiatic influx.
('13', 127, 6, 15, 249149) Indian Opinion reported Fischer to have stated: “ .
('13', 127, 6, 16, 249201) complications had arisen through the coloured population in their midst, and thus they had, perhaps, to be more careful in regard to those who would come in, who were not of that civilization which they had in the country, and not best fitted to promote the best interests of South Africa.
('13', 127, 6, 17, 249491) With Europeans they in this country could assimilate.

('13', 128, 4, 6, 250407) 87. THE SECOND READING
('13', 128, 5, 7, 250430) In spite of the unanimous opposition of the Unionist Party, the Immigration Bill has been read a second time without a division.
('13', 128, 5, 8, 250559) The result would be considered astounding if we did not know the ways of the Botha Ministry.
('13', 128, 5, 9, 250652) The Right Hon’ble Mr. Fischer has bought his second reading by promising to consider favourably the suggestions made by the Opposition for improving the Bill and by telling the House that he had secured the general approval of the Imperial Government for his measure.
('13', 128, 5, 10, 250920) We may expect lively debates and drastic amendments during the committee stage.
('13', 128, 5, 11, 251000) But this may not serve our purpose in the least degree.
('13', 128, 5, 12, 251056) Nothing but a total acceptance of our demands can satisfy us, and this not because we do not compromise but because there can be no question of compromise on points of existence or honour.
('13', 128, 5, 13, 251245) Passive Resisters are under a vow not to accept anything in satisfaction of their demands if it disturbs existing rights.
('13', 128, 5, 14, 251367) By their very constitution they are precluded from bargaining away the rights of others in order to save themselves the sufferings of imprisonment.
('13', 128, 5, 15, 251515) From Mr. Fischer’s language, it is clear that he wants to egg on the Europeans of South Africa to rise against us, and us to offer passive resistance.
('13', 128, 5, 16, 251666) Though the majority of the speakers during the debate spoke against his Bill and advised him to placate passive resisters, he gratuitously mentioned that the threat of passive resistance might make the Government to come to “plain terms”.
('13', 128, 5, 17, 251905) We wish they would.
('13', 128, 5, 18, 251925) We certainly do not want ambiguity.
('13', 128, 5, 19, 251961) And in pleading for gen eral terms in an Immigration Bill, we do not countenance a subterfuge, as it has been called, but we ask for a continuance of the excellent part
('13', 129, 0, 1, 252130) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 129, 1, 2, 252172) of the British Constitution which requires that, however persistent a bad practice may be, it shall not be incorporated into the law.
('13', 129, 1, 3, 252306) In Lord Ampthill’s words, theory should be sound, though one may fail to carry it out in practice.
('13', 129, 1, 4, 252405) In theory, there is no such thing as a straight line that can be drawn, but because we draw a line that is only fairly but not quite straight, we are not supposed to have resorted to a subterfuge by having still the true, though theoretical, definition in view.
('13', 129, 1, 5, 252667) To keep our theory right is to obey the law of our higher nature; to depart from it in practice is to concede the weakness of human nature.
('13', 129, 1, 6, 252807) If, therefore, the Government wish to depart from the theory of the British Constitution to which they owe their very existence, they are welcome to do so; only, then, they will not have used “plain ter ms” but they will have avowed their enmity to the origin of their exis tence.
('13', 129, 1, 7, 253088) And passive resisters who still cling to the beautiful vision of that Constitution are prepared to fight for making it a reality or die in the attempt.

('13', 129, 3, 9, 253266) 88. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XX]
('13', 129, 4, 10, 253307) 2. WATER TREATMENTS (CONTINUED)
('13', 129, 5, 11, 253339) After numerous experiments, a German named Kuhne has discovered that certain water treatments are most effective in a number of ailments.
('13', 129, 5, 12, 253477) His book on this subject has been translated into many languages.
('13', 129, 5, 13, 253543) Translations are available in India also.
('13', 129, 5, 14, 253585) His thesis is that the stomach is the source of all disease.
('13', 129, 5, 15, 253646) If there is excessive heat in the stomach, it erupts by way of boils on the skin or rheumatism or some such trouble, or as fever, causing the whole body to become hot.
('13', 129, 5, 16, 253814) There were many before Kuhne to write on water treatments.
('13', 129, 5, 17, 253873) There is a very old book called Water treatments.
('13', 129, 5, 18, 253923) But no one before Kuhne had laid the same emphasis as he did on the basic identity of diseases.
('13', 129, 5, 19, 254019) No one had pointed out that all ailments had their origin in the stomach.
('13', 129, 5, 20, 254093) It is not necessary for us to accept Kuhne’s thesis as gospel truth, nor need we go into the details of the matter.
('13', 129, 5, 21, 254209) But it seems quite certain that, in a large number of cases, Kuhne’s diagnosis and
('13', 130, 0, 1, 254292) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 131
('13', 130, 1, 2, 254339) treatment are correct.
('13', 130, 1, 3, 254362) Thousands have found this by experience.
('13', 130, 1, 4, 254403) The late magistrate of Durban, Mr. Titan, was struck down by paralysis after an attack of tetanus.
('13', 130, 1, 5, 254502) Having tried various treatments without success, he was advised by someone to see Kuhne.
('13', 130, 1, 6, 254591) He went to him, was completely cured and lived in Durban for many years after his return.
('13', 130, 1, 7, 254681) He always advised people to try Kuhne’s treatments.
('13', 130, 1, 8, 254733) There is a clinic in Natal which gives his treatments.
('13', 130, 1, 9, 254788) It is near Sweetwaters station.
('13', 130, 1, 10, 254820) This is only one instance of its popularity; one can find many others.
('13', 130, 1, 11, 254891) Kuhne says that the excessive heat in the stomach can be removed by cooling, and for this purpose he advises a bath which will cool the stomach and the adjacent areas of the body.
('13', 130, 1, 12, 255071) He has invented a special tin bath to make the process easy, but we can do without it.
('13', 130, 1, 13, 255158) Oval tin tubs of 36 inches, more or less as may suit the patient, are readily available; one of these will do for a Kuhne bath.
('13', 130, 1, 14, 255286) Three quarters of the tub should be filled with cold water and the patient should be placed in it so that his feet rest outside on a board and the upper part of the trunk also remains above the water line.
('13', 130, 1, 15, 255492) Only the portion from the navel to the thigh should be submerged.
('13', 130, 1, 16, 255558) The patient must be naked in water.
('13', 130, 1, 17, 255594) If he feels cold, the upper part of his trunk and his feet may be covered with blankets or he or she may wear a shirt or `a blouse, keeping it out of the water.
('13', 130, 1, 18, 255755) This bath should be taken in a room which can let in light, air and sunshine and, in fact, does let them in while the bath is proceeding.
('13', 130, 1, 19, 255893) After seating himself in the tub, the patient should rub his abdomen, under the water, with a rough towel or get it rubbed by an attendant.
('13', 130, 1, 20, 256033) This kind of bath can be taken for 5 to 30 minutes or longer.
('13', 130, 1, 21, 256095) Sometimes the relief is imme diate.
('13', 130, 1, 22, 256131) If the patient is suffering from gas, wind begins to pass or he begins to belch.
('13', 130, 1, 23, 256212) If he has fever, his temperature is bound to fall by one or two degrees 5 minutes after the bath has commenced.
('13', 130, 1, 24, 256324) He will have a free motion.
('13', 130, 1, 25, 256352) An exhausted person will feel refreshed.
('13', 130, 1, 26, 256393) One suffering from insomnia will feel relaxed and be able to sleep.
('13', 130, 1, 27, 256461) One who is excessively drowsy becomes alert and lively.
('13', 130, 1, 28, 256517) The reason why such seemingly opposite effects are produced has already been stated.
('13', 130, 1, 29, 256602) Lethargy and insomnia are different results produced by the same cause; they are only apparently opposites.
('13', 130, 1, 30, 256710) Both diarrhoea and consti pation arc similarly the results of indigestion.
('13', 130, 1, 31, 256785) Some get diarrhoea while others get constipation.
('13', 130, 1, 32, 256835) The bath has a highly beneficial effect
('13', 131, 0, 1, 256875) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 131, 1, 2, 256917) on both conditions.
('13', 131, 1, 3, 256937) Very old cases of piles are cured by this bath treatment in conjunction with correct dieting.
('13', 131, 1, 4, 257031) If a person feels nausea, he will probably be cured immediately he starts the bath.
('13', 131, 1, 5, 257115) The weak grow strong with it.
('13', 131, 1, 6, 257145) Many have been cured of their rheumatism by this means.
('13', 131, 1, 7, 257201) The bath is also excellent for haemorrhage and useful in cases of blood poisoning.
('13', 131, 1, 8, 257284) Anyone having a severe headache will get immediate relief with this bath.
('13', 131, 1, 9, 257358) Kuhne himself thought that his baths were invaluable even in such terrible diseases as cancer.
('13', 131, 1, 10, 257453) Pregnant women will have easier deliveries if they take these baths.
('13', 131, 1, 11, 257522) It is a treat ment that can be taken by children, by the young and the aged, by men and women.
('13', 131, 1, 12, 257617) There is another way of taking this bath which is unfailingly effective in certain ailments.
('13', 131, 1, 13, 257710) It is called the wet sheet pack, which in Gujarati means “a bandage of wet cloth”.
('13', 131, 1, 14, 257793) The manner of treatment is as follows: Place a table or low seat, long enough for the patient to lie on full length, if possible in the open air.
('13', 131, 1, 15, 257939) Arrange on this four or more blankets according to the weather, so that they hang down on all sides.
('13', 131, 1, 16, 258040) Spread over them two clean bed sheets, long and thick, which have been soaked in cold water and wrung out.
('13', 131, 1, 17, 258147) Place a pillow under the blankets for the head.
('13', 131, 1, 18, 258195) The patient should then be stripped of all clothing, except a small handkerchief or cloth round his waist which may be retained if desired.
('13', 131, 1, 19, 258335) He should be laid flat on his back between the sheets arranged as above, the arms hanging own and the [lower] sheet and blankets wrapped round him from both sides, one over the other.
('13', 131, 1, 20, 258519) The covering at the bottom should be carefully wrapped round his feet.
('13', 131, 1, 21, 258590) If there is sunshine, a wet cloth should be placed on his head and face, leaving the nose uncovered in all cases.
('13', 131, 1, 22, 258704) The patient will feel a momentary chill which will be immediately followed by a feeling of relief and comfortable warmth.
('13', 131, 1, 23, 258826) He may remain in this condition for 5 minutes to an hour or more.
('13', 131, 1, 24, 258892) By and by, the patient becomes so hot that he perspires.
('13', 131, 1, 25, 258949) Frequently, he falls asleep at this stage.
('13', 131, 1, 26, 258992) When he comes out of the wet sheets, he must im mediately have a cold bath.
('13', 131, 1, 27, 259068) This treatment is highly effective in many skin diseases.
('13', 131, 1, 28, 259126) Eczema, ringworm, pimples, chickenpox, smallpox, sim ple boils, fever, etc., yield quickly to the “wet sheet pack”.
('13', 131, 1, 29, 259242) However severe the attack, smallpox can, in most cases, be cured by this treatment.
('13', 131, 1, 30, 259326) An attack of rash is cured by taking one or two baths.
('13', 132, 0, 1, 259381) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 133
('13', 132, 1, 2, 259428) technique of taking or arranging this bath is easily learnt and everyone will discover its effectiveness in experience.
('13', 132, 1, 3, 259548) During the bath, the dirt from the skin is deposited on the wet sheet.
('13', 132, 1, 4, 259619) The latter should, there fore, never be used again by the same or another patient until it has been thoroughly washed in boiling water.
('13', 132, 1, 5, 259755) Finally, there is one point to be kept in mind about these water treatments, that, if the bath is taken without proper attention to diet and exercise, it can never have full effect or may have no effect at all.
('13', 132, 1, 6, 259966) If a man suffering from arthritis takes the Kuhne bath or “wet sheet pack” but eats unsuitable food, does not breathe fresh air, lives in dirty surroundings and takes no exercise, he cannot hope to benefit from the treatment alone.
('13', 132, 1, 7, 260198) It can be of help only if other rules of health are duly observed.
('13', 132, 1, 8, 260265) There is no doubt whatever that, if they are, water treatment will help the patient to a most speedy recovery.

('13', 134, 2, 3, 263736) [PHOENIX,] May 19, 1913
('13', 134, 3, 4, 263760) I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, in reply to mine of the 14th ultimo2 regarding the validity of Indian marriages.
('13', 134, 3, 5, 263921) My Committee had, it was thought, made it clear that, in its request, it had not raised the question of polygamy, which could be treated on its merits.
('13', 134, 3, 6, 264073) What the Searle judgment does is to disregard marriages contracted in India or in South Africa in accordance with the rites prescribed by Indian faiths.
('13', 134, 3, 7, 264226) I beg to inform the Hon’ble the Minister that the religious ceremonies in India do not mention polygamy, nor do all Indian faiths necessarily recognize polygamy.
('13', 134, 3, 8, 264388) All my Association asks for is that monogamous marriages celebrated in India or in South Africa according to the ceremonies prescribed by the great Indian faiths may be lawfully recognized, as they were before the Searle judgment.
('13', 134, 3, 9, 264619) Where my countrymen bring or have more than one wife the indulgence promised in the Government com munication may be exercised till the time is ripe for legal recognition of such marriages.
('13', 134, 3, 10, 264809) I do respectfully hope that the position taken up by my Association has now been made clear.

('13', 135, 1, 2, 265068) 91. THE BILL
('13', 135, 2, 3, 265081) The Immigration Bill promises to become the law of the land, if one may judge from the considerable progress made by it in Commi ttee since Monday last.
('13', 135, 2, 4, 265234) Mr. Fischer, in spite of his unsatisfactory letter to Mr. Cachalia which we reproduce this week, has seen the error of his ways and actually himself moved amendments which, in his tele graphic and other communications, he evinced no desire to do.
('13', 135, 2, 5, 265481) The amendments include the restoration of the existing rights of inter pro vincial migration under the Cape and the Natal laws, also of the rights of domiciled Indians whose right to return after three years’ absence was threatened.
('13', 135, 2, 6, 265714) The exact effect of the amendments it is impossible to ascertain unless we have the full text thereof before us.
('13', 135, 2, 7, 265827) Mr. Alexander, who has been working so disinterestedly and zealously for all causes which are neglected or unpopular owing to the colour prejudice, moved a reasonable amendment which would probably have met our demand on the marriage law, and was met with a fishy and misleading reply from the Minister, although Mr. Chaplin supported Mr. Alexander in a well informed speech.
('13', 135, 2, 8, 266203) The Minister threw dust in the eyes of the Members by stating that we had declined to accept a Marriage Officer as we wanted polygamy recognized in South Africa.
('13', 135, 2, 9, 266365) It has been made perfectly clear that the Searle judgment invalidates every non Christian Indian marriage if it is not registered.
('13', 135, 2, 10, 266496) No appointment of a Marriage Officer can meet this difficulty unless Indians are to be expected to register existing marriages and thus impliedly admit their illegality prior to registration—a position which no Indian would humiliate himself by accepting.
('13', 135, 2, 11, 266752) Nor would such appointment meet the difficulty of wives who may come from India.
('13', 135, 2, 12, 266833) The Transvaal Marriage Law provides for legal recognition of European marriages, no matter how celebrated in Europe in the following terms:
('13', 135, 3, 13, 266973) All marriages entered into outside this state by persons of whom one or both were not at the time of entering into such marriage resident within this state shall be recognized and considered to be equally valid in this state as in the country where such marriages shall have been solemnized, and should the
('13', 136, 0, 1, 267280) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 137
('13', 136, 1, 2, 267327) legality of such marriages be questioned by any heirsor other interested parties, the same may be proved in any court of law by producing the marriage registers or certificates, if it should be customary to keep such registers in such country, or to grant certificates thereof, or by producing duly authenti cated copies thereof, or by witnesses, or any other means of proof admissible by law in all other ordinary cases.
('13', 136, 2, 3, 267749) Presumably, such marriages may, therefore, well be even polygamous; they may be performed according to any rites.
('13', 136, 2, 4, 267863) Why should not the same recognition be vouchsafed to Indian marriages?
('13', 136, 2, 5, 267934) Moreover, Mr. Fischer has evidently not studied Mr. Justice Gardiner’s recent judgment.
('13', 136, 2, 6, 268022) According to that judgment, an Indian wife, unless her marriage is registered, is not exempt from liability to give evidence against her husband.
('13', 136, 2, 7, 268168) Here, at least, there was not even a suspicion of the question of polygamy arising.
('13', 136, 2, 8, 268252) But the fact is that Mr. Fischer does not scruple as to how he misleads the House when he has to deal with an awkward situation.
('13', 136, 2, 9, 268381) So it may be that the Immigration Bill now in Committee may come out of it satisfying all our demands but the one about marriage.
('13', 136, 2, 10, 268511) Mr. Fischer proposes to deal with the marriage difficulty administratively.
('13', 136, 2, 11, 268587) In the words of The Natal Mercury parliamentary correspondent, “the objection to the administrative solution is, of course, that it reduces the title of the domiciled Indian to import a wife from a right to a favour—one, moreover, which is dependent on the discretion or caprice of an official”.
('13', 136, 2, 12, 268883) We warn Mr. Fischer that, even if this question is the only one left unsolved, revival of passive resistance is a certainty.

('13', 137, 0, 1, 269034) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 137, 1, 2, 269076) 92. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XXI]
('13', 137, 2, 3, 269118) 3. EARTH CURES
('13', 137, 3, 4, 269133) We have learnt something about water treatments.
('13', 137, 3, 5, 269182) In some cases, earth cures, have shown even more spectacular results.
('13', 137, 3, 6, 269252) Our bodies are made up largely of earth; it is, therefore, not surprising that earth should have an effect on us.
('13', 137, 3, 7, 269366) All people regard earth as something sacred.
('13', 137, 3, 8, 269411) The ground is coated with mud to destroy odours, earth is sprinkled over refuse, dirty hands are cleansed with earth, the private parts can also be wiped clean with earth.
('13', 137, 3, 9, 269583) Yogis coat their bodies with mud.
('13', 137, 3, 10, 269617) The original inhabitants of this country [Africa] apply mud to boils.
('13', 137, 3, 11, 269687) We filter water through sand or earth in order to purify it.
('13', 137, 3, 12, 269748) Finally, dead bodies buried in earth will not pollute the air.
('13', 137, 3, 13, 269811) Such, we observe, is the undoubted excellence of earth.
('13', 137, 3, 14, 269867) From this we may make a fair guess that earth, probably, has some highly beneficial qualities peculiar to itself.
('13', 137, 3, 15, 269981) Just as Kuhne gave much thought to water and said many useful things about it, another German named Juste has written about earth.
('13', 137, 3, 16, 270112) He goes to the extent of saying that even incurable diseases may yield to earth treatment.
('13', 137, 3, 17, 270203) He reports how once, in a neighbouring village, a man bitten by a snake and even given up as dead by many was brought to him on someone’s advice.
('13', 137, 3, 18, 270349) Juste placed him under earth and the man soon regained consciousness.
('13', 137, 3, 19, 270419) This is not an impossible thing to have happened.
('13', 137, 3, 20, 270469) Juste had no reason to tell a lie.
('13', 137, 3, 21, 270504) It is obvious that great heat will be generated in anyone buried under earth.
('13', 137, 3, 22, 270582) We have no means of discovering how the invisible bacteria in the earth act upon the body; it does seem, however, that earth has the power to absorb poisons.
('13', 137, 3, 23, 270740) By citing Juste’s illustration, it is not of course intended to suggest that every case of snake bite can be cured by earth treatment, but it should certainly be tried on such occasions.
('13', 137, 3, 24, 270927) The suggestion that earth should be used for bee and scorpion stings is easier to accept.
('13', 137, 3, 25, 271017) I have myself tried it on such stings and found that immediate relief followed.
('13', 137, 3, 26, 271097) For this purpose, a stiff paste made of earth soaked in cold water is applied on the affected part, which is then bandaged.
('13', 138, 0, 1, 271221) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 139
('13', 138, 1, 2, 271268) The illustrations that follow are from my personal experience.
('13', 138, 1, 3, 271331) A patient suffering from dysentery was cured in two or three days by the application of a mud pack to his abdomen.
('13', 138, 1, 4, 271446) Immediate relief has been obtained by this method in cases of headache.
('13', 138, 1, 5, 271518) Inflammation of the eyes is cured by placing a mud pack just over the affected eyes.
('13', 138, 1, 6, 271603) Swelling brought about by blows is relieved.
('13', 138, 1, 7, 271648) For a number of years I could keep well only if I took fruit salt, etc.
('13', 138, 1, 8, 271720) I learnt of the efficacy of earth treatment in 1904, since when I have never had to take fruit salt.
('13', 138, 1, 9, 271821) For anyone suffering from constipation, the application of mud packs to the abdomen is found to be highly beneficial.
('13', 138, 1, 10, 271939) Stomach ache also is relieved in this way.
('13', 138, 1, 11, 271982) Diarrhoea can also be cured by a mud pack.
('13', 138, 1, 12, 272025) High fever is reduced in an hour or two by tying mud packs to the stomach and the forehead.
('13', 138, 1, 13, 272117) Boils, the itch, eczema, etc., often yield to treatment by mud pack.
('13', 138, 1, 14, 272186) However, once pus is formed in the boils, mud packs are found to be of little use.
('13', 138, 1, 15, 272269) In the case of burns, the immediate application of mud pack reduces pain and prevents swelling.
('13', 138, 1, 16, 272365) Piles yield to the mud pack.
('13', 138, 1, 17, 272394) As a result of frost, the hand and feet often become red and swollen.
('13', 138, 1, 18, 272464) Mud packs are a sure remedy for this condition.
('13', 138, 1, 19, 272512) Mud has been found to be good for eczema.
('13', 138, 1, 20, 272554) For pain in the joints, the application of mud brings immediate relief.
('13', 138, 1, 21, 272626) From these numerous experiments with mud packs, I have come to the conclusion that as a house hold remedy mud is invaluable.
('13', 138, 1, 22, 272751) Every kind of earth is not equally efficacious.
('13', 138, 1, 23, 272799) Red earth has been found to be particularly effective.
('13', 138, 1, 24, 272854) The earth to be used should always be dug out from a clean spot.
('13', 138, 1, 25, 272919) Earth containing a mixture of dung, etc., should not be used.
('13', 138, 1, 26, 272981) It should not be excessively sticky.
('13', 138, 1, 27, 273018) Earth which is partly sandy and partly sticky is excellent.
('13', 138, 1, 28, 273078) It should be altogether free from grass or roots.
('13', 138, 1, 29, 273128) It is sometimes advisable to strain the earth through a fine sieve.
('13', 138, 1, 30, 273196) It must always be mixed with cold water and the paste should be of the consistency of dough.
('13', 138, 1, 31, 273289) It should normally be placed in a clean unstarched piece of cloth and applied like a poultice to the affected part.
('13', 138, 1, 32, 273405) The pack should be removed before the mud is about to dry up.
('13', 138, 1, 33, 273467) A pack usually lasts for two or three hours.
('13', 138, 1, 34, 273512) Mud from a used pack should not be used again.
('13', 138, 1, 35, 273559) The cloth, however, may be used after washing, provided there was no pus on it.
('13', 138, 1, 36, 273639) When mud is applied to the abdomen, a warm cloth should be placed over the pack and then the whole thing tied with a bandage.
('13', 139, 0, 1, 273765) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 139, 1, 2, 273807) One should have a tin of earth handy so that it can be used whenever necessary and one does not have to go hunting for it in emergency.
('13', 139, 1, 3, 273943) In case of scorpion stings, etc., the earlier the mud is applied the better.

('13', 152, 2, 3, 289468) [If there is no God, how can there be moksha?
('13', 152, 2, 4, 289514) What is the meaning of moksha?] 1
('13', 152, 3, 5, 289548) To ask how there can be moksha if there is no God is to fail to understand moksha.
('13', 152, 3, 6, 289631) We can grasp only a part of the meaning of moksha; the rest must be experienced; it cannot be put into words.
('13', 152, 3, 7, 289741) We have no organs with which to describe it.
('13', 152, 3, 8, 289786) In so far as we can understand, it means deliverance from having to assume an endless succession of various bodies, and from the resultant suffering.
('13', 152, 3, 9, 289936) There is no need, however, to deny the existence of God.
('13', 152, 3, 10, 289993) We may try to define God in accordance with the limits of our knowledge.
('13', 152, 3, 11, 290066) At any rate, God is no dispenser of rewards and punishments, nor is He an active agent.
('13', 152, 3, 12, 290154) But, if one atman 2 can be conceived after the embodied atmans have become free, it is God.
('13', 152, 3, 13, 290246) He is no material thing, but pure consciousness.
('13', 152, 3, 14, 290295) This is also the view ofthe advaitavadins 3. At no time and in no circumstances do we need a kinglike God.
('13', 152, 3, 15, 290402) By thinking that we do, we put a limit to the power of the atman, which is infinite.
('13', 152, 4, 16, 290487) 2. The same distorted meanings, and as many of them, have been and are being read in the Bible as in any other holy book.
('13', 152, 4, 17, 290609) Those who level charges against Tolstoy are ignorant.
('13', 152, 4, 18, 290663) I do not know the truth about Marie Corelli 4. But to describe her as a witch is sheer ignorance.
('13', 152, 5, 19, 290761) 3. [What should I do if, though I would not injure a cow and have never done so, I am attacked by one even when I am not in her way?
('13', 152, 5, 20, 290894) What could be the reason for my being thus attacked?]
('13', 152, 6, 21, 290948) If we are attacked by a cow, it must be because we fear cows and other creatures and so the fault is ours.
('13', 152, 6, 22, 291055) All fear is of the nature of a moral weakness and, so long as we are subject to it, we shall always have to face such misfortunes.
('13', 152, 6, 23, 291186) While we fear cows, we should take care not to stand in the way of any.
('13', 152, 6, 24, 291258) If accidentally we find ourselves doing so, we should put up with the injuries.
('13', 152, 6, 25, 291338) By hitting the cow, we shall do
('13', 152, 7, 26, 291370) 1 The question have been supplied from Mahatma Gandhijina Patro.
('13', 152, 7, 27, 291435) 2 The Self, not identifiable with any aspect of human individuality 3 Those who hold the view that the atman, the Self in man, is not distinct from the Brahman, the Absolute 4 (1864 1924); celebrated novelist

('13', 153, 1, 2, 291686) no service to ourselves or to her.
('13', 153, 2, 3, 291721) 4. [How can one say that a tiger will not kill a man living in his den without fear?]
('13', 153, 3, 4, 291807) A tiger will never eat up a man who, on occasion, lives in his den without any fear whatever.
('13', 153, 3, 5, 291901) In what circumstances he might do so, would need to be considered.
('13', 153, 4, 6, 291968) 5. I do not in the least approve of the European custom in regard to marriages.
('13', 153, 4, 7, 292048) When a young man is to be married, wisdom lies in the parents choosing [the bride].
('13', 153, 4, 8, 292132) This is true for any young man, even a man of 25 or older.
('13', 153, 4, 9, 292191) Of course, the parents will consult him.
('13', 153, 5, 10, 292232) 6. [Did or did not Dharmaraja 1 commit a sin in declaring that Ashvatthama was killed?
('13', 153, 5, 11, 292319) Why did Lord Krishna advise him to say this?]
('13', 153, 6, 12, 292365) The only lesson I draw is that even a Dharmaraja may stumble, so that we too should be on our guard.
('13', 153, 6, 13, 292466) If we believe that a Shri Krishna in the body advised a Yudhisthira in the body, there is no harm in conceding that Shri Krishna was not perfect.
('13', 153, 6, 14, 292612) If we look upon Shri Krishna as the Supreme Being, the entire episode will have to be interpreted symbolically.
('13', 153, 6, 15, 292724) One will then read in it a meaning which accords with one’s moral principles.
('13', 153, 6, 16, 292802) The shastras 2 need not be regarded as infallible.
('13', 153, 6, 17, 292853) We will never go wrong if, having got hold of the inviolable principles of morality, we interpret the shastras in the light of these principles and then are guided by them.
('13', 153, 7, 18, 293026) 7. [Is it necessary that there should be only one religion for the whole world?]
('13', 153, 8, 19, 293107) Personally, I think the world as a whole will never have, and need not have, a single religion.
('13', 153, 9, 20, 293203) 8. There is no such rule that all wholesome foods can be taken irrespective of one’s condition.
('13', 153, 9, 21, 293299) Food which is wholesome for a labourer cannot be so for a tubercular patient.
('13', 153, 9, 22, 293377) I have no more time now, but this answers one of your letters.
('13', 153, 10, 23, 293440) 1 In the battle of Kurukshetra, Yudhishthira, eldest of the Pandava heroes in the Mahabharata and known for his absolute truthfulness, was prevailed upon to say within Dronacharya’s hearing: “Ashvatthama is killed.” Ashvatthama was the name of Dronacharya’s son and also that of an elephant.

('13', 154, 5, 7, 294260) 105. THE OUTLOOK
('13', 154, 6, 8, 294277) It is difficult to state definitely the position that now faces our countrymen under Mr. Fischer’s Bill.
('13', 154, 6, 9, 294382) It must be admitted that some amendments (we refuse to call them concessions) in the right direction have, undoubtedly, been made.
('13', 154, 6, 10, 294513) But much more must be done if there is to be no revival of passive resistance, and if there is to be even a bare fulfilment of the terms of the provisional settlement of 1911. Not a single existing right can be surrendered.
('13', 154, 6, 11, 294737) Passive resisters may not— dare not—buy peace and freedom from imprisonment at the cost of the rights of others.
('13', 154, 6, 12, 294850) And yet the right of South Africa born Indians to enter the Cape, which they possess today in virtue of the Cape Immigration Act of 1906, is being taken away by the Bill.
('13', 154, 6, 13, 295021) South Africa born Indians, i.e., in practice, the Natal born Indians, are not pining to go to the Cape.
('13', 154, 6, 14, 295125) They rarely evinced any such desire throughout all these years.
('13', 154, 6, 15, 295189) But they will certainly not give up on that account the right they possess of being able to enter the Cape.
('13', 154, 6, 16, 295297) Nor can passive resisters be party to a Bill which deprives them of such a right.
('13', 154, 6, 17, 295379) That Mr. Fischer has accepted the marriage amendment, moved by Mr. Advocate Alexander, shows, let us assume, a desire on his part to meet us on the point.
('13', 154, 6, 18, 295534) But, through no fault of Mr. Alexander’s, the amendment has a fatal defect in it.
('13', 154, 6, 19, 295616) It requires re registration at the place of celebration.
('13', 154, 6, 20, 295673) Mr. Alexander does not know that there is no system of registration of marriages in India.
('13', 154, 6, 21, 295764) It is, therefore, not pos sible to produce registration certificates.
('13', 154, 6, 22, 295834) This impossible requirement makes the amendment useless for the very purpose for which it is
('13', 155, 0, 1, 295927) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 155, 1, 2, 295969) intended.
('13', 155, 1, 3, 295979) Nor is registration necessary as a safeguard against the intro duction of undesirable women.
('13', 155, 1, 4, 296072) In the first place, the amendment requires the marriages to be celebrated in accordance with the faiths of the respective parties.
('13', 155, 1, 5, 296203) Indian marriages are accompanied with great solemnity and elaborate ceremonial, lasting for days, and in some cases even months.
('13', 155, 1, 6, 296332) Indeed, there is much greater publicity and cere monial about ordinary Indian marriages than there is in the publi cation of banns that precede European Christian marriages.
('13', 155, 1, 7, 296506) This in itself acts as a perfect safeguard better than any system of registration that could be devised.
('13', 155, 1, 8, 296611) In the second place, it is a well known fact that there is hardly a case on record during the past thirty years or more of an undesirable Indian woman having been introduced, although Indian women have entered until lately, on the mere verbal statement of their husbands.
('13', 155, 1, 9, 296883) It should, therefore, cause no difficulty to remove the registration clause during the progress of the Bill in the Senate.
('13', 155, 1, 10, 297006) And if this marriage question is settled, and no other existing rights are taken away, and if the Free State difficulty is satisfactorily solved, there will remain the one question of the existing right of the South Africa born Indians.
('13', 155, 1, 11, 297243) We can only hope that the Senate will rise to the occasion, the Government will see the necessity of fulfilling a solemn compact, and that this right will be restored.
('13', 155, 1, 12, 297411) But, if it is not, passive resisters will fight, we have no doubt, on that single issue.
('13', 155, 2, 13, 297500) Indian Opinion, 31 5 1913
('13', 156, 0, 1, 297526) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 157
('13', 156, 1, 2, 297573) 106. MUNIEN’S CASE1
('13', 156, 2, 3, 297593) The evidence in this case and the cruel sentence passed by the Verulam Magistrate were reported by us a fortnight ago in these columns.
('13', 156, 2, 4, 297729) Thanks to the sympathy of Sir David Hunter, the case became the subject matter of a question by him in the House of Assembly.
('13', 156, 2, 5, 297855) Mr. Sauer gave a chill, unsympathetic and haughty reply to Sir David’s very pertinent question.
('13', 156, 2, 6, 297951) Readers can see elsewhere both the question and the answer, and judge for themselves.
('13', 156, 2, 7, 298037) It is plain to us that Mr. Sauer gave the answer he did because the matter was one that concerned only a poor, neglected ex indentured man, belonging to a race that is unrepresented in the House that Mr. Sauer and his colleagues dominate, and that is labouring under a prejudice which makes it possible for anybody to heap insults upon it with impunity.
('13', 156, 2, 8, 298391) Had the case been that of a European, Mr. Sauer would not have dared in a most careless manner to shirk inquiry, profess and glory in his ignorance of the case and consider Magistrates’ decisions above criticism by the Legislature, which, after all, is the body finally responsible for the well being of the meanest subject of the State.
('13', 156, 2, 9, 298729) But truly does pride go before destruction and haughtiness before a fall.
('13', 156, 2, 10, 298803) Hardly had Mr. Sauer finished his heartless reply when Justice Hathorn began his review of the Magistrate’s action and considered it to be so irregular and illegal that he quashed the conviction against Munien and awarded him costs of appeal.
('13', 156, 2, 11, 299046) The Magistrate, who was more jealous of obedience to his orders than of the welfare of those who had the misfortune to appear before him, gave it as a reason for his vindictive judgment that Munien was punished as an example to others, so that his orders might be obeyed by them.
('13', 156, 2, 12, 299326) We suppose Mr. Sauer’s cynicism will permit him even now to defend the Magistrate and his own action in shirking investigation.
('13', 156, 3, 13, 299454) Indian Opinion, 31 5 1913
('13', 156, 4, 14, 299480) 1 Munien, an Indian, was charged for default of payment of £3 tax arrears.
('13', 156, 4, 15, 299555) He was sentenced to 14 days’ imprisonment with hard labour for contempt of court even after the amount due was paid.
('13', 157, 0, 1, 299672) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 157, 1, 2, 299714) 107. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XXII]
('13', 157, 2, 3, 299758) 4. FEVER AND ITS REMEDIES
('13', 157, 3, 4, 299784) Having considered the principal remedies, we shall now turn to a few specific diseases and in the process we shall get some idea of other forms of treatment which do not call for separate chapters.
('13', 157, 3, 5, 299982) We use the term fever for any rise in body temperature but English doctors have distinguished many varieties of it and written big volumes on these, ending up in sheer confusion.
('13', 157, 3, 6, 300161) As shown in these chapters, and according to the popular view of the matter, one remedy is enough for most types of fever.
('13', 157, 3, 7, 300284) I have had experience of a single remedy applied in all cases of fever ranging from simple fever to the bubonic plague and I believe the results have been quite satisfactory.
('13', 157, 3, 8, 300459) In 1904, there was an epidemic of the plague among our people.
('13', 157, 4, 9, 300522) Twenty three persons were attacked by it.
('13', 157, 4, 10, 300564) In twenty four hours, twenty one cases proved fatal and only two could be removed to hospital.
('13', 157, 4, 11, 300659) Of these, one survived and he happened to be the only one who could be treated with the mud pack.
('13', 157, 4, 12, 300757) We cannot, of course, conclude from this that the patient was saved by the earth treatment, but it can at any rate be maintained that the latter did him no harm.
('13', 157, 4, 13, 300919) All the victims had inflammation of the lungs and fever.
('13', 157, 4, 14, 300976) They had become unconscious.
('13', 157, 4, 15, 301005) A mud poultice was applied to the chest of one of them.
('13', 157, 4, 16, 301061) He was bringing up blood and phlegm.
('13', 157, 4, 17, 301098) After taking him to hospital, I learned from the doctor that he had previously been given very little food and that too only milk.
('13', 157, 4, 18, 301229) Fever has its origin generally in some stomach trouble.
('13', 157, 4, 19, 301285) The first step to be taken therefore is fasting.
('13', 157, 4, 20, 301334) The notion that a weak person or one suffering from fever will be weakened by fasting is entirely mistaken.
('13', 157, 4, 21, 301442) We saw in an earlier chapter that only that food is useful which can be digested and converted into blood.
('13', 157, 4, 22, 301549) The rest merely remains in the stomach like a lump of lead, as we have seen in earlier chapters.
('13', 157, 4, 23, 301646) The digestive system of one who has fever becomes extre mely slack.
('13', 157, 4, 24, 301714) The tongue becomes dark or coated and the lips are dry.
('13', 157, 5, 25, 301770) 1 Vide “Plague in Johannesburg”, 9 4 1904.
('13', 158, 0, 1, 301813) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 159
('13', 158, 1, 2, 301860) What can a person digest in such a condition?
('13', 158, 1, 3, 301906) Giving him food is bound to raise his temperature.
('13', 158, 1, 4, 301957) By stopping all intake of food, we give the stomach a chance to do its work.
('13', 158, 1, 5, 302034) The fast, therefore, must be continued for at least a day or longer.
('13', 158, 1, 6, 302103) Kuhne baths should be administered during and after the fast.
('13', 158, 1, 7, 302165) At least two should be taken every day.
('13', 158, 1, 8, 302205) In the intervals between baths, a mud pack should be applied to the abdomen.
('13', 158, 1, 9, 302282) If there is headache or the head feels very hot, a pack should be applied to the head also.
('13', 158, 1, 10, 302374) The patient should be adequately covered but kept in the open air.
('13', 158, 1, 11, 302441) The fast should be broken with orange juice added to warm or cold water.
('13', 158, 1, 12, 302514) Juice should be squeezed out of the orange and strained and then hot or cold water added as required.
('13', 158, 1, 13, 302616) As far as possible, sugar should not be added.
('13', 158, 1, 14, 302663) This mixture of orange juice and water will have an excellent effect.
('13', 158, 1, 15, 302733) If a patient can take lime juice and water without his teeth being set on edge, he should be given that.
('13', 158, 1, 16, 302838) For the next meal he can take half or a whole banana, well mashed.
('13', 158, 1, 17, 302905) One spoon of olive oil and half a spoon of lime juice should be added to the mashed banana and given to the patient after mixing them well.
('13', 158, 1, 18, 303045) If he feels thirsty, he should be given water, which has been boiled and cooled, or lime juice and water.
('13', 158, 1, 19, 303151) Unboiled water should never be given.
('13', 158, 1, 20, 303189) Cold water must always be previously boiled.
('13', 158, 1, 21, 303234) Methods of purifying water have been described in an earlier chapter which should be referred to.
('13', 158, 1, 22, 303332) The patient should wear only a minimum of clothing and this should be frequently changed.
('13', 158, 1, 23, 303422) As he is to be covered with a sheet, very little clothing is necessary with this treatment.
('13', 158, 1, 24, 303514) Some persons suffering even from such a severe illness as typhoid fever have been known to recover and, what is more, they now enjoy excellent health.
('13', 158, 1, 25, 303665) Quinine brings about an apparent cure but the patient suffers from side effects.
('13', 158, 1, 26, 303746) Quinine is believed to be particularly effective for patients suffering from “malaria fever”, but in fact they are rarely found to be entirely free of it, whereas I have seen even malaria patients completely cured by nature treatment.
('13', 158, 1, 27, 303981) Much reliance is placed by others on a milk diet during fever, but my experience has been that milk taken in the early stages of fever does actual harm.
('13', 158, 1, 28, 304134) It is, moreover, difficult to digest.
('13', 158, 1, 29, 304172) If necessary, it should be given along with wheat coffee or boiled with a little quantity of rice flour and water.
('13', 158, 1, 30, 304287) But in cases of obstinate or high
('13', 159, 0, 1, 304321) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 159, 1, 2, 304363) fever, it cannot be given even in this form.
('13', 159, 1, 3, 304408) At such times I have found lime juice mixed in water to be remarkably beneficial.
('13', 159, 1, 4, 304490) When the patient’s tongue has become clear, the banana diet should be started, the banana being prepared in the manner described earlier.
('13', 159, 1, 5, 304628) If the patient is constipated, rather than a purgative he should be given an enema of hot water mixed with borax to clear his bowels.
('13', 159, 1, 6, 304762) Olive oil in the diet will thereafter help to keep the intestines clear.
