('13', 159, 4, 9, 304877) 108. STATEMENT ON IMMIGRATION BILL 1
('13', 159, 5, 10, 304914) [DURBAN, June 2, 1913]
('13', 159, 6, 11, 304937) If the Bill is not amended in several material particulars I feel that a revival of passive resistance is inevitable.
('13', 159, 6, 12, 305055) The provisional settlement of 1911 contains two principal conditions to be fulfilled by the Government, namely, that existing rights should be maintained intact in any legislation that might be passed in order to satisfy the Indian claims, and that Transvaal Act No.
('13', 159, 6, 13, 305322) 2 of 1907, subject to reservation of the rights of minors, should be repealed, and there should be no racial bar introduced in any such legislation.
('13', 159, 6, 14, 305471) Both of these conditions are violated by the Bill even in its amended form.
('13', 159, 6, 15, 305547) Our claim that existing rights should be maintained is fortified by a declaration of the Imperial Government in their despatch dated October 7, 1910, in which it is specially laid down that “any solution (of the Transvaal controversy) which prejudiced or weakened the present position of Indians in the Cape Colony and Natal would not be acceptable to His Majesty’s Government,” and Mr. Harcourt emphasized the point once more in his telegram of February 15, 1911, in discussing the Immigration Bill of that year.
('13', 159, 6, 16, 306061) That existing
('13', 159, 7, 17, 306075) 1 Lord Gladstone, Governor General, sent from Cape Town a copy of this statement to the Secretary of State for the Colonies on June 4. It was also published in the Cape Times, 3 6 1913 and in Indian Opinion, 7 6 1913, along with editorial comments from The Natal Mercury.
('13', 160, 0, 1, 306347) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 161
('13', 160, 1, 2, 306394) rights are jeopardized is clear from a consideration of the following facts:
('13', 160, 2, 3, 306471) South Africa born Indians have, under the present Cape Immigration Act, the unconditional right to enter that Province.
('13', 160, 2, 4, 306591) This right is now being taken away.
('13', 160, 2, 5, 306627) If the Bill is not adequately amended, this deprivation will constitute a very serious grievance, and passive resisters will lose all title to respect if, for the sake of avoiding the hardships of gaol or any other penalty to which they might be liable, they were to accept such a bargain.
('13', 160, 2, 6, 306917) I do not know what other fatal defects there may be in the Bill as amended.
('13', 160, 2, 7, 306993) The question of domicile, for instance, may have been left in a most unsatisfactory position, and so also that of the right of appeal to the Supreme Court.
('13', 160, 3, 8, 307149) The marriage amendment moved by Mr. Alexander, and accep ted by the Minister will, I fear, frustrate the very purpose with which Mr. Alexander moved it in such a public spirited manner.
('13', 160, 3, 9, 307335) It requires the fulfilment of an impossible condition, namely, registration of marriage at the place of its celebration, in addition to proof of due performance of religious rites.
('13', 160, 3, 10, 307516) There is, however, no system of State registration of marriage in India.
('13', 160, 3, 11, 307589) As a matter of fact, a recent arrival from India endeavoured to obtain a certificate of marriage from a magistrate at Bombay, who refused to issue it, on the ground that he was not authorized by law to do so.
('13', 160, 3, 12, 307798) Nor is this requirement necessary for any purpose whatsoever.
('13', 160, 3, 13, 307860) The religious celebration is accompanied by so much solemnity, ceremonial and publicity, that it is the best possible safeguard against collusive connexions.
('13', 160, 3, 14, 308018) Finally, the strictness with which the marriage question has been dealt with by the Govern ment is quite unwarranted by past experience.
('13', 160, 3, 15, 308155) During my 20 years’ experience in South Africa, I have never known of the entry under the Immigration Law of a single Indian woman belonging to the unde sirable class.
('13', 160, 4, 16, 308323) The second condition of the settlement appears also to have been broken by the Government in that a declaration is to be required of such Indian immigrants as may possibly be admitted into the Free State, it not being required of European immigrants.
('13', 160, 4, 17, 308574) The declaration in question will be highly offensive and wantonly irritating, because, in the case of an educated Indian, who alone could enter that Province,
('13', 161, 0, 1, 308733) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 161, 1, 2, 308775) it would be wholly unnecessary.
('13', 161, 1, 3, 308807) It is merely a statement that the declarant shall not hold landed property, trade, or farm there, disabilities to which he is subject whether he makes the declaration or not.
('13', 161, 1, 4, 308982) It will be remembered that it was the Free State difficulty that came in the way of a permanent settlement on the two previous occasions.
('13', 161, 1, 5, 309120) 1 Mr. Fischer cannot now settle the controversy by ignoring it as if it were not of the most vital importance.
('13', 161, 1, 6, 309231) One can only hope that the Senate will perform its duty as a vigilance chamber and the guardian of unrepresented interests, by insisting upon amendment of the measure, so as to fulfil both the letter and the spirit of the provisi onal settlement.

('13', 162, 6, 7, 310583) 110. THE BILL
('13', 162, 7, 8, 310597) The correspondence between Mr. Fischer and Mr. Gandhi, published elsewhere, 1 shows clearly that Mr. Fischer had fully intended to deprive us of almost every right that we have been enjoying under the existing Immigration Laws of the different Provinces.
('13', 162, 7, 9, 310852) The only right that was to be left to us was for those, who are at present physically residing in the respective Provinces, to live confined in their Provinces with little chance of being able to re enter if they left their Province.
('13', 162, 7, 10, 311086) Thanks, however, to the stubborn opposition from the Unionist Members and the fear of passive resistance, some slight modifications have been introduced into the measure.
('13', 162, 7, 11, 311257) We wish that the Unionist Members had retained their firmness to the last.
('13', 162, 7, 12, 311332) But Mr. Fischer successfully put them off the scent by telling them that the Imperial Government had already approved of the will.
('13', 162, 7, 13, 311463) But the correspondence makes it clear that, in spite of the amendments, the Bill offers no settlement of the Indian question, that it leaves many big gaps and that, if they are not filled up, passive resistance is sure to revive.
('13', 162, 7, 14, 311693) Mr. Fischer must consider us to be a perfectly stupid community, if he thinks that, with vested rights taken away, we are going to accept his measure.
('13', 162, 7, 15, 311844) The threat to withdraw the marriage amendment, if we do not accept his measure, is unworthy of a responsible Minister.
('13', 162, 7, 16, 311963) Either the amendment is intended to remedy a fault or it is useless.
('13', 162, 7, 17, 312032) If it is so intended, the attitude of the community cannot affect the necessity of the amendment.
('13', 162, 7, 18, 312130) But it is perfectly true that the amendment is quite useless and it would be more honest to tell us that our marriages are not to be recognized than
('13', 162, 8, 19, 312279) 1 Vide letters and telegrams to the Minister and the Secretary for the Interior, 1 4 1913; 9 4 1913; 15 4 1913; 27 5 1913; 27 5 1913 & 30 5 1913.
('13', 163, 0, 1, 312425) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 163, 1, 2, 312467) to mislead us, by an ineffective amendment, into believing that our wishes are being respected.
('13', 163, 1, 3, 312563) This marriage difficulty, however, is only one of the many defects in the Bill.
('13', 163, 1, 4, 312643) And, unless the Senate is prepared to adopt heroic measures, the Bill, which is supposed to have been designed to satisfy passive resisters, will simply compel them to revive the struggle, cost what it may.

('13', 163, 3, 6, 312875) 111. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XXIII]
('13', 163, 4, 7, 312920) 5. CONSTIPATION, SPRUE, DYSENTERY, PILES
('13', 163, 5, 8, 312961) It will certainly appear strange to most readers that four diseases are considered together in this chapter.
('13', 163, 5, 9, 313070) But they are, in fact, closely related to one another and our cures for them, which require no medicines, are common to all.
('13', 163, 5, 10, 313195) When the intestines are heavily loaded, some people, because of their peculiar constitution, become constipated.
('13', 163, 5, 11, 313308) That is, they do not pass stools regularly and in proper quantity and have to strain.
('13', 163, 5, 12, 313394) If this goes on for a long time, they begin to pass blood.
('13', 163, 5, 13, 313453) This results sometimes in the rectum becoming flaccid and sometimes in piles.
('13', 163, 5, 14, 313531) Still others suddenly develop diarrhoea.
('13', 163, 5, 15, 313572) If the motions are numerous continuing during all hours at short intervals and in small quantities, the condition is known as sprue.
('13', 163, 5, 16, 313705) Some have dysentery in which mucus is passed and there is griping.
('13', 163, 6, 17, 313772) All these patients suffer from lack of appetite, look pale, become weak, have offensive breath and a coated tongue.
('13', 163, 6, 18, 313888) Some have headaches or develop other ailments.
('13', 163, 6, 19, 313935) Constipation is so common that hundreds of medicines and powders have been invented for it.
('13', 163, 6, 20, 314027) Mother Seagle’s Syrup, fruit salt, etc., are intended chiefly to cureconstipation and thousands come to harm through them, since they are apparently effective.
('13', 163, 6, 21, 314187) Any ordinary hakim or doctor will tell us that the root cause of constipation is indigestion and will also add that constipation will disappear if the causes of indigestion are removed.
('13', 163, 6, 22, 314373) The more honest among us freely admit that patients want to shake off the disease without shaking off their own bad habits, and hence they are driven to
('13', 164, 0, 1, 314526) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 165
('13', 164, 1, 2, 314573) prescribing powders and decoctions.
('13', 164, 1, 3, 314609) Advertisements nowadays actu ally announce that those who take the medicines in question will not need to change their diet or other habits; they will be cured by the medicine alone!
('13', 164, 1, 4, 314792) Those who have been following these chapters must have realized that such advertisements are fraudulent.
('13', 164, 1, 5, 314897) The effect pro duced by a purgative is always bad.
('13', 164, 1, 6, 314948) Though it may remove constipa tion, it will, however mild it be, give rise to other poisons in the body.
('13', 164, 1, 7, 315053) Having taken a purge, if one proceeds to change one’s bad habits so that purgatives will not again be necessary, one may perhaps derive some benefit from it.
('13', 164, 1, 8, 315211) Those, however, who continue with their bad habits arc bound to get some other ailment even if they are cured of constipation or sprue.
('13', 164, 2, 9, 315347) We shall now consider remedies for these four diseases.
('13', 164, 2, 10, 315403) The first is for the patient to reduce his diet.
('13', 164, 2, 11, 315452) Heavy foods, those prepared with excessive ghee, sugar and milk kept boiling over a long time, should be eschewed.
('13', 164, 2, 12, 315567) If he has any addictions like smoking, drinking, hemp taking, etc., he must give them up.
('13', 164, 2, 13, 315657) If he is in the habit of eating white bread, he should give it up.
('13', 164, 2, 14, 315724) Tea, coffee and cocoa should be given up.
('13', 164, 2, 15, 315766) The diet should consist mainly of fresh fruits, together with olive oil.
('13', 164, 3, 16, 315839) Treatment should begin with a 36 hour fast.
('13', 164, 3, 17, 315883) During this time and later, mud packs should be applied to the abdomen on retiring and one or two Kuhne baths should be taken daily.
('13', 164, 3, 18, 316016) The patient should walk at least two hours a day.
('13', 164, 3, 19, 316066) Anyone following this regimen is bound to benefit.
('13', 164, 3, 20, 316117) I have actually seen severe cases of diarrhoea, constipation, dysentery, and also of severe and chronic piles, cured in this way.
('13', 164, 3, 21, 316247) With regard to piles, it is necessary to insist that, as long as mucus or blood is being passed, no food is to be taken.
('13', 164, 3, 22, 316368) When the patient is in a position to take food, he should have orange juice filtered and added to boiling water.
('13', 164, 3, 23, 316481) In this way, the worst case of dysentery can be cured in the shortest time without harming the patient.
('13', 164, 3, 24, 316585) If dysentery is accompanied by severe griping, the abdomen should be fomented with a bottle filled with very hot water or with a heated brick.
('13', 164, 3, 25, 316728) As in all illnesses, the patient needs fresh air here too.
('13', 164, 4, 26, 316787) The following fruits are regarded as especially beneficial in constipation: figs, French plums, muscatel raisins, large grapes, black
('13', 165, 0, 1, 316921) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 165, 1, 2, 316963) grapes, green grapes and oranges.
('13', 165, 1, 3, 316997) One should not, however, imagine from this that these fruits should be eaten even when one is not hungry.
('13', 165, 1, 4, 317103) When there is griping or a bad taste in the mouth, even these fruits can be harmful.
('13', 165, 1, 5, 317188) When food is needed, these fruits will be specially beneficial in constipation, that is all that the statement above should be understood to mean.
('13', 165, 2, 6, 317335) [From Gujarati]

('13', 167, 3, 10, 321093) If, therefore, now the tax is not removed from both males and females, the presumption will be that the Natal members do not desire to see men released from the burden.

('13', 167, 3, 12, 321331) I can recall many a Town Hall meeting held for less important purposes.
('13', 167, 3, 13, 321403) I am sure that Natal holds its honour dearer than the navigability of its beautiful harbour.

('13', 168, 5, 15, 324238) The Free State difficulty has been, since 1911, a racial dif

('13', 169, 0, 1, 324407) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 169, 1, 2, 324449) ficulty.
('13', 169, 1, 3, 324458) Mr. Fischer has not surmounted it, and he says distinctly in his telegram that he will meet it by administrative action.
('13', 169, 1, 4, 324579) If such a proposal could have been accepted in 1911, the Bill of that year would have become law, but it could not be then and it cannot be now.
('13', 169, 1, 5, 324724) The Union Government, if they have any sense of honour, are bound to remove the racial inequality before the law, and in any measure passed to bring about that end, they are bound not to disturb existing rights.
('13', 169, 1, 6, 324936) They have failed to carry out either part of the compact.
('13', 169, 1, 7, 324994) Mr. Harcourt seems also to be under the impression that the few amendments that have been made in the Bill are due to the initiative of the Union Government or their desire to do justice.

('13', 169, 1, 9, 325306) Indeed, had the Opposition been only a little stronger and more consistent we should now have a law in spite of the Union Government, that would have made final the provisional settlement of 1911. ('13', 169, 1, 10, 325802) The Union Government may be, indeed are, indifferent whether it is or is not, but I have faith enough in this sovereign remedy for all the ills that the civic and political life of a community is heir to know that, if we are true to ourselves, it must succeed.The latest proposal of the Government to remove the £3 tax only from women demonstrates beyond doubt their consistently hostile attitude and bad faith towards the Indian community.

('13', 170, 1, 2, 326316) 115. THE BILL
('13', 170, 2, 3, 326330) The Bill may now become the law of the land any moment and Indians may find themselves deprived on the 1st August and, thereafter, of several rights which they have hitherto enjoyed.
('13', 170, 2, 4, 326513) It is not possible to speak with certainty of the amendments so far carried or of the full effect of the Bill.
('13', 170, 2, 5, 326624) Mr. W. P. Schreiner, who put up a strenuous fight on our behalf, was able to secure a modification of the marriage amendment and, in spite of Mr. Fischer’s threat that he would not only not withdraw the registration clause but that if we did not accept the Bill in full, he might take out the whole amendment and restore the original draft, the registration clause seems to have been omitted.
('13', 170, 2, 6, 327017) What the new clause in its latest form is one cannot judge without having the full text.
('13', 170, 3, 7, 327106) But even if the marriage difficulty is over, there is no doubt that the Bill leaves much that is offensive enough to compel passive resisters to resist it.
('13', 170, 3, 8, 327262) It appears to leave the question of jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in a very unsatisfactory state.
('13', 170, 3, 9, 327364) It deprives Indians resident in Natal of the usual facility with which they have hitherto been able to re enter it.
('13', 170, 3, 10, 327480) They may not now, as of yore, be able to do so on the strength of three years’ previous residence in Natal.
('13', 170, 3, 11, 327588) Nor may indentured Indians who may have paid the £3 tax be allowed to claim the right of residence therein.
('13', 170, 3, 12, 327696) South Africa born Indians may not now enter the Cape under the Cape Act.
('13', 170, 3, 13, 327769) The Free State difficulty remains as it was before.
('13', 170, 3, 14, 327821) It therefore appears that this is a Bill, resistance to which is a duty and compliance a crime.
('13', 170, 4, 15, 327917) It is remarkable, however, that the Bill, though avowedly an anti Indian Bill, had a stormy passage through both the Houses and that concessions, such as they are, were wrung from an unwilling and hard hearted Minister.
('13', 170, 4, 16, 328137) In the Senate, on two occasions the voting on certain clauses resulted in a tie.
('13', 170, 4, 17, 328218) This is a good augury for the future and speaks well for the effect of passive resistance.
('13', 170, 4, 18, 328309) It has quickened the spirit of in inquiry into Indian matters on the part of a large number of members.
('13', 170, 5, 19, 328413) But, if some members of the Union Parliament have spoken
('13', 171, 0, 1, 328470) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 171, 1, 2, 328512) zealously in our behalf, the Imperial Government seem to have neglected us entirely and wholly accepted the Union Government’s view.
('13', 171, 1, 3, 328645) Indeed, so far as they are concerned, they appear, incredible as it may seem, to have accepted the Bill as it was originally published, thus going back upon their own despatches.
('13', 171, 1, 4, 328824) If Mr. Harcourt is correctly reported, he appears to believe that the Union Government are desirous of doing us full justice.
('13', 171, 1, 5, 328950) This opinion certainly could not be based upon the original Draft Bill nor upon what happened in Parliament.
('13', 171, 1, 6, 329059) The original draft could not well be more drastic; it was so considered by the South African Press; the attitude of the Minister in charge of the Bill could not well be more hostile.
('13', 171, 2, 7, 329242) But we need not feel sore if the Imperial Government have betrayed us and neglected their trust.
('13', 171, 2, 8, 329339) They are more concerned with pleasing the Union Government who represent an infinitesimal but a boisterous European portion of the Empire, than with pleasing India which, though supposed to be the brightest diadem in the British crown, represents a people who are long suffering and who do not require to be pleased, much less pampered.
('13', 171, 2, 9, 329676) Our final court of appeal must be ourselves.
('13', 171, 2, 10, 329721) If we are true to ourselves, no doubt others will be true to us, as soon as they discover the fact, but no sooner.
('13', 171, 3, 11, 329836) Indian Opinion, 14 6 1913
('13', 172, 0, 1, 329862) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 173
('13', 172, 1, 2, 329909) 116. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XXIV]
('13', 172, 2, 3, 329953) 6. INFECTIOUS DISEASES: SMALLPOX—I
('13', 172, 3, 4, 329988) We have discussed a few things about fever and some other ailments.
('13', 172, 3, 5, 330056) It is not intended in these chapters to go into detail with regard to all diseases.
('13', 172, 3, 6, 330140) Indeed, it is unnecessary to write individually of each disease when both cause and treatment are common to all of them.
('13', 172, 3, 7, 330261) Infectious diseases like smallpox also arise from the same cause and it is not really necessary, therefore, to write separately about them either.
('13', 172, 3, 8, 330408) It will not be wrong, however, to devote one chapter to smallpox.
('13', 172, 3, 9, 330474) An outbreak of smallpox creates such a scare that hundreds of superstitions connected with it are current.
('13', 172, 3, 10, 330581) In India, it is actually ascribed to a particular goddess and countless men and women take vows in order to be cured of the disease.
('13', 172, 3, 11, 330714) Like other illnesses, smallpox arises from polluted blood, which in its turn originates in fever of the intestines.
('13', 172, 3, 12, 330830) The body throws out accumulated poisons by way of eruptions.
('13', 172, 3, 13, 330891) If this view is correct, there is no need whatever to be afraid of smallpox.
('13', 172, 3, 14, 330968) If it was uniformly infectious, then all those who freely touch the body of the smallpox patient would catch the disease.
('13', 172, 3, 15, 331090) But we know that this does not happen.
('13', 172, 3, 16, 331129) There is no need, therefore, to dread smallpox, though, of course, we should take precautions against it.
('13', 172, 3, 17, 331235) We cannot say definitely that it is not infectious.
('13', 172, 3, 18, 331287) If anyone pre disposed to the disease touches a smallpox patient, he will certainly get it.
('13', 172, 3, 19, 331379) That is why, whenever smallpox breaks out, a number of people fall a prey to it.
('13', 172, 3, 20, 331460) Because the infection is caught in this manner through contact, people are infected with cowpox and misled into believing that the cowpox infection will induce smallpox in a mild, harmless form and so prevent an actual attack of smallpox.
('13', 172, 3, 21, 331699) The process consists in first infecting a cow’s udder with smallpox and then introducing the vaccine taken from that part into our body through the skin, in order to induce smallpox in us and thus protect us against an attack in an acute form.
('13', 172, 3, 22, 331943) At first it was believed that one vaccination of this sort would provide life long immunity.
('13', 172, 3, 23, 332036) But on experience it was found that even those who had been so vaccinated
('13', 173, 0, 1, 332110) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 173, 1, 2, 332152) did not remain immune against infection for a very long time.
('13', 173, 1, 3, 332214) It has been concluded, accordingly, that after the lapse of a certain period, it is necessary to repeat vaccination.
('13', 173, 1, 4, 332331) Nowadays, the rule is to vaccinate the entire population wherever an epidemic breaks out, irrespective of whether the people had been previously vaccinated or not.
('13', 173, 1, 5, 332495) One thus comes across persons who have been vaccinated five or six times or even oftener.
('13', 173, 1, 6, 332585) Vaccination seems to be a savage custom.
('13', 173, 1, 7, 332626) It is one of the poisonous superstitions of our times the equal of which is not to be found even among so called primitive societies.
('13', 173, 1, 8, 332760) Its advocates are not satisfied with voluntary vaccination.
('13', 173, 1, 9, 332820) They insist on making it compul sory.
('13', 173, 1, 10, 332858) Those who refuse to take it are prosecuted and awarded harsh penalties.
('13', 173, 1, 11, 332930) Vaccination was invented in 1798. Thus it is not an ancient superstition.
('13', 173, 1, 12, 333004) During this short period, millions of people have been victims of it.
('13', 173, 1, 13, 333074) Those who are vaccinated are presumed to be immune against smallpox, but the presumption is without any sound basis.
('13', 173, 1, 14, 333191) No one can say that they would surely have had a severe attack of the disease if they had not been vaccinated.
('13', 173, 1, 15, 333302) On the contrary, in view of the fact that there have been cases of vaccinated persons being attac ked by smallpox, it certainly cannot be claimed that anyone getting vaccinated will escape the infection.
('13', 173, 1, 16, 333506) Vaccination is a filthy remedy.
('13', 173, 1, 17, 333538) Vaccine from an infected cow is introduced into our bodies; more, even vaccine from an infected human being is used.
('13', 173, 1, 18, 333655) Some persons generally vomit at the sight of the vaccine.
('13', 173, 1, 19, 333713) If it so much as comes into contact with the hand, they wash the hand with soap.
('13', 173, 1, 20, 333794) If we were asked to eat it, we would be nauseated and would pounce upon anyone who might make such a suggestion even in fun.
('13', 173, 1, 21, 333919) And yet scarcely anyone realizes that, when he is vacci nated, he is absorbing a substance which is in reality infected blood.
('13', 173, 1, 22, 334046) It is well known that patients are given medicine or liquid nourishment through the skin and this takes effect more rapidly than if given by mouth.
('13', 173, 1, 23, 334194) What is taken by the mouth is not immediately absorbed into the blood but anything taken through the skin is, and even a small dose acts very quickly.
('13', 173, 1, 24, 334345) From this point of view, the taking of any medicine or nourishment through the skin is the same as eating it.
('13', 173, 1, 25, 334455) Even then, in order to save ourselves from smallpox, we, in effect, eat vaccine.
('13', 173, 1, 26, 334536) It is said cowards die before their death.
('13', 173, 1, 27, 334579) Similarly, from fear
('13', 174, 0, 1, 334600) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 175
('13', 174, 1, 2, 334647) of death or disfigurement by smallpox, we die before our time by getting ourselves vaccinated.
('13', 174, 1, 3, 334742) I personally feel that in taking this vaccine we are guilty of a sacrilege.
('13', 174, 1, 4, 334818) Even meat eaters are forbidden to drink blood, and the flesh and blood of living animals are, I find, prohibited in all circumstances.
('13', 174, 1, 5, 334953) But here blood is taken from a blameless living creature, is cultured, besides, and then fed to us through our skins.
('13', 174, 1, 6, 335071) A religious man would rather get smallpox a thousand times or an early death than take such blood.
('13', 174, 2, 7, 335170) [From Gujarati]

('13', 175, 10, 12, 336571) PHOENIX, NATAL, June 20, 1913
('13', 175, 11, 13, 336601) DEAR MR. GOKHALE,
('13', 175, 12, 14, 336619) The Bill is so bad that passive resistance is a necessity.
('13', 175, 12, 15, 336678) By the time this is in your hands, some of us may be already in gaol.
('13', 175, 12, 16, 336748) I propose to go to Johannesburg next week and from there send a final letter to Mr. Fischer reciting our I objections and asking him to meet them next year.
('13', 175, 12, 17, 336905) If he gives a definite written promise that he would do so, the struggle will be suspended.
('13', 175, 12, 18, 336997) There is very little hope that he would.
('13', 175, 12, 19, 337038) But before I ask fellow passive resisters to embark on what would undoubtedly be a very bitter and prolonged struggle, I want to adopt all legitimate methods that prudence may dictate to avert the misery that must result from a renewal of the struggle.
('13', 175, 12, 20, 337291) These are the defects in the Bill:
('13', 175, 13, 21, 337326) (1) The Free State difficulty appears to remain and therefore

('13', 176, 1, 3, 337834) (2) The existing rights are disturbed in that
('13', 176, 2, 4, 337880) (a) the right of appeal to the Supreme Court is modified,
('13', 176, 3, 5, 337938) (b) the right of the South African Indians to enter the Cape is taken away,
('13', 176, 4, 6, 338014) (c) the right of domicile of ex indentured Indians .
('13', 176, 4, 7, 338067) 1 pay the tax seems to have been taken away,
('13', 176, 5, 8, 338112) (d) the existing marriage position is considerably modified, though the amendment has eased the tension considerably.

('13', 178, 5, 6, 341894) 119. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XXV]
('13', 178, 6, 7, 341937) 6. INFECTIOUS DISEASES [CONTINUED]: SMALLPOX—2
('13', 178, 7, 8, 341984) A number of thoughtful men in England have carried out researches on the harmful effects of vaccination and a big anti vac cination society has been formed.
('13', 178, 7, 9, 342141) Its members refuse vaccination and oppose the law making it compulsory.
('13', 178, 7, 10, 342213) Some have suffered imprison ment in this cause.
('13', 178, 7, 11, 342261) They also advise others against vaccination.
('13', 178, 7, 12, 342306) Many books have been written on the subject and much discussion is being carried on.
('13', 178, 7, 13, 342391) The following are the reasons the opponents of vac cination advance in support of their stand:
('13', 178, 8, 14, 342486) Taking vaccine from a cow’s udder, which in fact belongs to her calf, is itself an act of extreme cruelty to thousands of living creatures.
('13', 178, 8, 15, 342626) This cruelty is no credit to man’s sense of pity and it behoves him, therefore, to forgo any benefit that may accrue from it.
('13', 178, 9, 16, 342752) 2. No benefit is derived from such vaccine.
('13', 178, 9, 17, 342796) On the contrary, taking the vaccine causes other infections.
('13', 178, 9, 18, 342857) The sponsors of this move ment are of the opinion that, since vaccination was introduced, the incidence of other diseases has increased.
('13', 178, 10, 19, 342994) 3. The infection originates in man’s blood, so that the germs of other diseases in the person are likely to be present in the culture and in all the samples of the vaccine.
('13', 178, 11, 20, 343167) 4. Vaccination does not guarantee protection from smallpox.
('13', 178, 11, 21, 343227) Its inventor, Dr. Jenner, had claimed that vaccination at one spot on one arm would provide life long immunity.
('13', 178, 11, 22, 343339) Later, he said
('13', 179, 0, 1, 343354) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 179, 1, 2, 343396) vaccination on both arms would give such immunity.
('13', 179, 1, 3, 343447) Then it came to vaccination on more than one spot on both arms.
('13', 179, 1, 4, 343511) When the disease occurred in spite of this, it was said that immunity could not be guaranteed for more than seven years.
('13', 179, 1, 5, 343632) This period has now been reduced to three years.
('13', 179, 1, 6, 343681) Thus doctors themselves are far from certain in this regard.
('13', 179, 1, 7, 343742) In fact, the idea that one who is vaccinated will never get smallpox is entirely untrue.
('13', 179, 1, 8, 343831) No one can prove that a person who has been vaccinated and has never caught smallpox would have caught the infection if he had not been so vaccinated.
('13', 179, 2, 9, 343982) 5. Finally, they hold that vaccination is a filthy practice and that it is sheer barbarism to imagine that filth can be removed by filth.
('13', 179, 3, 10, 344120) With these and many other arguments and illustrations, the anti vaccination society has been able to exert a great influence on the British public.
('13', 179, 3, 11, 344268) There is a town in England where the majority of the population refuse to be vaccinated and, yet, the incidence of the disease among them is very low.
('13', 179, 3, 12, 344419) Some enthusiastic members of this society have probed carefully into the whole question and have shown that doctors find it in their interest to keep this superstition alive.
('13', 179, 3, 13, 344594) They earn thousands of pounds annually through vaccination.
('13', 179, 3, 14, 344654) Conse quently, either intentionally or otherwise, they are blind to its harmful effects.
('13', 179, 3, 15, 344743) This opinion has been expressed by certain doctors themselves and most of these have strongly opposed vaccination.
('13', 179, 3, 16, 344858) If, then, vaccination is harmful, should we submit to it?
('13', 179, 3, 17, 344916) My personal reply would be a definite “No”.
('13', 179, 3, 18, 344960) There are certain excep tions, however.
('13', 179, 3, 19, 345000) I am certain that no one should get himself vaccinated voluntarily.
('13', 179, 3, 20, 345068) But in all places where we have settled, the law has made vaccination compulsory.
('13', 179, 3, 21, 345150) In this country ([South] Africa), to break the law involves a tremendous risk, for, if we refuse to comply with it, we shall invite on ourselves the charge of wilfully endangering public health, in addition to the many other charges often made against us.
('13', 179, 3, 22, 345406) What should we do in such circumstances?
('13', 179, 3, 23, 345447) If we live where the majority believe in the benefits of vaccination, it becomes something of a duty for us to fall in line with themto avoid a panic among them.
('13', 179, 3, 24, 345609) Those who object to vaccination on religious grounds, in view of the facts I have set out above, must resist it even if they have to stand
('13', 180, 0, 1, 345748) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 181
('13', 180, 1, 2, 345795) alone and must be prepared to suffer the consequences.
('13', 180, 1, 3, 345850) Those who refuse vaccination merely in the belief that they would remain healthier on that account would not be justified in opposing the law in this regard outright.
('13', 180, 1, 4, 346017) Anyone who wants to do so must have made a thorough study of the matter.
('13', 180, 1, 5, 346090) He should be able to convert others to his point of view and should undertake to change public opinion.
('13', 180, 1, 6, 346194) If one cannot do these things, one may not ignore public opinion merely to protect one’s health.
('13', 180, 1, 7, 346291) There are many things which we dislike and yet feel compelled to do out of regard for the society in which we live.
('13', 180, 1, 8, 346407) Personal convenience has to yield to public interest.
('13', 180, 1, 9, 346461) The accepted principle is that only in matters of morality or religion do situations arise in which a man will be justified in standing alone against the opinion of the majority.
('13', 180, 1, 10, 346640) Those, however, who have no belief of their own but are possibly swayed by writings such as the present one and are unwilling to be vaccinated through sheer apathy, should certainly abide by the law.
('13', 180, 1, 11, 346840) Further, those who do not get vaccinated must take pains to study and observe the rules of cleanliness, etc.
('13', 180, 1, 12, 346949) One who does not want smallpox infection [by way of vaccination] and, at the same time, contracts diseases on account of immoral conduct or suffers in other ways by disregarding the rules of hygiene, has no right to oppose vaccination in a country or society in which it is regarded as a means of preserving health.

('13', 182, 1, 2, 348136) 121. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [—XXVI]
('13', 182, 2, 3, 348180) 6. INFECTIOUS DISEASES [CONTINUED]: SMALLPOX—3
('13', 182, 3, 4, 348227) Writing of smallpox, we have so far considered the harmful effects of vaccination.
('13', 182, 3, 5, 348310) We must now study ways of preventing small pox.
('13', 182, 3, 6, 348358) One who faithfully and intelligently observes the rules concer ning fresh air, water and diet described in earlier chapters is in no danger of getting smallpox because his blood will itself contain the antidote against the infection.
('13', 182, 4, 7, 348592) For one who has contracted the disease, the wet sheet pack is a miraculous remedy.
('13', 182, 4, 8, 348675) The pack should be applied to the patient at least three times.
('13', 182, 4, 9, 348739) This will reduce the burning sensation in the body and the sores will subside in a very short time.
('13', 182, 4, 10, 348839) It is not necessary to apply ointment, etc., to the sores.
('13', 182, 4, 11, 348898) If the latter are limited to one or two spots where mud packs can be applied, that also should be done.
('13', 182, 4, 12, 349002) The patient should be given rice, lemons and light fresh fruit according to appetite.
('13', 182, 4, 13, 349088) I have said “light fruit” because, when the body is burning with smallpox, highly nourishing fruit such as dates and almonds should not be eaten.
('13', 182, 4, 14, 349234) The sores are bound to subside after a week’s treatment with the wet sheet pack.
('13', 182, 4, 15, 349315) If they do not, it means that some poison still remains in the body and is being thrown out.
('13', 182, 4, 16, 349408) Smallpox need not be regarded as so very serious a disease.
('13', 182, 4, 17, 349468) It is only a symptom of poison escaping from the body and, therefore, of the body regaining health.
('13', 182, 5, 18, 349568) The last explanation applies to many diseases but is more likely to be correct in regard to diseases of the smallpox group.
('13', 182, 5, 19, 349692) The reason why some patients remain weak or suffer from other ailments, after recovery, is to be found not in the original disease but in the remedies employed.
('13', 182, 5, 20, 349853) Thus, quinine taken for malaria often causes deafness.
('13', 182, 5, 21, 349908) Some even get a serious complaint known as quininism.
('13', 182, 5, 22, 349962) Venereal diseases are cured with mercury, etc.
('13', 182, 5, 23, 350009) The disorders which this gives rise to, as is well known, remain with the patient for ever.
('13', 182, 5, 24, 350101) Thus medicines not only do not cure the disease but in fact cause new ones.
('13', 182, 5, 25, 350177) We shall find numerous instances of patients who resort to purgatives
('13', 183, 0, 1, 350247) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 183, 1, 2, 350289) in order to cure constipation and develop piles, etc., in consequence.
('13', 183, 1, 3, 350360) To understand and remove the basic cause of a disease and, when the latter has disappeared, to obey the laws of Nature is a better tonic than any bhasma 1. Metals are processed so as to make them assimilable and turned into powders like lohabhasma 2. But it is wrong to regard these as unfailing remedies.
('13', 183, 1, 4, 350666) They do indeed seem to have some beneficial properties, but to the extent that they benefit the body, they strengthen the passions.
('13', 183, 1, 5, 350798) Thus, they are ultimately harmful to one in their total effect.
('13', 183, 1, 6, 350862) These medicines find greater favour as cures for smallpox.
('13', 183, 1, 7, 350921) One who has had an attack of this disease rarely contracts it again.
('13', 183, 1, 8, 350990) As a matter of fact, he often enjoys excellent health after his recovery because all poisons from the body have been drained out.
('13', 183, 2, 9, 351120) When the attack subsides and the sores dry up, olive oil should be applied to the skin and the patient regularly bathed.
('13', 183, 2, 10, 351241) If this is done, most of the scars will disappear altogether and new skin will be formed.
('13', 183, 3, 11, 351331) [From Gujarati]
('13', 183, 4, 12, 351347) Indian Opinion, 28 6 1913
('13', 183, 5, 13, 351373) 1 Form of metallic medication in Ayurveda 2 Bhasma with properties of iron

('13', 184, 1, 2, 351495) 122. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO MINISTER OF INTERIOR 1
('13', 184, 2, 3, 351554) JOHANNESBURG,
('13', 184, 3, 4, 351568) June 28, 1913
('13', 184, 4, 5, 351582) THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO
('13', 184, 5, 6, 351607) THE MINISTER OF THE INTERIOR PRETORIA
('13', 184, 6, 7, 351645) DEAR SIR,
('13', 184, 7, 8, 351655) I have endeavoured to study the Immigrants’ Regulation Act, and observe with thankfulness that it is an improvement upon the original Bill.
('13', 184, 7, 9, 351795) 2 But I respectfully beg to point out that it fails to carry out the provisional settlement of 1911 in at least four important particulars.
('13', 184, 7, 10, 351935) In my humble opinion, if redress is granted in regard to these four particulars, the policy of the Government will not be affected, and yet the terms of the settlement, as my countrymen read it, will be just, but only just, satisfied.
('13', 184, 7, 11, 352170) The points are:
('13', 184, 8, 12, 352186) (1) According to the definition of the term “domicile”, those indentured Indians who arrived after the Indian Immi gration Law Amendment Act of 1895 and their descen dants appear to become prohibited immigrants.
('13', 184, 9, 13, 352398) (2) The descendants of this class, although born in South Africa, will, if the above interpretation be correct, be unable henceforth to enter the Cape Province.
('13', 184, 10, 14, 352559) (3) Women married in South Africa according to the rites of Indian religions, and going to India, and returning with their husbands will not be on the same footing as those
('13', 184, 11, 15, 352732) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion, 13 9 1913, under the title “Revival of Passive Resistance”.
('13', 184, 11, 16, 352832) 2 A detailed comparison of the draft Bill and the Act as gazetted was published in Indian Opinion; Vide Appendix “Draft Immigration Regulation Bill and the Act”, 28 6 1913.
('13', 185, 0, 1, 353005) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 185, 1, 2, 353047) [married]1 in India.
('13', 185, 1, 3, 353068) Nor are the hundreds of women married according to non Christian faiths provided for by the amendment.
('13', 185, 2, 4, 353171) (4) The Free State difficulty seems to remain as it was before.
('13', 185, 3, 5, 353235) With reference to the first point, in view of the fact that the Minister has respected the right of the South Africa born Indians to enter the Cape, if they are born of Indian parents domiciled in South Africa, but not of indentured parents if they were indentured after the Natal Act 17 of 1895. It seems to me to be a small matter for the Government if they were to recognize the status of the descendants born in South Africa of those Indians who were indentured after the Act of 1895. I am sure the Government do not intend to set up distinctions between one class of Colonial born Indians and another.
('13', 185, 3, 6, 353842) Nor can it affect the policy of the Government to recognize the right of domicile of such indentured Indians themselves.
('13', 185, 3, 7, 353963) There could not be more than seven thousand such Indians at the outside.
('13', 185, 3, 8, 354036) This number, compared with the Indian population of Natal, which is estimated at 133,000 cannot fairly be deemed a dangerous permanent increase to the Indian population, especially when it is borne in mind that these men are wanted by the Europeans of Natal.
('13', 185, 3, 9, 354295) To the Indian community both the first and the second points are of the highest moment.
('13', 185, 3, 10, 354383) According to the judgment of the Natal Courts, these men, if they are paying the annual tax of £3, have a right to remain in Natal as permanent residents.
('13', 185, 3, 11, 354538) Are they now to become prohibited immigrants?
('13', 185, 3, 12, 354584) I presume that the Government do not intend to deport them, but do they intend to enforce the provisions of the Act as to trading or the holding of land by them?
('13', 185, 3, 13, 354746) As to the marriage question, the difficulty raised by me is, in my humble opinion, obvious and calls for consideration.
('13', 185, 3, 14, 354866) As to the last point, in the correspondence that took place between General Smuts and myself, doubt was expressed whether, in spite of the reservation clause, the declaration referred to in Section 8 of Chapter 33 could be required of an Indian who might be permitted to enter that Province under the new Act.

('13', 186, 1, 3, 355427) If this be particularly mentioned in the Act itself, they cannot reasonably object to the removal of the clause which requires the declaration.
('13', 186, 1, 4, 355571) For the moment, and for the purposes of a settlement, I do not raise the question of the ousting (now only partial, I admit) of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, and the other drastic provisions of the Act which at once make it far more illiberal than the previous Provincial Acts which it replaces.

('13', 187, 2, 3, 357605) [JOHANNESBURG,] July 2, 1913
('13', 187, 4, 4, 357634) With reference to the interview between us this morning, and in accordance with your wishes, I reduce to writing the points discussed between us:
('13', 187, 5, 5, 357780) With reference to Indians born in South Africa and their right under the Cape Immigration Act to enter the Cape, in my opinion, under Section 5 of the new Act, such men will not be able to enter the Cape by reason of the Proviso of Section 5. If the Government intend to recognize their right to enter the Cape on proving their South African birth as heretofore, they can do so without further legislation, by regulations that would exempt them from the operation of Section l Clause (a) of the Act.
('13', 187, 5, 6, 358280) It may be observed that, if such Indians can pass the simple education test of the Cape, they can enter that Province under Paragraph A of sub section 2 of Clause 5. As you are aware, most of the Colonial born Indians have passed through the Government Indian schools and possess sufficient knowledge to undergo the Cape examination.
('13', 187, 5, 7, 358614) It is also a well known fact that, throughout the time that the Cape Act has been in force, hardly any South African born Indian not belonging to the Cape has endeavoured to migrate to that Province; the reason is that there is no scope for them there.
('13', 187, 6, 8, 358867) 2. With reference to the indentured Indians who entered Natal under the amending legislation of 1895, as I have already told you, the Natal Courts have held that these indentured men, after they have finished their indentures, are free to settle in Natal and could not be treated as prohibited immigrants if they have not reindentured themselves, and that, after three years’ residence without indenture, these people acquire under the Natal Immigration Act full rights of domicile in the same manner as other Indians; such Indians now appear to be affected by the definition of the term “domicile” in the present Act.
('13', 187, 6, 9, 359486) I have already told you that we have obtained best legal opinion in Natal, which is to the effect that the definition does not
('13', 188, 0, 1, 359613) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 189
('13', 188, 1, 2, 359660) cover such Indians and that their rights will not be affected by the new Act.
('13', 188, 1, 3, 359738) However, I do not wish to take upon my shoulders the responsibility of advising my countrymen that they may be guided by that opinion alone.
('13', 188, 1, 4, 359879) It is my sincere desire that any points which I, at least, can foresee should not be left open or not entirely understood.
('13', 188, 1, 5, 360002) If the Government, however, give the same interpretation to the term “domicile” that our Counsel does, an assurance to that effect settles this point.
('13', 188, 1, 6, 360153) Let me state it as clearly as I can.
('13', 188, 1, 7, 360190) We are not seeking to gain any new rights for indentured Indians, but we are anxious that their present rights should be left intact, and these according to the belief of the Indians are that, if an indentured Indian entering into a contract of service after 1895, having become free at the end of his contract, does not re indenture, lives in the Province for three years, then goes to India and returns, he has a right to re enter under the present Immigration Law of Natal by reason of his three years’ free residence.
('13', 188, 2, 8, 360712) 3. As to the Free State, I have drawn your attention to the letter from General Smuts to the effect that, in his opinion, possibly the Free State declaration was not required.
('13', 188, 2, 9, 360888) If that is the legal position according to the opinion of the legal advisers of the Government, a statement to the effect that such is the position will meet the difficulty.
('13', 188, 2, 10, 361062) I venture to suggest that the declaration that will be required in terms of Section 19 of the new Act may have all the disabilities printed at the back thereof, including Section 28 of the new Act.
('13', 188, 2, 11, 361260) Then there need be no repetition of a declaration when a British Indian is recognized as an immigrant for the Free State.
('13', 188, 3, 12, 361382) 4. As to the marriage question, in view of the Searle judgment 1, it is absolutely necessary to legalize Indian marriages celebrated or to be celebrated within the Union.
('13', 188, 3, 13, 361553) This can be done by amending the new Act by removing the words “outside the Union” from the marriage clause of the Act, or by amending the Marriage Laws of the different Provinces authorizing the Government to appoint Marriage Officers for different denominations whose certificates as to the celebration of marriages according to the rites of the respective religions of the parties would be recognized as proper
('13', 188, 4, 14, 361967) 1 Vide Appendix “Text of the Searle Judgement”, 21 6 1913.
('13', 189, 0, 1, 362026) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 189, 1, 2, 362068) proof of marriage.
('13', 189, 1, 3, 362087) With reference to the marriage amendment in the new Act, I understand that only monogamous marriages will be recognized, and I appreciate that nothing more can be done in law at present, but an assurance is necessary to the effect that the present practice of admitting one wife of an Indian immigrant so long as she is the only one in South Africa, irrespective of the number of wives he might have in India, will be continued.
('13', 189, 1, 4, 362516) Then there will remain the question of polygamous marriages.
('13', 189, 1, 5, 362577) As I have told you, there are not many such cases, but it is necessary to admit or re admit plural wives of Indians who are already resident in South Africa.
('13', 189, 1, 6, 362735) No new polygamous unions need be administratively recognized.
('13', 189, 1, 7, 362797) A list can easily be prepared of those who have more than one wife either in the Union or outside it.
('13', 189, 1, 8, 362899) My remarks are naturally applicable to the children of these unions also.
('13', 189, 1, 9, 362973) I may point out that, in the July of 1911, General Smuts gave the assurance that special cases of polygamy would be considered by the Government.
('13', 189, 1, 10, 363119) I think that I have now exhausted all the points we discussed.

('13', 189, 1, 12, 363287) It is clear to me that the solution of this difficulty is very easy because, with the exception of the marriage difficulty, all the points can be settled without an Act of Parliament.

('13', 189, 1, 15, 363851) I make the suggestion so that there may be no correspondence necessary in order to elucidate any doubt that might arise as to the language of any letter that might be given to me, and the.

('13', 190, 3, 4, 364752) 124. LETTER TO JAMNADAS GANDHI

('13', 190, 5, 6, 364816) JAMNADAS,
('13', 190, 6, 7, 364826) You have asked me some questions about serpent bite and cited the experiences of others.
('13', 190, 6, 8, 364915) What I say about this should be treated as no more than my inference.
('13', 190, 6, 9, 364985) It is not based on experience.
('13', 190, 6, 10, 365016) The instances you have come across do not deserve much attention.
('13', 190, 6, 11, 365082) There may be something behind the cases of frenzied shaking of the head from side to side, but for the most part they are cases of fraud.
('13', 190, 6, 12, 365220) I believe the same about cures of snake[ bite] and scorpion[ sting].
('13', 190, 6, 13, 365289) Possibly there is something in them, but one had better not go inquiring into these matters.
('13', 190, 6, 14, 365382) We are to concern ourselves only with activities that tend to spiritual welfare.
('13', 190, 6, 15, 365463) Everything else—even health—is subordinate to that.
('13', 190, 6, 16, 365515) Certain it is thathe who strives to realize the Self will have everything else given to him.
('13', 190, 7, 17, 365608) Many people put on woollen clothes all through the year.
('13', 190, 7, 18, 365665) Though it is true that they are non conductors, it will be better not to use them in summer, for one may otherwise grow a little too soft in body.
('13', 190, 7, 19, 365812) Instead of trying to maintain the body at an even temperature, we should train it to stand both cold and heat.
('13', 190, 8, 20, 365923) God exists, and yet does not.
('13', 190, 8, 21, 365953) He does not, in any literal sense.
('13', 190, 8, 22, 365988) The atman that has attained moksha is God and therefore omniscient.
('13', 190, 8, 23, 366056) The true meaning of bhakti 2 is search for the atman.
('13', 190, 8, 24, 366110) When the atman realizes itself, bhakti is transformed into jnana.
('13', 190, 9, 25, 366176) 1 Pragji Khandubhai Desai, a satyagrahi.
('13', 190, 9, 26, 366217) 2 Devotion
('13', 191, 0, 1, 366228) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 191, 1, 2, 366270) Narsimha [Mehta] 1 and others gave themselves to such devoted search of the atman.
('13', 191, 1, 3, 366353) Krishna, Rama and others were divine incarnations, but we, too, can be like them when immense punya 2 has accrued to us.
('13', 191, 1, 4, 366474) The atmans about to attain moksha are so many divine incarnations.
('13', 191, 1, 5, 366541) We need not believe in their perfection while yet alive.
('13', 191, 1, 6, 366598) It is difficult to say who was the greatest among Krishna, Rama, the Buddha, Jesus, etc.
('13', 191, 1, 7, 366687) Their achievements differed, because they lived in different times and under different circumstances.
('13', 191, 1, 8, 366789) In point of character alone, possibly the Buddha was the greatest.
('13', 191, 1, 9, 366856) But who can say?
('13', 191, 1, 10, 366873) They have been described by their devotees according to their own inclinations.
('13', 191, 1, 11, 366953) Vaishnavas attribute perfection to Krishna.
('13', 191, 1, 12, 366997) One has to, of course.
('13', 191, 1, 13, 367020) Otherwise singleminded bhakti would be impossible.
('13', 191, 1, 14, 367071) Christians do the same to Jesus.
('13', 191, 1, 15, 367104) In India, Krishna being the last [of the incarnations], his figure is invested with especial greatness.
('13', 191, 1, 16, 367208) Those who deny the existence of God will end up on the wrong path, for they will be obliged to deny the existence of the atman.
('13', 191, 1, 17, 367336) Avatar is, and will always remain, a necessity.
('13', 191, 1, 18, 367384) It is only when people are in utter despair and immorality is widespread that a belief in avatar comes to prevail.
('13', 191, 1, 19, 367499) A small number following normal morality in the midst of a wicked majority looks for support.
('13', 191, 1, 20, 367593) In a situation of this kind, a man of great moral strength who has no fear of the wicked but of whom the wicked stand in fear, is looked upon as an avatar after his death, or even during his life time.
('13', 191, 1, 21, 367795) It is not probable, in most cases, that such a person regards himself as an avatar right from the beginning.
('13', 191, 1, 22, 367904) Comparison of religions is uncalled for.
('13', 191, 1, 23, 367945) One must gain a mature understanding of one’s own religion and then study others.
('13', 191, 1, 24, 368027) For purposes of comparison in a general way, the criterion is compassion [taught] as a rule of life.
('13', 191, 1, 25, 368128) The greater the scope for compassion in a way of life, the more of religion it has.
('13', 191, 1, 26, 368212) “The ethical way has its roots in compassion”—that is the first principle to be taught to everyone; and the second, “Brahman is the Reality; the Phenomenal world is unreal.” No single principle may appeal to all, but it would seem that
('13', 191, 2, 27, 368448) 1 Poet saint of Gujarat 2 Accumulated merit
('13', 192, 0, 1, 368492) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 193
('13', 192, 1, 2, 368539) one who is in quest of the atman will have the right principle spring to his lips at the right time.
('13', 192, 1, 3, 368640) Caste distinctions are both necessary and unnecessary.
('13', 192, 1, 4, 368695) Their forcible observance is unnecessary.
('13', 192, 1, 5, 368737) G’s action in giving encouragement to the pariah was praiseworthy.
('13', 192, 1, 6, 368804) In fact, there are as many paths as there are human beings.
('13', 192, 1, 7, 368864) So long as men differ [in temperament], their paths are bound to differ.
('13', 192, 1, 8, 368937) He who sees the identity of his atman with the atmans of others will also see unity in the [different] religions.

('13', 193, 4, 7, 370206) 1635. I promised to let you have the Natal case regarding the indentured Indians who are paying the £3 tax.
('13', 193, 4, 8, 370314) The case is Subrayen versus the Principal Immigration Officer, Natal Reports, page 638. This is the substance telegraphed to me of the case:
('13', 193, 5, 9, 370455) Subrayen had served indentures which expired in 1906. Thereafter, he had paid tax till May 1911. He then proceeded temporarily to India, leaving his wife in charge of business.
('13', 193, 5, 10, 370632) Subrayen returned in November 1912, but was restricted under Section 5, sub section A of the Natal Act, 1903. Under sub section B, Section 32, the Court held that Subrayen’s residence in Natal as free Indian on payment of the tax did not come within the meaning of the words “or the like” following after “indenture” [in] section 32 and that he was entitled to exemption from operation of the Act under Section 4.
('13', 193, 6, 11, 371046) I think you will agree that the case completely bears out the contention submitted by me.
('13', 193, 7, 12, 371136) I remain,
('13', 193, 8, 13, 371146) Yours truly,
('13', 193, 9, 14, 371159) E. M. GORGES, ESQ.

('13', 194, 1, 2, 371285) 126. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [—XXVII]
('13', 194, 2, 3, 371330) 7. OTHER INFECTIOUS DISEASES
('13', 194, 3, 4, 371359) We have considered smallpox in some detail.
('13', 194, 3, 5, 371403) Now remain allied diseases such as chickenpox, measles, etc.
('13', 194, 3, 6, 371464) The plague, cholera, and fast spreading dysentery are also infectious diseases.
('13', 194, 3, 7, 371544) We are not afraid of chickenpox and measles because they are seldom fatal, nor do they cause disfigurement.
('13', 194, 3, 8, 371652) Apart from this, they are very similar in effect to smallpox and are contracted in the same manner.
('13', 194, 3, 9, 371752) Cold water treatments and wet sheet packs are the best remedies for them.
('13', 194, 3, 10, 371826) Diet during the attacks should be extremely light and bland.
('13', 194, 3, 11, 371887) If a patient can subsist on fresh fruit, his recovery will be rapid.
('13', 194, 3, 12, 371956) The “tumour fever” is a terrible disease.
('13', 194, 3, 13, 371998) In English it is called “the bubonic plague”.
('13', 194, 3, 14, 372044) Hundreds of thousands have died of it in India since 1896. Despite much fuss, doctors have so far been able to discover no remedy for it.
('13', 194, 3, 15, 372182) Nowadays, a preventive inoculation similar to vaccination is given for this disease also.
('13', 194, 3, 16, 372272) Producing with it a mild attack of the plague, the doctors explain that this will confer immunity against further infection.
('13', 194, 3, 17, 372397) But this is a mockery similar to vaccination and is an equally sinful experiment.
('13', 194, 3, 18, 372479) Just as it cannot definitely be stated of anyone who has been vaccinated that he would surely have got smallpox if he had not been vaccinated, so also is it impossible to say that one who has been inoculated against the plague would have got it were it not for the inoculation.
('13', 194, 3, 19, 372757) There is no known antidote against the bubonic plague.
('13', 194, 3, 20, 372812) Nor can any guarantee be given that water and mud treatments will prove effective against the disease.
('13', 194, 3, 21, 372915) However, for the benefit of those who do not fear death and who have trust in God, the following measures may be suggested:
('13', 194, 4, 22, 373039) On getting fever or at the very first signs of it, take a wet sheet pack.
('13', 194, 5, 23, 373113) 2. A thick mud pack should be applied to the swollen glands.
('13', 194, 6, 24, 373174) 3. The patient should be given no food whatever.
('13', 194, 7, 25, 373223) 4. If he feels very thirsty, cold lime juice and water
('13', 195, 0, 1, 373278) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 195, 1, 2, 373320) should be administered.
('13', 195, 2, 3, 373344) 5. The patient should lie in a place open to plenty of fresh air.
('13', 195, 3, 4, 373410) 6. Except for one person, no one should be allowed to go near him.
('13', 195, 4, 5, 373477) 7. If anything can bring about a cure, these measures certainly will.
('13', 195, 5, 6, 373547) No definite knowledge is available regarding the origin of the plague.
('13', 195, 5, 7, 373618) Many, however, are of the opinion that it is spread by rats and there seems to be some basis for this impression.
('13', 195, 5, 8, 373732) In areas where cases of the plague have occurred, it is imperative that houses be cleared of rats, and that grains, etc., be stored so that rats cannot gain access to them and are not attracted.
('13', 195, 5, 9, 373927) Rat holes should be filled in; if a house cannot be completely freed of rats, it must, of course, be vacated.
('13', 195, 6, 10, 374037) But the best insurance against the plague is to adopt from the start a clean, wholesome and spare diet, give up all addictions, take regular exercise, live in fresh air, keep one’s home and surroundings clean and thus maintain oneself so fit that this fashion of a plague does not touch one.
('13', 195, 6, 11, 374329) This should be the normal manner of living but, even if that is not possible, it should in any case be followed while an epidemic is on.
('13', 195, 7, 12, 374466) An even more terrible disease and one which breaks out simultaneously with the bubonic plague is fever accompanied by difficult breathing, known in English as the pneumonic plague.
('13', 195, 7, 13, 374647) The temperature shoots up very high and the patient remains for the most part unconscious.
('13', 195, 7, 14, 374738) Recovery from this kalajwar 1 is rare.
('13', 195, 7, 15, 374777) This disease came to Johannesburg in 1904 and only one out of twenty three cases survived.
('13', 195, 7, 16, 374868) Some account of this incident has already been given.
('13', 195, 7, 17, 374922) For this condition, too, the remedies are the same as those suggested for the bubonic plague, except that in this case it is necessary to apply mud packs to both sides of the chest.
('13', 195, 7, 18, 375104) If there is not enough time in which to keep the patient in a wet sheet pack, thin mud poultices should be applied to the head.
('13', 195, 7, 19, 375232) For this disease also preventive
('13', 195, 8, 20, 375265) 1 Literally, deadly fever
('13', 196, 0, 1, 375291) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 197
('13', 196, 1, 2, 375338) measures are easier to take and more effective than remedies for cure, and it will be wise to employ these as shown above.
('13', 196, 2, 3, 375461) Cholera appears horrible when there is an actual case but, in fact, it is a much less serious disease than the plague.
('13', 196, 2, 4, 375580) Wet sheet packs cannot be used here because the patient suffers from cramps, especially in the thighs.
('13', 196, 2, 5, 375683) It may be of some benefit in this condition to apply mud packs to the abdomen, but where there are cramps it is necessary to foment the spot with hot water bottles, The patient’s feet should be rubbed with mustard oil.
('13', 196, 2, 6, 375902) No food, of course, must be given.
('13', 196, 2, 7, 375937) The patient’s friends should see that, instead of his getting scared out of his wits, his courage is kept up.
('13', 196, 2, 8, 376047) If he has frequent motions, he should not be made to leave bed for the purpose, but he should be provided with a shallow pan without sharp edges in which he may pass stools.
('13', 196, 2, 9, 376221) If these measures are taken without delay, there will be little risk for the patient.
('13', 196, 2, 10, 376307) During an epidemic of cholera, there are effective measures with which to protect oneself against it.
('13', 196, 2, 11, 376409) The disease usually appears in summer.
('13', 196, 2, 12, 376448) People suddenly start eating unripe or rotten fruit.
('13', 196, 2, 13, 376501) We are not as a rule accustomed to eat fruit, but many kinds ripen in this season and are cheap, so that they are eaten in large quantities.
('13', 196, 2, 14, 376642) This is in addition to the usual food, with the result that the harmful effect of such fruit follows immediately.
('13', 196, 2, 15, 376756) Even as it is, we frequently suffer from stomach ache and such other complaints.
('13', 196, 2, 16, 376837) When the stomach can stand the strain no longer, we get cholera.
('13', 196, 2, 17, 376902) Others’ physical condition is similar to ours and hence they also get an attack.
('13', 196, 2, 18, 376983) No special precautions are taken regarding the patient’s stools and the germs from these pollute the atmosphere.
('13', 196, 2, 19, 377096) Water also is bad during the hot weather.
('13', 196, 2, 20, 377138) With everything going dry, water becomes dirty and infected and is drunk without being filtered or boiled.
('13', 196, 2, 21, 377245) Under such conditions, is it any wonder that diseases occur?
('13', 196, 2, 22, 377306) It is only because Nature has provided us with a tough physique that we survive at all.
('13', 196, 2, 23, 377394) Otherwise, looking at our conduct and habits, we deserve a very early end indeed.
('13', 196, 3, 24, 377476) We shall now consider the precautions to be taken during an epidemic of cholera.
('13', 196, 3, 25, 377557) It is very important to keep the diet light and moderate.
('13', 196, 3, 26, 377615) Good fruit may certainly be eaten but it should be carefully examined.
('13', 196, 3, 27, 377686) We should never, out of miserliness or because of their
('13', 197, 0, 1, 377742) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 197, 1, 2, 377784) tastefulness, eat mangoes or any other fruits which are rotten in parts.
('13', 197, 1, 3, 377857) Fresh air is essential.
('13', 197, 1, 4, 377881) Drinking water must always be boiled and filtered through a thick and clean piece of khadi 1. Excreta of patients must be burned and the place covered with dry earth.
('13', 197, 1, 5, 378048) If it became a regular practice with every person to sprinkle ashes over the excreta after using the latrine, the danger would be greatly reduced.
('13', 197, 1, 6, 378195) To tell the truth, this should be a permanent rule.
('13', 197, 1, 7, 378247) Cats dig a hole into which they pass stools and then cover it up with earth.
('13', 197, 1, 8, 378324) It is only we who neglect to do this, thinking it to be a kind of pollution or feeling squeamish about doing it, and so fall victims to disease.
('13', 197, 1, 9, 378469) If ashes are not available, dry earth should be used.
('13', 197, 1, 10, 378523) If in lumps, the earth should first be broken up and made into dust.
('13', 197, 1, 11, 378592) The fast spreading dysentery is the least serious of these infectious diseases.
('13', 197, 1, 12, 378672) In this condition, if only mud packs are properly applied to the abdomen and all intake of food stopped, the disease will be cured.
('13', 197, 1, 13, 378804) It is essential that excreta be covered up in the manner described above.
('13', 197, 1, 14, 378878) In regard to water, the same precautions should be taken as for cholera.
('13', 197, 1, 15, 378951) Finally, when any of these infectious diseases occurs, neither the patient nor his friends and relatives should lose courage.
('13', 197, 1, 16, 379077) With fear, the patient will succumb much sooner, and his relatives, and others as well, will be in danger of catching the infection.

('13', 199, 2, 3, 380628) HISTORY OF STRIKE
('13', 199, 3, 4, 380646) In Johannesburg, the white workers in the mines had gone on a big strike unprecedented in the gold area.
('13', 199, 3, 5, 380751) It ended on Monday.
('13', 199, 3, 6, 380771) Nearly 40,000 labourers had struck work.
('13', 199, 3, 7, 380812) It was all much ado about nothing.
('13', 199, 3, 8, 380847) 1 The cause was insignificant.
('13', 199, 3, 9, 380878) Forty new labourers were hired in a mine.
('13', 199, 3, 10, 380920) The management demanded a quarter of an hour’s extra work from them on Saturdays, which the labourers refused.
('13', 199, 3, 11, 381031) The management insisted.
('13', 199, 3, 12, 381056) This was a downright mistake.
('13', 199, 3, 13, 381086) There was a conflagration.
('13', 199, 3, 14, 381113) The secretary of the Union gave notice that the workers would go on strike if they were made to work a quarter of an hour longer.
('13', 199, 3, 15, 381243) The secretary was not employed in any of the mines.
('13', 199, 3, 16, 381295) No weight was attached to his letter.
('13', 199, 3, 17, 381333) This was an insult to the Union, and added fuel to the fire.
('13', 199, 3, 18, 381394) The workers went on strike.
('13', 199, 3, 19, 381422) The proprietors then came round.

('13', 202, 6, 16, 388306) 8. CONFINEMENT
('13', 202, 7, 17, 388321) We have so far considered general diseases.
('13', 202, 7, 18, 388365) It is not the intention, in these chapters, to write on all the maladies one may come across in this world or make suggestions about them, but rather to show that most diseases have a common origin and a common form of treatment.
('13', 202, 7, 19, 388595) Those who have been driven to desperation by illness and are afraid of death will certainly consult a doctor, whatever books are placed before them.
('13', 202, 7, 20, 388744) The most that these chapters can indicate is how those who suffer from ordinary ailments may recover and, observing the laws of good health, may not fall ill again or become a prey to a serious disease.
('13', 202, 7, 21, 388947) Only a few have the courage even for this.

('13', 208, 1, 2, 397792) 132. IMMIGRATION LAWS
('13', 208, 2, 3, 397814) Regulations have been framed under the Immigration Act and published in The Union Gazette.
('13', 208, 2, 4, 397905) 1 We have no time just now to give a summary of the regulations.
('13', 208, 2, 5, 397970) We must study them carefully and decide what is best to be done about them.
('13', 208, 2, 6, 398046) The administration of the Act will depend on these regulations.
('13', 208, 2, 7, 398110) Even an otherwise excellent law can be made oppressive, and an oppressive law can be made milder, through regulations.
('13', 208, 2, 8, 398229) We have glanced through these regulations and have so far not seen any section which may prove particularly dangerous.
('13', 208, 2, 9, 398348) But we can also see that much has been left out in them and that supplementary regulations are likely to be published.
('13', 208, 2, 10, 398467) We must state in this connection that some gentlemen have drawn our attention to section 19 of the Act and told us that we have either overlooked or failed to understand the implications of that section.
('13', 208, 2, 11, 398671) It has certainly not escaped our attention.
('13', 208, 2, 12, 398715) We have gone through it again, word by word.
('13', 208, 2, 13, 398760) We see nothing dangerous in it.
('13', 208, 2, 14, 398792) The section is to the following effect:
('13', 208, 3, 15, 398832) Every person who enters or is found within the Union will, if required, have to appear before an [immigration] officer and satisfy such officer that he is not a prohibited immigrant either in respect of the Union or in respect of any particular province.
('13', 208, 3, 16, 399087) The officer may require every such person to give a declaration in the form prescribed under the regulations and to produce documentary or other evidence relative to his claim to enter or remain.
('13', 208, 3, 17, 399283) The person must submit to any examination or test.
('13', 208, 3, 18, 399334) If he is suspected of being afflicted with any disease [which would render him a prohibited immigrant], the officer may also require him to submit to a medical examination.
('13', 208, 3, 19, 399507) Every such declaration will be exempt from stamp duty.
('13', 208, 3, 20, 399562) After such test, every person whom the officer considers not to be a prohibited immigrant will be free [to enter or remain,] but if any person fails to undergo the test as above or, having given it fails to
('13', 208, 4, 21, 399769) 1 For an analysis of the Regulations and the related documents, vide Appendix “Immigration Act Regulations”, 26 7 1913.
('13', 209, 0, 1, 399889) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 209, 1, 2, 399931) satisfy the officer that he is not a prohibited immigrant, he will not be permitted to land and will be informed in writing that he may, if he chooses, appeal to an immigration board.
('13', 209, 1, 3, 400115) If the person is on board a ship, such notice [of appeal] will have to be given immediately; otherwise, within three days of the receipt of written intimation from the officer.
('13', 209, 1, 4, 400292) This is the meaning of Section 19 as we understand it, and according to this interpretation we find nothing objectionable in it.
('13', 209, 1, 5, 400421) This Section can be used oppressively.
('13', 209, 1, 6, 400460) But so can many other sections.
('13', 209, 1, 7, 400492) Under this Section, the Government can authorize an officer to demand finger prints or other humiliating means of identification, but it has not done so.
('13', 209, 1, 8, 400646) There are such sections even in the old Act.
('13', 209, 1, 9, 400691) If, when the regulations are framed, the Government prescribes under this Section evidence which it would be a hardship to produce, we must certainly protest.
('13', 209, 1, 10, 400850) But this is a separate question and does not arise from Section 19. We cannot object to the Government being invested with such power under the law.
('13', 209, 1, 11, 400999) Laws cannot even be enforced unless the Government is armed with such powers.
('13', 209, 1, 12, 401077) What we must do is to protest every time against their abuse.
('13', 209, 1, 13, 401139) As we have said above, we see no provision in the regulations framed under Section 19 which need cause alarm.
('13', 209, 1, 14, 401249) After we have read the regulations again, and made sure of their correct interpretation, we shall be in a better position to advise the community.

('13', 210, 1, 2, 401485) 133. NEW IMMIGRATION ACT
('13', 210, 2, 3, 401510) ITS OBJECTIONABLE FEATURES
('13', 210, 3, 4, 401537) Mr. Gandhi has returned from Johannesburg.
('13', 210, 3, 5, 401580) In a message to him, General Smuts says that the current agitation by white Railway workers leaves him no time for anything else, and he will, therefore, think about the matter when conditions become a little more peaceful.
('13', 210, 3, 6, 401804) The following are the points in this Act which remain to be settled:
('13', 210, 4, 7, 401873) 1. Indentured labourers who arrived after 1895 seem to lose their right of settling down [in Natal] on the expiry of their term of indenture.
('13', 210, 5, 8, 402015) 2. The right of entry into the Cape which all Indians born in South Africa have enjoyed seems to disappear.
('13', 210, 6, 9, 402123) 3. Indian marriages celebrated in South Africa must be recognized as valid.
('13', 210, 6, 10, 402199) Moreover, the term “monogamous” used in the Bill must not be interpreted by the Government to imply that any woman intending to immigrate should be the only wife of her husband in India.
('13', 210, 6, 11, 402386) So long as the husband does not have another wife in South Africa, there should be no objection to the entry of such a woman.
('13', 210, 6, 12, 402512) Further, if any of those who are already resident in South Africa have married twice in India, or here, both the wives should be free to leave and return [to South Africa].
('13', 210, 7, 13, 402685) 4. An Indian entering the [Orange] Free State as a fresh immigrant should not be required to sign the declaration that he has to at present.
('13', 210, 8, 14, 402826) 5. Particulars about the admission of Indians this year must be settled.
