('13', 211, 0, 1, 402941) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 211, 1, 2, 402983) 134. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XXIX]
('13', 211, 2, 3, 403027) 9. CARE OF CHILDREN
('13', 211, 3, 4, 403047) It is not intended in this article to go into the details with which midwives are concerned.
('13', 211, 3, 5, 403140) We shall therefore turn to the time after the child has been delivered.
('13', 211, 3, 6, 403212) Those who have understood the previous chapters will realize that even during confinement it is not necessary that the mother and child must be kept roasting in a dark, unventilated room, with bedding all too dirty and heated from beneath.
('13', 211, 3, 7, 403452) However old the practice of keeping a confined woman in a dark room, it is cruel all the same.
('13', 211, 3, 8, 403547) Keeping out fresh air is even more cruel.
('13', 211, 3, 9, 403589) The custom of placing fire under [the cot] is entirely unnecessary and one full of risk.
('13', 211, 3, 10, 403678) During the winter the patient will certainly need greater warmth.
('13', 211, 3, 11, 403744) For this purpose, she should be supplied with extra coverings.
('13', 211, 3, 12, 403807) If the room is cold, a fire, first lighted outside, may be brought in after the smoke has subsided, and the air in the room be warmed but it is absolutely unnecessary to place it under the cot.
('13', 211, 3, 13, 404001) A hot water bottle in the mother’s bed will as well help to keep it warm.
('13', 211, 3, 14, 404075) It is also a cruel and superstitious practice to provide her with dirty sheets to sleep on.
('13', 211, 3, 15, 404167) After recovery, the clothes can be thoroughly washed and used again.
('13', 211, 3, 16, 404236) The child’s health depends on the condition of the mother.
('13', 211, 3, 17, 404295) Therefore, in addition to these precautions, she should be given an easily digestible and nourishing diet.
('13', 211, 3, 18, 404402) There is no evidence that [tonic foods made with] gum and things of that kind are particularly beneficial.
('13', 211, 3, 19, 404509) If the mother eats a diet of wheat, banana and olive oil, sufficient heat will be generated in her body and she will have plentiful supply of milk.
('13', 211, 3, 20, 404657) Olive oil will give milk a mildly laxative quality, and this will ensure clear motions for the child.
('13', 211, 3, 21, 404759) If the baby has any complaint, it is the mother who should be examined.
('13', 211, 3, 22, 404831) To give any drug to the baby will be risking its life.
('13', 211, 3, 23, 404886) The child’s intestines being extremely delicate, the toxic effects of the drug will be felt immediately.
('13', 211, 3, 24, 404991) At such times, it is the mother who should take the medicine as its curative properties will in an imperceptible manner pass into her milk.
('13', 211, 3, 25, 405131) If the baby appears to have too many motions or to be coughing frequently, there is no need for panic.
('13', 211, 3, 26, 405234) Instead, one
('13', 212, 0, 1, 405247) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 213
('13', 212, 1, 2, 405294) should wait for a day or two.
('13', 212, 1, 3, 405324) The specific cause of the trouble should be removed and the child will recover.
('13', 212, 1, 4, 405404) Flying into a panic and giving medicines will definitely harm the baby’s health.
('13', 212, 2, 5, 405485) Infants should be bathed in lukewarm water and should have a minimum of clothing.
('13', 212, 2, 6, 405567) For the first few months it will be better for the baby to have no clothing at all.
('13', 212, 2, 7, 405651) It is best wrapped in a soft white sheet and then covered with a warm shawl.
('13', 212, 2, 8, 405728) In this way the bother of dressing the child is avoided.
('13', 212, 2, 9, 405785) Fewer clothes will be soiled and the baby will come to have a tough rather than a weak constitution.
('13', 212, 2, 10, 405886) A folded thin cloth should be laid over the umbilicus and a bandage tied over it.
('13', 212, 2, 11, 405968) The custom of tying the umbilical cord to the neck with a string is bad.
('13', 212, 2, 12, 406041) The bandage should be changed every day.
('13', 212, 2, 13, 406082) If there is any raw skin round the umbilicus, finely strained powder of cleaned rice should be sprinkled over it with clean cotton wool.
('13', 212, 2, 14, 406219) This will help the part to dry up.
('13', 212, 3, 15, 406254) As long as the mother has a plentiful supply of milk, it is unnecessary to give the infant any other food.
('13', 212, 3, 16, 406361) When the supply decreases, the child should be given the flour of roasted wheat, mixed with warm water and a little jaggery and this will have the qualities of milk.
('13', 212, 3, 17, 406527) Alternatively, half a banana mashed and well mixed with half a spoon of olive oil will prove very beneficial.
('13', 212, 3, 18, 406637) If cow’s milk is to be given to start with, a mixture of one part milk and three parts water, heated to boiling point, should be used.
('13', 212, 3, 19, 406772) A little quantity of pure jaggery should also be added to this.
('13', 212, 3, 20, 406836) Substituting sugar for jaggery seems to be harmful.
('13', 212, 3, 21, 406888) If the child is gradually given increasing quantities of fresh fruits, its blood will remain in excellent condition from the very start and it will grow strong and vigorous.
('13', 212, 3, 22, 407062) Many mothers feed babies with dal, rice, vegetables, etc., as soon as its teeth appear or even earlier than that.
('13', 212, 3, 23, 407176) But this is undoubtedly no good for it.
('13', 212, 3, 24, 407216) Tea and coffee should in no case be given to a child.
('13', 212, 4, 25, 407270) When the baby has grown up, that is, has learnt to walk, it may be dressed in a shirt, etc.
('13', 212, 4, 26, 407362) Shoes are quite superfluous.
('13', 212, 4, 27, 407391) An infant does not have to walk among thorns.
('13', 212, 4, 28, 407437) If, therefore, it remains barefoot, the child’s feet will be toughened and there will be no obstacle to the circulation of blood which might otherwise be constricted because of the shoes.
('13', 212, 4, 29, 407625) It is both vulgar and cruel to dress up a child, for the sake
('13', 213, 0, 1, 407687) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 213, 1, 2, 407729) of show, with silken clothes, or dresses padded with cotton, narrow pyjama, a cap on head and ornaments round the neck.
('13', 213, 1, 3, 407849) To imagine that we can improve upon the appearance that Nature has given the child is sheer vanity and ignorance.
('13', 213, 1, 4, 407963) It must be realized that the child’s education begins right from its birth and that its real teachers are its father and mother.
('13', 213, 1, 5, 408092) To threaten a child, to pad its body [with dresses], to overload its stomach all these are a violation of educational principles.
('13', 213, 1, 6, 408222) If the parents are irritable, the child will grow likewise, and from parents who are soft it will learn to be soft.
('13', 213, 1, 7, 408338) Its ways of speech also it will learn from the parents; if the parents pronounce words correctly, so will the child; if they use stammering or foul speech, the child will do likewise.
('13', 213, 1, 8, 408522) If they follow immoral ways, to be sure, the child will learn them.
('13', 213, 1, 9, 408590) “As the father so will be the child, as the banyan tree so will be its fruit” 1—is indeed a true saying.
('13', 213, 1, 10, 408695) Here the word ‘father’ stands for both parents.
('13', 213, 1, 11, 408743) The child learns to eat the food the father eats.
('13', 213, 1, 12, 408793) Later on, it will never get elsewhere the education that it can receive in its home.
('13', 213, 1, 13, 408878) When we consider all this, it becomes clear how very delicate is the responsibility the parents carry.
('13', 213, 1, 14, 408981) Man’s primary duty is to teach children purity of conduct so that they may bring credit to themselves and the parents.
('13', 213, 1, 15, 409100) We observe of trees and their fruits that only plantains can come from a plantain tree and that an excellent tree alone produces good fruit.
('13', 213, 1, 16, 409241) A fine animal has fine offspring.
('13', 213, 1, 17, 409275) Man falsifies this rule.
('13', 213, 1, 18, 409300) Parents with a reputation for purity have children of impure conduct and apparently healthy parents have unhealthy offspring.
('13', 213, 1, 19, 409426) The chief or rather the only reason for this is that, though not worthy to be parents, we frequently become such merely in consequence of self indulgence.
('13', 213, 1, 20, 409581) How then can we be mindful of children’s interests?
('13', 213, 1, 21, 409633) But it is incumbent on right minded parents to bring up their children in the best possible manner.
('13', 213, 1, 22, 409733) To be able to do this, both father and mother must have received true education.
('13', 213, 1, 23, 409814) Parents who have not done so should, if they realize their error, leave their children in the charge of other well educated and virtuous persons.
('13', 213, 1, 24, 409960) It is vain to hope that children will learn good behaviour at school.
('13', 213, 1, 25, 410030) There is only one way of teaching good behaviour and that is to give the child an opportunity
('13', 213, 2, 26, 410124) 1 A Gujarati saying
('13', 214, 0, 1, 410144) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 215
('13', 214, 1, 2, 410191) to live constantly in that kind of atmosphere.
('13', 214, 1, 3, 410238) If there is one sort of training at home and another at school, the children can never improve.
('13', 214, 1, 4, 410334) It follows from this that there are no fixed times when a child is to receive its education.
('13', 214, 1, 5, 410427) Its education commences at its birth and from that very moment begins its physical, mental and spiritual or religious training.
('13', 214, 1, 6, 410555) Its training in language starts the moment it begins to prattle.
('13', 214, 1, 7, 410620) Instruction in letters also it can have from its parents, as it plays.
('13', 214, 1, 8, 410691) In olden days, this was what usually happened.
('13', 214, 1, 9, 410738) Now, it has become the custom to send children to schools.
('13', 214, 1, 10, 410797) If parents would do their duty by their children, there would be no limit to the heights the latter could reach.
('13', 214, 1, 11, 410910) But, if we regard children merely as toys, fondle them excessively, spoil them out of a mistaken notion of affection with sweets and rich clothes right from their childhood, allow them to do as they please, if we are greedy for money ourselves and teach this greed to children, are engrossed in pleasures and set that example before children, are lazy ourselves and make them lazy, are dirty and teach them dirty ways, tell lies and teach them lies, then is it any wonder that our progeny grow up to be feeble, immoral, lying, lustful, selfish and greedy?
('13', 214, 1, 12, 411466) Thoughtful parents need carefully to ponder over these remarks.
('13', 214, 1, 13, 411530) India’s future, a good half of it, lies in the hands of parents.

('13', 224, 0, 1, 424955) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 225
('13', 224, 1, 2, 425002) 142. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XXX]
('13', 224, 2, 3, 425045) 10. ACCIDENTS: DROWNING
('13', 224, 3, 4, 425069) We have made a brief study of certain ailments.
('13', 224, 3, 5, 425117) Everyone should have some knowledge regarding accidents that may occur at any time so that he can render assistance if anyone is in mortal danger.
('13', 224, 3, 6, 425264) If children are given such knowledge from quite an early age, they are likely to develop kindliness in greater measure.
('13', 224, 3, 7, 425384) We shall begin with the treatment to be given to one who may have fallen into water.
('13', 224, 3, 8, 425469) In England, a philanthropic association has been established to render assistance in such emergencies.
('13', 224, 3, 9, 425572) It has issued some valuable suggestions.
('13', 224, 3, 10, 425613) The following note is chiefly based on these, with some modifications and additions.
('13', 224, 3, 11, 425698) It is said that a person can live for hardly five minutes after he stops breathing.
('13', 224, 3, 12, 425782) That means that, when a drowning man is taken out of the water, there is little life left in him.
('13', 224, 3, 13, 425880) Immediate measures have to be taken to keep life going—to bring the drowning person back to consciousness.
('13', 224, 3, 14, 425987) Two things must especially be attended to in such a case.
('13', 224, 3, 15, 426045) One is to make the victim resume normal breathing by giving artificial respiration and the second is to give him warmth.
('13', 224, 3, 16, 426166) When thinking of remedies, it has to be kept in mind that immediate treatment has to be given, if needed, at places like river banks where no equipment is available.
('13', 224, 3, 17, 426332) It is possible to render treatment to a drowning man only if there are two or three other persons present.
('13', 224, 3, 18, 426439) These must possess presence of mind, courage and promptness.
('13', 224, 3, 19, 426500) If they themselves fall into a panic, nothing can be done.
('13', 224, 3, 20, 426559) If each of the two or three men wants to follow his own method or starts advising the others, there is little hope for the victim.
('13', 224, 3, 21, 426690) They must immediately recognize the most capable among the themselves and follow his instructions at once.
('13', 224, 3, 22, 426797) As soon as the victim is taken out of the water, his wet clothes should be removed.
('13', 224, 3, 23, 426881) His body should be wiped with any cloth the companions may have.
('13', 224, 3, 24, 426946) A hand should then be placed on his forehead and he should be gently turned over for a minute.
('13', 224, 3, 25, 427041) A hand should be pressed against his chest and dirt and water removed from his mouth.
('13', 225, 0, 1, 427127) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 225, 1, 2, 427169) When the tongue comes out, it should be held.
('13', 225, 1, 3, 427215) This can be easily done with a handkerchief, etc., kept ready in the hand.
('13', 225, 1, 4, 427290) The tongue should be kept pulled out all the time, till there are signs that life is reviving.
('13', 225, 1, 5, 427385) The patient should then be turned on his back, but with the head and upper parts a little higher than the feet.
('13', 225, 1, 6, 427497) A man should now kneel behind his head.
('13', 225, 1, 7, 427537) The patients’ arms should be slowly lifted and drawn full length towards the person volunteering this service.
('13', 225, 1, 8, 427648) With this the ribs will be lifted and air from without will enter the patient’s body.
('13', 225, 1, 9, 427734) Then the arms should be bent and placed on his chest.
('13', 225, 1, 10, 427788) Thereby the ribs will be pressed down and the breath exhaled.
('13', 225, 1, 11, 427850) Hot and cold water should be dashed against the chest.
('13', 225, 1, 12, 427905) If the materials required to make a fire are within reach or if fire can be obtained immediately from some source, fomentation should be applied and the victim be made warm.
('13', 225, 1, 13, 428079) Those present should cover him with whatever clothes they have.
('13', 225, 1, 14, 428143) His body should be vigorously rubbed so as to make it warm.
('13', 225, 1, 15, 428203) It is necessary to continue these measures for quite some time.
('13', 225, 1, 16, 428267) Hope should not be abandoned too soon.
('13', 225, 1, 17, 428306) Dr. Moore states that with these measures a victim resumed breathing even after five hours.
('13', 225, 1, 18, 428398) They should be taken, therefore, with great energy and promptness.
('13', 225, 1, 19, 428465) If he comes round, the patient should be given a hot drink.
('13', 225, 1, 20, 428525) If given orange juice in hot water or a decoction of cinnamon, cloves and pepper, he will quickly rally.
('13', 225, 1, 21, 428630) It may also help if he is made to smell tobacco.
('13', 225, 1, 22, 428679) People should not crowd round him as he has need of all the fresh air he can get.
('13', 225, 1, 23, 428761) Signs of death in these cases are generally as follows: The victim does not breathe and no heart beat can be detected by the hand or stethoscope.
('13', 225, 1, 24, 428907) There is no pulse, the eyes are half closed, the pupils are dilated, the jaws are clenched, the fingers are bent, the tongue is between the teeth, there is froth in the mouth, the nose is slimy and the whole body extremely pale.
('13', 225, 1, 25, 429136) A feather held over the mouth does not flutter nor does vapour collect on the mirror.
('13', 225, 1, 26, 429222) If all these symptoms are present, it may be taken that life is extinct.
('13', 225, 1, 27, 429295) But Dr. Moore says that even with these signs, life is sometimes not over.
('13', 225, 1, 28, 429370) The only definite symptom of death is that decomposition starts within the body.
('13', 225, 1, 29, 429451) We may conclude from this that hope should be abandoned only after prolonged treatment has been given.
('13', 225, 2, 30, 429554) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 26 7 1913

('13', 232, 6, 9, 437380) Already you have worked the oracle.

('13', 232, 6, 24, 438207) You must however use your judgment.

('13', 232, 6, 26, 438550) Whilst I give you the financial position, you need not give yourself anxiety over it.

('13', 233, 6, 8, 439275) 151. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XXXI]
('13', 233, 7, 9, 439319) 11. ACCIDENTS: BURNS
('13', 233, 8, 10, 439340) When any person’s clothing or something else about him catches fire, we get into a panic, which is like branding a man who has already sustained burns 2—instead of being helpful to the victim, we make things worse for him.
('13', 233, 8, 11, 439563) It is everyone’s duty therefore to know what remedies to apply to a man who has suffered burns.
('13', 233, 8, 12, 439659) The person whose clothes catch fire should also not become terrified but, if it is the loose end of a garment, should promptly rub it with the hand.
('13', 233, 8, 13, 439808) If the entire clothing has caught fire, he shouldroll on the ground or, if there is a carpet or similar thick cloth within reach, he should wrap himself in it.
('13', 233, 8, 14, 439968) If water is available, it should be thrown on the flames.
('13', 233, 8, 15, 440026) As soon as the fire is extinguished, he should be examined for burns.
('13', 233, 8, 16, 440096) If there are any, the cloth is likely to stick to those parts.
('13', 233, 8, 17, 440159) This should not be pulled off.
('13', 233, 8, 18, 440190) The remaining clothing should be cut round with a pair of scissors and the part that has stuck to the skin left in place.
('13', 233, 8, 19, 440312) Great care should be taken not to tear the skin.
('13', 233, 8, 20, 440361) Leaving the victim in this condition, one should collect clean earth forthwith and mix it with cold water to make a poultice and this should be tied over the burns so that the victim will suffer the minimum of pain.
('13', 233, 8, 21, 440577) If cloth is sticking to the burns, it may safely be left
('13', 233, 9, 22, 440634) 1 “Brother”; this was how associates addressed Gandhiji.
('13', 233, 9, 23, 440691) 2 A Gujarati saying
('13', 234, 0, 1, 440711) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 235
('13', 234, 1, 2, 440758) under the bandage.
('13', 234, 1, 3, 440777) As soon as the mud dries, the poultice should be changed.
('13', 234, 1, 4, 440835) There is no need to be afraid of using cold water.
('13', 234, 2, 5, 440886) For anyone who may not think of this treatment at the moment, here are others which will be useful to note.
('13', 234, 2, 6, 440994) They are taken from a book by a British writer.
('13', 234, 2, 7, 441042) Take a green banana leaf and spread olive oil or sweet oil [sesame oil] over it.
('13', 234, 2, 8, 441123) Then place it over the burn and tie it up.
('13', 234, 2, 9, 441166) In the absence of a leaf, a clean soft cloth soaked in oil will do as well.
('13', 234, 2, 10, 441242) A mixture of linseed oil and lime water in equal proportion and well shaken is also effective.
('13', 234, 2, 11, 441337) If cloth pieces get stuck and cannot later be removed, lukewarm milk and water should be used to soak them.
('13', 234, 2, 12, 441445) When they are softened, it will be possible to remove them.
('13', 234, 2, 13, 441505) If oil bandages have been used, they should be changed after two days in the first instance and subsequently renewed every day.
('13', 234, 2, 14, 441633) If a blister is formed, it is necessary to open it.
('13', 234, 2, 15, 441685) The skin need not be removed.
('13', 234, 3, 16, 441715) If the burn has only caused redness of the skin, there is no better remedy than a mud poultice.
('13', 234, 3, 17, 441811) The burning will cease immediately.
('13', 234, 4, 18, 441847) If the fingers have been burnt, they should be kept carefully separated from each other by clean bandages.
('13', 234, 4, 19, 441954) Sometimes a person receives burns through a strong acid which falls on his skin.
('13', 234, 4, 20, 442035) The remedies suggested above are effective in this case also.
('13', 234, 5, 21, 442097) [From Gujarati]

('13', 235, 1, 2, 442180) 152. LETTER T0 JAMNADAS GANDHI
('13', 235, 2, 3, 442211) [JOHANNESBURG, ] Shravana Sud 6 [August 7,1913] 1
('13', 235, 3, 4, 442261) JAMNADAS,
('13', 235, 4, 5, 442271) You say you were scared by what Harilal told you about baths.
('13', 235, 4, 6, 442333) There is no reason for it, though.
('13', 235, 4, 7, 442368) Harilal has been talking in his ignorance.
('13', 235, 4, 8, 442411) All that caution is unnecessary.
('13', 235, 4, 9, 442444) I never bother to take the temperature and so on.
('13', 235, 4, 10, 442494) There is no need to.
('13', 235, 4, 11, 442515) The temperature of the water should be lower than that of the body.
('13', 235, 4, 12, 442583) The rest one knows from experience.
('13', 235, 4, 13, 442619) Whenever Kuhne baths seem to be called for, they may be taken without the least hesitation.
('13', 235, 4, 14, 442711) This is the reason behind the notion that tomato, lime, etc., are a cause of fever.
('13', 235, 4, 15, 442795) When they are taken with a heavy meal and illness follows, it is blamed on them.
('13', 235, 4, 16, 442876) Secondly, when a person whose blood is excessively hot through the use of spices, such as chillies and pepper, and pulses and things of that nature, starts taking lime, etc., there is likely to be a crisis at first.
('13', 235, 4, 17, 443092) If, however, he gives up the use of spices and similar things and starts the use of lime, etc., according to need, there is no doubt that his blood will be purified.
('13', 235, 4, 18, 443258) A man who has been in a very hot place and then suddenly exposes himself to a breeze may get cramps.
('13', 235, 4, 19, 443359) It is possible that lime may have a similar effect on one who has been accustomed to eating chillies, etc.
('13', 235, 4, 20, 443466) I think I have written to you about looking upon Brahmins with reverence I am not against a good school, but I believe that a school with too many pupils cannot be a good one.
('13', 235, 4, 21, 443642) Moreover, that alone is a school in which the pupils are on the campus for all the twenty four hours.
('13', 235, 4, 22, 443744) Otherwise, one receives education of two different sorts.
('13', 235, 4, 23, 443802) When I am there, the Press will continue to work as usual.

('13', 238, 3, 4, 447999) Men have always feared snakes.
('13', 238, 3, 5, 448030) There are countless supers titions, too, connected with the serpent.
('13', 238, 3, 6, 448099) We are afraid even to mention its name.
('13', 238, 3, 7, 448139) At night we refer to it as “the big creature”.
('13', 238, 3, 8, 448186) Among Hindus, the snake is an object of worship.
('13', 238, 3, 9, 448235) Nagpanchami 1 is regarded especially as the day of snake worship.
('13', 238, 3, 10, 448301) There is a popular belief that the earth is supported on the head of the serpent Sheshnag.
('13', 238, 3, 11, 448392) God also is held to be Sheshshayi, i.e., lying on Sheshnag.
('13', 238, 3, 12, 448452) God Shiva is said to wear a snake as a garland.
('13', 238, 3, 13, 448500) “Sheshnag with his thousand mouths could not describe this”; in saying this we attribute intelligence and knowledge to the serpent.
('13', 238, 3, 14, 448632) There is a similar idea in Christianity also.
('13', 238, 3, 15, 448678) “Be wise as the serpent”, so runs a saying in English.
('13', 238, 3, 16, 448733) The serpent karkotak conferred a boon upon Nala 2 by biting him, thereby making him so ugly and deformed through its poison, that none would look upon him with evil intent as hewandered in the forests.
('13', 238, 3, 17, 448935) The serpent also stands, in the Bible, for the Devil.
('13', 238, 3, 18, 448989) It was he who tempted Eve.
('13', 238, 4, 19, 449016) Thus there are all kinds of beliefs and tales about this creature.
('13', 238, 4, 20, 449083) It is easy to understand the dread of snakes.
('13', 238, 4, 21, 449129) If a snake bite takes full effect, death is inevitable, and no one wishes to die.
('13', 238, 4, 22, 449211) Hence this fear.
('13', 238, 4, 23, 449228) It is also easy to see how snakes have been worshipped out of fear.
('13', 238, 4, 24, 449296) If the snake had been a tiny creature, it would not perhaps have inspired such worship despite its being the terror that it is.
('13', 238, 4, 25, 449424) But being long, large, beautiful and of strange aspect, it is even ceremonially worshipped.
('13', 238, 5, 26, 449516) It is more difficult to say without thinking why the snake has been credited with intelligence.
('13', 238, 5, 27, 449612) Modern scientists aver that it has none.
('13', 238, 5, 28, 449653) According to them, a snake should be killed at sight.

('13', 245, 5, 13, 462790) 157. AN EFFECT OF THE NEW ACT
('13', 245, 6, 14, 462820) We understand that an Indian named Purshotam Mavji, a British Indian, duly registered in terms of Act 36 of 1908 (Transvaal), was deprived of his registration certificate whilst he was on his way to India and was told by the officer who took the certificate from him that it would be restored to him if he returned within one year of the date of his departure from the Transvaal.

('13', 246, 1, 2, 463669) 158. THE LATE SIR ADAMJEE PEERBHAI
('13', 246, 2, 3, 463704) We learn through Reuter’s cables with regret that Sir Adamjee Peerbhai, a great philanthropist of Bombay, is no more.
('13', 246, 2, 4, 463822) He was a wealthy merchant who knew how to use his money.
('13', 246, 2, 5, 463879) He was best known to many as the owner of a famous sanatorium in Bombay.
('13', 246, 2, 6, 463952) But his charities were not confined to a particular project or persons.
('13', 246, 2, 7, 464024) They were most catholic.
('13', 246, 2, 8, 464049) Sir Adamjee’s son, Mr. Cureembhai, it will be remembered, paid a visit to Natal some years ago.
('13', 246, 2, 9, 464145) Ever since that time, a link was established between the Indians of South Africa and the late Sir Adamjee, who always took a kindly interest in all South African Indians who visited him.
('13', 246, 2, 10, 464332) We sympathise with the deceased’s family in their loss.
('13', 246, 3, 11, 464388) Indian Opinion, 16 8 1913
('13', 247, 0, 1, 464414) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 247, 1, 2, 464456) 159. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XXXIII]
('13', 247, 2, 3, 464502) 13. ACCIDENTS: SCORPION AND OTHER STINGS
('13', 247, 3, 4, 464543) We have a saying, “May none suffer the agony of a scorpion sting”, so unbearable it is.
('13', 247, 3, 5, 464631) As a matter of fact, it is far more painful than snake bite and yet we dread the latter more, for it is likely to prove fatal.
('13', 247, 3, 6, 464758) A scorpion sting rarely causes death.
('13', 247, 3, 7, 464796) Dr. Moore says that one whose blood is pure suffers less pain.
('13', 247, 3, 8, 464859) The remedies for this and similar stings are simple.
('13', 247, 3, 9, 464912) A cut should be made at the spot with a sharp knife or with the special instrument used for snake bite, and some blood allowed to escape.
('13', 247, 3, 10, 465050) The cut should then be sucked and the poison spat out.
('13', 247, 3, 11, 465105) A bandage should be tied a little above the spot, to prevent the poison from spreading, and a large mud poultice applied.
('13', 247, 3, 12, 465227) With the latter, much of the pain will probably subside at once.
('13', 247, 3, 13, 465292) Some books recommend the frequent application of a compress soaked in equal parts of water and vinegar or washing of the area with salt water.
('13', 247, 3, 14, 465435) If the affected part can be held in the solution, it should be.
('13', 247, 3, 15, 465499) But the mud poultice is by far the most effective remedy, as anyone unfortunate enough to be stung by a scorpion can test for himself.
('13', 247, 3, 16, 465634) It must be remembered that the poultice should be as large as possible.
('13', 247, 3, 17, 465706) The use of two seers of earth for the purpose will not be excessive.
('13', 247, 3, 18, 465775) If a finger has been stung, it will not be too much to extend the poultice as far as the elbow.
('13', 247, 3, 19, 465871) If the mud is placed in a long vessel and the arm buried in it, the pain is immediately relieved.
('13', 247, 3, 20, 465969) Even for the stings of centipedes, bees, etc., the remedies are the same.
('13', 247, 4, 21, 466043) [From Gujarati]
('13', 247, 5, 22, 466059) Indian Opinion, 16 8 1913
('13', 248, 0, 1, 466085) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 249
('13', 248, 1, 2, 466132) 160. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ XXXIV]
('13', 248, 2, 3, 466177) CONCLUSION
('13', 248, 3, 4, 466188) These chapters on the subject of health have been appearing for the past few months.
('13', 248, 3, 5, 466273) They have now come to an end.
('13', 248, 3, 6, 466303) If I get time, I plan to publish, as a sort of supplement, the qualities and uses of a number of simple materials.
('13', 248, 3, 7, 466418) The present series, however, ends with the preceding chapter.
('13', 248, 3, 8, 466480) Before I take leave of my readers, I feel it will not be out of place if we once again examine the purpose of these chapters.
('13', 248, 4, 9, 466606) I have repeatedly asked myself why I wrote them.
('13', 248, 4, 10, 466655) I am not a vaidya.
('13', 248, 4, 11, 466674) My knowledge of the subject is but superficial.
('13', 248, 4, 12, 466722) Is it not likely that my suggestions have been made after inadequate thought or observation?
('13', 248, 4, 13, 466815) In truth, both study and observation are bound to be incomplete, a process without end.
('13', 248, 4, 14, 466903) Every day new facts are observed and new ideas emerge.
('13', 248, 4, 15, 466958) Why, then, this effort?
('13', 248, 4, 16, 466982) Thus has my mind been perplexed.
('13', 248, 5, 17, 467015) And yet, medical science is itself based on inconclusive experiments.
('13', 248, 5, 18, 467085) Most of it is quackery, as I have shown.
('13', 248, 5, 19, 467126) With so much of it about, if these chapters are also reckoned as such, no great harm will be done !
('13', 248, 5, 20, 467226) They have been written from a worthy motive.
('13', 248, 5, 21, 467271) The intention is not to recommend what medicines to take after the onset of a disease.
('13', 248, 5, 22, 467358) The more immediate purpose, rather, has been to show how sickness may be averted.
('13', 248, 5, 23, 467440) A little thought will show that the steps for prevention of diseases are easy enough.
('13', 248, 5, 24, 467526) No specialized knowledge is necessary for this.
('13', 248, 5, 25, 467574) The difficulty lies in taking to that way of life.
('13', 248, 5, 26, 467625) I have felt it proper to write on certain diseases, but only in order to show that most ailments have a common origin and, as a result, the treatment also should be common to them all.
('13', 248, 5, 27, 467810) Moreover, despite all precautions, the diseases mentioned in these chapters do occasionally occur.
('13', 248, 5, 28, 467909) Some remedies for these, one finds, are known to all.
('13', 248, 5, 29, 467963) If my experience is added to these, nothing is likely to be lost.
('13', 248, 6, 30, 468029) The main question, however, still remains to be considered.
('13', 248, 6, 31, 468089) Why is good health necessary?
('13', 248, 6, 32, 468119) We behave as if no such necessity exists.
('13', 249, 0, 1, 468161) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 249, 1, 2, 468203) be sure, rather than build a stout and healthy body and give it over to the enjoyment of luxuries, regard the body as the only thing worth preserving and be puffed up with pride to see it strong, it will be better to have it rotting with leprosy.
('13', 249, 2, 3, 468450) All religions have looked upon this body as a place where one may meet and recognize God.
('13', 249, 2, 4, 468540) It is called the House of the Lord.
('13', 249, 2, 5, 468576) It has been leased to us, all the rent we have to pay being praises of the Master.
('13', 249, 2, 6, 468659) Another condition in the rent note is that we must not misuse it.
('13', 249, 2, 7, 468725) It should be kept clean and pure inside and out and returned to the Master in due course in the same condition in which it came to us.
('13', 249, 2, 8, 468860) If all the conditions are duly fulfilled, the Master will reward us at the end of our tenure and will make us his heirs.
('13', 249, 3, 9, 468981) All living creatures have bodies alike in their design, in that they have organs for hearing, sight, smell and pleasure.
('13', 249, 3, 10, 469102) But the human body has been described in prose and verse as a ratnachintamani.
('13', 249, 3, 11, 469181) The term signifies a jewel which secures to one anything one may wish for.
('13', 249, 3, 12, 469256) In an animal body, the soul cannot attain to the highest knowledge and cultivate devotion to God.
('13', 249, 3, 13, 469354) Without these, there can be no freedom for the soul and, so long as the soul has not attained freedom, there can be no true happiness and no ending to our real suffering.
('13', 249, 3, 14, 469525) This body is of some service only if it is well used, that is, made the abode of God, otherwise, it is a filthy mass of bones, flesh and blood, and the breath and water that exude from it are full of poison.
('13', 249, 3, 15, 469733) Of all the excreta coming out of the innumerable openings in the body, there is nothing that we would wish to retain.
('13', 249, 3, 16, 469851) One is nauseated at the very thought or sight or touch of them.
('13', 249, 3, 17, 469915) It is only with the greatest difficulty that we can prevent them from being infested with worms.
('13', 249, 3, 18, 470012) By means of the body, we practise a thousand things which we would do better to avoid, cunning, self indulgence, deceit, stealing, adultery, etc.
('13', 249, 3, 19, 470158) Its desires are endless.
('13', 249, 3, 20, 470183) 1 Even when they are all gratified, it is so like a glass bangle that it has less strength to resist a blow than has a broken vessel.
('13', 249, 3, 21, 470317) It is destroyed in an instant.
('13', 249, 4, 22, 470348) Such a state is quite natural for the body.
('13', 249, 4, 23, 470392) Anything that can be used for the highest purpose is also capable of being misused.
('13', 249, 5, 24, 470476) 1 The original Gujarati saying literally means: “That little pot must needs have thirteen things.”

('13', 250, 1, 2, 470622) Otherwise, it would be impossible to know or estimate its value.
('13', 250, 1, 3, 470687) We can measure the value of sunlight because we experience the darkness that follows the sun’s absence.
('13', 250, 1, 4, 470791) In that same sun, without which we cannot live, resides the power to turn us to ashes.
('13', 250, 1, 5, 470878) A king can be both magnanimous and wicked.
('13', 250, 2, 6, 470921) God is striving for mastery over the body, and so is Satan engaged in a desperate struggle for it.
('13', 250, 2, 7, 471020) When it is under the control of God, it is like a jewel.
('13', 250, 2, 8, 471077) When it passes into the control of the Devil, it is a pit of filth.
('13', 250, 2, 9, 471145) If engrossed in pleasure, gorging itself the wholeday with all variety of putrifying food, exuding evil odours, with limbs employed in thieving, the tongue uttering unworthy words and taking in unwholesome things, the ears hearing, the eyes seeing and the nose smelling what they ought not to, the body is worse than hell.
('13', 250, 2, 10, 471468) Everyone recognizes hell for what it is.
('13', 250, 2, 11, 471509) But though we use the body as if it were hell, we go on pretending that it is heaven.
('13', 250, 2, 12, 471595) Such is our hypocrisy in regard to the body.
('13', 250, 2, 13, 471640) Knowing a latrine for what it is, we shall know its right use.
('13', 250, 2, 14, 471703) If a splendid hall, however, comes to be used as a lavatory, the result is bound to be evil.
('13', 250, 2, 15, 471796) Therefore, if the body be in the Devil’s control, it would be far better to desire its destruction, rather than its well being.
('13', 250, 2, 16, 471924) In these chapters on health, an effort has been made to bring home the truth that the body can remain in health only by obeying the laws of God.
('13', 250, 2, 17, 472069) It can never be healthy if it the Devil.
('13', 250, 2, 18, 472110) Where there is real health, there alone is true happiness possible, and in order to achieve real health we must conquer the palate.
('13', 250, 2, 19, 472242) If we succeed in this, all other organs will be automatically under our control and one who has this body under control can subdue the world because such a one becomes God’s heir, a part of Him.
('13', 250, 2, 20, 472437) Rama is not in the Ramayana, nor Krishna in the Gita.
('13', 250, 2, 21, 472491) Khuda is not in the Koran, nor Christ in the Bible.
('13', 250, 2, 22, 472543) They all live and have their being in the purity of human conduct, which springs from morality.
('13', 250, 2, 23, 472639) Morality consists in truth, which is the same as Shiva 1. You may know it by whatever name you please.
('13', 250, 2, 24, 472742) That one may have a glimpse, if only occasional, of this truth in these chapters on health has been the underlying purpose of this effort.

('13', 257, 1, 2, 481347) 166. THE LATE MR. JOSEPH J. DOKE 1
('13', 257, 2, 3, 481382) Mr. Doke is no more!
('13', 257, 2, 4, 481403) The thought is terrible.
('13', 257, 2, 5, 481428) He who was seen only the other day by a host of friends, when he set out on his journey) to the North western border of Rhodesia, close to the Congo border, full of hope and buoyancy, has gone to his reward.
('13', 257, 2, 6, 481636) And he quitted this mortal frame without any of his relations by his side.
('13', 257, 2, 7, 481711) Even his son Clement, who accompanied him, was sent home.
('13', 257, 2, 8, 481769) But in a death like this is summed up Mr. Doke’s life.
('13', 257, 2, 9, 481824) He claimed no exclusive relationship with anybody.
('13', 257, 2, 10, 481875) To him every human being was truly a friend and brother.

('13', 259, 1, 3, 486100) The late Rev.
('13', 259, 1, 4, 486114) Joseph J. Doke was born at Chudleigh, Devonshire, on the 5th November, 1861. He was the younger, by some two and a half years, of a family of two.
('13', 259, 1, 5, 486261) His father was the Baptist Minister of Chudleigh.
('13', 259, 1, 6, 486311) His brother, the late Mr. William H. Doke, died as a missionary at the end of 1882 on African soil.
('13', 259, 1, 7, 486411) The late Rev.
('13', 259, 1, 8, 486425) Doke had very little schooling, owing to delicate health.
('13', 259, 1, 9, 486483) At the age of 16 he lost his mother.
('13', 259, 1, 10, 486520) At the age of 17, on the resignation of his father from the pastorate, he became pastor.
('13', 259, 1, 11, 486609) At the age of 20 he came to South Africa, where he was in Cape Town for a short time.
('13', 259, 1, 12, 486695) Later, he was sent by the South African Baptist Union to open up a new cause in Great Reinet.
('13', 259, 1, 13, 486789) Here he met and married Miss Biggs, in 1886. Shortly after, he returned to Chudleigh.
('13', 259, 1, 14, 486875) From Chudleigh Mr. Doke was called to the pastorship of the City Road Baptist Church, Bristol, where, with the exception of a visit to Egypt, Palestine and India, he remained until 1894. In 1894, Mr. Doke removed with his family to New Zealand.
('13', 259, 1, 15, 487120) Here he was Minister of the Oxford Terrace Baptist Church, Christchurch, for a period of seven and a half years, returning to England in 1902. In addition to the duties connected with his pastorship, Mr. Doke conducted a class for Chinese, which was greatly appreciated and which is still being continued by his successors.
('13', 259, 1, 16, 487444) Towards the end of 1903, Mr. Doke received a call to the Grahamstown Baptist Church, and took up his work in South Africa again.
('13', 259, 1, 17, 487573) After four years in Grahamstown, he came to the Rand as Minister of the Central Baptist Church.
('13', 259, 1, 18, 487669) He remained Minister of this Church until his death.
('13', 259, 1, 19, 487722) All his life, more especially since the death of his brother, Mr. Doke’s ambition was for missionary work, but owing to his health and family circumstances, the way was not clear, until, just at the end of his life, it seemed to open up.
('13', 259, 1, 20, 487960) Together with his son, Clement, he decided to visit a lonely mission station in North western Rhodesia close to the Congo border, and on the 2nd July they set out on this trip, which was to take about six weeks.
('13', 259, 1, 21, 488172) Mr. Doke was also entrusted by the South African Baptist Mission Society to visit a mission station near Umtali, they taking advantage of his
('13', 260, 0, 1, 488314) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 261
('13', 260, 1, 2, 488361) being in Rhodesia to secure particulars which they wanted.
('13', 260, 1, 3, 488420) Mr. Doke enjoyed the trip to the ’Ndla District immensely, and maintained good health throughout.
('13', 260, 1, 4, 488518) He suffered, however, from footsoreness —the distance to be traversed was some 350 miles—and he travelled most of the way by “machilla”—a hammock slung on a pole and carried by two natives—, but despite this he was in the best of spirits and had the greatest hope for the success of his mission.
('13', 260, 1, 5, 488814) Through an interpreter he spoke at numerous villages, and he did a great deal of writing and took many photographs with a view to lecturing on his return.
('13', 260, 1, 6, 488969) On the 4th August, Broken Hill was reached, and on the 7th August, Mr. Doke parted from his son at Bulawayo, the latter being called home by business duties.
('13', 260, 1, 7, 489127) Mr. Doke then proceeded to Umtali, after a few days’ waiting at Bulawayo, reaching the end of his train journey on the morning of the 9th instant.

('13', 260, 1, 10, 489389) In the afternoon the party proceeded to the residence of Mr. Webber—a friend—just outside the town, where, owing to Mr. Doke’s feeling too unwell, they remained for the night.
('13', 260, 1, 11, 489565) The next morning, Mr. Doke was up before sunrise, feeling very ill, and all thought of going to the mission station then was abandoned.
('13', 260, 1, 12, 489701) Mr. Doke complained of severe pains in the back and had to take to his bed again.
('13', 260, 1, 13, 489783) The usual remedies for fever were applied, but, as there seemed to be no temperature, it was concluded that the malady was not fever, and a doctor was sent for, who at once ordered him to the Umtali Hospital, whither he was conveyed by “machilla”.
('13', 260, 1, 14, 490031) Here he was under the best doctors and nursing supervision possible.
('13', 260, 1, 15, 490100) On the 12th a telegram was sent to Mr. Doke’s family, saying that he had a slight attack of pleurisy, but that there was nothing serious and no one was to come.
('13', 260, 1, 16, 490261) On Friday evening, the 15th, a further telegram was received by Mrs. Doke saying that Mr. Doke was seriously ill with enteric.
('13', 260, 1, 17, 490388) Mrs. Doke at once made preparations to leave by Saturday night’s train, but on the morning of that day a telegram was received that Mr. Doke had passed away at 7 o’clock the previous evening.

('13', 261, 3, 6, 491148) 167. THE LATE MR. DOKE
('13', 261, 4, 7, 491171) In the death of Mr. Joseph J. Doke, the Indian community of South Africa has lost one of its truest friends.
('13', 261, 4, 8, 491280) This is not the place to recount Mr. Doke’s general public work, great and substantial as it was.
('13', 261, 4, 9, 491378) But, paying our humble tribute to the memory of the deceased, we cannot help contemplating Mr. Doke’s noble work for us.
('13', 261, 4, 10, 491499) When Mr. Doke came to the cause, he threw himself into it heart and soul and never relaxed his efforts in our behalf.
('13', 261, 4, 11, 491617) It was usual with Mr. Doke to gain complete mastery over the subject he handled.
('13', 261, 4, 12, 491698) He, therefore, became one of the best informed men on the subject in South Africa.
('13', 261, 4, 13, 491781) He loved passive resisters as they were his own congregation.
('13', 261, 4, 14, 491843) The poorest Indian had free access to this pious Englishman.
('13', 261, 4, 15, 491904) His pen and his eloquence were continually used by him during the troublous times through which the community has passed.
('13', 261, 4, 16, 492026) He missed no opportunity of visiting passive resistance prisoners in gaol.
('13', 261, 4, 17, 492101) And at a critical period in the history of the community and this journal, he magnanimously and at no small inconvenience to himself, took charge of our editorial department, and those who came in contact with him during that period know how cautious, how painstaking, how gentle and how forbearing he was.
('13', 261, 4, 18, 492408) It is such a noble soul whose withdrawal from this transitory world we, the Indian community, mourn in common with his family and his congregation.
('13', 261, 4, 19, 492556) We tender our respectful sympathy to Mrs. Doke and family.

('13', 268, 1, 2, 505660) 171. INDIA’S GRAND OLD MAN
('13', 268, 2, 3, 505687) Our readers hardly need a reminder that India’s G.O.M. celebrates his eighty ninth birthday on Thursday next, the 4th September.
('13', 268, 2, 4, 505816) We again have the pleasure of expressing our good wishes to India’s greatest son.
('13', 268, 2, 5, 505898) Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji has done more than one man’s share of public work and is now enjoying rest from his labours.
('13', 268, 2, 6, 506012) The memory of his strenuous life in the interests of his countrymen is a constant spur to our small efforts.
('13', 268, 2, 7, 506121) Such lives make a nation rich— not in material possession—but in all that goes to make national honour and faithfulness to duty.
('13', 268, 2, 8, 506250) For those who may wish to send messages of congratulations and who may not know his cable address we may state that messages addressed “Dadabhai Naoroji, Versova, Bombay”, will find him.
('13', 268, 2, 9, 506437) We present with this issue a special supple ment, giving the portrait of Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji.

('13', 269, 0, 1, 506558) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 269, 1, 2, 506600) 172. MORE FRIENDS GONE
('13', 269, 2, 3, 506623) The fates seem to have decreed that South Africa should lose, in quick succession, some of its best men.
('13', 269, 2, 4, 506728) Following on the heels of the news of Mr. Doke’s death, comes the shocking news of the death of Dr. Ross, that well known Presbyterian Minister on the Rand who relinquished his ministry only last year and the death of the popular Editor of The Natal Mercury, Mr. Milligan.
('13', 269, 2, 5, 507001) Dr. Ross’s was an influen tial personality.
('13', 269, 2, 6, 507045) We say nothing about him as a public man of Johan nesburg.
('13', 269, 2, 7, 507104) But we cannot help recalling with gratefulness the fact that Dr. Ross had made himself acquainted with the Transvaal Indian struggle and that he had joined Mr. Hosken’s Committee 1. He was often present at Indian functions and never hesitated, in unequivocal language, to show his sympathy towards us.
('13', 269, 2, 8, 507406) We know that, when passive resistance was at its height, he even carried on personal corres pondence with General Smuts, urging him to grant the demands of passive resisters.
('13', 269, 2, 9, 507581) With Mr. Milligan’s services to the Indian cause Indians are quite familiar.
('13', 269, 2, 10, 507658) He carried out the best traditions of the Mercury and worthily filled the chair that used to be occupied by the late Sir John Robinson 2 and the late Mr. Ramsay Collins—no easy task.
('13', 269, 2, 11, 507841) Only the other week, we had the pleasure to reproduce a trenchant leading article written in his paper by the deceased regarding the arbitrary action of immigration officials.
('13', 269, 2, 12, 508017) His pen was ever ready to be used for any just cause.
('13', 269, 2, 13, 508071) In the passing away of such men, South Africa is undoubtedly the poorer.
('13', 269, 2, 14, 508144) And the loss will be difficult to make up.
('13', 269, 2, 15, 508187) We tender our sympathy to the families of the deceased.
('13', 269, 3, 16, 508243) Indian Opinion,30 8 1913
('13', 269, 4, 17, 508268) 1 Committee of European sympathizers of the Indian cause led by William Hosken, M.L.A. ('13', 270, 0, 1, 508612) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 271
('13', 270, 1, 2, 508659) 173. IMPORTANT JUDGMENT ABOUT MARRIAGE
('13', 270, 2, 3, 508698) An Indian woman named Bai Manchhi was stopped by the Immigration Officer when entering [the Cape Colony] with her husband.
('13', 270, 2, 4, 508821) The latter, Bhagwan Bhikha by name, obtained an interdict to enable her to land.
('13', 270, 2, 5, 508902) Since their marriage in India was not recog nized, the counsel advised marriage with the woman here.
('13', 270, 2, 6, 509003) On the counsel writing to the magistrate, the latter expressed his inability to register the marriage on the ground that the woman was a prohibited immigrant.
('13', 270, 2, 7, 509162) The husband thereupon went in appeal, which Mr. Justice Gardiner decided in his favour last week.
('13', 270, 2, 8, 509260) The judge has held that under the law anyone’s marriage can be registered.
('13', 270, 2, 9, 509335) The parties must only prove that they are both eligible to get married under the law in force here.
('13', 270, 2, 10, 509435) At the time of marriage, whether one is a prohibited immigrant or not is an irrelevant question.
('13', 270, 2, 11, 509532) Accordingly, the magistrate has been ordered to register the marriage without raising any such issue, provided there is no other ground for objection.
('13', 270, 2, 12, 509683) As a result of this judgment, if any Indian brings out his wife and she is stopped by the Immigration Officer, they can get married after landing.
('13', 270, 2, 13, 509830) Whether, after the marriage, she can stay on or not is a different question, which the judgment referred to above does not decide.
('13', 270, 2, 14, 509961) It is also a separate question, and a big one, whether or not one should go through a marriage in this manner.
('13', 270, 2, 15, 510072) If a man, having married a woman once, declares that he has not and so marries her again, his action will prove him to be a man without honour and, therefore, a coward.
('13', 270, 2, 16, 510241) The poor people must have patience and assure themselves that the problem will solve itself in due course.
('13', 270, 2, 17, 510348) If they fail to get relief meanwhile, the honourable course for them is to leave their wives in India.
('13', 270, 3, 18, 510451) [From Gujarati]

('13', 272, 1, 2, 511363) 175. LETTER TO ASSISTANT SECRETARY FOR INTERIOR
('13', 272, 2, 3, 511411) [JOHANNESBURG,] September 3, 1913 As I informed you through the telephone, today, I am leaving for Phoenix tomorrow.
('13', 272, 2, 4, 511528) But, before I leave, I would like to draw General Smuts’ attention to the eagerness and impatience with which many of my co workers are looking forward to some final answer.
('13', 272, 2, 5, 511702) Indeed, I have even been blamed for writing the first letter.
('13', 272, 2, 6, 511764) Their impatience is natural.
('13', 272, 2, 7, 511793) All our activity is at a standstill.
('13', 272, 2, 8, 511830) Several have been obliged to refuse offers of handsome employment owing to the suspense.
('13', 272, 2, 9, 511919) I hope, therefore, that among the many important matters that engage General Smuts’ attention, this will find its proper place.
('13', 272, 2, 10, 512047) If nothing definite is vouchsafed by Tuesday next,—the day given by you—may Mr. Gorges’ letter be taken as the final answer?
('13', 272, 2, 11, 512172) I would also like to mention that, if the negotiations now going on prove abortive, the struggle will be revived on a wider issue.
('13', 272, 2, 12, 512303) Several most important items have been omitted from my correspondence for the purpose 1 of securing a settlement and in order to show that we are not pining for a revival of the struggle.
('13', 272, 2, 13, 512491) I hope that General Smuts will appreciate the spirit in which this letter has been written.

('13', 273, 2, 3, 512715) ON THE TRAIN, Thursday [September 4, 1913]
('13', 273, 3, 4, 512758) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE, You must be firmer with yourself.
('13', 273, 3, 5, 512813) You often speak and give opinions on the spur of the moment.
('13', 273, 3, 6, 512874) That is called being impulsive.
('13', 273, 3, 7, 512906) And you are impulsive very much so.
('13', 273, 3, 8, 512942) Now the last hymn we sang was: “Take my life”, etc.
('13', 273, 3, 9, 512994) I know that neither you nor I have given our life or anything completely to God.
('13', 273, 3, 10, 513075) But is it our earnest longing to do so?
('13', 273, 3, 11, 513115) If it is, our impulsivenss must go I can give you scores of instances where you would have spoken otherwise if you had thought before speaking.
('13', 273, 3, 12, 513259) Do you know that you harmed Manilal by suggesting that you would surrender your ticket if he wanted to go or was going as far as Germiston.
('13', 273, 3, 13, 513399) The ticket is untransferable.
('13', 273, 3, 14, 513429) That is one thing.
('13', 273, 3, 15, 513448) I had to say that there was no occasion for him to go whereas he might have thought differently and therefore he might consider my judgment to be harsh.
('13', 273, 3, 16, 513601) This is the last illustration of what I want to say: ‘Think before you speak and look before you leap’ (as in the case of the proposed lease in Pretoria).
('13', 273, 3, 17, 513756) You have need to examine yourself much more than you are doing ≈ though you are doing a great deal, it is not enough.
('13', 273, 3, 18, 513874) I shall save the 2/6 for the bed.
('13', 273, 3, 19, 513908) I know there will be no need.
('13', 273, 3, 20, 513938) I saved 6 d.
('13', 273, 3, 21, 513951) by not buying tomatoes on the spur of the moment.
('13', 273, 3, 22, 514001) Medh did not stock my basket with tomatoes.
('13', 273, 3, 23, 514045) He had sent his messenger.
('13', 273, 3, 24, 514072) Manilal did not pluck your nice tomatoes.
('13', 273, 3, 25, 514114) The flesh wanted to spend 6 d.
('13', 273, 3, 26, 514145) the spirit resolutely declined to yield and triumphed.
('13', 273, 3, 27, 514200) I am none the worse for having not had them.
('13', 273, 3, 28, 514245) I did not act on the spur of the moment.
('13', 273, 3, 29, 514286) This does not mean that I never act or speak hastily.
('13', 273, 3, 30, 514340) But you must not copy me in my weaknesses.
('13', 273, 3, 31, 514383) With love,
('13', 273, 4, 32, 514394) UPPER HOUSE [PS.] Please hand [over] the enclosure to Manilal at the first opportunity.

('13', 274, 1, 2, 514619) 177. THE DEBATE IN THE LORDS
('13', 274, 2, 3, 514648) We have now the full text of the debate initiated by Lord Amp thill in the House of Lords on the Immigration Act of the Union.
('13', 274, 2, 4, 514775) 1 The debate is memorable for more than one reason.
('13', 274, 2, 5, 514827) Most weighty contributions were made to it by an ex Governor of Madras and one time acting Viceroy of India in the person of Lord Ampthill, by an ex Governor of Bombay in the person of Lord Sydenham 2 who has only just returned from India and who, therefore, knows the pulse of India on this question, and by an ex Viceroy of India in the person of Lord Curzon.
('13', 274, 2, 6, 515189) All these noblemen spoke fervently in our behalf and admitted the full justice of our demands.
('13', 274, 2, 7, 515284) They did not satisfy themselves with general statements but each of them showed a mastery of details of the question which one is not accustomed to in such debates.
('13', 274, 2, 8, 515449) Of Lord Ampthill’s great pains, care and attention we have now known for a number of years.
('13', 274, 2, 9, 515541) His Lordship has made our question his own.
('13', 274, 2, 10, 515585) But it is most consoling and refreshing to find Lords Curzon and Sydenham also possessing a wonderful grasp of the subject.
('13', 274, 2, 11, 515709) Their interest in our question is a happy augury for the future and it considerably strengthens Lord Ampthill’s hands in his advocacy of a cause he has found to be just and of such Imperial importance as to warrant, in the midst of his many other activities, his constant and personal attention.
('13', 274, 3, 12, 516005) The debate shows, too, that Lord Crewe had no case.
('13', 274, 3, 13, 516057) The attitude of non possumus that he took up is dangerous in the extreme.
('13', 274, 3, 14, 516131) We venture to think that the doctrine of non interference by the Imperial authority with the domestic affairs of self governing Colonies is being carried too far and is reaching a point that endangers the very stability of the Empire.
('13', 274, 3, 15, 516366) It is a mockery to describe self governing Colonies as part of the British Dominions if they are to

('13', 282, 1, 2, 524365) 182. LETTER TO SECRETARY FOR INTERIOR 1
('13', 282, 2, 3, 524405) 110, FIELD STREET,
('13', 282, 3, 4, 524424) DURBAN, September 11,1913
('13', 282, 4, 5, 524450) THE SECRETARY FOR THE INTERIOR PRETORIA
('13', 282, 6, 6, 524490) I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st ultimo in reply to mine of the 15th idem regarding the regulations framed under the Immigrants’ Restriction Act.
('13', 282, 6, 7, 524675) On behalf of the Anjuman, I respectfully submit that most of the objections raised by my Anjuman are to principles and not to details.
('13', 282, 6, 8, 524810) Lapse of time will certainly fail to affect principles.
('13', 282, 6, 9, 524866) That certificates of identity whose applicability is limited to a period of one year would be of infinitely less value than the permanent certificates that were issued under the old Natal Act is a fact of which the value will not be affected either way by lapse of time.
('13', 282, 6, 10, 525137) Nor will the fact of the imposition of the fee of £1 for even interprovincial visiting permits be affected by time.
('13', 282, 6, 11, 525253) In the humble opinion of my committee, the objec tions raised on its behalf merit early and favourable consideration.
('13', 282, 6, 12, 525371) With reference to the appointment of Immigration Officers as members of Appeal Boards, their inclusion is open to serious objec tion in spite of their not deciding all the individual cases themselves in the first instance.
('13', 282, 6, 13, 525594) They are the officials who are responsible to the Government for administering the Act in accordance with their ins tructions and they are the officials who will, my committee presumes, issue instructions to their subordinates.
('13', 282, 6, 14, 525822) They, therefore, could not be considered unbiased judges applying their minds without precon ceived ideas to cases before them.
('13', 282, 6, 15, 525950) My committee, therefore, strongly urges that the appointment of these officials should be cancelled in order to give the public interested in the proceedings of the Appeal
('13', 282, 7, 16, 526122) 1 An office copy of this letter is found in the Sangrahalaya papers and it is presumed that this was drafted by Gandhiji.
('13', 283, 0, 1, 526244) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 283, 1, 2, 526286) Boards a sense of security and to inspire that public with confidence in the decision of these Boards.
('13', 283, 2, 3, 526389) I have, etc.,
('13', 283, 3, 4, 526403) CHAIRMAN,
('13', 283, 4, 5, 526413) ZOROASTRIAN ANJUMAN
('13', 283, 5, 6, 526433) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S. N. 5858
('13', 283, 6, 7, 526493) 183. LETTER TO SECRETARY FOR INTERIOR 1
('13', 283, 7, 8, 526533) [JOHANNESBURG, September 12, 1913]
('13', 283, 9, 9, 526568) On behalf of the British Indian Association, I have the honour to submit, for the information of the Hon’ble the Minister, that, after having read your telegram 2 of September 9, addressed to Mr. Gandhi, it has been most reluctantly and with the utmost regret decided to revive passive resistance, owing to the inability or unwillingness of the Government to concede the points submitted by Mr. Gandhi in his letters to you, which my Association has seen.
('13', 283, 9, 10, 527024) I venture shortly to explain the position that unfortunately faces the community represented by my Association.
('13', 283, 9, 11, 527136) Ever since the British occupation, the position of the Indians residing in this Province has admittedly grown worse than it was during the Republican regime.
('13', 283, 9, 12, 527294) In 1906 it culminated in the Bill of that year, which not only summed up the black past but foreshadowed a blacker future, and which, though then vetoed; was repassed almost as the first Act of the Responsible Government, and became known as Act 2 of 1907 3. As the measure was considered by the community to
('13', 283, 10, 13, 527603) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion, 20 9 1913, under the caption “The Indian Demands”.
('13', 283, 10, 14, 527694) 2 Vide footnote 3 to “Letter to Secretary for Interior”, 24 8 1913 3 The Transvaal Asiatic Law Amendment Act, also known as the Transvaal Asiatic Registration Act.
('13', 284, 0, 1, 527858) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 285
('13', 284, 1, 2, 527905) be humiliating, and as the circumstances surrounding it showed a policy deliberately hostile to an honourable existence of the com munity in the Transvaal, my countrymen solemnly decided in the month of September, 1906 to adopt passive resistance.
('13', 284, 1, 3, 528153) 1 As is well known, over 3,500 imprisonments were suffered by my countrymen during the struggle, over 100 deportations to India took place, and even two deaths occurred, owing to the suffering gone through during the crisis.
('13', 284, 1, 4, 528378) Several families were rendered homeless, and they had to be supported from public funds.
('13', 284, 1, 5, 528467) Then came the provisional settlement of 1911, which the Indians thought not only promised them what they had been suffering for but also meant an attitude of friendliness towards them such that, almost complete prohibition of Indian immi gration being obtained, the resident Indian population would be free from the state of uncertainty it had lived in and might look forward to a steady improvement in its status, as a permanent element of the new nation that was forming in South Africa.
('13', 284, 1, 6, 528957) Moreover, the inauguration of the Union gave it some hope, though it filled it equally with misgivings and threw on the passive resisters a responsibility for the whole of the Union instead of for the Transvaal only.
('13', 284, 1, 7, 529174) But the community was soon disillusioned.
('13', 284, 1, 8, 529216) The administration of existing laws specially affecting it grew steadily harsher.
('13', 284, 1, 9, 529298) The Cape Licensing Act, the Natal Licensing Act, the Gold and the Township Laws of the Transvaal and the existing Immigration Laws of the Provi nces began to be administered as they never had been before.
('13', 284, 1, 10, 529503) What has been termed the “northern,” spirit began to pervade the admini stration in Natal and the Cape.
('13', 284, 1, 11, 529607) Thus the spirit of the settlement cer tainly began to be broken as soon as it was effected.
('13', 284, 1, 12, 529699) The abortive Bill of 1912 showed that even the letter would be broken.
('13', 284, 1, 13, 529770) The original draft contained serious flaws and was in conflict with the two principles of the settlement—the removal of the racial bar and the maintenance of existing rights throughout the Union.
('13', 284, 1, 14, 529966) I must admit in fairness that, so soon as the defects were pointed out, there was a willingness on the part of the Minister to remodel his objection able clauses.
('13', 284, 1, 15, 530129) But that Bill fell through, and fresh assurances were issued to the community that the settlement would be carried out.
('13', 284, 2, 16, 530249) 1 Vide “The Mass Meeting”, 11 9 1906.
('13', 285, 0, 1, 530287) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 285, 1, 2, 530329) Then came the memorable visit of the Hon’ble.
('13', 285, 1, 3, 530375) Mr. Gokhale.
('13', 285, 1, 4, 530388) High hopes were again raised.
('13', 285, 1, 5, 530418) The position was made perfectly clear.
('13', 285, 1, 6, 530457) And declarations were made by responsible statesmen inducing the expectation that a satisfactory Bill would be passed during the ensuing session, and that the iniquitous and admittedly unjust tax of £3 on certain ex indentured men and women would be withdrawn.
('13', 285, 1, 7, 530718) The Hon’ble Mr. Gokhale declared at public meetings that he had every confidence that the tax would be abolished both for men and women.
('13', 285, 2, 8, 530855) But the last session dashed all hope to the ground.
('13', 285, 2, 9, 530907) The Draft Immigration Bill broke almost every condition of the settlement of 1911, and it showed that the community was to expect nothing from the Government, who would have carried the Bill as it was, could they have done so.
('13', 285, 2, 10, 531134) That the Act itself is a great improvement on the original Bill is due entirely to the unexpected opposition that the Government met from all quarters of both Houses of Parliament.
('13', 285, 2, 11, 531315) The attempt of the Government to remit the £3 tax only on women showed also that they, at any rate, were not prepared to remove it from men.
('13', 285, 3, 12, 531456) Notwithstanding such gloomy indications of the hostile spirit of the Government, Mr. Gandhi was authorized to enter into negotiations for a settlement by submitting proposals which, if accepted, would have just, but only just, sufficed to fulfil the letter of the provisional settlement of 1911 above referred to.
('13', 285, 3, 13, 531770) The community had hoped that, if even such a settlement were effected, the terrible passive resistance could be avoided, and that other grievances could be pressed on the attention of the Government by means involving less personal sacrifice and suffering by the community.
('13', 285, 4, 14, 532044) But the Government evidently thought otherwise.
('13', 285, 4, 15, 532092) They have not only rejected most of Mr. Gandhi’s proposals, but they are showing by their administration of the new Act in Natal and by their having passed regulations under the Act, some of which are harsh and unjust, that it is their desire not only to keep out new immigrants, but also to keep out domiciled residents who, before the new Act, found no difficulty in re entering, and to put obstacles in the way of wives of domiciled Indians entering the respective Provinces.
('13', 285, 5, 16, 532571) In the circumstances, there is now no course left open to the community but to take up passive resistance again, which now
('13', 286, 0, 1, 532694) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 287
('13', 286, 1, 2, 532741) naturally will not be confined to this Province alone, and which, on this occasion, will be taken up by women as well as men.
('13', 286, 1, 3, 532867) The leaders of the community fully realize their responsibility in the matter.
('13', 286, 1, 4, 532946) They know also what they and their countrymen will have to suffer.
('13', 286, 1, 5, 533013) But they feel that, as an unrepresented and voiceless community which has been so much misunderstood in the past and which is labouring under a curious but strong race prejudice, it can only defend its honour and status by a process of sacrifice and self suffering.
('13', 286, 1, 6, 533279) Passive resistance has been recognized by the Government as a legitimate means of securing redress.
('13', 286, 1, 7, 533379) It is, therefore, hardly necessary to assure the Government that the community has no desire to defy the laws of the land, to which it will submit by bearing the penalties provided for a breach of the obligations thereunder which the com munity cannot discharge consistently with its honour and self respect.
('13', 286, 1, 8, 533688) In conclusion, I beg to state that the struggle will be continued so long as:
('13', 286, 2, 9, 533766) (1) a racial bar disfigures the Immigration Act;
('13', 286, 3, 10, 533815) (2) the rights existing prior to the passing of the Act are not restored and maintained;
('13', 286, 4, 11, 533904) (3) the £3 tax upon ex indentured men, women, and children is not removed;
('13', 286, 5, 12, 533979) (4) the status of women married in South Africa is not secured;
('13', 286, 6, 13, 534043) (5) generally, so long as a spirit of generosity and justice does not pervade the administration of the existing laws referred to herein.
('13', 286, 7, 14, 534181) And it is respectfully submitted that a smooth and just working of the laws is not possible until the Government consult the leaders of the community in the different Provinces.
('13', 286, 8, 15, 534359) [I have, etc.,]
('13', 286, 9, 16, 534375) A. M. CACHALIA
('13', 286, 10, 17, 534390) CHAIRMAN,
('13', 286, 11, 18, 534400) BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('13', 286, 12, 19, 534427) Rand Daily Mail, 15 9 1913
('13', 287, 0, 1, 534454) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 287, 1, 2, 534496) 184. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('13', 287, 2, 3, 534530) [Phoenix, September 12, 1913]
('13', 287, 3, 4, 534560) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('13', 287, 4, 5, 534581) I have your letter.
('13', 287, 4, 6, 534601) It is strange you did not receive my letter on Monday.
('13', 287, 4, 7, 534656) I gave it to Sorabji to post.
('13', 287, 4, 8, 534686) But the careless boy evidently never posted it or posted it too late.
('13', 287, 5, 9, 534756) If I receive a reply tomorrow that Cachalia’s letter has gone, I shall send the resisters from here on Monday.
('13', 287, 5, 10, 534867) They will reach Volksrust on Tuesday.
('13', 287, 5, 11, 534905) You should leave Monday night by the mail train so that you are at the station when the Kaffir Mail reaches Volksrust on Tuesday evening.
('13', 287, 5, 12, 535043) You should simply watch as a spectator.
('13', 287, 5, 13, 535083) They are not to speak in English.
('13', 287, 5, 14, 535117) One of them only will speak in that tongue, interpret for the others.
('13', 287, 5, 15, 535187) They will not give finger prints.
('13', 287, 5, 16, 535221) If the police arrest them, they must ask for shelter at the police station.
('13', 287, 5, 17, 535297) If the police do not arrest them, you should, there and then, buy tickets for them and proceed to Johannesburg.
('13', 287, 5, 18, 535409) I then suggest their being housed at Mountain View.
('13', 287, 5, 19, 535461) If strangers don’t come, it might be well to make Mountain View the headquarters.
('13', 287, 5, 20, 535543) But you are to be the judge, not I, of this thing.
('13', 287, 5, 21, 535594) If they are to go to Mountain View, you may buy nothing but leave instructions for purchases so that you have full stock at once.
('13', 287, 5, 22, 535724) No more than Boer meal and a little dholl and rice will be required and fruit and nuts of course.
('13', 287, 5, 23, 535822) If they are arrested, you should attend court, send full wire to me from Volksrust as also full letter.
('13', 287, 5, 24, 535926) If they are imprisoned you should immediately see the gaol doctor and the jailor and tell them of religious and health foods they may take and may not take.
('13', 287, 5, 25, 536083) But you should also say that they will not complain if they do not get what they want.
('13', 287, 5, 26, 536170) Mrs. Gandhi will be purely fruitarian.
('13', 287, 5, 27, 536209) Jeki and others will not touch bread.
('13', 287, 5, 28, 536247) Some of them will be able to take only one meal.
('13', 287, 5, 29, 536296) The names and further details later.
('13', 287, 5, 30, 536333) It is well that you will be free from your business even if passive resistance is to start.
('13', 287, 5, 31, 536425) Your whole time will be wanted for the struggle.
('13', 287, 5, 32, 536474) You should read my letter to be
('13', 288, 0, 1, 536506) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 289
('13', 288, 1, 2, 536553) signed by Cachalia most carefully.
('13', 288, 3, 3, 536588) UPPER HOUSE
('13', 288, 4, 4, 536600) From the original: Gandhi Kallenbach Correspondence.
('13', 288, 4, 5, 536653) Courtesy: National Archives of India
('13', 288, 5, 6, 536690) 185. NO SETTLEMENT
('13', 288, 6, 7, 536709) We reported earlier that negotiations for a settlement were going on between the Government and Mr. Gandhi.
('13', 288, 6, 8, 536817) We have now to announce that they have failed and that satyagraha will be revived.
('13', 288, 6, 9, 536900) In this, too, there must be some divine purpose.
('13', 288, 6, 10, 536949) So far as we can judge, the revival of the struggle is to our advantage.
('13', 288, 6, 11, 537022) Had there been a settlement, it would have barely fulfilled the letter of the terms of the 1911 settlement.
('13', 288, 6, 12, 537130) The object of the settlement would have been defeated, for the settlement would have been honoured only in the letter.
('13', 288, 6, 13, 537249) The rights of Indians born in South Africa to enter the Cape would have been safeguarded.
('13', 288, 6, 14, 537339) The marriage problem would have been solved and, in theory, the colour bar would have disappeared.
('13', 288, 6, 15, 537438) Even this would have been all right, though it was not likely to have satisfied the community.
('13', 288, 6, 16, 537533) Now the Government has placed us under an obligation by not granting even that much.
('13', 288, 6, 17, 537618) The real object of our fight must be to kill the monster of racial prejudice in the heart of the Government and the local whites.
('13', 288, 6, 18, 537748) We feel the presence of this monster in the Government’s administration of the Gold Law in the Transvaal and the new immigrant law, in its insistence on the collection of the £3 tax from poor, miserable, helpless Indians, and in its attitude towards our women.
('13', 288, 7, 19, 538009) The best cure for all this lies, not in securing the repeal or amendment of the respective laws, but in rooting out the evil from the heart.
('13', 288, 7, 20, 538150) There is only one way to kill the monster and that is to offer ourselves as a sacrifice.
('13', 288, 7, 21, 538239) There is no life except through death.
('13', 288, 8, 22, 538278) 1 Vide “Letter to Secretary for Interior”, 12 9 1913.
('13', 289, 0, 1, 538332) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 289, 1, 2, 538374) alone can raise us.
('13', 289, 1, 3, 538394) It is the only effective means of persuasion.
('13', 289, 1, 4, 538440) It is a seal which leaves a permanent imprint.
('13', 289, 1, 5, 538487) We will not conquer the whites by hating them.
('13', 289, 1, 6, 538534) We can gain no victory by killing them.
('13', 289, 1, 7, 538574) We may kill a white in the body, but the monster inside will survive and multiply.
('13', 289, 1, 8, 538657) A tree will grow the larger when a branch is cut.
('13', 289, 1, 9, 538707) It will be destroyed only if it is pulled out by the roots.
('13', 289, 1, 10, 538767) In the same way, we are not concerned with the body of any white, but only with the evil in his heart.
('13', 289, 1, 11, 538870) The only effective way of bringing about a change in his attitude is satyagraha.
('13', 289, 1, 12, 538951) It is a divine law that even the most hard hearted man will melt if he sees his enemy suffering in innocence.
('13', 289, 1, 13, 539061) The satyagrahi volunteers to suffer in this way.
('13', 289, 1, 14, 539110) There is another remedy, but it is not likely to be adopted.
('13', 289, 1, 15, 539171) For the prejudice in the heart of the whites against us, we are partly responsible.
('13', 289, 1, 16, 539255) We have several defects.
('13', 289, 1, 17, 539280) We tell lies and follow wrong courses.
('13', 289, 1, 18, 539319) We give false evidence.
('13', 289, 1, 19, 539343) We are dirty in our ways.
('13', 289, 1, 20, 539369) We can overcome the whites’ prejudice only if we give up these bad habits.
('13', 289, 1, 21, 539444) But this is not likely to happen.
('13', 289, 1, 22, 539478) The Indian who is full of faults will not read writings of this kind.
('13', 289, 1, 23, 539548) Nor can those who do make him see reason.
('13', 289, 1, 24, 539590) Satyagrahis should die for his sake as well.
('13', 289, 1, 25, 539635) Their death will be an education for these our brethren, whom ignorance has made blind.
('13', 289, 1, 26, 539723) It has always been the way of this world that the fruit of one’s death is reaped by others.
('13', 289, 1, 27, 539815) Not to seek gain through one’s death is in itself a gain.
('13', 289, 1, 28, 539873) This difficult saying needs to be pondered over.
('13', 289, 1, 29, 539922) It is the great secret by which one can gain true life.
('13', 289, 1, 30, 539978) Those alone who join satyagraha in this spirit will win in this great fight that is beginning.
('13', 289, 1, 31, 540073) We entreat those who cannot join the fight not to oppose it, but to give whatever help they can.
('13', 289, 1, 32, 540170) They should think of the community’s interest.
('13', 289, 1, 33, 540217) If they can do or say nothing good, let them stay quiet.
('13', 289, 1, 34, 540274) If they are weak, let them admit their weakness rather than weaken others.
('13', 289, 1, 35, 540349) In this way we can help one another.
('13', 289, 1, 36, 540386) The campaign this time has no programme or plan of action.
('13', 289, 1, 37, 540445) The plan will unfold itself as we proceed.
('13', 289, 1, 38, 540488) This is a fight for bringing about a change in the Government’s hostile attitude to us.
('13', 289, 1, 39, 540576) The obnoxious £3 tax must go at any cost.
('13', 289, 1, 40, 540618) That is a debt we owe to the defenceless Indians, and to Mr. Gokhale.
('13', 289, 1, 41, 540688) The Government, breaking a promise made to him, has broken a promise made to us.
('13', 289, 1, 42, 540769) We hope that many Indians will utilize this golden opportunity and that God will give the requisite strength and
('13', 290, 0, 1, 540882) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 291
('13', 290, 1, 2, 540929) faith to those who join the fight.
