('13', 290, 4, 5, 541006) 186. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('13', 290, 5, 6, 541040) [PHOENIX], [September 15, 1913] 1
('13', 290, 6, 7, 541074) DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('13', 290, 7, 8, 541092) I am dictating this to Ramdas as I am eating.
('13', 290, 7, 9, 541138) I have your two letters.
('13', 290, 7, 10, 541163) When you meet the train tomorrow you will not at once identify yourself but simply watch as a spectator.
('13', 290, 7, 11, 541268) I am sending special foodstuff for Mrs. Gandhi.
('13', 290, 7, 12, 541316) Until she is in jail she will use the food I have prepared.
('13', 290, 7, 13, 541376) When she is sentenced you should take charge of her food and after you have received permission to give her special food you should take charge of the food.
('13', 290, 7, 14, 541533) After the sentence and after you have made arrange 2 ments you should give it to the gaoler.
('13', 290, 7, 15, 541626) So far as possible you would arrange for her to receive the food from the Government.
('13', 290, 7, 16, 541712) She is only fruitarian, for health and religious reasons and she can take olive oil, bananas, plums, dried figs, almonds, tomatoes, grapes, oranges, lemons, banana flour, apples.
('13', 290, 7, 17, 541891) You will stay there until everything is fixed up and either come here or return to Johannesburg according to the exigencies of the struggle and of your own personal affairs.
('13', 290, 7, 18, 542065) About your business, we shall talk later or I shall write later on.
('13', 290, 8, 19, 542133) Yours, FOR BAPU, CHHAGANLAL

('13', 291, 4, 5, 542784) 187. LETTER TO KASHI GANDHI AND SANTOK GANDHI
('13', 291, 5, 6, 542830) [September 15, 1913] 1
('13', 291, 6, 7, 542853) KASHI 2 AND SANTOK 3,
('13', 291, 7, 8, 542875) Today is Friday and I have finished my writing work.
('13', 291, 7, 9, 542928) So I have some free time.
('13', 291, 7, 10, 542954) Jeki 4 wants to know whether the children will be able to live without you.
('13', 291, 7, 11, 543030) Parents fondly imagine that their children would not be able to live without them.
('13', 291, 7, 12, 543113) To uphold their conceit, parents believe that their children will be fretting restlessly in their absence.
('13', 291, 7, 13, 543220) They do not realize that all the people about them get deprived of their parents and still none of them pines away to death.
('13', 291, 7, 14, 543345) To children, those who love them at the moment are their parents.
('13', 291, 7, 15, 543411) Rukhi laughed and frisked about as soon as the train moved out.
('13', 291, 7, 16, 543475) Radha cried a little after the train had left but when I told her of a prize for her, after about five minutes, she also started talking to others.
('13', 291, 7, 17, 543623) Krishna and Keshu were not even aware that anything had happened.
('13', 291, 7, 18, 543689) They were shouting and running all the way back.
('13', 291, 7, 19, 543738) All of them lifted up one another and played among themselves.
('13', 291, 7, 20, 543801) When they reached home, they asked for the finest dishes to be served.
('13', 291, 7, 21, 543872) I even had to tell Krishna and Keshu, “See now, your parents have gone to jail and so, though you are children, you ought to exercise some self control.” They, then, felt a little abashed.
('13', 291, 7, 22, 544061) These two do not call to mind anyone even for a moment.
('13', 291, 7, 23, 544117) Rukhi and Radha are real ladies.

('13', 302, 0, 1, 559671) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 303
('13', 302, 1, 2, 559718) 195. MR. CACHALIA’S LETTER 1
('13', 302, 2, 3, 559747) The irrevocable step has been taken.
('13', 302, 2, 4, 559784) The British world knows, through the magnificent agency of Reuter, that the handful of Indians in South Africa have declared passive resistance— that this microscopic minority of men have pitted themselves against a mighty Government, against a European population comparatively overwhe lming in numbers and enjoying the privileges which cannot belong to Indians in this sub continent, perhaps, for generations.
('13', 302, 2, 5, 560196) Indeed, this time, passive resistance is not merely against the Govern ment and the Europeans of South Africa, but it is equally against the Imperial Government.
('13', 302, 2, 6, 560358) Lord Ampthill, in his great speech in the House of Lords, has made it clear that, had the Imperial Government done their duty, the course of legislation would have been different; had they been only neutral, the Immigration Act would probably have not been passed.
('13', 302, 2, 7, 560623) We may not, therefore, expect any assistance from them unless, by passive resistance, we open their eyes and they begin to see clearly how criminally they neglected their trust.
('13', 302, 2, 8, 560801) Mr. Cachalia has made it perfectly clear why the great and awful step has been taken—a step that may mean ruin to hundreds of our countrymen.
('13', 302, 2, 9, 560943) He states definitely the demands of the community.
('13', 302, 2, 10, 560994) He asks for (l) removal of the racial bar from the Immigration Act, (2) the restoration of rights that existed prior to the legislation, (3) a generous and just administration of the existing laws throughout the Union affecting Indians, (4) the removal of the £3 tax, and finally (5) a spirit of friendliness towards the community in place of one ofhostility which one notices in all their acts concerning Indians.
('13', 302, 2, 11, 561409) And this is what Lord Ampthill asked in his speech just referred to.
('13', 302, 2, 12, 561478) Let us examine each point as briefly as possible.
('13', 302, 2, 13, 561528) We notice that The Natal Mercury, in its otherwise admirable leaderette on the situation, falls foul of the objection to the racial bar.
('13', 302, 2, 14, 561665) We feel sure that our usually well informed contemporary has in this instance secured the service of a leader writer who is not yet au fait with the question.
('13', 302, 3, 15, 561824) 1 Vide “Letter to Secretary for Interior”, 12 9 1913.
('13', 303, 0, 1, 561878) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 303, 1, 2, 561920) That the racial bar should be removed has been common cause since 1910. Indeed, the Union Government have defended—and the Imperial Government have approved of—the measure, contending that there is no racial bar in it.
('13', 303, 1, 3, 562139) Nor does its removal in this case involve racial equality in every other case.
('13', 303, 1, 4, 562218) To remove the racial bar merely means a reversion to the state that existed in 1906. It refers to racial equality in law for purposes of immigration.
('13', 303, 1, 5, 562368) Even when this equality is granted, as it must be sooner or later, there will still remain racial inequality in respect of many other laws in all the provinces.
('13', 303, 1, 6, 562529) That, in spite of the Government’s protestations, racial inequality is to be found in the Act has been clearly shown by Lord Ampthill.
('13', 303, 1, 7, 562664) The Act requires from an Indian immigrant an unnecessary and insulting declaration which it does not from a European immigrant.
('13', 303, 1, 8, 562792) The declaration is merely an admission of the legal disabilities imposed on the Indians of the Free State.
('13', 303, 1, 9, 562899) Without the admission the disabilities, as had been admitted by the Government, will remain.
('13', 303, 1, 10, 562992) The retention of this racial bar is due merely to the unreasoning obstinacy of the Free State Members of the Union Parliament.
('13', 303, 1, 11, 563119) The Government do not wish to offend these, their supporters.
('13', 303, 1, 12, 563181) Otherwise, removal of the racial bar means nothing to the Government and it may not add a single Indian resident to the Free State population.
('13', 303, 1, 13, 563324) As a matter of fact, removal of the racial bar is one of the items of existing rights.
('13', 303, 1, 14, 563411) It has been separated from other such rights because the struggle hinged, prior to 1911, only round the racial bar question.
('13', 303, 1, 15, 563536) The existing rights attacked by the new Act are.
('13', 303, 1, 16, 563585) for instance, the right of South Africa born Indians to enter the Cape under the now repealed Cape Act by reason merely of their birth, the right that existed, or was assumed to exist, of the wive of resident Indians married in South Africa according to non Christian rites, to be regarded as legally married; the right of Natal Indians to absent themselves for any length of time from Natal and to return if they were proved to be bona fide holders of certificates of domicile.
('13', 303, 1, 17, 564064) We do not touch upon minor existing rights which may or may not have been taken away by the Act.
('13', 303, 1, 18, 564161) The £3 tax is the sorest question from many points of view.
('13', 303, 1, 19, 564221) It is a burden imposed upon a most helpless class and it is a tax which was universally condemned during Mr. Gokhale’s stay last year in South
('13', 304, 0, 1, 564364) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 305
('13', 304, 1, 2, 564411) Africa and, as Lord Ampthill most emphatically states, “the Ministers in South Africa definitely promised Mr. Gokhale that this £3 poll tax should be removed and Ministers told the Governor General that they had given him this promise”.
('13', 304, 1, 3, 564648) We hold that a promise given to Mr. Gokhale is a promise given to the Indian community.
('13', 304, 1, 4, 564736) It, therefore, becomes our sacred duty to offer passive resistance until the tax is repealed.
('13', 304, 1, 5, 564830) Indians cannot be expected to sit still if the administration of the existing laws is made harsher day by day.
('13', 304, 1, 6, 564941) Formerly Indian wives were admitted without fuss and without much questioning.
('13', 304, 1, 7, 565020) Now the Government have instructed Immigration Officers to demand closest proof, and then, too, there are all kinds of quibbles raised.
('13', 304, 1, 8, 565156) Kulsam bibi’s case is the latest.
('13', 304, 1, 9, 565190) There never has been any justification offered for such harshness of procedure in admitting Indian wives.
('13', 304, 1, 10, 565296) There has been no charge brought against us of having attempted to bring in women of questionable character or of our women having offered any competition.
('13', 304, 1, 11, 565452) Then, take the unreasonable deposit of £25 required from men who want to prove their domicile as against £10 which used to be demanded before.
('13', 304, 1, 12, 565595) Visiting passes which used to be issued fairly liberally are now being granted in a most niggardly spirit.
('13', 304, 1, 13, 565702) We know of cases in which sons have been refused permits to visit their parents and business people to visit other provinces to collect their debts.
('13', 304, 1, 14, 565851) It is no easy matter for an Indian creditor to secure a permit to visit the Transvaal for the purpose of collecting his book debts.
('13', 304, 1, 15, 565983) The tendency of the administration is to wipe out the resident Indian population by making its life in South Africa as intolerable as possible.
('13', 304, 1, 16, 566127) The administration of the Gold Law and the Townships Act in the Trans vaal and of the trade licensing laws in Natal and the Cape has been simply scandalous.
('13', 304, 1, 17, 566284) Mr. Cachalia, therefore, insists that this method of administering the laws affecting us must be changed.
('13', 304, 1, 18, 566390) And none of the reforms Mr. Cachalia desires can possibly be attained unless the Government and the Europeans of South Africa adopt a less hostile and more reasonable attitude.
('13', 304, 1, 19, 566567) If the former continue to frown upon us and the latter continue to pass resolutions demanding our destruction by a process of compulsory civic starva tion, we must meet them by showing that we are capable of dying for our honour and an honourable existence in South Africa, not by
('13', 305, 0, 1, 566848) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 305, 1, 2, 566890) fighting them bodily, but by a process of voluntary suffering which at once purifies and dignifies.
('13', 305, 2, 3, 566990) Indian Opinion, 20 9 1913
('13', 305, 3, 4, 567016) 196. HOW TO DO IT
('13', 305, 4, 5, 567034) Passive resistance, this time, will be comparatively an easy matter, as it will extend to all the Provinces of the Union,—not that the sufferings will be less; indeed, they are likely to be greater, but to court imprisonment will be easier.
('13', 305, 4, 6, 567275) Hitherto, passive resisters have challenged arrest by crossing the Transvaal border.
('13', 305, 4, 7, 567360) That is how the present struggle, too, has been commenced.
('13', 305, 4, 8, 567419) We may, on this question of the crossing of the border, at once say that this method of resistance does not mean that we are asking for a breaking of the provincial boundaries.
('13', 305, 4, 9, 567596) On the contrary, as soon as the reason for the struggle ceases, those who will have crossed the borders of different Provinces will return to the Province of their domicile.
('13', 305, 4, 10, 567770) Passive resisters are not fighting—Dare not fight—for personal and individual rights.
('13', 305, 4, 11, 567856) But the crossing is an expensive business.
('13', 305, 4, 12, 567899) Those who feel inclined to take an active part in the campaign can, in a quiet and dignified manner, court arrest by hawking or trading without licences, or, if they have their licences, without showing them.
('13', 305, 4, 13, 568108) They should, in each case, inform the police or the courts that it is not their intention thus to break the law but that, until there is a settlement with the Government, they propose not to assist the authorities in carrying out the laws of the land which have no moral or natural but only an artificial basis.
('13', 305, 4, 14, 568420) This is not a struggle of a day.
('13', 305, 4, 15, 568453) Each one can think out for himself how he can best court arrest.
('13', 305, 4, 16, 568518) Time and experience will show the right way if we have the will to suffer for the sake of our own and our country’s honour.
('13', 305, 5, 17, 568642) Indian Opinion, 20 9 1913
('13', 306, 0, 1, 568668) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 307
('13', 306, 1, 2, 568715) 197. HOW TO ORGANIZE THE STRUGGLE
('13', 306, 2, 3, 568749) This third campaign will embrace the whole of South Africa.
('13', 306, 2, 4, 568809) We believe, therefore, that going to gaol will be an easy matter.
('13', 306, 2, 5, 568875) It does not mean that this time the sufferings in gaol will be less.
('13', 306, 2, 6, 568944) They may even be more.
('13', 306, 2, 7, 568967) Only, it will not be difficult, as it was before, to find ways of going to gaol.
('13', 306, 2, 8, 569048) So far, people courted imprisonment by entering the Transvaal.
('13', 306, 2, 9, 569111) There is no need to do that this time.
('13', 306, 2, 10, 569150) If, in every town and every province, a few Indians at least take intelligent interest in the fight, they will be able to participate in it in some measure, however small, and help it.
('13', 306, 2, 11, 569335) The easiest way is for the hawkers.
('13', 306, 2, 12, 569371) Those who are hawkers by profession, as also those who are not, can get arrested by hawking without licences.
('13', 306, 2, 13, 569481) For this, the imprisonment will be only for a short term.
('13', 306, 2, 14, 569539) It will involve no risk of goods being auctioned.
('13', 306, 2, 15, 569589) Moreover, they can pause and rest when tired.
('13', 306, 2, 16, 569635) If we can have such a movement in every town, we shall have put up a big fight.
('13', 306, 2, 17, 569715) It will agitate the whole of South Africa and compel the most serious attention from those in power.
('13', 306, 2, 18, 569816) Even those who hold licences can act in this manner.
('13', 306, 2, 19, 569869) The police demand licences from time to time.
('13', 306, 2, 20, 569915) If, having them, we do not produce them, it will be their duty to arrest us.
('13', 306, 2, 21, 569992) Store keepers and even their assistants can do this and so get arrested.
('13', 306, 2, 22, 570065) As we think of it, we see that this is the easiest way and the simplest.
('13', 306, 2, 23, 570138) It will involve compara tively little of suffering, the initiative will always be with us and we shall be able to have rest whenever we want.
('13', 306, 2, 24, 570280) The hawkers and store keepers should remember that their interests are deeply involved in the struggle.
('13', 306, 2, 25, 570384) Both the Government and the whites feel sore over trade more than anything else.
('13', 306, 2, 26, 570465) If we were not to engage in trade, we would provoke much less envy.
('13', 306, 2, 27, 570533) Trade is our very life here.
('13', 306, 2, 28, 570562) One should always remember that our sufferings will diminish in the measure in which we command increased respect.
('13', 306, 2, 29, 570677) We hope, therefore, that the business community will utilize this excellent opportunity which will cost them so little.
('13', 306, 2, 30, 570797) We need hardly say that even one single Indian in a town can put up such a fight.
('13', 306, 2, 31, 570879) If there is any such hero, he should send us his name before going to gaol.
('13', 306, 2, 32, 570955) Those who get arrested by crossing the border must bear in mind that they will not thereby acquire any
('13', 307, 0, 1, 571058) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 307, 1, 2, 571100) rights for themselves.
('13', 307, 1, 3, 571123) Satyagraha is not meant for acquiring rights for oneself.
('13', 307, 1, 4, 571181) Selfishness and satyagraha can never go together.
('13', 307, 2, 5, 571231) HOW TO HELP IN OTHER WAYS
('13', 307, 3, 6, 571257) We have seen above that it is only by going to gaol that we can best help the struggle.
('13', 307, 3, 7, 571345) But we know that all Indians do not have the pluck for this.
('13', 307, 3, 8, 571406) We need them to consider what such Indians should do.
('13', 307, 3, 9, 571460) We give below the ideas that occur to us.
('13', 307, 4, 10, 571502) One may look after the business of those who go to gaol and care for their families or see to the maintenance of their dependants.
('13', 307, 4, 11, 571633) 2. This time we are not going to ask for money from India.
('13', 307, 4, 12, 571692) At the same time, we are left at present with very little money; it is up to everyone to send contributions to the satyagraha fund.
('13', 307, 5, 13, 571824) 3. Those who cannot afford to give money, may send foodgrains.
('13', 307, 6, 14, 571887) 4. In every town of every province, meetings should be held and resolutions passed approving of Mr. Cachalia’s letter 1 and these resolutions should be dispatched, by telegram or post, both to the local and the Imperial Governments.
('13', 307, 7, 15, 572120) 5. Telegrams welcoming the fight should be sent to the [British Indian] Association.
('13', 307, 8, 16, 572205) 6. Wherever meetings cannot be held, telegrams and letters should be sent to the Government on behalf of public bodies.
('13', 307, 9, 17, 572325) 7. The matter should be discussed with the whites of one’s town and they should be kept well informed through issues of Indian Opinion having a bearing on the struggle.
('13', 307, 10, 18, 572494) 8. Shaking off lethargy, every Indian must acquaint himself with the aims of the campaign and the nature of the issues involved.
('13', 307, 10, 19, 572623) 9. Issues of Indian Opinion pertaining to the struggle should be procured and sent to different places in India and England.
('13', 307, 11, 20, 572748) 10. One should help in the collection of funds for the London Committee.
('13', 307, 12, 21, 572821) 11. Every Indian should set apart some time for the fight and engage himself during that period in some work or other connected
('13', 307, 13, 22, 572949) 1 Vide “Letter to Secretary for Interior”, 12 9 1913.
('13', 308, 0, 1, 573003) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 309
('13', 308, 1, 2, 573050) with it.
('13', 308, 2, 3, 573059) Most of these things may be done by every Indian and by every organization.
('13', 308, 2, 4, 573135) Every individual and every association must undertake as many of them as possible.
('13', 308, 2, 5, 573218) What can be done right now is to hold meetings at every place, pass resolutions and send them to both Governments.

('13', 310, 1, 2, 576025) 200. LETTER TO “THE NATAL MERCURY” 1
('13', 310, 2, 3, 576062) [DURBAN,] September 21, 1913
('13', 310, 4, 4, 576091) There is evidence in the special article from Pretoria on the Indian position which you published in your issue of Saturday last that its writer has been in the know.
('13', 310, 4, 5, 576258) It will, therefore, be accepted by the public as a weighty pronouncement on behalf of the Government.
('13', 310, 4, 6, 576360) You will, therefore, perhaps permit me to correct some of its most glaring errors.
('13', 310, 4, 7, 576443) The writer contends that two of the four things in dispute were granted by the Government.
('13', 310, 4, 8, 576534) This is only partly true.
('13', 310, 4, 9, 576560) The Free State difficulty is that of the legal racial bar.
('13', 310, 4, 10, 576619) The last telegram from Mr. Smuts lends colour to the suggestion that the difficulty is removed.
('13', 310, 4, 11, 576715) But in reality it is not.
('13', 310, 4, 12, 576741) What is required is an admission in the same way in which it was made about the point raised regarding the right of ex indentured Indians, that the new Act does not in law require any declaration not required from any other immigrant, from an Indian who may, under the Act, enter the Free State.
('13', 310, 4, 13, 577037) This is quite different from saying that such declaration will only be taken upon an Indian entering the Union.
('13', 310, 4, 14, 577149) The point is that, so far as immigration only is concerned, an Indian should be able to enter on the same terms as a European.
('13', 310, 4, 15, 577276) Administrative differentialism there undoubtedly will be.
('13', 310, 4, 16, 577334) But that will regulate the number of entrants, not the legal mode of entry.
('13', 310, 4, 17, 577410) The point is somewhat technical from the nature of the case.
('13', 310, 4, 18, 577471) The struggle has been directed hitherto towards guarding against a fundamental change in the British Constitution which is based upon the theory of equality.
('13', 310, 4, 19, 577629) The letter of the Indian contention was granted in 1910 after four years’ continuous suffering on the part of my countrymen.
('13', 310, 4, 20, 577754) But the spirit of it is missed even now in the new Act by reason of the ambiguous Free State clause.
('13', 310, 4, 21, 577855) The second difficulty not solved is the marriage question.
('13', 310, 5, 22, 577914) 1 Evidently, Gandhiji had simultaneously sent a copy of this letter to Indian Opinion, which published it in its issue of September 24.
('13', 311, 0, 1, 578050) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 311, 1, 2, 578092) correspondent asserts that I have asked for legal recognition of polygamy, and therefore, a subversion of the marriage law of the country, which is based on the Christian doctrine.
('13', 311, 1, 3, 578273) A glance at the correspondence 1 between the Government and myself, published in Indian Opinion, September 13, will show that I have not asked for any such thing.
('13', 311, 1, 4, 578436) I have asked that the legality of marriages of Indians celebrated in South Africa should be recognized in the same way as those celebrated in India will be, under the new Act.
('13', 311, 1, 5, 578612) I directed alteration to the flaw in the wording of the marriage clause in the new Act, and showed two ways of dealing with it, i.e., either by slightly amending the new Act or by similarly amending the marriage laws of the Union without in any way interfering with the monogamous nature of marriages.
('13', 311, 1, 6, 578914) The writer at Pretoria has raised the question of the meaning of “monogamous marriage”.
('13', 311, 1, 7, 579002) The point will be soon decided by the Supreme Court.
('13', 311, 1, 8, 579055) If the phrase does not mean what it was meant to mean when the marriage clause was passed, the blame will be that of the Government.
('13', 311, 1, 9, 579188) They have raised the issue, not the Indian community.
('13', 311, 1, 10, 579242) Millions of Indian unions in which the husband has married only one wife are, to the lay mind, monogamous marriages.
('13', 311, 1, 11, 579359) If the phrase means anything else, the Government have misled the Senate, the Imperial and Indian Governments, and the Indian community.
('13', 311, 1, 12, 579496) It will not be denied that this marriage question is one of the highest importance to us.
('13', 311, 1, 13, 579586) I am sure the Europeans of South Africa will permit us to cherish the honour of our womanhood as much as they cherish that of theirs.
('13', 311, 1, 14, 579720) As to the £3 poll tax, I note that your correspondent does not seriously contend that it is a new point.
('13', 311, 1, 15, 579825) He has only to look at the reservation clause in the correspondence of 1911 to see that it cannot be treated as a new point.
('13', 311, 1, 16, 579950) It is new in the sense that it was not included in the recent negotiations.
('13', 311, 1, 17, 580026) It could not well be as the discussion turned only upon the new Act.
('13', 311, 1, 18, 580095) Had there been a settlement on the basis of the negotiations, the community would have continued to urge the removal by way of petitioning, etc., but the negotiations having failed,
('13', 311, 2, 19, 580277) 1 This, inter alia, included letters addressed to the Private Secretary to the Minister of the Interior dated June 28, to the Secretary for the Interior dated July 2 and August 24, and to the Assistant Secretary for the Interior dated September 3. These have been given in their chronological order.
('13', 312, 0, 1, 580577) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 313
('13', 312, 1, 2, 580624) the way was open for the community to include this matter of simple humanity in the struggle.
('13', 312, 1, 3, 580718) Lord Ampthill has declared that the Union Government gave Mr. Gokhale a definite promise that the tax would be removed.
('13', 312, 1, 4, 580838) If the Government intend to keep the promise, they have but to say so, and there will be no struggle on that point.
('13', 312, 1, 5, 580954) If they do not intend to keep it, Indians would have no right to exist side by side with a free and self respecting community if they have no decency, and moral strength, to suffer imprisonment, or worse, in order that a promise given to their distinguished countryman may be fulfilled, and their poor, helpless countrymen freed from a burden which ought never to have been imposed on them, and for which the sin must, I fear, be shared by the free Indian population of South Africa almost equally with the Europeans.
('13', 312, 1, 6, 581472) Lastly, your correspondent’s advice that we should accept thankfully what has been granted, and what has been denied as being of little importance, and then press forward the redress of the balance of grievances by way of petitions, etc., and his suggestion that, then, we may be blessed with a special law such as the Natives’ Land Act, whereby we may have a reserve set apart for us where we can buy land, etc., remind me, if he will forgive me for the analogy, of Æsop’s justice loving wolf.
('13', 312, 1, 7, 581967) We have petitioned in vain all these years.
('13', 312, 1, 8, 582011) Right after right has been taken away from us.
('13', 312, 1, 9, 582058) And an Indian reserve means that the substantial right at present enjoyed of owning and buying land in Natal, and the Cape, and a modified right of possessing land in the Transvaal should be surrendered, and we must allow ourselves to be penned in an enclosure, and then bless the Government for this grace as a reward for not offering passive resistance, which involves suffering for nobody but ourselves, but which, if it ensures nothing else, at least saves us from a surrender of our manhood.
('13', 312, 2, 10, 582555) I am, etc.,
('13', 312, 3, 11, 582567) M. K. GANDHI
('13', 312, 4, 12, 582580) The Natal Mercury, 25 9 1913
('13', 313, 0, 1, 582609) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 313, 1, 2, 582651) 201. LETTER TO SECRETARY FOR INTERIOR
('13', 313, 2, 3, 582689) [DURBAN,] September 22, 1913
('13', 313, 3, 4, 582718) DEAR MR. GORGES,
('13', 313, 4, 5, 582735) I am much obliged to you for your letter 1 of the 19th instant regarding the marriage question.
('13', 313, 4, 6, 582831) I have not widened the original scope of my request.
('13', 313, 4, 7, 582884) But I shall endeavour as clearly as possible to re state the position.
('13', 313, 4, 8, 582955) It is submitted that authority should be taken from Parliament during its next session to legalize monogamous marriages already solemnized or hereafter to be solemnized by Indian priests among Indians belonging to non Christian denominations.
('13', 313, 4, 9, 583198) Legislation has become necessary only because the marriage clause in the new Act was hastily worded without considering the full position.
('13', 313, 4, 10, 583337) Unless the relief now sought is granted soon, the status of Indian women married in South Africa is that of concubines and their children not lawful heirs of their parents.
('13', 313, 4, 11, 583510) Such is, as I take it, the effect of the Searle judgment combined with the action of the Natal Master of the Supreme Court and the Gardiner judgment 2. I have asked for a promise of amelioration during the next session because I submit that the matter is one of urgency.
('13', 313, 4, 12, 583781) With regard to polygamy, I have not asked for legal recognition but the admission, under the powers vested in the Minister, of plural wives without the Government in any way recognizing their legal status.
('13', 313, 4, 13, 583987) The admission is to be restricted only to plural wives already married to Indians who may be found to be unquestionably domiciled in the Union.
('13', 313, 4, 14, 584131) This at once restricts the scope of the Government’s generosity and enables them to know now how many such wives will have to be admitted.
('13', 313, 4, 15, 584270) I have already submitted a plan as to how this can be brought about.
('13', 313, 4, 16, 584339) In my humble opinion, the letter of the 10th August, 1911, referred to in your communication, bears the interpretation I have
('13', 313, 5, 17, 584465) 1 Vide 2nd footnote to “Telegram to Secretary for Interior”, 10 9 1913. 2 Vide “Important Judgment about Marriage”, 30 8 1913.
('13', 314, 0, 1, 584592) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 315
('13', 314, 1, 2, 584639) placed upon it.
('13', 314, 1, 3, 584655) The British Indian Association raised the question of polygamy and the above mentioned letter containing the assurance was the reply.
('13', 314, 1, 4, 584789) I suppose you know that plural wives have actually been admitted by the Immigration Officers and that polygamous unions are even registered on the Transvaal registration certificates.
('13', 314, 1, 5, 584973) As doubts have arisen as to the meaning of the term “monogamous marriage”, I beg to record that the meaning that the community has placed upon it is that a marriage is monogamous if a man is married to only one woman, no matter under what religion and no matter whether such religion under given circumstances sanctions polygamy or not.
('13', 314, 1, 6, 585310) I observe that paragraph 2 of your letter seems to suggest that my reply to your last wire did not [cover], though it might have covered, the other points referred to therein.
('13', 314, 1, 7, 585486) I purposely refrained from touching the other points as I felt that no scope was left open for me to do so.
('13', 314, 1, 8, 585594) But if General Smuts is still prepared to consider the other points, I shall be certainly prepared to make a further submission.
('13', 314, 1, 9, 585723) I cannot help feeling that the unfortunate rupture has taken place on points very vital to the Indian community but of little consequence to the Government or the dominant population of the Union.
('13', 314, 1, 10, 585920) Pray, always consider me to be one the least desirous to obstruct the Government and most anxious to serve it in so far as I can do so consistently with my duty to my countrymen.
('13', 314, 2, 11, 586099) [I have, etc.,]
('13', 314, 3, 12, 586115) M. K. GANDHI

('13', 317, 0, 1, 589195) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 317, 1, 2, 589237) 204. THE RESISTERS AT VOLKSRUST
('13', 317, 2, 3, 589269) We reported last week that the passive resisters were told they would be deported on receipt of warrants from Pretoria.
('13', 317, 2, 4, 589389) Fuller details that have come to hand show that the spokesman 1 was summoned before the Immigration Officer on Thursday 2 last and told that he had received instructions from Pretoria to submit to the party for filling in forms prescribed under the Act.
('13', 317, 2, 5, 589643) The spokesman regretted that the party could not comply with the request.
('13', 317, 2, 6, 589717) Would they submit to the test?
('13', 317, 2, 7, 589748) The spokesman said they could not do that either.
('13', 317, 3, 8, 589798) “Then,” said the officer, “you are all prohibited immigrants.” And, so saying, he handed the usual notices for all, informing them of his decision and saying that they could appeal against his decision to the Appeal Board within 3 days.
('13', 317, 3, 9, 590035) The spokesman said the party did not want to appeal at all.
('13', 317, 3, 10, 590095) The officer then said that, in that event, he would deport them all upon receipt of warrants.
('13', 317, 3, 11, 590189) Thereupon, the spokesman urged that they should all be taken in custody, as they did not wish to remain free and not proceed with their journey.
('13', 317, 3, 12, 590334) But the officer said he could not take them in custody.
('13', 317, 3, 13, 590390) The next day the party informed the officer that, unless they were kept under custody, they would proceed to Johannesburg.
('13', 317, 4, 14, 590513) “Then,” said the officer, “I shall have to stop you, but I will not imprison you.” Thereupon, the following letter was addressed to the officer, signed by the spokesman:
('13', 317, 5, 15, 590683) My fellow passive resisters and I have been stopped by you from continuing our journey to Johannesburg since Tuesday last, the 16th instant.
('13', 317, 5, 16, 590824) I told you then that, if you wished to detain or arrest us, you could do so only by keeping us in prison, as we did not desire to remain in Volksrust with friends, however insistent they might be to accommodate us.
('13', 317, 5, 17, 591039) But you told us that you had not sufficient room at the Police Station for such a large company as ours and that, therefore, you would rather that we remained out, pending receipt of instructions from the Government.
('13', 317, 5, 18, 591256) We have waited, it would be admitted, long enough to enable you to receive your instructions.
('13', 317, 6, 19, 591350) 1 Chhaganlal Gandhi 2 September 18
('13', 318, 0, 1, 591385) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 319
('13', 318, 1, 2, 591432) On my telling you on Friday that, if you could not keep us under custody, the party would consider itself free to proceed to Johannesburg, you informed me that you would prevent it from so doing and that yet you could not keep us in custody until you had heard from the Government.
('13', 318, 2, 3, 591714) I beg, therefore, now to inform you that unless you take charge of the party, we shall entrain for Johannesburg on Monday, by the Kaffir Mail, and if you offer physical resistance at the time, as passive resisters, we can only yield to it for the time being.
('13', 318, 2, 4, 591973) But, if you set us free afterwards and do not hold us bodily, we shall seek some other means of continuing our forward journey.
('13', 318, 3, 5, 592101) Later wires received from Volksrust show that the delivery of the notice acted like a charm.
('13', 318, 3, 6, 592194) The whole party was deported on Monday, at 10 a.m., to the Natal border.
('13', 318, 3, 7, 592267) Deportation merely consists in pushing the deportees beyond a line midway in a shallow stream.
('13', 318, 3, 8, 592362) As soon as the party was deported and the back of the deporting officer was hardly turned, they re crossed and were arrested.
('13', 318, 3, 9, 592488) They were straigh taway taken to the Charge Office.
('13', 318, 4, 10, 592540) Indian Opinion, 24 9 1913
('13', 319, 0, 1, 592566) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 319, 1, 2, 592608) 205. THE LATE MR. HOOSEN DAWAD
('13', 319, 2, 3, 592639) We regret to announce that young Hoosen Dawad, who was ailing for a long time and who had the benefit of the most skilled medical attendance and the unceasing and devoted nursing of a loving father, passed away on Monday night.
('13', 319, 2, 4, 592867) We consider that Mr. Hoosen gave promise of being one of the greatest Indians of South Africa.
('13', 319, 2, 5, 592962) We extend our sympathy to the bereaved family.
('13', 319, 2, 6, 593009) We hope to give a special memoir 1 and portrait of the deceased in our next issue.
('13', 319, 2, 7, 593092) This issue being specially published for giving news of the passive resistance struggle, it is impossible for us to cope with the memoir.
('13', 319, 3, 8, 593230) Indian Opinion, 24 9 1913
('13', 319, 4, 9, 593256) 206. THE £3 TAX
('13', 319, 5, 10, 593272) For many reasons we consider that the central point of the struggle is this blood tax, as we have not hesitated to call it.
('13', 319, 5, 11, 593396) It ought never to have been imposed.
('13', 319, 5, 12, 593433) The history of the imposition does not reflect any credit on Natal.
('13', 319, 5, 13, 593501) It would never have been imposed if we, the free Indian settlers of Natal, had, at the time, done our duty completely.
('13', 319, 5, 14, 593620) It would never have been imposed if the otherwise fine statesmen of Natal, who were then in power, had not truckled to the planter and the farming communities.
('13', 319, 5, 15, 593780) We may here recall the fact that the original intention of the then Government was to impose an annual tax of £25 on ex indentured Indians and to make its non payment a criminal offence.
('13', 319, 5, 16, 593967) This was too much for the Government of India, though it was soft and accommodating enough.
('13', 319, 5, 17, 594059) The figure was, therefore, brought down to £3 and the Government of India would not listen to the proposal to make its non payment a criminal offence.
('13', 319, 5, 18, 594210) So a Bill was passed in 1895 imposing the tax, the condition being that, if the ex indentured Indian left for India on the
('13', 319, 6, 19, 594333) 1 Vide “The Late Mr. Haji Hoosen Dawad Mahomed”, 1 10 1913.
('13', 320, 0, 1, 594393) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 321
('13', 320, 1, 2, 594440) termination of his indenture or entered into further indenture, he was exempt but, if he did not do either and wished to settle in Natal as a free man, he and his were bound to pay the tax which could be collected by a civil summary process.
('13', 320, 1, 3, 594682) The first collections started in 1900, and since then men, women and children have been harassed, more or less inexorably, to pay this wretched penalty for their freedom.
('13', 320, 1, 4, 594853) We call it a penalty because it is admittedly not a revenue producing impost.
('13', 320, 1, 5, 594931) It is avowedly for the purpose of compelling the helpless people to re indenture or to return to India from whence they came to avoid starvation, and on the strength of unscrupulous allurements of touts.
('13', 320, 1, 6, 595135) The law officers then set about working to find out how they could send these men to gaol although it was a compact between the Natal and the Indian Governments that it was not to be deemed a criminal offence if the tax was not paid.
('13', 320, 1, 7, 595369) They found out that it was possible to use effectively the small debts clause of the Magistrates’ Courts Act in order to override the compact and send these people to gaol if they did not pay the tax.
('13', 320, 1, 8, 595570) Disobedience of an order of Court is contempt of Court for which the defaulter is sentenced to imprisonment.
('13', 320, 1, 9, 595679) There is an exception to the clause to the effect that, if a debtor shows that he has been unable, through want of means, to discharge a debt which he is ordered to pay, he may not be imprisoned.
('13', 320, 1, 10, 595875) But we know that, in most cases, the Magistrates, after all human beings living in the midst of the all powerful planting community, have disbelieved the evidence as to poverty and sentenced the men to be imprisoned for non payment.
('13', 320, 1, 11, 596108) The latest case in point is that of Sarjoo 1. He has not paid for the last three years.
('13', 320, 1, 12, 596196) He paid what he could and then pleaded inability.
('13', 320, 1, 13, 596246) But the plea was not accepted and he had to serve imprisonment with hard labour for 30 days.
('13', 320, 1, 14, 596339) And even this imprisonment does not free him from payment.
('13', 320, 1, 15, 596398) If he is believed by a police officer to have means, he can be re arrested and re sen tenced unless he pays the tax.
('13', 320, 1, 16, 596515) Thus we hold that the local Government have broken faith with the Government of India by resorting to the Magistrates’ Courts Act to thrust the poor men and women into gaols for non payment.
('13', 320, 2, 17, 596706) 1 An ex indentured Indian who had not paid his tax arrears; Maganlal Gandhi was summoned for employing him.
('13', 321, 0, 1, 596814) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 321, 1, 2, 596856) But one would have thought that, with the stoppage of the system of indenture, the tax would be abolished.
('13', 321, 1, 3, 596963) Nothing of the kind has happened.
('13', 321, 1, 4, 596997) The relentless employers, who want indentured labour, having tasted the sweets of it, are not satisfied with anything less, certainly not with free labour.
('13', 321, 1, 5, 597153) And so the tax has continued.
('13', 321, 1, 6, 597183) Then came the climax.
('13', 321, 1, 7, 597205) Prominent people of Natal assured Mr. Gokhale that the tax would go, that they did not want it.
('13', 321, 1, 8, 597301) The Union Government made a definite promise to our distinguished countryman that they would remove the tax.
('13', 321, 1, 9, 597410) And yet, during the last session of Parliament, they broke the promise.
('13', 321, 1, 10, 597482) Who can say that the local Indian community have decided a second too soon upon passive resistance?
('13', 321, 1, 11, 597582) It would have been proper at any moment.
('13', 321, 1, 12, 597623) It is doubly so at this moment.
('13', 321, 1, 13, 597655) If our readers only knew, as we know, how this breach of faith, this failure to remove the tax, has shaken Mr. Gokhale and how, in spite of strong medical advice, he decided to return to India to rouse the Government and the people to action, and what extraordinary pressure was brought to bear upon him to induce him to postpone his departure from England, every Indian would let every consideration of self go and fight for the removal of this tax even unto death.
('13', 321, 1, 14, 598122) It is a simple, primary duty every Indian in South Africa owes to his country, to Mr. Gokhale and to the poor men who are the victims of gold hunger on the part of the employers of indentured Indian labour.
('13', 321, 2, 15, 598329) Indian Opinion, 24 9 1913
('13', 322, 0, 1, 598355) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 323
('13', 322, 1, 2, 598402) 207. WHAT APPEAL BOARDS STAND FOR
('13', 322, 2, 3, 598436) The Natal Mercury, in a leaderette, offers the opinion that the Appeal Boards are a distinct advantage to the Indians because one or two men have been successful in their appeals.
('13', 322, 2, 4, 598616) This would be true if the Appeal Boards had taken the place of something worse.
('13', 322, 2, 5, 598696) But the facts are that they are dealing with a situation that did not exist before.
('13', 322, 2, 6, 598780) That is to say, before the Act was passed, men who were undisputed possessors of their domicile certificates re entered as a matter of right.
('13', 322, 2, 7, 598922) Now the Act has nullified the effect of these certificates and created work for the Boards which reject the majority of cases, which formerly were quite safe and then grant one or two.
('13', 322, 2, 8, 599107) Thus the law, having deprived the community of all its rights, allows Appeal Boards to restore some.
('13', 322, 2, 9, 599208) If, for this mercy, one has to be thankful, one ought also to thank a thief who restores part of stolen property.
('13', 322, 2, 10, 599322) Of course, we have nothing to say against the Boards as such.
('13', 322, 2, 11, 599384) Indeed, the appointment of Mr. Binns and Mr. Maurice Evans is unexceptionable.
('13', 322, 2, 12, 599463) But the best judge is of no use, if he is appointed merely to act as an anaesthetic acts when a patient has to undergo a severe operation resulting in the loss of a limb.
('13', 322, 2, 13, 599634) And the analogy is somewhat too flattering for the Government.
('13', 322, 2, 14, 599697) In the latter case, the patient submits to the operation willingly and for his own good.
('13', 322, 2, 15, 599786) In the former case, he is the unwilling victim.
('13', 322, 3, 16, 599834) Indian Opinion, 24 9 1913
('13', 323, 0, 1, 599860) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 323, 1, 2, 599902) 208. THE £3 TAX
('13', 323, 2, 3, 599918) It is, I think, our good fortune that the £3 tax has been included among the issues for satyagraha.
('13', 323, 2, 4, 600018) The previous history of this problem is worth recalling.
('13', 323, 2, 5, 600075) The proposal for the £3 tax first came up in 1894. The Natal Government sent a deputation to India.
('13', 323, 2, 6, 600175) At that time the Indians protested violently against it.
('13', 323, 2, 7, 600232) 1 The Government’s original intention was to levy a tax of £25 and, if any Indian could not pay that tax, the Government wanted to be empowered to effect hiscompulsory repatriation.
('13', 323, 2, 8, 600414) Thanks to our agitation, the Indian Government rejected both the proposals and passed a resolution that an Indian who, after completing his indenture, did not re indenture himself should either return to his country or pay an amount of £3 tax each for himself, his wife and his children.
('13', 323, 2, 9, 600702) If anyone did not pay the tax, it could be recovered by auctioning his property, if he had any, but that the Government would have no power to imprison him.
('13', 323, 2, 10, 600859) The Indian community made a strong representation against this too.
('13', 323, 2, 11, 600927) In 1896, meetings were also held in India in this connection.
('13', 323, 2, 12, 600989) 2 Nevertheless the tax remained.
('13', 323, 2, 13, 601022) For some time, thereafter, the Government collected the tax from those who paid it.
('13', 323, 2, 14, 601106) Meanwhile, though there was no provision for imprisonment [in case of default], the Government found an indirect way of sending defaulters to gaol.
('13', 323, 2, 15, 601254) According to a section in the law relating to magistrates’ courts, anyone failing to comply with a magistrate’s judgment is guilty of contempt of court for which the court could sentence him to imprisonment.
('13', 323, 2, 16, 601462) Under this section, first a decree would be issued on an Indian to pay his tax.
('13', 323, 2, 17, 601542) Then, if he did not pay the tax, he would be brought before the court for contempt of court.
('13', 323, 2, 18, 601635) If he is able to prove his poverty, the court must discharge him.
('13', 323, 2, 19, 601701) Why should the court believe the evidence of such a miserable wretch?
('13', 323, 2, 20, 601771) The result was violation of the agreement made with the Indian Government.
('13', 323, 2, 21, 601846) This was breach of trust.
('13', 323, 2, 22, 601872) And hundreds of Indians found themselves in prison.
('13', 323, 2, 23, 601924) Several women and young men were also
('13', 323, 3, 24, 601962) 1 Vide “Open Letter”, before 19 12 1894, and “Petition to Lord Ripon”, before 5 5 1895. 2 Vide “Speech at Meeting, Madras”, 26 10 1896.
('13', 324, 0, 1, 602098) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 325
('13', 324, 1, 2, 602145) imprisoned.
('13', 324, 1, 3, 602157) Are we not to blame for all this?
('13', 324, 1, 4, 602191) Had we taken more pains than we did, these poor people would have been free from the yoke which they had borne for 15 years.
('13', 324, 1, 5, 602316) Would not thousands of pounds of the poor have been saved?
('13', 324, 1, 6, 602375) It must sear our hearts to hear all these questions.
('13', 324, 1, 7, 602428) We did not hear the cry for help at our own doors !
('13', 324, 1, 8, 602480) Who can tell how much of such burden [of guilt] we have to bear?
('13', 324, 1, 9, 602545) It is enjoined by all religions that we should share in the suffering that we see around us.
('13', 324, 1, 10, 602638) We have failed to do so.
('13', 324, 1, 11, 602663) An opportunity has offered itself today.
('13', 324, 1, 12, 602704) We are sure that, if many from the community fight against it, the tax will be repealed forthwith.
('13', 324, 1, 13, 602803) If only a few do so, there is likely to be delay.
('13', 324, 1, 14, 602853) But the repeal of the tax is certain.
('13', 324, 1, 15, 602891) The campaign that is now coming is such that it should be easy for all Indians to join it with zest.
('13', 324, 1, 16, 602992) So far we could ask nothing of the thousands of ex indentured Indians.
('13', 324, 1, 17, 603063) Now, they too can join the fight with all their heart.
('13', 324, 1, 18, 603118) We are convinced that, if every Indian who is not able to court imprisonment or give money for this cause, just spares one hour of his time to acquaint the poor and the illiterate people with the issue of the tax, there will be a real fight indeed.
('13', 324, 1, 19, 603367) No one, moreover, should remain complacent in the belief that the tax is bound to be repealed.
('13', 324, 1, 20, 603462) On the contrary, everyone must do his best.
('13', 324, 1, 21, 603506) The community will find a great deal to learn from this struggle and will be able to raise itself very high.
('13', 324, 1, 22, 603615) A wise man does not avert his face or go to wash it when Lakshmi 1 comes to him, in his own house, to put a tilak 2 on his forehead.
('13', 324, 2, 23, 603748) [From Gujarati]
('13', 324, 3, 24, 603764) Indian Opinion, 24 9 1913
('13', 324, 4, 25, 603790) 1 Hindu goddess of prosperity 2 Auspicious vermilion mark

('13', 328, 3, 7, 609196) 211. LETTER TO SOUTH AFRICAN RAILWAYS
('13', 328, 4, 8, 609234) [JOHANNESBURG,] September 27, 1913
('13', 328, 5, 9, 609269) TO THE GENERAL MANAGER SOUTH AFRICAN RAILWAYS
('13', 328, 7, 10, 609315) With two other Indians I was travelling by the Kaffir Mail that left Durban on Thursday to the Transvaal.
('13', 328, 7, 11, 609421) We were all travelling third class.
('13', 328, 7, 12, 609457) We occupied one of the corridor third class compartments which are usually attached to the Natal trains.
('13', 328, 7, 13, 609562) My companions and I were put in the compartment we occupied by one of the conductors.
('13', 328, 7, 14, 609648) At Ladysmith, however, the new conductor came and told me that we would have to shift from the compartment we were occupying to another.
('13', 328, 7, 15, 609785) On enquiring for the reason I was told that the compartment we were occupying was meant for Europeans only.
('13', 328, 7, 16, 609893) I drew the conductor’s attention to a compartment which was so labelled, also to the fact that our compartment was not labelled at all, and that I had travelled in such compartments several times on the Natal line.
('13', 328, 7, 17, 610108) I informed him also that the conductor at Durban had placed me in that compartment, but the new conductor said that I was to obey instruc tions or to get permission from the Station Master to remain where I was.
('13', 328, 7, 18, 610320) Thereupon, I saw the Station Master, but I must say that, in rather a rude manner, he told me that I was to do as the conductor asked me, and that I ought to know that the conductors could ask passengers to
('13', 328, 8, 19, 610527) 1 The original is not clear at this point.
('13', 329, 0, 1, 610570) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 329, 1, 2, 610612) shift as many times as they chose without giving any reason whatso ever.
('13', 329, 1, 3, 610685) I did not argue the matter with the Station Master but simply went and occupied the compartment I was in and awaited develop ments there.
('13', 329, 1, 4, 610823) Meantime, unknown to me, a friend who happened to be on the platform, and who knew me, disclosed my identity to the cond uctor who subsequently spoke to me and told me that, in asking me as he had done to remove, he was only carrying out instructions.
('13', 329, 1, 5, 611075) I told the conductor then that, after having known who I was, it was his duty to have me arrested for disobeying instructions, but that he would not do.
('13', 329, 1, 6, 611228) I was told by the Indians who were on the platform at the time, and who were watching the proceedings, that such difficulties hap pened to Indian passengers very often.
('13', 329, 1, 7, 611397) I do not know what truth there is in what the conductor told me.
('13', 329, 1, 8, 611462) I can only hope that he has misread the instructions of the administration, because, in my humble opin ion, it would be preposterous if even third class Indian passengers may not travel without being disturbed, and without being told that the nicest compartments were always reserved for Europeans.
('13', 329, 1, 9, 611761) I hope that you will be good enough to investigate this matter and do whatever you consider is necessary.
('13', 329, 1, 10, 611867) I feel that high officials, such as Station Masters, ought to be told to realize their responsibility and behave courteously towards passengers even though they may not belong to the European race.
('13', 329, 1, 11, 612065) I hardly think that it was necessary for me to disclose my identity before I could claim courteous treatment from the Station Master.

('13', 329, 3, 13, 612214) M. K. GANDHI]

('13', 330, 1, 2, 612301) 212. ON POINT OF BEING ARRESTED
('13', 330, 2, 3, 612333) [September 27, 1913] 1
('13', 330, 3, 4, 612356) On Thursday 2 last, Mr. Gandhi went to the Transvaal with some satyagrahis.
('13', 330, 3, 5, 612432) He and his companions were in a third class compart ment.
('13', 330, 3, 6, 612490) Among the third class carriages, there are some which are clean and comfortable.
('13', 330, 3, 7, 612571) The railway official had put Mr. Gandhi and his companions in one of these.
('13', 330, 3, 8, 612647) When the train reached Ladysmith, the conductor ordered them to vacate the compartment and occupy the next one.
('13', 330, 3, 9, 612759) Mr. Gandhi said: “We are not going to, and we will reach the Transvaal in this very compartment.”
('13', 330, 4, 10, 612857) The conductor said, “I order you to go.”
('13', 330, 5, 11, 612898) Mr. Gandhi said, “It was the conductor at Durban who placed us here.” The conductor retorted, “Don’t argue with me.
('13', 330, 5, 12, 613014) I tell you to get out.
('13', 330, 5, 13, 613037) This compartment is for the Europeans.
('13', 330, 5, 14, 613076) This train is under my charge.”
('13', 330, 6, 15, 613108) Without entering into an argument, Mr. Gandhi decided to remain in the same compartment with his companions and hoped to be arrested for disobeying the conductor’s order.
('13', 330, 6, 16, 613279) He thought that this was a good opportunity that had offered itself for him to go to gaol.
('13', 330, 6, 17, 613370) Some Indians who were present there saw what was happening and were glad to think the incident would have a good result.
('13', 330, 6, 18, 613491) But Mr. Windon, who was on the spot, spoiled the game.
('13', 330, 6, 19, 613546) The conductor did not recognize Mr. Gandhi.
('13', 330, 6, 20, 613590) Mr. Windon went to him and told him the name.
('13', 330, 6, 21, 613636) That made the conductor hold his peace.
('13', 330, 6, 22, 613676) Afterwards he had a long conversation with Mr. Gandhi in the presence of other conduc tors and told him that he was only doing his duty.
('13', 330, 6, 23, 613813) In his ignorance, however, the friend, with the best of intentions, behaved like an enemy.
('13', 330, 6, 24, 613904) Had Mr. Gandhi been arrested at Ladysmith, some of the problems concerning railways would have been solved and, incidentally, the struggle would have gained strength.
('13', 330, 6, 25, 614071) All the Indians on the platform were disappointed and, later on, Mr. Windon realized
('13', 330, 7, 26, 614156) 1 Vide reference to preceding item in the last paragraph.

('13', 331, 1, 2, 614271) that it would have been far better if he had not interfered.
('13', 331, 2, 3, 614332) Mr. Gandhi has sent a written complaint about this to the Gen eral Manager, telling him that he was informed by the Indians who were on the station that such hardships were a common experience.
('13', 331, 2, 4, 614526) He has also pointed out in the letter that the Station Master, instead of attending to the complaint, behaved rather rudely.

('13', 331, 5, 7, 614693) 213. LETTER TO SECRETARY FOR INTERIOR
('13', 331, 6, 8, 614731) [JOHANNESBURG,] September 28, 1913
('13', 331, 7, 9, 614766) DEAR MR. GORGES,
('13', 331, 8, 10, 614783) I do not know that I am justified in writing this letter to you, but, as you have been personally solicitous about the non revival of passive resistance, and as, in the course of my conversations with you, I have so often told you that I have nothing to withhold from the Government, I may as well inform you of what is now going on.
('13', 331, 8, 11, 615117) I wrote to you 1 from Phoenix in reply to your last letter, and if you have not yet replied to my communication but intend to do so, I would suggest your sending your reply to my Johannesburg address, as I shall be here for some time at least.
('13', 331, 8, 12, 615361) The campaign has started in earnest.
('13', 331, 8, 13, 615398) As you know, sixteen passive resisters, including four women, are already serving three months’ imprisonment with hard labour.
('13', 331, 8, 14, 615525) 2 The resisters here were awaiting my arrival and the activity here will commence almost immediately.
('13', 331, 8, 15, 615627) I cannot help saying that the points on which the struggle has re started are such that the Government might gracefully grant them
('13', 331, 9, 16, 615758) 1 Vide “Letter to Secretary for Interior”.
('13', 331, 9, 17, 615801) The Secretary’s reply dated September 27 had evidently not reached Gandhiji by this time.
('13', 331, 9, 18, 615891) 2 Vide “Letter to Harilal Gandhi”, 18 9 1913.
('13', 332, 0, 1, 615937) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 333
('13', 332, 1, 2, 615984) to the community.
('13', 332, 1, 3, 616002) But what I would like to impress upon the Govern ment is the gravity of the step we are about to take.
('13', 332, 1, 4, 616105) I know that it is fraught with danger.
('13', 332, 1, 5, 616144) I know also that, once taken, it may be difficult to control the spread of the movement beyond the limits one may set.
('13', 332, 1, 6, 616263) I know also what responsibility lies on my shoulders in advising such a momentous step, but I feel that it is not possible for me to refrain from advising a step which I consider to be necessary, to be of educational value and, in the end, to be valuable both to the Indian community and to the State.
('13', 332, 1, 7, 616565) This step consists in actively, persistently and continuously asking those who are liable to pay the £3 tax to decline to do so and to suffer the penalties for non payment and, what is more important, in asking those who are now serving indenture and who will, therefore, be liable to pay the £3 tax on completion of their indenture to strike work until the tax is withdrawn.
('13', 332, 1, 8, 616941) I feel that, in view of Lord Ampthill’s declaration in the House of Lords, 1 evidently with the approval of Mr. Gokhale, as to the definite promise made by the Government and repeated to Lord Gladstone, this advice to indentured Indians would be fully justified.
('13', 332, 1, 9, 617204) That the tax has weighed most heavily upon the men I know from personal experience, that the men resent it bitterly I also know from personal knowledge.
('13', 332, 1, 10, 617357) But they have submitted to it more or less with quiet resignation, and I am loth to disturb their minds by any step that I might take or advise.
('13', 332, 1, 11, 617502) Can I not even now, whilst in the midst of the struggle, appeal to General Smuts and ask him to reconsider his decision on the points already submitted and on the question of the £3 tax and, whether this letter is favourably considered or not, may I anticipate the assurance that it will in no wise be taken to be a threat?

('13', 333, 1, 2, 617968) 214. SPEECH AT VREDEDORP MEETING 1
('13', 333, 2, 3, 618003) [JOHANNESBURG, September 28, 1913]
('13', 333, 3, 4, 618038) Mr. Gandhi at the outset stated that he had already addressed two meetings that afternoon, one of which consisted of some fifty Indian women who were mostly affected by the Immigration Act.
('13', 333, 3, 5, 618228) All of them had decided to throw in their lot with their sisters who were serving three months’ hard labour at Vereeniging (Applause.) They had decided, some of them with babies in arms, to undergo all the hardships that gaol life meant.
('13', 333, 3, 6, 618466) They were going to suffer for their own honour, and though he had warned them, and had even exaggerated the factor of the hardships of gaol life, they would be gratified and surprised, possibly, to hear that the women were staunch.
('13', 333, 3, 7, 618698) In a few days’ time they would be in His Majesty’s gaol.
('13', 333, 3, 8, 618755) (Applause.)
('13', 333, 4, 9, 618767) Mr. Gandhi touched upon the requests of the Indian community and the reasons for resuming the campaign of passive resistance.
('13', 333, 5, 10, 618893) Our demands are, in my opinion, incredibly simple.
('13', 333, 5, 11, 618944) The first in point of importance is that the poll tax of £3 be abolished.
('13', 333, 5, 12, 619018) This is payable by all the ex indentured Indians, their wives and grown up children, so that in the case of a family of six the tax is £18 per year.
('13', 333, 5, 13, 619167) This tax, as Lord Ampthill stated in the House of Lords, was on promise of repeal during the last session of Parliament.
('13', 333, 5, 14, 619288) This was a promise made to Gokhale when he came to South Africa.
('13', 333, 5, 15, 619353) The second thing is the marriage difficulty.
('13', 333, 5, 16, 619398) I see wild statements made to the effect that we are trying to alter the whole basis of the marriage law of South Africa and to legalize polygamy.
('13', 333, 5, 17, 619545) Nothing can be further from our thought than that.
('13', 333, 5, 18, 619596) All we ask for is the restoration of the status that existed before the Searle judgment, and that is, legal recognition of monogamous marriages according to our own religious rites.
('13', 333, 5, 19, 619778) Surely, this does not mean any alteration of the basis of the marriage law of South Africa.
('13', 333, 5, 20, 619870) We have certainly asked for the admission of the existing plural wives of the Indians who are domiciled here, but for no legal recognition of their status.
('13', 333, 5, 21, 620026) This has been done before, and we
('13', 333, 6, 22, 620060) 1 Gandhiji addressed a well attended mass meeting of Indians at the Hamidia Hall.
('13', 333, 6, 23, 620142) A. M. Cachalia presided.
('13', 334, 0, 1, 620167) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 335
('13', 334, 1, 2, 620214) simply ask for its continuation.
('13', 334, 1, 3, 620247) It affects a very small number of Indian women.
('13', 334, 1, 4, 620295) You will be surprised to know that the law of South Africa has actually, in the interests of the planting community, even legally recognized polygamy in the case of the indentured Indians.
('13', 334, 1, 5, 620484) But we are asking for no such legal recognition for plural wives of free Indian settlers.
('13', 334, 1, 6, 620574) The third point is the retention of the right of South Africa born Indians to enter the Cape by reason of their birth.
('13', 334, 1, 7, 620693) The fourth point is the Free State difficulty.
('13', 334, 1, 8, 620740) This is almost settled.
('13', 334, 1, 9, 620764) We claim that the new Act does not mean that an Indian who may possibly enter the Free State is required to make as an immigrant the Free State declaration as to prohibition of holding landed property, to farm and to trade.
('13', 334, 1, 10, 620988) If such is the interpretation placed upon the law by the Government also, there is no dispute.
('13', 334, 1, 11, 621083) If the Government make that admission, the whole difficulty is solved.
('13', 334, 1, 12, 621154) (Applause.) [Resolution] 1
('13', 334, 2, 13, 621181) That this meeting held under the auspices of the British Indian Association endorses the action taken by Mr. Cachalia in his letter to the Government, and congratulates the pioneers from Natal who are waiting in His Majesty’s gaol at Vereeniging.
('13', 334, 2, 14, 621428) This meeting further resolves upon the immediate taking up of passive resistance and to continue it until the requests contained in Mr. Cachalia’s letter are granted.
('13', 334, 2, 15, 621595) The meeting respectfully urges the Union Government to grant that request in fairness to the community and also asks the Imperial and Indian Governments to help the community and trusts that the leaders of thought, both in England and India, will support the community in the endeavour to conserve national honour.
('13', 334, 3, 16, 621910) Rand Daily Mail, 29 9 1913

('13', 336, 1, 2, 623821) 216. INTERVIEW TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER”
('13', 336, 2, 3, 623862) [JOHANNESBURG, September 29, 1913]
('13', 336, 3, 4, 623897) Mr. Gandhi...
('13', 336, 3, 5, 623911) discussed the situation fully and frankly.
('13', 336, 3, 6, 623954) He considers that the people of the Transvaal are all with the Indians in their demand for fuller rights.
('13', 336, 3, 7, 624060) Everyone he spoke to, he said, was sympathetic.
('13', 336, 4, 8, 624108) [REPORTER:] Then you do not consider that Parliament truly reflects the feeling of the country?
('13', 336, 4, 9, 624204) [GANDHIJI:] No, there you have professional men.
('13', 336, 5, 10, 624253) Mr. Gandhi said that the Indians were as steadfast and loyal to the cause as ever.
('13', 336, 5, 11, 624336) Numerically they would not be so strong, but they were quite as earnest as before.
('13', 336, 5, 12, 624419) The trouble, he said, had arisen to purify them.
('13', 336, 5, 13, 624468) Asked why the number of resisters would be smaller, he stated that many who had experienced the discomforts of Transvaal prisons had no wish to return.
('13', 336, 6, 14, 624620) Some merchants too are not joining your ranks?
('13', 336, 6, 15, 624667) They may not go to prison, but they will help us with money.
('13', 336, 7, 16, 624728) Are you as well off in a financial way as on the occasion of the last campaign?
('13', 336, 7, 17, 624808) No, we are not.
('13', 336, 8, 18, 624824) He went on to say that it was not a question of 3,000 convictions this time.
('13', 336, 8, 19, 624901) A different procedure will be followed.

('13', 341, 1, 2, 632189) 219. THE LATE MR. HAJI HOOSEN DAWAD MAHOMED 1
('13', 341, 2, 3, 632235) The rose has withered in its bloom.
('13', 341, 2, 4, 632271) Young Hoosen has died in the prime of life, leaving a nation in mourning.
('13', 341, 2, 5, 632345) He was but twenty two, but he carried on his shoulders a head that would sit well on a wise man of forty two.
('13', 341, 2, 6, 632455) Truly do the gods take away those they love best.
('13', 341, 2, 7, 632505) Had Mr. Hoosen Dawad lived to see the winter of life, I feel sure that he would have left a mark on the history of the Indian community in South Africa.
('13', 341, 2, 8, 632658) Not that he has not, by the purity of his life, influenced it even now.
('13', 341, 2, 9, 632730) But what he was able to do was merely the shadow of what was to come.
('13', 341, 2, 10, 632800) He was a young man of truth for which alone he lived.
('13', 341, 2, 11, 632854) He was impatient of cant, hypocrisy and humbug even in those who were his elders.
('13', 341, 2, 12, 632936) He stood up for truth against all odds.
('13', 341, 2, 13, 632976) From his early age, he wanted his word to be as good as a bond.
('13', 341, 2, 14, 633040) He was innocence personified.
('13', 341, 2, 15, 633070) No evil company could influence him.
('13', 341, 2, 16, 633107) He influenced his companions, no matter how depraved they might be.
('13', 341, 2, 17, 633175) Once Mr. Dawad Mahomed wrote to him, asking him to beware of snares that lured young men in London and of bad companions.
('13', 341, 2, 18, 633297) He was indignant and wrote almost in these words: “Father, you do not know your boy.
('13', 341, 2, 19, 633382) Snares cannot affect Hoosen.
('13', 341, 2, 20, 633411) Bad companions mislead those who do not know where they are.
('13', 341, 2, 21, 633472) Your son knows where he is.
('13', 341, 2, 22, 633500) He lives for truth and will die for it.” To this sterling character, he added a burning enthusiasm for his country, India, which then existed only in his imagination.
('13', 341, 2, 23, 633667) He had never seen it.
('13', 341, 2, 24, 633689) But it was enough that it was the land of his forefathers.
('13', 341, 2, 25, 633748) He had read about it and he had learnt to love it with a passion that could not be stifled.
('13', 341, 2, 26, 633840) “O, Mr. Rustomjee,” young Hoosen said to him when he went forward on the 16th ultimo as a passive resister, “if I rise from this sick bed, you will find me in gaol.
('13', 341, 2, 27, 634005) What a glorious death it would be, to die in gaol for the sake of Truth and Justice!” He clung to life desperately.
('13', 341, 2, 28, 634121) But his desire was unalloyed with selfishness.
('13', 341, 2, 29, 634168) He wanted to live in order to serve his country and humanity.
('13', 341, 2, 30, 634230) When quite young, he began to hate trade, though Mr. Dawad,

('13', 342, 1, 2, 634381) his father, was and is a merchant prince.
('13', 342, 1, 3, 634423) He scorned possession of wealth.
('13', 342, 1, 4, 634456) He wanted to study.
('13', 342, 1, 5, 634476) He was placed with me at Phoenix by Mr. Dawad Mahomed and the whole settlement began to value the golden worth of the boy.

('13', 342, 1, 30, 635983) The pilgrimage made a lasting impression on him.
('13', 342, 1, 31, 636032) In one of his letters, he broke into raptures over the powers of the Prophet who could summon millions, year after year, to pay their homage to the Creator in this special manner.
('13', 342, 1, 32, 636212) Thence the party proceeded to Constantinople whilst the war with Italy was going on.
('13', 342, 1, 33, 636297) Young Hoosen was really his father’s guide and friend.

('13', 343, 1, 2, 636892) returning to die in his lap, and so he died, conscious to the last moment, in the lap of a father whose love was rare.
('13', 343, 1, 3, 637011) (I had almost said, supernatural.) Mr. Dawad Mahomed became Hoosen’s exclusive nurse.
('13', 343, 1, 4, 637097) For five long months and more, this loving father never left the side of Hoosen’s bed.
('13', 343, 1, 5, 637184) It was a privilege to me to make a pilgrimage to Mr. Dawad’s house to see the young patient whenever I was in Durban and it was a treat to see how Mr. Dawad nursed the son and how the latter relied entirely upon his nursing and no other.
('13', 343, 1, 6, 637422) Dr. MacKenzie, assisted by Dr. Adams, treated him.
('13', 343, 1, 7, 637473) But Hoosen never left the bed that he occupied on his return from Turkey.
('13', 343, 1, 8, 637547) The funeral procession was enormous.
('13', 343, 1, 9, 637584) Thousands followed the hearse.
('13', 343, 1, 10, 637615) Hindus from all provinces of India vied with the Mahomedans in paying their respects to the memory of this good youth.
('13', 343, 1, 11, 637734) Colonial born Indians mustered in strong force to pay their respects to the memory of one who, like themselves, was born in South Africa.
('13', 343, 1, 12, 637872) Special trams emptied themselves at Congella, during practically the whole of the Tuesday on which the funeral took place.
('13', 343, 1, 13, 637995) All Indian shops in Durban were closed for two hours and so was the Indian Market, by consent of the Corporation.
('13', 343, 1, 14, 638109) No Indian has ever received the spontaneous tribute to his memory that this young man of brilliant promise received.
('13', 343, 1, 15, 638226) His death made us all forget, for the moment, that we were Hindus, Mahomedans, Parsees or Christians.
('13', 343, 1, 16, 638328) He, even in his death, makes us realize that we are sons of India after all—we are kith and kin, owning the same mother.
('13', 343, 1, 17, 638449) I have loved to linger on Mr. Hoosen’s character.
('13', 343, 1, 18, 638499) I knew him as few did.
('13', 343, 1, 19, 638522) And it has not been my good fortune to meet many young men—aye, even old men—with a spotless character that Hoosen possessed.
('13', 343, 1, 20, 638648) To me Hoosen is not dead.
('13', 343, 1, 21, 638674) He lives in his character.
('13', 343, 1, 22, 638701) May this humble tribute be accepted by Indian youths throughout South Africa in the spirit in which it has been offered, and may we all copy the example set to us by Mr. Hajee Hoosen Dawad Mahomed.
