('13', 344, 0, 1, 638925) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 345
('13', 344, 1, 2, 638972) 220. THE MARRIAGE QUESTION
('13', 344, 2, 3, 638999) The struggle, this time, involves so many matters of highest importance that it is well to devote particular attention to each.
('13', 344, 2, 4, 639127) We dwelt, last week, on the £3 tax question.
('13', 344, 2, 5, 639172) This week we propose to examine the marriage question which, in so far as it has drawn our women into the struggle, is of even greater importance than that of the annual exaction from ex indentured men, women and children.
('13', 344, 3, 6, 639395) The marriage difficulty dates from the Searle judgment.
('13', 344, 3, 7, 639451) It is, therefore, necessary to understand the position that existed before that now historic judgment.
('13', 344, 3, 8, 639554) Little did Justice Searle know what effect his judgment was likely to produce among the Indians of this sub continent.
('13', 344, 4, 9, 639673) Before the judgment, Indian wives were recognized as lawful married wives of their husbands.
('13', 344, 4, 10, 639766) The masters of the Supreme Courts of the different Provinces recognized the claims of such wives and their issue in intestate estates.
('13', 344, 4, 11, 639901) Never did an Indian have cause to suspect that the legality of marriage might be questioned by the Courts of South Africa on the ground of the want of its Christian character or the want of registration in South Africa.
('13', 344, 4, 12, 640121) But the Union Government, in pursuance of their policy of greater repression of the Asiatic than before and not being satisfied with their attack on the male members of the community, wanted to extend their hostile operations to our womenfolk.
('13', 344, 4, 13, 640365) Some zealous law officer discovered that it was possible to prevent the entry of wives of domiciled Indians by declaring their marriage to be illegal in terms of the South African law.
('13', 344, 4, 14, 640550) They, therefore, challenged the entry of such a woman at the Cape, and Justice Searle was called upon to decide the issue now raised for the first time by the Government.
('13', 344, 4, 15, 640721) The learned Judge pronounced marriages performed according to the rites of a religion that allows polygamy to be illegal, and, as the person, claiming before him to be the wife of a domiciled Indian, was a Mahomedan, her marriage could not be recognized by the Courts of the Union.
('13', 344, 4, 16, 641003) This ruling was followed by the Master of the Natal Provincial Division of the Supreme Court.
('13', 344, 4, 17, 641097) The Master rejected the claim of the only wife of a
('13', 345, 0, 1, 641149) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 345, 1, 2, 641191) deceased Indian for exemption from succession duty by reason of her marriage not being in accordance with the laws of the Union.
('13', 345, 1, 3, 641320) The doctrine was carried to its furthest limit by Justice Gardiner when he declined to recognize the marriage of an Indian wife when she claimed exemption from liability to give evidence against her husband in a trial against him upon a charge of murder.
('13', 345, 1, 4, 641575) Thus, suddenly, non Christian Indians found that, in South Africa, their wives occupied merely the position of concubines and their children were considered illegitimate.
('13', 345, 1, 5, 641746) The reader must remember that, not only does this discovery of their awful position hurt the susceptibilities of a proud race, but it also effectually prevents the entry of almost every Indian wife and every Indian child.
('13', 345, 1, 6, 641968) If the Government had dared to follow out the consequences of the Searle judgment which they deliberately invited, not an Indian wife or her children could have entered the country.
('13', 345, 1, 7, 642150) That would have been an injustice which even the humanity of the Europeans of South Africa would not have tolerated.
('13', 345, 1, 8, 642267) Therefore, after having us at their mercy, the Government were graciously pleased to declare that the judgment would not interfere with the practice of the administration to admit the wife of a domiciled Asiatic so long she was the only wife of his in South Africa.
('13', 345, 1, 9, 642533) This so called forbearance, it must be remembered, would not have saved the wives and children thus admitted on sufference from the other consequences already adverted to of the Searle judgment.
('13', 345, 1, 10, 642728) Indians were not to be satisfied with exchanging the legal status of their wives for a position of total uncertainty in law, notwithstanding their admission.
('13', 345, 1, 11, 642886) They were not prepared to put up with the implied slur on their womenfolk.
('13', 345, 1, 12, 642961) The Government, therefore, reluctantly, in a most niggardly spirit, and in instalments, accepted, first Mr. Alexander’s and then Senator Schreiner’s amendments to the Immigration Bill that was under consideration by the Union Parliament.
('13', 345, 1, 13, 643199) But the amend ments, being hastily drawn, gave (if they did at all) partial relief only.
('13', 345, 1, 14, 643288) For they legalized Indian monogamous marriages celebrated outside South Africa, no matter under what religious rites they were solemnized.
('13', 345, 1, 15, 643427) These amendments, therefore, left undefined the status of women married or to be married in South Africa.
('13', 345, 1, 16, 643533) Indians now con tend that Indian marriages celebrated in South Africa should be placed upon the same footing as those celebrated in India.
('13', 345, 1, 17, 643672) And this, as
('13', 346, 0, 1, 643685) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 347
('13', 346, 1, 2, 643732) has been 1 pointed out to the Government, can be done with but a slight alteration in the Immigration Act or by an amendment of the marriage laws of the Union.
('13', 346, 1, 3, 643892) We have used the expression “if they did at all” with reference to the relief granted by the amendments.
('13', 346, 1, 4, 643997) This qualification has become necessary owing to the attitude of the Government in the case of Kulsumbibi now pending before the Supreme Court.
('13', 346, 1, 5, 644141) The Immigration Officer at Durban, no doubt upon instructions from the Government, has raised the question whether a marriage celebrated under the rites of a religion which permits polygamy can be called monogamous, although the woman so married may be the only wife of her husband.
('13', 346, 1, 6, 644424) This issue the Government need not have raised.
('13', 346, 1, 7, 644472) But they evidently intend to show that the amendments made were not made in good faith.
('13', 346, 1, 8, 644560) They were made ostensibly to meet the Indian demand for legalization 2 of Indian marriages.
('13', 346, 1, 9, 644652) Mr. Alexander’s amen dments fell short of that.
('13', 346, 1, 10, 644700) Mr. Schreiner’s was, therefore, accepted.
('13', 346, 1, 11, 644742) The Government knew that the most popular religions of India, viz., Hinduism and Islam, did not prohibit polygamy.
('13', 346, 1, 12, 644857) If, therefore, they accepted the amendment with the mental reservation that the adjective “monogamous” would by law still exclude the women married according to the rites of these two great religions, they certainly misled Parliament and the Indian community.
('13', 346, 1, 13, 645117) We think that the Supreme Court will reject the Government interpretation, but, should its decision be otherwise, it certainly will be necessary to alter the Immigration Act in order to clothe all Indian marriages with legality.
('13', 346, 1, 14, 645346) Even at this eleventh hour, the Government could withdraw the case and not challenge a decision.
('13', 346, 1, 15, 645443) Then, there remained the question of the admission of plural wives as distinguished from their legal status after admission.
('13', 346, 1, 16, 645568) The practice has been always to admit such wives of domiciled Indians.
('13', 346, 1, 17, 645639) In the Transvaal such unions are even noted on the registration certificates.
('13', 346, 1, 18, 645717) The first shock of disturbance in this practice was felt in 1911 by a decision of Justice Wessels, 3 which, too, was invited by the
('13', 346, 2, 19, 645849) 1 The original has “even”.
('13', 346, 2, 20, 645876) 2 The original has “legislation”.
('13', 346, 2, 21, 645910) 3 Vide “Indian Wives”, 8 7 1911 & “Johannesburg”, 8 7 1911.

('13', 347, 1, 2, 646012) Government.
('13', 347, 1, 3, 646024) As a result of the decision, the British Indian Association carried on correspondence with the Government and an assurance was given by them that all cases of hardship would be considered by them.
('13', 347, 1, 4, 646221) This correspondence seemed to settle the question, for the Indian demand as to plural wives is not for legal recognition but for admission into the Union of the existing plural wives of domiciled Indians.
('13', 347, 1, 5, 646426) But the disposition of the Government seems to be now to recede from the assurance contained in their communication.
('13', 347, 1, 6, 646543) We shall reproduce this correspondence in our next issue so that the reader may judge for himself whether the correspondence can bear any other interpretation than that put upon it by the community.
('13', 347, 1, 7, 646742) To sum up, then, the demands of the community are simple and three fold:
('13', 347, 2, 8, 646815) (1) Legalization of monogamous marriages already celebrated and to be celebrated in South Africa; (2) The term “monogamous” to include marriages celebrated according to the rites of religions that may not prohibit polygamy, so long as the woman whose union is to be recognized is the only wife of her husband; (3) the admission of existing plural wives of domiciled Indians without granting such wives a legal status apart from full residential rights.

('13', 348, 0, 1, 647294) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 349
('13', 348, 1, 2, 647341) 221. THE MARRIAGE QUESTION
('13', 348, 2, 3, 647368) Just as we considered last week the obnoxious £3 tax, we must now consider the marriage question.
('13', 348, 2, 4, 647466) Not one, but many important issues, unrelated to one another, are involved in this struggle.
('13', 348, 2, 5, 647559) The community must have a clear understanding of all these issues.
('13', 348, 2, 6, 647626) The marriage question itself has three aspects.
('13', 348, 3, 7, 647674) First, that marriages celebrated according to Hindu, Muslim or Parsi religious rites are not recognized as legally valid.
('13', 348, 3, 8, 647796) Before the Searle judgment, there simply was no problem about Indian marriages.
('13', 348, 3, 9, 647876) All marriages were recognized in courts.
('13', 348, 3, 10, 647917) But the Searle judgment changed all that.
('13', 348, 3, 11, 647959) The Government acted deliberately in seeking that verdict.
('13', 348, 3, 12, 648018) After the formation of the Union, there came to be greater strictness than before.
('13', 348, 3, 13, 648101) The desire entered the Government’s mind to root out Indians from South Africa, be the means what they might.
('13', 348, 3, 14, 648211) Till now the Government did not lay hands on women.
('13', 348, 3, 15, 648263) But now it has cast its evil eyes on them.
('13', 348, 3, 16, 648306) The Government seems to have had the wicked idea that, by preventing the entry of women, their children can also be stopped.
('13', 348, 3, 17, 648431) Its officers, accordingly, looked up the various laws and found that it might be possible to hold that Indian marriages were not valid according to the laws of this country and that, if this was proved right, the Government’s object would more or less be fulfilled.
('13', 348, 3, 18, 648697) And so the Government challenged the right of one woman, and the case went up to Mr. Justice Searle.
('13', 348, 3, 19, 648798) He held that a marriage solemnized under a religion which permitted polygamy, even if it was in fact monogamous, could not be recognized in South African law.
('13', 348, 3, 20, 648957) Following upon this judgment, the Master of a Natal Court decided that a widow and her children could not be exempted from payment of succession duty after the decease of her husband if her marriage with the deceased husband had been celebrated otherwise than under Christian rites.
('13', 348, 3, 21, 649240) 1 In Ladysmith, again, Mr. Justice Gardiner ruled that a woman so married could not claim the privilege of exemption from giving evidence against her husband.
('13', 348, 3, 22, 649399) 2 The result
('13', 348, 4, 23, 649412) 1 Vide also “Janubie Case”, 12 4 1913. 2 Kulsumbibi’s case
('13', 349, 0, 1, 649471) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 349, 1, 2, 649513) of these three decisions is that Indian women and their children cannot come to this country.
('13', 349, 1, 3, 649607) The women who are already here become mere concubines and their children will not be accepted as the legal heirs of their parents.
('13', 349, 1, 4, 649738) Having established this as the legal position, the Government declared, in its graciousness, that despite the new law it will permit one wife to come in with every individual.
('13', 349, 1, 5, 649914) This only means that the women will be granted right of domicile but that they will be looked upon as concubines.
('13', 349, 1, 6, 650028) Consequently, neither they nor their heirs will have any rights in a court.
('13', 349, 1, 7, 650104) Indians cannot accept such a position.
('13', 349, 1, 8, 650143) Strong letters [of protest] were addressed to the Government.
('13', 349, 1, 9, 650205) It introduced in the new Bill amendments suggested by Mr. Alexander, and later by Mr. Schreiner.
('13', 349, 1, 10, 650302) But it did so rather unwillingly, without applying its mind to them, and only because it was left with no choice in the matter; the amendments, therefore, remained defective, and the result was that the validity of marriages celebrated in India was recognized, but not that of marriages which have been or which may be celebrated in this country under our religions.
('13', 349, 1, 11, 650669) Hence, we have asked the Government to treat marriages celebrated in South Africa, or those that may be celebrated in future, on the same footing as marriages celebrated in India.
('13', 349, 1, 12, 650849) We have also pointed out how this may be effected.
('13', 349, 2, 13, 650900) The second point is that the amendment made in the Bill has the effect of recognizing the validity of monogamous marriages.
('13', 349, 2, 14, 651024) In Kulsumbibi’s case, the Government purposely raised the objection that the new law does not recognize a marriage solemnized under a religion which permits polygamy.
('13', 349, 2, 15, 651191) If this interpretation is correct, the difficulty created by the Searle judgment has not been removed and the Government can be accused of a bit of sharp practice.
('13', 349, 2, 16, 651355) It knew well enough that our demand related to marriages solemnized under the Hindu and Muslim faiths.
('13', 349, 2, 17, 651458) If it was the Government’s intention not to recognize such marriages, it has deceived us, and also deceived the Parliament, the Imperial Government and the Indian Government.
('13', 349, 2, 18, 651633) Kulsumbibi’s case was not brought up by us.
('13', 349, 2, 19, 651677) It was the Government that did so.
('13', 349, 2, 20, 651712) The decision is not likely to be what the Government wants it to be.
('13', 349, 2, 21, 651781) But in case it is, the Government will have to hide its face in shame and amend the law again so as to include within its scope marriages celebrated under our faiths.
('13', 350, 0, 1, 651948) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1919 25 DECEMBER, 1920 351
('13', 350, 1, 2, 651995) The third point refers to cases of polygamy.
('13', 350, 1, 3, 652040) The issue was raised in 1911. If an Indian had more than one wife, all the wives were [previously] allowed to come in.
('13', 350, 1, 4, 652159) But the Government brought up the issue and Mr. Justice Wessels ruled that under the law here only one wife could come in.
('13', 350, 1, 5, 652282) Mr. Cachalia thereupon addressed a letter to the Government and the latter replied that it would consider such cases.
('13', 350, 1, 6, 652400) We acquiesced in the position.
('13', 350, 1, 7, 652431) We did not ask for recognition of polygamous marriages but for permission for all one’s wives to enter this country.
('13', 350, 1, 8, 652548) The Government now says that its letter of 1911 is not to be interpreted as we have done.
('13', 350, 1, 9, 652638) We are, however, convinced that it can bear no other interpretation.
('13', 350, 2, 10, 652707) We have thus made three demands of the Government.
('13', 350, 2, 11, 652758) One, that marriages celebrated in this country, and those to be celebrated in future, according to our religious rites should be recognized as valid.
('13', 350, 2, 12, 652908) Two, that the term “monogamous” marriage should include a mar riage celebrated according to our religions.
('13', 350, 2, 13, 653015) Three, that in case an Indian is already married to more than one woman, all his wives should be permitted to come in.
('13', 350, 3, 14, 653134) We will not sit down for a moment’s rest till the Government concedes these demands.
('13', 350, 3, 15, 653219) Since women have been attacked, they too have had to join the struggle.
('13', 350, 3, 16, 653291) In so far as this marriage question involves an insult to our religions and an attack upon our national honour, it is far more serious than that of the obnoxious tax.
('13', 350, 3, 17, 653458) A nation that cannot protect its women’s honour and the interests of its children does not deserve to be called by that name.
('13', 350, 3, 18, 653584) Such people are not a nation but mere brutes.
('13', 350, 3, 19, 653630) Even animals use their horns to defend their young ones.
('13', 350, 3, 20, 653687) Will men, then, if they are men, hang back, clinging to their wretched finery and their pleasures?

('13', 351, 1, 2, 653870) 222. CRIPPLED WITHOUT WEAPONS
('13', 351, 2, 3, 653900) Much has been written by correspondents in the columns of this paper about the Indians not getting licences for weapons.
('13', 351, 2, 4, 654021) We sympathize with them.

('13', 351, 2, 6, 654108) But this rule can apply only to those who have no interest in wealth.
('13', 351, 2, 7, 654178) Those who carry on business and wish to protect themselves from attack need weapons, no doubt.

('13', 351, 2, 13, 654820) In the present satyagraha campaign, we can take up many new issues whenever we think it right.

('13', 352, 1, 2, 655077) 223. HAJI HUSSAIN DAWAD MAHOMED
('13', 352, 2, 3, 655109) It is with full deliberation that I say that the untimely death of Bhai Hussain has widowed the Indian community here.
('13', 352, 2, 4, 655228) People may wonder whether it is not something of an exaggeration to say that a young man of 22, of whom most Indians had not even heard, whom not many had seen, who never made any big speeches and never sought to teach wisdom to people, has widowed the people by his death, but my answer will still be the same.
('13', 352, 2, 5, 655540) The character which Bhai Hussain possessed I have seen in few youths or grown up men.
('13', 352, 2, 6, 655626) In South Africa, I can think of no grown up man who can equal him, and I doubt if there is any among the many youths whom I know.
('13', 352, 2, 7, 655756) If there is anyone who can surpass him, such a one is not known to me.
('13', 352, 2, 8, 655827) Bhai Hussain had based his way of life on truth.
('13', 352, 2, 9, 655876) He lived for truth.
('13', 352, 2, 10, 655896) Bhai Hussain detested lying, deceit, cunning and hypocrisy.
('13', 352, 2, 11, 655956) He felt extremely uncomfortable in the presence of deceit.
('13', 352, 2, 12, 656015) Whenever he saw people lying, his head would ache and he felt like flying away from there, if only he had wings.
('13', 352, 2, 13, 656128) The lies that go on in ordinary company were so disgusting to this youth that, many a time, he felt disinclined to stay on in Durban.
('13', 352, 2, 14, 656262) Whenever he heard and believed that a man was good, he was all admiration for him.
('13', 352, 2, 15, 656345) So guileless was he.
('13', 352, 2, 16, 656366) His heart was meek like a cow’s.
('13', 352, 2, 17, 656399) I never observed the slightest taint of sin in him.
('13', 352, 2, 18, 656451) His innocence and his frankness were all his own.
('13', 352, 2, 19, 656501) A budding rose has withered.
('13', 352, 2, 20, 656530) But its fragrance remains.
('13', 352, 2, 21, 656557) We can still enjoy deep draughts of it.
('13', 352, 2, 22, 656597) He has left that fragrance with everyone who came in contact with him.
('13', 352, 2, 23, 656668) Evil company had no effect on him.
('13', 352, 2, 24, 656703) Once Mr. Dawad Mahomed wrote to Hussain, “My son, guard yourself against the temptations of life in England.

('13', 356, 1, 14, 665437) Let everyone be an Indian of the same stamp as Hussain.
('13', 356, 1, 15, 665493) Let us all, young and old, emulate Bhai Hussain’s conduct, no matter whether we are Hindus or Muslims.
('13', 356, 1, 16, 665596) If we cherish his memory and follow in his footsteps, we shall cease to make distinctions among us.
('13', 356, 1, 17, 665696) Let us hold on to truth and dedicate our all to the country’s cause.
('13', 356, 1, 18, 665765) Though Bhai Hussain was on his death bed, when Rustomjee Sheth went to visit him before starting again on the 16th on a pilgrimage to gaol, he said, “Yes, uncle, you are going.
('13', 356, 1, 19, 665942) If I could leave this bed, I too would go to gaol with you.
('13', 356, 1, 20, 666002) How happy I would be to die in gaol for the sake of the country!” May India beget thousands of Hussains!

('13', 360, 1, 2, 669776) 227. RESOLUTION AT PATIDAR ASSOCIATION MEETING 1
('13', 360, 2, 3, 669825) JOHANNESBURG, October 5, 1913
('13', 360, 3, 4, 669855) This meeting of the Patidar Association resolves that, in its opinion, The Transvaal Leader report, to the effect that the mercantile section of the Indian community is against passive resistance and that only some of the poorest in the community are likely to take part in the struggle is unjust and false; the meeting is heart and soul with the movement, approves of Mr. Cachalia’s letter to the Government, and will undertake to support the movement with men and money, and requests the Government to end the sufferings of those already incarcerated by conceding the just demands of the community.
('13', 360, 4, 5, 670456) Indian Opinion, 15 10 1913
('13', 360, 5, 6, 670483) 1 The meeting was addressed by Gandhiji at some length and, thereafter, a number of Indians announced their intention to go to gaol immediately.
('13', 360, 5, 7, 670628) No report of Gandhiji’s speech, however, is available.
('13', 360, 5, 8, 670683) The resolution adopted at the meeting was presumably drafted by Gandhiji.

('13', 362, 1, 2, 671937) 229. IMPORTANCE OF VOWS
('13', 362, 2, 3, 671961) If we resolve to do a thing, and are ready even to sacrifice our lives in the process?
('13', 362, 2, 4, 672048) we are said to have taken a vow.
('13', 362, 2, 5, 672081) It is essential for every person to train himself to keep such vows; one can strengthen one’s power of will by doing so and fit oneself for greater tasks.
('13', 362, 2, 6, 672236) One may take easy and simple vows to start with and follow them with more difficult ones.
('13', 362, 2, 7, 672326) It seems the negroes of the Congo have taken such a [simple] vow.
('13', 362, 2, 8, 672392) For the past three years, the whites have been trying hard to get the negroes over there to extract rubber, but they answer that their forefathers had pledged themselves not to do so.
('13', 362, 2, 9, 672576) They are, therefore, unable to go against their plighted word.
('13', 362, 2, 10, 672639) We shall find several examples in history of men undergoing great suffering for the sake of a pledge.
('13', 362, 2, 11, 672741) To embrace satyagraha amounts to taking a great vow.
('13', 362, 2, 12, 672794) Having taken it, one must die rather than forsake it.
('13', 362, 2, 13, 672848) Such is the profound import of satyagraha, and it is for this reason that satyagraha may be said to know no defeat.
('13', 362, 3, 14, 672964) [From Gujarati]
('13', 362, 4, 15, 672980) Indian Opinion, 8 10 1913
('13', 363, 0, 1, 673006) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 363, 1, 2, 673048) 230. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS 1
('13', 363, 2, 3, 673085) [JOHANNESBURG,] October 9, 1913
('13', 363, 4, 4, 673117) Messrs Medh and other British Indian passive resisters, who last week served a term of imprisonment at the Fort of Johannesburg, complained that Dr. Visser was unnecessarily and wantonly rude and insulting to them.
('13', 363, 4, 5, 673332) 1 hey were asked to strip themselves entirely bare in the presence of other prisoners, for medical examination.
('13', 363, 4, 6, 673444) They respectfully submitted to the doctor that it was contrary to their moral scruples and to their notions of decency, and they added that they were prepared to submit to the examination in a separate cell.
('13', 363, 4, 7, 673652) Dr. Visser grew angry over this request and used most insulting language.
('13', 363, 4, 8, 673726) The exact expression used by him was “the .
('13', 363, 4, 9, 673770) coolies”.
('13', 363, 4, 10, 673780) He also charged them with disobedience, but my Committee is informed that the charge was never pursued, and that, upon their complaining to the Superintendent of the gaol, they were privately examined.
('13', 363, 4, 11, 673982) My Com mittee hopes that an inquiry will be instituted into this complaint, and necessary steps will be taken to prevent officers using language alleged to have been used by Dr. Visser, even though it be towards prisoners.
('13', 363, 4, 12, 674205) The discharged passive resisters also complained that there was no ghee or any vegetable fat supplied with their meals, as used to be the case before.
('13', 363, 4, 13, 674356) Their meals, my Committee understands, consist of rice, mealie meal, vegetables, and a little bread.
('13', 363, 4, 14, 674457) My Committee showed, it is submitted, during the last campaign of passive resistance, that ghee or some vegetable fat was absolutely necessary for mainte nance of the human frame in fair order.
('13', 363, 4, 15, 674651) 2 My Committee understands
('13', 363, 5, 16, 674678) 1 This was published along with a letter to the Press dated October 7, signed by Surendra B. Medh, Pragji K. Desai and Manilal M. Gandhi, requesting the Editor to write in protest against the brutal treatment to which they had been subjected.
('13', 363, 5, 17, 674921) 2 Vide “Letter to E. F. C. Lane”, 29 4 1911; “Petition to Secretary of State for Colonies”, 1 5 1911 and “Memorial to Secretary of State for Colonies”, 15 5 1911.
('13', 364, 0, 1, 675084) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 365
('13', 364, 1, 2, 675131) that animal fat for one of the meals still forms part of the diet given to the Native prisoners.
('13', 364, 1, 3, 675228) It is therefore respectfully requested that instructions will be issued to supply one ounce of ghee per day, as was the case formerly with British Indian prisoners, who are precluded from taking meat or animal fat.
('13', 364, 2, 4, 675443) Yours, etc.,
('13', 364, 3, 5, 675456) Indian Opinion, 22 10 1913
('13', 364, 4, 6, 675483) 231. AN OFFICIAL STATEMENT
('13', 364, 5, 7, 675510) The situation today in regard to the Indian passive resistance movement is explained in the following statement which has been officially communicated to Reuter’s Agency, and the Press.
('13', 364, 5, 8, 675696) The demands of the Indian community are: (1) The removal of the annual tax of £3, which ex indentured Indians—men, women, and children—are liable to pay as the price of their remaining free from re indenture in Natal.
('13', 364, 5, 9, 675914) (2) (a) An amendment of the marriage law of the Union, so as to recognize the legality of monogamous Indian marriages celebrated, whether in India or South Africa, according to the rites prescribed by the Hindu and Mahomedan religions.
('13', 364, 5, 10, 676150) Although both of these religions countenance polygamy, statistics show that only 1 per cent of Indian marriages are polygamous.
('13', 364, 6, 11, 676278) (b) Administrative admission of existing plural wives (not more than 100 in all) and their children, of Indians already domiciled.
('13', 364, 6, 12, 676409) This was the position at the time of the inauguration of Union.
('13', 364, 6, 13, 676473) Legal recognition of polygamy is not asked for.
('13', 364, 7, 14, 676521) (3) Restoration of the right of South Africa born Indians to enter the Cape Province, a right that they possessed at the time of the introduction of the Immigration Bill, and its retention may in practice mean the admission of hardly more than a dozen Indians annually to the Cape from Natal and the Transvaal.
('13', 364, 8, 15, 676832) (4) The Government say that there is no racial bar in the
('13', 365, 0, 1, 676890) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 365, 1, 2, 676932) Immigration Act.
('13', 365, 1, 3, 676949) Therefore, an admission from them is necessary that no declaration will in law be required from an Indian at the Free State border that will not be equally necessary from a European.
('13', 365, 1, 4, 677132) In practice, this does not mean that any Indian will necessarily enter the Free State, but, if he does, he will still remain liable to the prohibition to own land, to farm and to trade.
('13', 365, 2, 5, 677318) (5) A declaration that existing laws, such as the Transvaal Gold Law and Townships Act, the Licensing Laws of the Cape and Natal, and the Immigration Act, shall be administered in a liberal spirit, and with due regard to vested rights.
('13', 365, 2, 6, 677554) The policy of the Government is, for example, to prevent Indians with bona fide proof of previous residence from re entering their respective Provinces, if they have been absent for a long period.
('13', 365, 2, 7, 677751) This situation is intolerable.
('13', 365, 3, 8, 677782) The first point was the subject of a definite promise to the Hon.
('13', 365, 3, 9, 677848) Mr. Gokhale.
('13', 365, 3, 10, 677861) The others arise out of the provisional settlement of 1911.
('13', 365, 4, 11, 677921) WHAT INDIANS DO NOT WANT
('13', 365, 5, 12, 677946) Indians do not fight for equal political rights.
('13', 365, 5, 13, 677995) They recognize that, in view of the existing prejudice, fresh immigration from India should be strictly limited, provision being made for the entrance of a sufficient number annually for reasonable wear and tear.
('13', 365, 6, 14, 678208) PASSIVE RESISTANCE
('13', 365, 7, 15, 678227) As no relief could be obtained by prayers, petitions, or negoti ations, Indians started passive resistance on September 15 by12 men and four women setting out from Natal to court imprisonment at Volksrust.
('13', 365, 7, 16, 678433) The movement is spreading.
('13', 365, 7, 17, 678460) There are already in gaol 35 passive resisters—a larger number than when the two previous campaigns started or when the provisional settlement of 1911 resulted in a suspension of passive resistance.
('13', 365, 7, 18, 678659) Numbers of men and women are coming forward daily to seek arrest.
('13', 365, 7, 19, 678725) Several of the women have taken their babies with them, as they have not yet been weaned or are incapable of being looked after otherwise.
('13', 365, 7, 20, 678864) Arrest is courted by crossing the border or by hawking without licences or by refusing to
('13', 366, 0, 1, 678954) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 367
('13', 366, 1, 2, 679001) show licences or permits, or by breaking other civil laws which do not involve a breach of the moral law.
('13', 366, 1, 3, 679107) The Free State border is left untouched, as there is no desire to inflame public opinion so far as it can be avoided, and there is every desire to show that Indians wish to respect the Free State prejudice.
('13', 366, 1, 4, 679314) The movement will also consist in advising indentured Indians to suspend work until the £3 tax is removed.
('13', 366, 1, 5, 679421) The indentured Indians will not be invited to join the general struggle.
('13', 366, 1, 6, 679494) On the strength of the promise made to Mr. Gokhale, and which promise was brought to the notice of the House of Lords by Lord Ampthill, these men were assured by Indian leaders, at meetings of thousands, that the tax would be repealed during the last session of Parliament.
('13', 366, 1, 7, 679768) Meetings in support of the claims of the passive resisters have been held at Cape Town, Port Elizabeth, East London, Woodstock, Durban, Maritzburg, Tongaat, Verulam, and Johannesburg (representing all the principal towns in the Transvaal), and similar meetings are being held at other centres.
('13', 366, 2, 8, 680062) THE WAY TO GRANT RELIEF
('13', 366, 3, 9, 680086) If the Government wish to grant relief, fresh legislation will be necessary only on the marriage and the £3 tax questions.
('13', 366, 3, 10, 680209) All other points are capable of easy adjustment without legislation.
('13', 366, 3, 11, 680278) The marriage difficulty can be solved by a brief amendment of the Immigration Act without in any way interfering with the general marriage law of the Union.
('13', 366, 4, 12, 680435) Indian Opinion, 15 10 1913
('13', 367, 0, 1, 680462) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('13', 368, 1, 2, 682078) 233. INTERVIEW TO “EVENING CHRONICLE”
('13', 368, 2, 3, 682116) [JOHANNESBURG, After October 17, 1913]
('13', 368, 3, 4, 682155) Interviewed by the Evening Chronicle (Johannesburg) on Mr. Fischer’s recent
('13', 368, 4, 5, 682231) statement, 1 Mr. Gandhi said that during the last session of Parliament, all the time the
('13', 368, 5, 6, 682321) A. Fischer said he would grant nothing, so long as there was talk of passive
('13', 368, 6, 7, 682398) resistance, he continued to grant.
('13', 368, 6, 8, 682433) He even withdrew his own threat of removing the
('13', 368, 7, 9, 682481) slight amendment in the marriage clause, if Indians did not withdraw their demand for
('13', 368, 8, 10, 682567) a better amendment.
('13', 368, 8, 11, 682587) In spite of that threat in the Senate, Mr. Fischer accepted the
('13', 368, 9, 12, 682651) very amendment that was suggested by the Indians, so that he could not help saying
('13', 368, 10, 13, 682734) that Mr. Fischer was not to be taken seriously.
('13', 368, 11, 14, 682782) Indian Opinion, 29 10 1913
('13', 368, 12, 15, 682809) 1 In an interview to Reuter’s Agency in London on October 17, Fischer had said: “My own department deals with the Indians, and it is impossible to alter the law on any material point.
('13', 368, 12, 16, 682993) Indeed the spirit in South Africa is to make the law more strict.
('13', 368, 12, 17, 683059) The Government will be content to let the law stand.
('13', 368, 12, 18, 683112) To meet the views of the Indians we will make administrative arrangements where we can, but the popular sentiment and needs of South Africa must be considered.
('13', 368, 12, 19, 683272) Therefore the Indians in their own interest must be cautious and moderate.
('13', 368, 12, 20, 683347) If the Indians abandon theoretical questions and adopt a practical standpoint, then a modus vivendi is possible”

('13', 369, 1, 2, 683502) 234. KULSUMBIBI’S CASE
('13', 369, 2, 3, 683525) A move is afoot in Durban to take this case to the Appeal Court.
('13', 369, 2, 4, 683590) A bioscope show was also arranged to collect money for the purpose.
('13', 369, 2, 5, 683658) There is no harm in taking the case to a higher court, but the community need not imagine that this is bound to bring some gain.
('13', 369, 2, 6, 683787) The case might just as well go against us as in our favour.
('13', 369, 2, 7, 683847) Even if the result should be so happy, it should be remembered that, where a marriage is solemnized in South Africa, the wife will continue to be treated as a concubine.
('13', 369, 2, 8, 684017) Hence those who know what the struggle means must not become lukewarm.
('13', 369, 2, 9, 684088) The fight must be carried on in right earnest.
('13', 369, 2, 10, 684135) We see on all sides that everyone concedes our demands to be reasonable, the latest instance being that of Mr. Orr, a member of Parliament, who said in a speech in Maritzburg that the £3 tax must be repealed and that we must get full justice on the marriage question.
('13', 369, 2, 11, 684403) Whatever the interpretation of the court, [he said] it was clearly understood by Parliament that a man with only one wife would have no difficulty in bringing her in.

('13', 371, 9, 9, 685973) 237. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('13', 371, 10, 10, 686007) Wednesday night [October 22, 1913] 3
('13', 371, 11, 11, 686044) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('13', 371, 12, 12, 686065) I am sorry that I was impatient with you regarding Baker and the walk to Chaplin’s.
('13', 371, 12, 13, 686149) Baker’s business simply shakes me.
('13', 371, 12, 14, 686184) I feel it deeply that one whom [I] so love has such a base commercial side to his character.
('13', 371, 12, 15, 686277) And how could I put on speed when I hardly walk?
('13', 371, 12, 16, 686326) It was torture to be told to walk fast in my present physical state.
('13', 371, 12, 17, 686395) I am surrounded by men.
('13', 371, 12, 18, 686419) I have recess as Mr. Lazarus is talking in Tamil to some men.
('13', 371, 12, 19, 686481) Went to Dannhauser today.
('13', 371, 12, 20, 686507) It was a grand meeting 4 .
('13', 371, 12, 21, 686534) The strike 5 is a real thing.
('13', 371, 12, 22, 686564) It is now making itself felt.
('13', 371, 13, 23, 686594) 1 These were: Mrs. Bhavani Dayal, Mrs. Thambi Naidoo, Mrs. N. Pillay, Mrs. K. M. Pillay, Mrs. A. P. Naidoo, Mrs. P. K. Naidoo, Mrs. K. C. Pillay, Mrs. N. S.Pillay, Mrs. Ramalingam, Miss M. Pillay and Miss M. B. Pillay.

('13', 373, 0, 1, 688036) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 373, 1, 2, 688078) 238. INTERVIEW TO “RAND DAILY MAIL”
('13', 373, 2, 3, 688114) [JOHANNESBURG, October 22, 1913]
('13', 373, 3, 4, 688147) In connection with the mass meeting of Indians held at Durban on Sunday 1, Mr. M. K. Gandhi told a Mail representative yesterday that the report published in a contemporary was only half the version and was incorrect.
('13', 373, 3, 5, 688365) There certainly was a disturbance at the meeting, said Mr. Gandhi, and one of the secretaries, at the time of tendering his resignation, made a long statement consisting of an attack upon Mr. Gandhi and upon his work during the past 20 years which he characterised as being not only worthless but highly injurious to the Indian community.
('13', 373, 3, 6, 688704) So much so that, in his opinion, Mr. Gandhi was instrumental in having enticed the Indian community into slavery.
('13', 373, 4, 7, 688818) [GANDHIJI: ] Personally, I don’t think that any but very few people at the meeting took him seriously, but I saw that there were elements of discord and that passions were rising on either side, and I felt that the best thing under the circumstances would be to have the meeting closed.
('13', 373, 4, 8, 689105) I, therefore, suggested to the chairman that he should dissolve the meeting, which he promptly did.
('13', 373, 4, 9, 689205) It was really an attempt to bring about a schism in the Indian community and was not on the question of passive resistance by any means, because I don’t think there was any difference of opinion as to passive resistance.
('13', 373, 4, 10, 689426) A great many side issues were brought forward having no bearing on the present trouble.
('13', 373, 4, 11, 689514) Upon the dissolution of this meeting, those who disapproved of the action of the secretary immediately formed themselves into a procession and a meeting was held at Mr. Rustomjee’s premises and a new body was formed, with Mr. Dawad Mohamed as president and Mr. Omar Haji Amod Jhaveri as secretary, two of the most respected Mohammedans in the community.
('13', 373, 4, 12, 689868) At this meeting a resolution was passed in support of the movement, and a collection was taken for defraying the expenses in connection with the fares, etc., of the passive resisters who accompanied me to court imprisonment.
('13', 373, 4, 13, 690093) The utmost
('13', 373, 5, 14, 690104) 1 October 19
('13', 374, 0, 1, 690117) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 375
('13', 374, 1, 2, 690164) enthusiasm prevailed, and it was considered that the most reasonable and peaceful Indians would join this body.
('13', 374, 1, 3, 690276) Personally, I feel that if this new Association is worked along strict passive resistance lines, then those who may be considered hostile to this body and even to the movement will ultimately throw in their lot with the body.
('13', 374, 1, 4, 690502) That the movement has a strong hold in Natal is demonstrated by the fact that Natal has supplied the largest number of gaol goers.
('13', 374, 1, 5, 690633) There are at present nearly 100 Indians in the gaols at Maritzburg and Newcastle, and of these by far the largest number are from Natal and include all sections of the Indian community.
('13', 374, 1, 6, 690819) A strike, too, which promises to become very formidable, is going on in Natal.
('13', 374, 1, 7, 690898) Up to now six collieries are affected and 2,000 Indians are on strike.
('13', 374, 1, 8, 690969) I may say that, though I had hoped that the strike would come about, I had never expected that the response would be so spontaneous, sudden and large.
('13', 374, 1, 9, 691120) The ladies who tried to get arrested at Vereeniging, as the public knows, failed, and they have further crossed over into Natal, where they were left untouched.
('13', 374, 1, 10, 691281) When they went into Natal, they were joined by eight men, none of whom was arrested on the Natal border.
('13', 374, 1, 11, 691386) It was proposed that they should go to Newcastle and there place the position before the men serving on the collieries and ask them to strike work pending the promise of removal of the annual tax of £3 which ex indentured Indians and their wives and children have to pay.
('13', 374, 1, 12, 691658) The presence of these brave women who had never suffered hardship and had never spoken at public meetings acted like electricity, and the men left their work.
('13', 374, 1, 13, 691817) The strike is being conducted on purely passive resistance lines, and the men have instructions on no account to use physical force, to retaliate or to defend themselves physically.
('13', 374, 1, 14, 691999) I saw a man who was severely assaulted at Dannhauser yesterday, and the assault was cruel.
('13', 374, 1, 15, 692090) He states that he had gone to fetch water and was assaulted by one of the compound managers.
('13', 374, 1, 16, 692183) The man himself is able bodied and well able to defend himself, but on account of the above order having been issued, he did not defend himself, and suffered the severe injury without a word.
('13', 374, 1, 17, 692375) He is now being looked after in Newcastle, and he will certainly make a deposition in this by no means isolated case.We are
('13', 375, 0, 1, 692499) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 375, 1, 2, 692541) at present putting up with physical injury, insults and everything.
('13', 375, 1, 3, 692609) The reason why we ask the men to strike is that by means of such demonstration we may bring about the repeal of the £3 tax.
('13', 375, 1, 4, 692733) It was stated during the last session of Parliament that the majority of employers of labour in Natal were adverse to the removal of the tax.
('13', 375, 1, 5, 692875) I feel that the only way in which such employers can be brought to see the humanity of removing it is for the men to strike work.
('13', 375, 1, 6, 693005) The strikers will immediately resume work as soon as the Government see their way to make a promise that the tax will be repealed during the coming session of Parliament.
('13', 375, 1, 7, 693176) If they make that promise, they will simply be fulfilling their obligation to Mr. Gokhale which, Lord Ampthill says, they incurred during the interview that took place between Mr. Gokhale and the ministers.
('13', 375, 1, 8, 693383) I may also add that the Government were not without notice that the strike was also on our programme.
('13', 375, 1, 9, 693485) I addressed a letter 1 on the 28th September to that effect to the Government.
('13', 375, 2, 10, 693564) Rand Daily Mail, 23 10 1913
('13', 375, 3, 11, 693592) 1 Vide “Letter to Secretary for Interior”, 28 9 1913. The official assessment of the strike situation was summed up in a confidential despatch from the Governor General to the Colonial Office, dated October 23, 1913; vide Appendix “Extract from Governor General’s Despatch to Colonial Office”, 23 10 1913. 2 The report concluded with the observation by Rand Daily Mail: “ .
('13', 375, 3, 12, 693966) the women mentioned above have been arrested at Newcastle and the strike is assuming larger proportions.
('13', 375, 3, 13, 694071) It is no longer confined to the coal fields, but is extending to the sugar and tea plantations and to the railways in Natal,”
('13', 376, 0, 1, 694197) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 377
('13', 376, 1, 2, 694244) 239. TELEGRAM TO GENERAL BOTHA
('13', 376, 2, 3, 694275) [NEWCASTLE, Before October 23, 1913]
('13', 376, 3, 4, 694312) WE HEAR YOU TOLD THE COLLIERIES’ MANAGERS
('13', 376, 4, 5, 694354) THAT THE INDIANS WERE ADVISED TO STRIKE FOR A
('13', 376, 5, 6, 694400) GENERAL STRUGGLE, AND THAT THE STRIKERS WERE SIMPLY
('13', 376, 6, 7, 694452) DECEIVED FOR SELFISH ENDS.
('13', 376, 6, 8, 694479) I BEG TO STATE THAT SUCH NEVER
('13', 376, 7, 9, 694510) WAS, AND IS NOT NOW, THE INTENTION.
('13', 376, 7, 10, 694546) THE STRIKE
('13', 376, 8, 11, 694557) HAS BEEN ADVISED PURELY REGARDING THE £3 TAX
('13', 376, 9, 12, 694602) AND THE STEP HAS BECOME NECESSARY OWING
('13', 376, 10, 13, 694642) TO THE NONFULFILMENT OF THE PROMISE MADE
('13', 376, 11, 14, 694683) TO THE HON.
('13', 376, 11, 15, 694695) MR. GOKHALE THAT IT WOULD BE,
('13', 376, 12, 16, 694725) AND AS A DEMONSTRATION AGAINST THE
('13', 376, 13, 17, 694760) STATEMENT MADE BY THE GOVERNMENT DURING
('13', 376, 14, 18, 694800) THE LAST SESSION THAT THE MAJORITY OF NATAL EMPLOYERS
('13', 376, 15, 19, 694854) ARE AVERSE TO THE REPEAL OF THE TAX.
('13', 376, 15, 20, 694891) IF GOVERNMENT WILL SEE
('13', 376, 16, 21, 694914) THEIR WAY TO PROMISE TO REPEAL IT NEXT SESSION, THE STRIKERS
('13', 376, 17, 22, 694975) WILL BE ADVISED TO RETURN TO WORK.

('13', 377, 9, 11, 695376) 241. LETTER TO MINISTER OF INTERIOR 2
('13', 377, 10, 12, 695414) [JOHANNESBURG,] October 23, 1913
('13', 377, 11, 13, 695447) THE HON’BLE THE MINISTER OF THE INTERIOR PRETORIA
('13', 377, 13, 14, 695497) I am directed by my Association respectfully to invite your attention to the following.
('13', 377, 13, 15, 695585) My Association has been informed that: 1. On or about the 27th September, a British Indian named Abdool Fazula Khan was arrested at Johannesburg under Section 4(Ia) of the Immigration Law of 1913, which reads:
('13', 377, 14, 16, 695795) Any such person as is described in any paragraph of this sub section who enters or is found within the Union, or who, though lawfully resident in one Province, enters or is found in another Province in which he is not lawfully resident, shall be a prohibited immigrant in respect of the Union or of that other Province (as the case may be), that is to say—any person or class of
('13', 377, 15, 17, 696174) 1 This was part of a Reuter message from Johannesburg according to which Gandhiji stated that Indians had struck work on more mines and that many had been arrested.
('13', 377, 15, 18, 696339) For the circumstances which prepared the ground for the march.
('13', 377, 15, 19, 696402) 2 This was sent on behalf of the Chairman, British Indian Association.
('13', 378, 0, 1, 696473) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 379
('13', 378, 1, 2, 696520) persons deemed by the Minister on economic grounds or on account of standard or habits of life to be unsuited to the requirements of the Union or any particular Province thereof.
('13', 378, 2, 3, 696699) 2. The said Khan appealed against the decision of the local Immigration Officer, and on the 13th October the said appeal was duly heard by the Board sitting at Pretoria and dismissed.
('13', 378, 3, 4, 696883) 3. The evidence led at the hearing of the appeal, and which was not disproved or rebutted, shows:
('13', 378, 4, 5, 696981) (a) That the said Khan first came to the Transvaal in 1900 as a private of the Indian Transport Corps No.
('13', 378, 4, 6, 697087) 2 Division.
('13', 378, 5, 7, 697099) (b) That he received a good discharge in November 1902 and, thereafter, remained in this Province for nearly another year— till towards the end of 1903.
('13', 378, 6, 8, 697252) (c) That he then went to Cape Town where he filled several situations, among others, working for Messrs Jagger & Co., Ohlson & Co., and Petersen & Co.
('13', 378, 6, 9, 697403) He remained in Cape Town about eight or nine years with the exception of a few months of service in German South West Africa.
('13', 378, 7, 10, 697529) (d) The said Khan then returned to the Transvaal by rail from the Cape and entered this Province without let or hindrance.
('13', 378, 8, 11, 697652) (e) While in German South West Africa, Khan lost his dis charge and several other papers of a similar character.
('13', 378, 9, 12, 697765) 4. On the day the said Khan’s appeal was dismissed, as stated in Paragraph 2 and immediately after, he was removed to Pretoria Gaol for deportation, but before removal, his Attorney, Mr. Ritch, saw the Principal Immigration Officer and represented to him the claims of the said Khan to be sent to the Cape Province.
('13', 378, 9, 13, 698081) Mr. Ritch gave the names of the principal employers for whom the said Khan claims to have worked.
('13', 378, 10, 14, 698179) 5. On the following evening, the said Khan was deported to Natal without his having had an opportunity to collect his clothes or other belongings and without any further communication having been made to his Attorney, and, thereafter, was immediately transported to India.
('13', 379, 0, 1, 698452) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 379, 1, 2, 698494) 6. I am desired to point out that no effort would appear to have been made to investigate the said Khan’s claims to be sent to the Cape, where he had resided for so many years, and to add that, in the respectful opinion of my Association, this should have been done even though it might have meant a few weeks’ longer detention in the Transvaal of the said Khan.
('13', 379, 2, 3, 698857) 7. My Association also desires me to call attention to the serious hardships which must necessarily follow such sudden deportation as this, in which case the deportee would appear to have been sent away without any means and with no more clothing than he stood in.
('13', 379, 2, 4, 699122) Had Khan’s Attorney been notified a few hours beforehand, his friends would have passed over to him his clothing and blankets and also money to assist him on his journey.
('13', 379, 3, 5, 699293) 8. My Association trusts that the facts in this case will be fully investigated by you; and that steps will be taken to prevent a repetition of the unfortunate incident.
('13', 379, 4, 6, 699463) I have, etc.,

('13', 380, 1, 2, 699584) 242. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('13', 380, 2, 3, 699618) NEWCASTLE, October 23, 1913
('13', 380, 3, 4, 699646) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('13', 380, 4, 5, 699667) Just now it seems to me that a solution has been found for the building proposal.
('13', 380, 4, 6, 699749) The strikers must leave the mines.
('13', 380, 4, 7, 699784) Otherwise the strike is bound to collapse.
('13', 380, 4, 8, 699827) I am therefore inviting them to come out.
('13', 380, 4, 9, 699869) If they do, one of us will march with them to the Transvaal border to court arrest.
('13', 380, 4, 10, 699953) We should be arrested on the way.
('13', 380, 4, 11, 699987) This avoids the difficulty of lodgings, etc., and keeps the men going.
('13', 380, 4, 12, 700058) The situation is certainly difficult and serious.
('13', 380, 4, 13, 700108) The strike is now having its effect.
('13', 380, 4, 14, 700145) But unless some such thing like the above is done, the movement is bound to collapse.
('13', 380, 4, 15, 700231) You should carefully watch the Press.
('13', 380, 4, 16, 700269) You should constantly make it clear that we do not wish to break the Provincial barrier.
('13', 380, 4, 17, 700358) Our only purpose is by intense suffering to make a striking demonstration against the £3 tax.
('13', 380, 4, 18, 700452) Not a minute to spare.
('13', 380, 4, 19, 700475) I hate writing.
('13', 380, 4, 20, 700491) With love,
('13', 380, 5, 21, 700502) UPPER HOUSE
('13', 380, 6, 22, 700514) From the original: Gandhi Kallenbach Correspondence.

('13', 382, 5, 6, 702473) 244. CABLE TO G. A. NATESAN 1
('13', 382, 6, 7, 702503) DURBAN, [Before October 25, 1913]
('13', 382, 7, 8, 702537) THE REPORT IS ENTIRELY FALSE; MEETINGS HELD

('13', 383, 5, 7, 704354) After the conference 2, Mr. Gandhi was asked by a Mercury representative whether there was any truth in the suggestion that the strike was at an end.
('13', 383, 5, 8, 704504) [GANDHIJI:] No, the strike is still continuing.
('13', 383, 5, 9, 704552) I have telegrams from Dannhauser district to say that that is so, and from Dundee and Newcastle also.
('13', 383, 5, 10, 704654) The position is that the men were to be withdrawn from the collieries in order to court arrest and imprisonment in Natal, or, failing that, to cross the border to the Transvaal, and be arrested there.
('13', 383, 5, 11, 704855) As this conference was coming, this movement was suspended.
('13', 383, 5, 12, 704915) So the position is that they are on strike, but have not left the mines.
('13', 383, 5, 13, 704988) The idea behind this proposed movement from the mines was that it was not a proper thing to draw rations from the mine owners, and yet not to work.
('13', 383, 5, 14, 705136) I personally felt that the strike was weak so long as the men did not actually leave the mines.
('13', 383, 5, 15, 705232) What will happen now will depend on the result of the conference, and that I am unable to

('13', 384, 1, 5, 706196) The effect of this is not entirely to stop work as they have a certain amount of Kaffir labour, and with this Kaffir labour and the Europeans they are able to do some work, though the bulk of it is certainly at a standstill.

('13', 384, 1, 10, 706742) As soon as the Government make a promise to the effect that the tax will be repealed during the next session of Parliament, the strikers will be advised to resume work.
('13', 384, 1, 11, 706911) It is not the intention to ask them to join the general struggle at all; because, apart from the £3 tax, there are other grievances also for which the passive resistance by the general body of the people will continue.
('13', 384, 1, 12, 707130) The other grievances are the marriage question; the question of domiciliary rights; the harsh administration of existing laws, as the Gold Law in the Transvaal; the right of S[outh] A[frica] born Indians to enter the Cape by reason of their birth; and the theoretical question of the social bar.
('13', 384, 1, 13, 707426) For these things, even if the promise to repeal the £3 tax is given, passive resistance, without the strike, will continue.
('13', 384, 1, 14, 707550) I may state also, that no intimidation of any sort was used against non strikers, and the strike is absolutely a voluntary act, and in so far as I have been able to see, quite spontaneous.
('13', 384, 1, 15, 707739) The men only needed the position to be placed before them to strike.
('13', 384, 1, 16, 707808) For the relief of the strikers, whom we have to support, subscriptions are being collected everywhere.

('13', 384, 1, 18, 708024) More collections are still going on.
('13', 384, 2, 19, 708061) If the Conference ends in a fiasco, we shall certainly endeavour to widen the area of the strike, but I am totally unable to say what response we shall have.

('13', 392, 5, 11, 718545) 254. GIST OF LETTER TO SECRETARY FOR JUSTICE 1
('13', 392, 6, 12, 718592) [CHARLESTOWN, October 31, 1913]
('13', 392, 7, 13, 718624) Mr. Gandhi wrote to the Secretary for Justice from Charlestown on the 31st ultimo pointing out that a large number of Indians had surrendered themselves for arrest and, as the Government had no accommodation for them nor facility for feeding them, they were being fed and housed by the Indian Committee there at Government expense.
('13', 392, 7, 14, 718956) Mr. Gandhi suggested that all the people should be arrested, but, if not, he stated that they would proceed with their march into the Transvaal—an event which he was anxious to avoid.
('13', 392, 7, 15, 719140) He also warned the Government against allowing Indians to remain free on the border and stated that it was the desire of the passive resisters to guard in every way they could against the surreptitious entry of a single Indian.
('13', 392, 8, 16, 719368) Indian Opinion, 12 11 1913
('13', 392, 9, 17, 719395) 1 The original letter is not available.
('13', 392, 9, 18, 719435) 2 Official policy in regard to the handling of the strike situation is clarified in a confidential despatch, dated November 6, from the Governor General to the Colonial Office; vide Appendix “Extract from Governor General’s Despatch to Colonial Office”, 6 11 1913.
('13', 393, 0, 1, 719700) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 393, 1, 2, 719742) 255. GIST OF LETTER TO IMMIGRATION OFFICER 1
('13', 393, 2, 3, 719787) [CHARLESTOWN, October 31, 1913]
('13', 393, 3, 4, 719819) A letter was addressed on the same day by Mr. Gandhi to the Immigration Officer, Pretoria, pointing out that all passive resisters receive at the Transvaal border three days’ notice of appeal, although they declare they do not wish to appeal, and that they are allowed to roam about as they please.
('13', 393, 3, 5, 720118) In Mr. Gandhi’s opinion the Act does not require the warning to be given in all circumstances.
('13', 393, 4, 6, 720213) Indian Opinion, 12 11 1913
('13', 393, 5, 7, 720240) 256. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('13', 393, 6, 8, 720274) CHARLESTOWN, November 3, 1913
('13', 393, 7, 9, 720304) The enclosed letter was written on the way.
('13', 393, 7, 10, 720348) 2 It is unfinished.
('13', 393, 7, 11, 720368) I have seen the quotations for tents, and it seems to me that, after all, bell tents would be the cheapest and the easiest to fix up.
('13', 393, 7, 12, 720502) One bell tent takes in twelve men.
('13', 393, 7, 13, 720537) At that rate in order to accommodate 1,200 men, we should want 100. The figures then amount to £75. That would be, in my opinion, prohibitive.
('13', 393, 7, 14, 720680) The alternative is to buy tarpaulin and make our own tents and poles.
('13', 393, 7, 15, 720750) It seems to me that this could be easily fixed.
('13', 393, 7, 16, 720798) If we could sew them on to the tarpaulin, the thing would be quite substantial, but it may be too long.
('13', 393, 7, 17, 720902) In that event we shall have to use handles.
('13', 393, 7, 18, 720946) I am now writing without any experience whatsoever, but I am giving you all these suggestions for what they are worth.
('13', 393, 7, 19, 721065) At the time of the Zulu Rebellion 3 we had tents which when erected simply looked like the wings of a roof without any wall.
('13', 393, 7, 20, 721190) There were pegs which were to be driven in.
('13', 393, 7, 21, 721234) They could easily be rigged up and two

('13', 396, 1, 2, 723736) 259. INTERVIEW TO “THE NATAL MERCURY”
('13', 396, 2, 3, 723774) [CHARLESTOWN, November 5, 1913]
('13', 396, 3, 4, 723806) Mr. Gandhi readily granted an interview, but had nothing to say, except that he and his followers were still quite determined, and would march into the Transvaal on the following day, courting arrest, and if they were unmolested, would march right on until they reached Tolstoy Farm.
('13', 396, 3, 5, 724090) They would then remain quietly there until satisfactory terms had been made with the Government.
('13', 396, 3, 6, 724187) All arrangements had been made along the route, and food depots established at eight different points along the way.
('13', 396, 3, 7, 724304) Their object was to court arrest, but they wished to do everything quite openly, and had acquainted the Government with their intentions.
('13', 396, 4, 8, 724442) Indian Opinion, 12 11 1913
('13', 396, 5, 9, 724469) 1 Before zero hour was reached, Gandhiji made a final bid to avert the march.
('13', 396, 5, 10, 724547) This is what he has himself recorded: “When all the preparations for the march were completed, I made one more effort to achieve a settlement.
('13', 396, 5, 11, 724690) I had already sent letters and telegrams.
('13', 396, 5, 12, 724732) I now decided to ‘phone even at the risk of my overtures being answered by an insult.
('13', 396, 5, 13, 724818) From Charlestown I ‘phoned to General Smuts in Pretoria.
('13', 396, 5, 14, 724875) I called his secretary and said: ‘Tell General Smuts that I am fully prepared for the march.
('13', 396, 5, 15, 724968) The Europeans in Volksrust are excited and perhaps likely to violate even the safety of our lives.
('13', 396, 5, 16, 725067) They have certainly held out such a threat.
('13', 396, 5, 17, 725111) I am sure that even the General would not wish any such untoward event to happen.
('13', 396, 5, 18, 725193) If he promises to abolish the £3 tax, I will stop the march, as I will not break the law merely for the sake of breaking it, but I am driven to it by inexorable necessity.
('13', 396, 5, 19, 725365) Will not the General accede to such a small request?’ I received this reply within half a minute: ‘General Smuts will have nothing to do with you.
('13', 396, 5, 20, 725512) You may do just as you please.’ With this the message closed.
('13', 396, 5, 21, 725574) “I had fully expected this result, though I was not prepared for the curtness of the reply.
('13', 396, 5, 22, 725666) I hoped for a civil answer, as my political relations with the General since the organization of Satyagraha had now subsisted for six years.
('13', 396, 5, 23, 725807) But as I would not be elated by this courtesy, I did not weaken in the face of his incivility.
('13', 396, 5, 24, 725902) The strait and narrow path I had to tread was clear before me.
('13', 396, 5, 25, 725965) The next day (November 6, 1913) at the appointed stroke of the hour (6.30) we offered prayers and commenced the march in the name of God.
('13', 396, 5, 26, 726103) The pilgrim band was composed of 2,037 men, 127 women and 57 children.” Satyagraha in South Africa, Ch. XLIII.

('13', 399, 4, 5, 729535) 263. APPLICATION FOR BAIL 1
('13', 399, 5, 6, 729563) STANDERTON, November 8, 1913
('13', 399, 6, 7, 729592) Before pleading, accused stated he was already on bail, and asked to be admitted on bail.
('13', 399, 6, 8, 729682) Accused stated his object in asking for bail was to enable him to take the men to their destination.
('13', 399, 6, 9, 729783) The Prosecutor opposed bail unless the accused would refrain from taking further part in the demonstration.
('13', 399, 6, 10, 729891) The accused said he was not prepared to give this assurance.
('13', 399, 7, 11, 729952) The Star, 8 11 1913
('13', 399, 8, 12, 729972) 1 Gandhiji arrived at Standerton with about 2,000 passive resisters.
('13', 399, 8, 13, 730041) 85 Indians who had left Hattingh Spruit Colliery were arrested.
('13', 399, 8, 14, 730105) Gandhiji was charged with “aiding or abetting prohibited persons to enter the Transvaal”.
('13', 399, 8, 15, 730195) 2 According to a report in The Transvaal Leader, when the Prosecutor protested against Gandhiji’s plea for bail, “the Magistrate pointed out that every prisoner not charged with a capital sentence was in law entitled to be allowed to give bail for his appearance, and said that Mr. Gandhi could not be deprived of that right.” Gandhiji was then released on his own recognizance of £50, and the case was remanded till the 21st.
('13', 399, 8, 16, 730622) As soon as Gandhiji was released, the column continued its march.
('13', 399, 8, 17, 730688) For a detailed first hand report of the next part of the march, vide “The Great March”, 8 11 1913; also Satyagraha in South Africa, Ch. XLIV.

('13', 400, 5, 10, 731344) 265. LETTER TO INDIANS 2
('13', 400, 6, 11, 731369) [Before November 11, 1913]
('13', 400, 7, 12, 731396) The like of this struggle will not come again.
('13', 400, 7, 13, 731443) We have reached the limit now.
('13', 400, 7, 14, 731474) The courage that the indentured labourers have shown and the suffering they have gone through have been boundless.
('13', 400, 7, 15, 731589) How many men will be ready to foot 24 miles a day on one and a half pounds of bread and a little sugar?
('13', 400, 7, 16, 731693) This is what our poor brethren have done.
('13', 400, 7, 17, 731735) They have suffered horses’ kicks.
('13', 400, 7, 18, 731769) They have silently endured kicks and blows by whites.
('13', 400, 7, 19, 731823) Women have walked in the heat of the noon, two month old babies in arms and bundles on head.
('13', 400, 7, 20, 731916) Everyone has braved the rigours of weather, heat and cold and rain.
('13', 400, 8, 21, 731984) 1 After Gandhiji was released on bail, a representative of Reuter who intervie wed Gandhiji asked him “what he thought would be the outcome of the demonstra tion”.

('13', 401, 0, 1, 732503) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 401, 1, 2, 732545) To what end?
('13', 401, 1, 3, 732558) For India.
('13', 401, 1, 4, 732569) Such sacrifice will no doubt result in repeal of the £3 tax but what is more, it will enhance India’s prestige.
('13', 401, 1, 5, 732681) I consider the Transvaal march to have been perfectly successful.
('13', 401, 1, 6, 732747) The object was to get arrested and all have been arrested.
('13', 401, 1, 7, 732806) It is only now, however, that the struggle will grow really exciting.
('13', 401, 1, 8, 732876) Hundreds of men, who are not ready for gaol, can play their part.
('13', 401, 1, 9, 732942) They have only to resolve that they themselves will go without meals but feed the strikers.
('13', 401, 1, 10, 733034) Whether or not any money arrives from India, we must supply the food from here.
('13', 401, 1, 11, 733114) We should put courage in the strikers’ hearts and advise them not to retaliate even if mercilessly kicked.
('13', 401, 1, 12, 733221) All Indians can do this.
('13', 401, 1, 13, 733246) An opportunity like this will not come again.
('13', 401, 1, 14, 733292) Every Indian may take a pledge.
('13', 401, 1, 15, 733324) He can cut out a meal every day, and with the money so saved provide food to the hungry.
('13', 401, 1, 16, 733413) Decency requires that traders in every place should give food and shelter to any striker who might find his way to that place and then send him on to where facilities exist for feeding large numbers.
('13', 401, 1, 17, 733613) If any Indian fails to play his part in this great venture, I for one will consider him an unfortunate man indeed.

('13', 401, 3, 19, 733744) Satyagrahi MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI

('13', 402, 0, 1, 733825) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 403
('13', 402, 1, 2, 733872) 266. TRIAL AT DUNDEE
('13', 402, 2, 3, 733893) [DUNDEE, November 11, 1913]
('13', 402, 3, 4, 733921) Mr. Gandhi was on the 11th instant charged on three counts, before the Resident Magistrate, Mr. J. W. Cross of Dundee, with inducing indentured immigrants to leave the Province.
('13', 402, 3, 5, 734099) The court was crowded with Indians and Europeans.
('13', 402, 3, 6, 734149) Mr. W. Dalzell Turnbull was specially instructed by the Attorney General to appear for the prosecution, and Mr. Advocate J. W. Godfrey appeared for Mr. Gandhi.
('13', 402, 3, 7, 734309) Mr. Gandhi pleaded guilty to the charges.
('13', 402, 4, 8, 734351) Mr. Turnbull read the section and left the matter in the hands of the Magistrate.
('13', 402, 5, 9, 734433) Mr. Godfrey stated that he was under an obligation to the defendant not to plead in mitigation in any way whatsoever.
('13', 402, 5, 10, 734551) The circumstances which had brought Mr. Gandhi before the Magistrate were well known to all persons, and he was only expressing the desire of the defendant when he stated that the Magistrate had a duty to perform, and that he was expected to perform that duty fearlessly, and should therefore not hesitate to impose the highest sentence upon the prisoner if he felt that the circumstances in the case justified it.
('13', 402, 6, 11, 734966) Mr. Gandhi obtained the permission of the Court, and made the following statement:
('13', 402, 7, 12, 735049) As a member of the profession, and being an old resident of Natal, he thought that, in justice to himself and the public, he should state that the counts against him were of such a nature that he took the responsibility imposed upon him, for he believed that the demonstration for which these people were taken out of the Colony was one for a worthy object.
('13', 402, 7, 13, 735407) He felt that he should say that he had nothing against the employers, and regretted that in this campaign, serious losses were being caused to them.
('13', 402, 7, 14, 735556) He appealed to the employers also, and he felt that the tax was one which was heavily weighing down his countrymen, and should be removed.
('13', 402, 7, 15, 735695) He also felt that he was in honour bound, in view of the position of things between Mr. Smuts and Professor Gokhale, to produce a striking demonstration.
('13', 402, 7, 16, 735849) 1 He was aware of the miscries caused to the women and babes in arms.
('13', 402, 7, 17, 735919) On the whole, he felt he had not gone beyond the principles and honour of the profession of which he was a member.
('13', 402, 8, 18, 736034) 1 The difference of opinion was over the abolition of the £3 tax, regarding which the Union Government insisted it had given Gokhale, in 1912, no assurance; vide “Extract from General Botha’s Speech”, 1 11 1913 for General Botha’s categorical denial.
('13', 403, 0, 1, 736285) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('13', 403, 1, 2, 736327) He felt that he had only done his duty in advising his countrymen, and it was his duty to advise them again, that until the tax were removed, to leave work and subsist upon rations obtained by charity.
('13', 403, 1, 3, 736529) He was certain that without suffering it was not possible for them to get their grievance remedied.
('13', 403, 2, 4, 736629) The Magistrate then addressed as follows: In this case the accused had pleaded guilty to the three counts, and the section of law under which the accused was charged made him liable to a fine of £20 for each immigrant he attempted to induce, or induced, to leave the Province.
('13', 403, 2, 5, 736906) Mr. Gandhi was an educated gentleman, and had the distinction of being a member of the legal profession, and whatever he had done, he had done with a full knowledge of the consequences of his act.
('13', 403, 2, 6, 737103) The Magistrate then referred to the conditions under which Indians were brought into this Province, and the terms they had agreed upon for remaining here after the expiry of their indentures.
('13', 403, 2, 7, 737295) He also referred to the contention of the Indians regarding Mr. Smuts’ alleged promise to the Indians.
('13', 403, 2, 8, 737398) The Natal members of Parliament had consented to the tax being removed so far as it affected the women and children, but not the men.
('13', 403, 2, 9, 737532) The Government had, therefore, not broken faith with the Indians and he believed this was the ground upon which Mr. Gandhi had advised the Indians to strike.
('13', 403, 2, 10, 737690) To strike was to defy the law, and the Government’s position was that, so long as the Indians were out on strike, it was impossible for them to consider any legislation regarding repeal.
('13', 403, 2, 11, 737877) The defendant was, by his threatening conduct, only bringing ruination to the men and harshness upon themselves.
('13', 403, 2, 12, 737990) He therefore advised the Indians to stop the passive resistance, and make representations to the Government.
('13', 403, 2, 13, 738099) He also believed that the Indians were alienating the sympathy of the Europeans who were at one with the Indians in requesting the Government for the repeal of the tax.
('13', 403, 2, 14, 738268) It was a painful duty to pass sentence upon the conduct of a gentleman like Mr. Gandhi, upon the deliberate contravention of the law, but he had a duty to perform, and Mr. Godfrey, his counsel, had asked him fearlessly to perform that duty.
('13', 403, 2, 15, 738509) The accused having pleaded guilty, he (the Magistrate) accepted that plea, and passed the following sentences: Count 1: £20, or three months’ imprisonment, with hard labour; Count 2: £20, or three mon ths’ imprisonment, with hard labour, to take effect upon the expiration of the sen tence in respect to Count 1; Count 3: £20, or three months’ imprisonment, with hard labour, this to take effect upon the expiration of the sentence imposed in Count 2.
('13', 403, 3, 16, 738961) Mr. Gandhi, in a clear and calm voice, said:
('13', 403, 4, 17, 739006) I elect to go to gaol.
('13', 403, 5, 18, 739029) Indian Opinion, 19 11 1913
('13', 403, 6, 19, 739056) 1 A large crowd of friends waited outside to see Gandhiji come out, but the police took him away secretly and no one knew how he was taken away.

('13', 407, 1, 2, 743521) 270. TRIAL AT VOLKSRUST
('13', 407, 2, 3, 743545) [VOLKSRUST, November 14, 1913]
('13', 407, 3, 4, 743576) Mr. Gandhi appeared in Court before Mr. Jooste, Assistant Magistrate, char ged under Section 20 of the Immigration Regulation Act.
('13', 407, 3, 5, 743707) He pleaded guilty, but the formal evidence of a resister named Poldat was called.
('13', 407, 4, 6, 743789) Witness stated he belonged to Ballengeich Mine, and remembered during the current month proceeding with a number of Indians into the Transvaal.
('13', 407, 4, 7, 743933) Poldat said Mr. Gandhi was leading them from Charlestown to Johannesburg.
('13', 407, 4, 8, 744007) Poldat recognized Mr. Gandhi as the leader.
('13', 407, 4, 9, 744051) Poldat knew he had no right in this Province, because he was a prohibited immigrant.
('13', 407, 5, 10, 744136) Mr. Gandhi said he would like to ask witness two questions.
('13', 407, 6, 11, 744196) Why did Poldat enter the Transvaal?
('13', 407, 7, 12, 744232) Poldat said he entered the Transvaal as a protest against the £3 tax.
('13', 407, 8, 13, 744302) Would Poldat have gone back to the mines if that £3 tax had been repealed?
('13', 407, 9, 14, 744377) Poldat said yes; if the Government had agreed to repeal the £3 tax, he would have gone back.
('13', 407, 10, 15, 744470) Mr. Gandhi was asked if he wished to make a statement.
('13', 407, 11, 16, 744525) Mr. Gandhi then addressed the Court.
('13', 407, 12, 17, 744562) I admit that I advised not only the last witness but hundreds of other Indians, whom I knew to be prohibited immigrants, to cross the border from Natal into the Transvaal.
('13', 407, 12, 18, 744734) Of my intention to do so I gave the Minister of the Interior due notice and I specially interviewed the Immigration Officer at Volksrust, and informed him even of the date on which I proposed to cross the border.
('13', 407, 12, 19, 744947) I told both the Government and the Immigration Officer that in doing so my only object was to make a demonstration against the £3 tax which was weighing heavily upon those who were affected by it, and to court for myself and the party who crossed with me imprisonment.
('13', 407, 12, 20, 745216) I assured them that nothing
('13', 407, 13, 21, 745244) 1 The statement as reported in Indian Opinion is in the third person.
('13', 407, 13, 22, 745314) The original statement given here is extracted from the Transvaal Court Records.
('13', 408, 0, 1, 745395) VOL. 13 : 12 MARCH, 1913 25 DECEMBER, 1913 409
('13', 408, 1, 2, 745442) could be further from my wish than to desire that a single one of those men who crossed the border should remain in the Transvaal and settle there.
('13', 408, 1, 3, 745590) I said also that, with such a large number crossing with me, I might be totally unable to prevent them for all time from roving about the country and that, therefore, I hoped that the Government would take charge of the men.
('13', 408, 1, 4, 745815) Throughout the march into the Transvaal, I endeavoured to keep the men under control and to prevent them from dispersing, and I claim that not a single Indian left the column if it may be so called.
('13', 408, 1, 5, 746014) I heard something at Heidelberg about the formation of a Vigilants Committee at Volksrust, whose aim I understand was to make the Government enforce the Immigration Act.
('13', 408, 1, 6, 746184) There is, therefore, common cause between the Committee and my co workers and myself.
('13', 408, 1, 7, 746270) Through the Court I beg to make the assurance that the present movement has nothing whatsoever to do with the unlawful entry for purposes of residence in the Transvaal of a single Indian.
('13', 408, 1, 8, 746458) I think I may fairly claim that my whole career in the Transvaal has been actuated with the motive of assisting Govern ment in preventing surreptitious entry and unlawful settlement, but I have pleaded guilty as I know that I have committed a technical breach, on a vast scale, of the section under which I am charged.
('13', 408, 1, 9, 746777) I am aware too that the steps I have taken are fraught with the greatest risks and intense personal suffering by those who have accepted my advice, but after very mature consideration, based upon 20 years’ experience of South Africa, I have come to the conclusion that nothing short of such suffering will move the conscience of the Government as also of the inhabitants of the Union of which, in spite of the so called breach of the Statutory Laws of the Union, I claim to be a sane and law abiding citizen.
('13', 408, 2, 10, 747286) The Court then adjourned for a quarter of an hour for the Magistrate to consider his decision.
('13', 408, 3, 11, 747381) On resuming, Mr. Jooste passed sentence of three months’ imprisonment.
('13', 408, 4, 12, 747452) Indian Opinion, 26 11 1913; also Transvaal Court Records
